comment:
I'm a parent of a 4th grader and I love this school.  PS261 is a very diverse school that has paid attention to social justice and emotional learning.  We have an amazing group of parents who have organized regular events for the children and I am often surprised to see the amazing things they are doing.  Yearly march to Boro Hall, with study of the civil right movements incorporated.  Arts week, with teaching artists brought in.  We have a beautiful garden and gardeners brought in to teach the children.  The after-school puts on an incredible musical as well as offering a wide variety of classes that my son loves.  Special shout-out to Ms. Khadiga, the science teacher, who has been a real mentor to my kid.  
Every time I'm in the school (not as often as when he was younger), I'm always impressed with the energy and smiles from everyone - teachers, kids, administration, school security, after-school counselors.  By no means is this school perfect, but I'm so glad I made this choice for my son.
The Brooklyn Eagle reports on PS 261's recent march to honor and celebrate Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., during which students made speeches that included his messages and principles.
A mother writes about her choice to send her biracial son to PS 261, a racially mixed school, rather than to her neighborhood school, on SchoolBook.

My son has had a wonderful year at PS 261. His teachers are kind, talented, hard working, and go above and beyond to provide the children with a fun, dynamic, and developmentally-appropriate learning environment. He has learned so much this year, and had fun doing it. Teachers actively seek out parent involvement. The parent community is likewise active, engaged, and friendly. I've also been very impressed with the students. The older kids generously accept the younger kids into their play, and really look out for them (on the playard after school). I think the school deserves at least some of the credit for the friendly, accepting students, since they emphasize social- emotional development along with academics. The joyful, controlled chaos on the beautiful playard after school is as close as my city kid will get to the free-range, kid-centric, suburban youth I experienced.

There are so many reasons why our family loves 261 and feels so thankful our daughter (currently in 2nd grade) can enjoy her elementary school years here. From Principal Mills to all of her teachers (classroom, science, music, art, arabic, gym, dance...), classmates and parents, we're having a superb experience.  My daughter is excited to go to school EVERY day and my husband and I look forward to all the meaningful classroom involvement we get to experience. Cannot say enough great things about this school and community.  Our most treasured blessing is flourishing here.

We love ps261. It is a very vibrant, tight knit, welcoming, super-diverse and involved community there.  You feel it as soon as you come in.  The commitment to the arts is very strong.  The arts committee funds specific arts enrichment for every grade which includes artist residencies, field trips and arts assemblies.   The principal is very open to parent, teacher suggestions and works harder than anyone. We have many amazing teachers and staff.  There are a few not so great teachers but not many.  Being one of the most truly diverse schools I have seen there can be some behavior problems from some kids that can interrupt the wonderful environment of the school.  But other than that we love everything. I don't find the teaching to be non traditional.

"Being one of the most truly diverse schools I have seen there can be some behavior problems from some kids that can interrupt the wonderful environment of the school." 

Please elaborate, because your comment comes off as prejudiced.

Our son started kindergarten at 261 this fall.  Thus far he loves going to school, and we are mostly happy.  My concern is with the curriculum.  It seems that he is learning a lot of the same things he did last year in Pre - K (not 261. private).  Aside from the art program, do you feel like there is a strong emphasis on reading, math, science, going forward into 1st, 2nd, etc. grade?

Hi, I'm a parent of a boy in K and we did not go to Pre-K here and I noticed a similar thing but in fact I like it. Often I feel like kids are pushed "academically" too quickly at the cost of developing other more age appropriate skills like curiosity, playing, exploring and fully understanding themselves as social creatures. A lot of research has recently been done shedding light on the fact that pushing kids too early in academics can be damaging in that it can lead to resentment and frustration with school--so its better to let the kids develop these skills through exploration in their own time I think. This is what I see happening at 261 as least at the K level, I mean they are only babies still in many ways. Having said that there are some kids in his class writing full sentences etc and I think they are equally challenged and supported as the kids still growing these skills. Conceptually, the bar is high at 261 especially in Social Studies and math--for me this is very important and seeing my child enjoy his new found "super powers" and growing new interests is more rewarding then knowing he can memorize 50 "at" words in a week, which is the type of stuff he was doing at his "academically rigorous" pre-K.

As you can see, there's more to a school than its stats. You'll have to go on a tour, see the teaching strategies, talk to parents at drop-off/pick-up to understand what can't be measured.


Note: you'll have to do that for middle school, high school and college. Welcome to parenthood and an education system with choices.

Wasn't being snarky; thought you didn't know the process. Writing without facial expressions to go along can cause misinterpretation.

You're asking parents who may only be familiar with one school to compare to another school down the road. If the stats are not providing you with what you need, then you need to see the schools for yourself in order to see if the environments are good for you.

But… if you knew the answer to the question, wasn't it snarky to ask?
66 percent of students at PS 261 opt out of the state's english and math exams. Read more here.

I graduated from PS 261 about 4 years ago. I loved that school then. And I'm sure people love it now. What I'm slightly upset about is how there's a new salad bar(?) (if someone could tell me about that please do) and how the playground is now beautiful and enviornment friendly. The reason why I'm upset is because when I graduated there, there was no salad bar. There was crappy gross lunch food that nobody liked. There was no beautiful playground! There were chairs here and there and some trees at the back COVERED in cigarettes. And then there was the new playground that was built a few years back that they wouldn't open to everybody at the same time! It was only the first graders or the fourth graders etc. I'm very happy that they have all of this now, but I'm also sad that I was not able to experience these amazing changes. These changes all happened the year of 6th grade for me which was totally unfair. I realize now that it is a better school, but I really wish that they had started to change the school a bit earlier so that I could experience this amazing change. But, I would totally reccomend this school to any parent. The teachers are caring and sweet and the building is friendly. This is coming from a student who graduated there and enjoyed the experience very much. This is an amazing school. For anyone who is curious, I am in 9th grade.
I should also add the the new playground began as a project two years ago and was paid for by Trust for the Public Land.

261 is working hard to make up for the absence of science in grades K, 1, and 5.  The absence of science in these grades currently is simply due to the fact that we are short one teacher and have not yet been able to replace this individual because it can only be filled as a part-time spot.  Our brilliant, hard-working, full-time science teacher is working closely with the teachers in these grades and incorporating the school's brand new garden as well as utilizing the fully-stocked science room to have science taught.  I am confident that it will be successful. The additional gym teacher is also teaching health containing some science, which is part of the curriculum.  The new librarian is being paid for entirely out of the PTA's budget through a grant, not the school's.  The absence of art for some classes is only due to the fact that one teacher is on maternity leave.  While it is great when every class has art, all teachers routinely incorporate various art projects as part of the curriculum (as well as 261 having a tremendous Arts Day in the winter and a fantastic after-school program with many art options).

This year some grades (Kindergarten, First Grade, and Fifth Grade) are not getting Science or Art instruction at PS261, yet the school hired one extra Gym teacher and a new librarian. Although I am a big fan of our school, I became very concerned with this big lapse of judgment by administration. The school's administrators claimed that children will be studying "Environmental Science" by visiting a brand new garden in the school's yard. If I had a choice, I would prefer our children have a proper Science lesson/curriculum rather than having a fancy playground to brag about. A rare recent "Science lesson" for fifth graders was a combined session with kindergarteners; they made a "poster" showing how to behave in the new garden and how not to litter. Granted, it is important to teach children not to litter, but that is not really Science. That is an Art activity. The administration has said that homeroom teachers are going to teach Science but the teachers are not prepared to teach Science (since they have never done this) and the 5th grade curriculum was already set for the year and they don't have room to fit in extra Science lessons (without eliminating other coursework). I am concerned about the impact of this decision on both children, parents and next year enrollment. While American children are behind other nations in Science, I was hoping that our educators understand the importance of fostering a good foundation in Science. It's very regrettable decision in many aspects and ultimately, it'll be our children who will be affected.
great school
PS 261's new playground is environmentally friendly and will manage stormwater runoff and alleviate the flooding of the Gowanus Canal. Learn more about the "green" playground here.
The new million dollar playground at PS 261 is open to the public. Read more here.
I go to the church there across the street, when we have bible school or other activities, i am grateful the park is open to the public
PS 261 is serving as a summer school site for multiple schools and is also hosting summer camps run by community organizations. Read more here.

The school has many children with behavior and emotional issues that you have to wonder if parents and school are in denial or too overwhelmed to address the issue. PS261 often is in utter chaos and majority of aides are completely incompetent and negligent. Many do not watch kids and never seemed to be interested in what they do. A lot of workers scream at children and I find this disturbing. The school needs to put higher expectation on both children and staff and hire quality staff.

I graduated from PS261 last year, and I loved it. The teachers and staff are all kind and caring, and now when I come back to visit they remember me and ask how I'm doing. Ms Mills knows and cares about every single kid. On my sisters first month of Pre-K, she noticed that it was her birthday and made sure to wish her a happy birthday. Part of what makes 261 so amazing is just the atmosphere it gives off.



The extra-curricular activities are amazing too. There is a dance group in grades 3-5, and band and chorus in 4-5. In band you pick one instrument, and get to borrow one and learn how to play it for free. The fourth and fifth graders also get to go to the opera, which is a very special trip. Last year, I was in band, chorus, drama club, the school play, yearbook, and student council, all of which provided an interesting and unique experience. 


If anyone is considering PS261 for their child, I highly recommend it. It is diverse and unique, with amazing staff and teachers, and a thoughtful, strong curriculum. There is a surprisingly low amount of bullying, and it is just a really friendly atmosphere.

My child has attended this school starting this year.  I love the school community, the teachers, students, staff and parents.  There is a lot of parental involvement, and Zip actually listens to the ideas of the parents although is realistic about what can actually be done.  The kids have one special class each day: Art, music, science, Arabic language, dance or gym.  The music and science teachers are amazing.  There are some great teachers, but many are mediocre with a low drive for improving, new ideas and a better classroom.  Some teacher morale has gone down with the NYC testing procedures and evaluation of the teachers.  The main problem for my child still is the difficulty with behavioral problems of other kids distracting her.  There is a little bit of bullying going on, with kids being unruly during lunch and recess.   
The pre-k have a very cute portable classroom out in the yard with their own playground, the classes seemed fun with nice teachers.  The K also has their own yard.
The big yard is also being constructed into  a beautiful new school yard now.  

Wish there could be some improvements but I love the school still yet.  My little one likes the school as well.

In March, construction began at PS 261 on a student-designed schoolyard that will include a synthetic turf field, an outdoor classroom, a kickball field, and a track. The project is scheduled to be completed by September 2013. Read more here.

Parentyparent - I do agree that the cafeteria is OUT OF CONTROL both in the morning during breakfast & during lunch (children running & cartwheeling about, yelling (extremely loud talking), "rough-unsafe play" that could easily turn into a fight, bullying behaviors (name calling/hitting) ALL with parents and some teachers milling about passively watching. 
 
I used to bring my daughter early so she could chat with friends before school started, but after seeing this chaotic start to the morning, I opted to bring her at 8:45am giving no room for any unsupervised mishaps.  There are WAY too many parents in the cafeteria standing around drinking coffee & chatting with their friends which while it should be an open welcoming community -contributes to the loud overcrowded state - especially when the parents don't do anything to help create a more relaxed environment.   I did hear mention a while back during a PTA meeting about parents volunteering in the morning but like everything else, nothing ever came of this.  How staff and parents can think this is okay is beyone me.  I do understand that budget cuts have limited the number of staff available however the cafeteria in the morning is sad sight to see - I got a headache one time from being there so I can imagine how my daughter used to feel.   **Maybe this is why so many parents are there because they wouldn't DARE leave their child in the cafeteria without better organization or proper supervision.

I can only imagine how crazy it is for teachers who then have to enter this crazy chaos to try & line their classes up while everyone then tries to exit through one set of doors - ALL while parents with concerns are trying to have their needs addressed amid this chaos.  Then get the classes upstairs to spend 10-20 minutes calming the class down from the cafeteria chaos.
  
My only suggestion to your concern would be to send an email to the teachers if there is a "pressing issue" - it unfortunately seems a little impersonal, but you have to try to balance how many other parents are vying for 2-3 minutes of convo time with the teachers immediate need to manage 20-25 riled up kids & get them safely to their classroom.  Emailing my daughter's teachers has always worked for me & they typically respond as soon as they can.  Hopefully things have since changed with your child's teachers - unfortunately nothing has changed in the cafeteria.

My daughters started attending PS 261 in the fall of 2012 (k and 1st) and they LOVE the school. Thanks to her wonderful teacher, Jen, who nurture her skills and work on her weaknesses my kindergartener  went from being a shy introvert to a social butterfly that is eager to learn. Due to their progressive approach to education, my 1st grader, who only liked math,  has now learn to love reading and writing. She has jumped 5 levels in 6 months. The teachers always have time for the parents. The school has a very active PTA and LOTS of parent involvement. Their arts program is phenomenal.  PS 261 is a unique school with staff and parents that are very warm and welcoming. Jerry, the parent coordinator, is AWESOME. I am extremely happy to be part of the PS 261 community-oriented family.

We have joined ps 261 for first grade from out of the zone.  It was by far the best option for her for public school.  We love the school.  There is a happy vibe throughout the halls.  There is tons of parent involvement.  I am involved there all the time, and we have the second most amount of learning leaders of all schools.  Great arts programs, science teachers: the famous Carmelow the Science Fellow and Mr. Scott.  The principal is very level headed and approachable.  There are many gem teachers there and the students are very diverse.  Like most public schools there is the challenge of some students being more of a behavioral challenge than others that always makes it more difficult of a learning environment.  

We think the school is very good though.
I went here for preschool, and I loved it. I had Ms. A
My daughter use to attend PS261 I had the opportunity to place her in SACH.  She has learned more in her 5 short weeks at SACH then she ever did in 261.

My daughter graduated from PS 261 yesterday, and loved all 6 years of her experience there. The daily instruction was fantastic but she also had tons of extra enrichment activities in the upper grades: band, chorus, student council, yearbook, drama, book club, and more. She loved her teachers and friends, and the relaxed, welcoming atmosphere of the school. It's really a special place that encourages all students to learn and grow.

PS 261 parents were among those protesting field testing outside the midtown Manhattan headquarters of Pearson, the testing company. Read more: Brandishing pineapples, parents and students target Pearson.

In the past year or two, I've noticed the school take on a decidedly political tone. While staff and teachers are certainly entitled to their beliefs--and to advocate for those beliefs in their personal time--it is wholly inappropriate for those opinions to spill into the classroom. The school is relatively large and very diverse, and it's stupid, naive and arrogant to assume that the entire community will agree with the opinions of a vocal few. What was once a warm and welcoming community is anything but that now.

Example: At least two teachers (that I know of) have spent class time disparaging charter schools to their students. One even had her students make anti-charter school posters during class. The personal political beliefs of teachers have no place in the classroom, and the lack of professionalism is shocking to me.

Several children in the school have siblings who attend charter schools, and it's cruel and insensitive to put a young child in a position where he/she must listen to a teacher criticize a personal family decision. Children, of course, want to be liked by their teachers, and few have the strength of will to listen to criticisms like that and not take them personally. 

Times are very difficult for NYC schools, and I appreciate that so many in the school community are fighting for what they believe in. But I strongly believe that their methods are causing more harm than good, and those fights need to be taken out of the school--entirely.

Yes, the PS 261 community (students, parents, and staff) has taken an active role in fighting back against the aggressive expansion of programs like Success Charter Academy. The teachers weren't disparaging charter schools in general, but giving the kids background on what happens in the school system and how SCA has tried to cannibalize existing schools. My daughter is in one of the classes that's probably being described here, and she came out of the discussions with a much better understanding of the democratic and non-democratic processes behind the rise of Success Charter Academy.

well put!! my children do not attend PS261.  I can tell you at their school, the anti-charter/anti-testing zealots are constantly hijacking schools meetings and the parents listsev to promote their point of view.

My child attended PS261 K-5 and is now in 6th grade I recommend this school highly. The teachers and the principal Zip Mills are very accessible and caring, my son thrived here in this wonderful community. We miss it!

A parent writes that a new Success charter school in the neighborhood could adversely affect student diversity at PS 261: http://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/17/opinion/how-charter-schools-can-hurt.html?partner=rss&emc=rss
Some PTA fund-raising efforts backfire. Read more: A Clash Over Cupcakes: http://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/18/education/at-the-pta-clashes-over-cupcakes-and-culture.html?_r=1&ref=nyregion

PS 261 offers exactly what they say they will- an engaging, dynamic curriculum in a very diverse environment, mimicking life in NYC and life right outside the schools walls. Children at 261 like going to school, love to read, write and love math! Teachers at the school work very hard to maintain a meaningful curriculum in face of high stakes tests and increasingly impossible standards. They are a group of people who think deeply about how curriculum is presented to students and care about children's social emotional well-being. The school culture is welcoming and vibrant- if you walked in you'd see children actively engaged in their learning!

PS 261 is one of several NYC schools with Dads as Parents Association president. Read about how men are becoming more active in schools. http://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/19/fashion/fathers-Shift-the-Dynamics-of-the-PTA.html?scp=1&sq=NYC+Parent+Associations+with+Dads+as+presidents&st=nyt

With two daughters in 4th grade, having been there since pre-K, I love this school. They have become avid writers & readers, as well as curious and respectful members of the community. The science program is strong. This school provides them a strong foundation for the balance of their school careers. Many of their teachers have been nothing less than rock-stars.

I am surprised to hear negative comments about the school! My son and daughter (3rd grade and K) love waking up and coming to P.S. 261 each day. I love the school's emphasis on social justice and the arts. I have found teachers to be very genuine and caring. P.S. 261 has a funky, uneven around the edges feeling that seems very real and warm.

My child is thriving at P.S. 261. His teacher is accessible through email and is very open to communicating with me. I receive a weekly newsletter telling me what the class is doing during the week and ways I can enrich what he is learning at home. I couldn't be happier!

Can you walk into your doctor's office and expect to be seen without an appointment? Teachers are professionals who happen to work with children. But, nonetheless, they are professionals. Parents need to understand that teachers cannot talk to every parent whenever it is good for a parent. That is why appointments are necessary.

Parentyparent -
Please consider meeting with me to address your concerns (completely confidential, of course) - I would welcome the chance to listen, and to try to set right some of the issues you've raised. I realize your comments were posted a few months ago, and I'm hoping that you've had a better experience since then.

Jerry Piper
PS261 Parent Coordinator

It's our last year at the school, and I just want to say that this school has a fantastic parent body and a lot of really, really great teachers who always have made time to discuss my child's needs.  I don't think the principal has a lot of vision or a mission, but somehow the school runs just fine, mostly.  There are a lot of extra arts happening and the student body is pretty grand. Tons of sweet kids. Overall, given that it is public school (too much testing), I am please with my experience. Again, very, very happy with the teachers my daughter has had. All very, very caring and accessible.

Of all the schools my children have attended over the years (4 including this one) PS 261 has the most unwelcoming policies towards parents by a landslide!  Lip-service is paid to 'parent involvement', but the school has done everything in it's power to keep parents at arm's length, and there's a distinct (and worrisome) lack of transparency.  One can't help but wonder if all of the barriers are in place to keep parents from seeing what's really going on.

Administration seems far more concerned with controlling the parent's behavior than the children's.  For instance, if you arrive after 8:30 you cannot escort your child into the the gym where the teachers pick them up, regardless of the circumstance... even if your child is crying.  You must also get passes and permission to access your child's teacher before or after school unless you make an appointment beforehand.  They deem it a "safety issue", but any proactive parent knows that some things cannot be foreseen, and need to be addressed on the spot.  Meanwhile, the kids run like wild animals in the cafeteria during breakfast (and I can only assume lunch) through spilled beverages and dropped breakfasts.  It is not unusual to see kids run and slip through various spilled liquids on the floor while the staff looks on without invervening (or cleaning up).  That, however, is not considered a "safety issue".

Of course, the teachers and administrators don't mind reaching out to the parents when they need or want something from them.  They welcome parents' money and support, but not the parents themselves.  As a former parent council member for two consecutive years at a previous school I would gladly fundraise for, and otherwise help out the school (which is in desperate need of funds), if only I felt like a welcome member of the school community instead of an annoyance with a wallet.

This parent's experience seems to be the opposite of mine (I have a current 4th grader and a daughter who graduated 2 years ago).  The kindergarten parents are able to bring their children directly into the classrooms.  It is true that if you are late, you are not allowed to bring your child into the cafeteria (not the gym) where the teachers pick them up, but this seems reasonable in light of the possibility of crowding.  Teachers are very accessible (just not at the moment of drop off or pick up when they have 22 other children to take care of).  The PTA and School Leadership Team are very open to parent involvement and Zip (the principal) is extremely available and open to parent concerns.  I am sorry for Parentyparent's experience, but it does not seem at all representative of the school community I have been part of for the last 7 years.  And Guest's perspective seems awfully out-of-date.  I have never had a safety concern for either of my daughters.

P.S. 295 is everything we hoped it would be and more. A warm, responsive, creative, caring community of teachers, parents, and staff who put their whole hearts into supporting the growth of every student. We love that the school deeply values the arts—teaching them with passion and rigor. We love that the school is small for the area. We love that the community includes a diversity of experiences and perspectives. Their approach to instruction is differentiated and includes targeted learning supports. During our time at the school we've witnessed our own children overcome several academic hurdles thanks to the attentive and thoughtful intervention of the teachers and administration. I feel thankful for P.S. 295 every day.

Our child had many wonderful years at PS 295, and has fond memories of those years. Unfortunately, with the exception of the last year in 5th grade. The 5th grade experience, in our opinion, did not foster or implement the ideals of the community we grew to love for many years. We found that the problem was a combination of large class sizes, and the style of teaching. The teachers seemed unwilling to accept challenges of having close to 35 students and completely gave up on the students mid year. They did not implement effective management techniques and were unwilling to work with parents through their concerns. They were defensive in nature and lacked confidence to find a solution. Each day students came home frazzled from all the chaos. However, the administration were actively working with parents to address their concerns but after a while there was nothing to be said and done due to the teachers unwillingness to work in effective management techniques. Having been a member of this community for years and having gotten to know the children in the grade, it was unacceptable to place the blame onto children who have flourished and thrived in other classroom environments with different styles of leadership. We made the mistake of speaking with other parents about our concerns way too late in the year, when there was little time left to take action, but we learned that so many families dealt with the same frustrations. I write this for future 5th grade families who also face these challenges. Join together and speak up the minute your child comes home and tells you stories that make you go “hmmm..” Join together with your concerns because with everyone individually voicing their experiences, then it is much easier for the concerns to get swept under the carpet. 
Some of our specific concerns were: teachers telling children “they werent ready for middle school” which triggered anxiety, teachers telling children they were not going to succeed at life, eliminating all parties and forms of entertainment creating an imbalance in the community, inconsistencies in homework and classwork (going weeks without anything to piling it on where children spent their entire night binge working), having a bottle on their desk with the phrase “tears of our students”, lack of creative instruction and a dry curriculum, not focusing on writing grammar, spelling and syntax, failing to differentiate instruction and understand individual needs and how to create a community. The teachers took a dictatorship approach which we found riled the children up rather than diffusing their behaviors. 
We met with the teachers many times, and then the administration many times and were told just to get through the year. It was a very sad way to end our time in a place that we loved so much.

Yes, we all know which teacher this post is referring to. I have had multiple children in the school, and put in a request for my youngest child not to have this teacher. Administration granted my request. Definitely a bully!

We have 2 kids at 295 now and we absolutely love it - I feel like we won the lottery being there. 

It's a small, tightly-knit community; we feel like we know almost everyone there and have formed deep friendships (both for the kids and parents!). Principal Mazza & VP Pagano are very approachable and warm and really know the kids. The teachers are easy to reach with in-person weekly meetings, or email. All of the staff engage with all the kids, whether they have them in class or not. We have a wonderful Parent Coordinator, Mr. Borrero, who is always helpful in sorting out any questions or concerns that come up - and the kids LOVE playing soccer with him!

Some of the things we love about 295 are: the diversity of the community, the emphasis on the arts, the focus on each child by their teachers, the idea of keeping school fun & approachable, the high level of commitment from everyone, and the ease of getting involved as a parent - however you're able. We find the academics to be challenging without being overwhelming; each child is engaged at their specific level. The support for special needs learners is great: the paraprofessionals, therapists and guidance counselor work as a team to help the kids, both academically and emotionally. 

The PTA is highly active and does amazing things for the school, with the parents working closely together with the staff. There are tons of events where you meet new people & kids make friends (Touch-a-Truck, monthly cupcake sales, Family Fun Fridays, Boogie Brunch, Spring Arts, Dance shares, etc.) There is an online group which is very supportive; information shared and advice to those who seek it. Parents are invited into the classrooms regularly: Parent-Teacher conferences two times a year, Bagel Bits every month (breakfast at the school & then they invite us into the classroom for a period to watch), monthly PTA meetings, countless committees to help out, weekly school bulletins, etc. And parents can arrange to come into the class to read a book or talk about a holiday, job or something else the kids are interested in. 

Congregation Beth Elohim runs the afterschool program and their teachers and on-site staff at 295 are very fun & friendly. 

The Cons are: small outdoor space and sometimes not enough free play time. However, they are always working with the parents to brainstorm new ideas and try to come up with creative solutions to these and other concerns.

As many posters have commented below, the community of parents at this school is super--many parents are involved, there are lots of school events and "Bagel Bits", which gives parents a chance to see their children in their class during school. Core academics are strong and my children have always had great teachers, including the specials teachers (art, drama and music). There are opportunities in the Spring for certain grades to take further arts classes afterschool (CASA grants program, thanks to Carlos Menchaca, who's considered a "friend" of the school's). 

We were signed up for our zoned school 7 years ago and, after I went to Touch a Truck and spoke with some parents and saw the school, I changed our application, put our son's name on a waitlist and, within a day, got a call from the Parent Coordinator and were in (I don't know if doing this is as easy now.) We also love the diversity-economic and cultural, that the school still has, despite a changing neighborhood. 295 has the feeling of a strong, arts focused neighborhood school; that is, friendly.

This is an AMAZING school and every day I feel grateful for all the teachers, staff, parents and children that make this a very special learning community.  We moved into the zone last year and LOVE the school.  Don't worry about awkward layout, small gym or lunchroom in the lobby.  The kids are extremely well looked after here.  What the building lacks the school makes up in heart!!!  The walls throughout the school are decorated with students' work that show how much they are learning and how much they love the school.  The community is great.  Parents are friendly at drop-off and many families hang out at the park after school.  There are lots of events that bring the community together.  The school and PTA work hard to include everyone e.g. Spanish and other language translations, coat drives in the winter and support for struggling families.  We've made so many friends and feel that this school enriches our lives everyday.

We are PS 295 parents with two boys in Pre-K and Kindergarten. We couldn't be happier with the school. The teachers are loving, supportive and incredibly attentive and the PTA is incredible. The school is a joyful and inclusive space with a vibrant arts program. Our boys love their school and we love PS 295! And most importantly the school really reflects and celebrates the diverse community it serves. We love it here.

I'm a new 295 Mama who fell in love with the school on a tour when I found myself weeping at how much what I was hearing from the principal - was exactly what I wanted to be hearing from my kids school. It is exceptional as compared with my zoned school which is suffering from chronic abstenteeism and an unsupportive Principal. I cant say enough about 295! The afterschool options are the best (partnered with Cong. Beth Elohim) and the teachers are happy and supported and you know it because they stay year after year. The specials are amazing. I just watched the 4th and 5th graders production of Little Red Robin Hood and was blown away! The Seeds of Kindness Program sends my first grader home teaching me about mindfulness (!) and the diversity is real - not tokenist. I love this community and if you're zoned for a school you're not into - come check out PS 295. There is often space for Kinders and 1st graders from out of zone. Last open house this year is this month!

We moved from SF to Brooklyn almost seven years ago and completely blindsided by the primary school enrollment process. Our zoned school was good, but after touring PS 295 for prek, we just felt this school had something special. We did not get in right away, but the minute we got the call, we moved from our zoned school to 295. School had already started. We've been at 295 ever since and I feel my kids have grown up so much here. We have one in first and another in fourth. It's their second home. 

It's a very warm, welcoming group of parents and teachers who work hard to provide anything our kids may need.  

Our programs and events are amazing! Every year, I look forward to seeing the kids perform in the dance festival, and now that my oldest is going into fifth grade, watching him in the school play next year. We have full-time science, drama and art teachers! Touch a Truck, Brooklyn Boogie Brunch, our Halloween Danceathon, the new Silent Art Auction coming up and not to mention Spirit Week, Field Day, Earth Day and the Spring Arts Festival. There's a lot going on at this school! 

I think our kids are getting a well-rounded education at 295. In addition, because we have such a strong community, they, too, are learning to be active participants and are often encouraged to jump in and help when they see parents volunteering at the school, or hear about a family in need.

I can't say enough what this school has meant to us. It definitely made the transition of moving from CA to NY easier! We're looking forward to the next four years, and it will definitely be bittersweet when the youngest graduates.

This school is a really special place.  My family has been part of the school community for almost 6 years.  There is a wonderful sense of community here with teachers, parents and administrators all working to give our children as enriching an experience as possible.  The primary reason that I was attracted to the school ( we are not zoned) was the warmth of all of the people in the building.  The people who work at PS 295 genuinely care for all of the children.  I have 2 gen ed children and 1 child in the ICT program and it is truly an inclusive environment.  The service providers for my special needs child are incredible and I don't feel that I have to fight to receive any of the services she needs.  My oldest child is a very high achiever and she has been challenged and I feel she is very prepared for middle school.  The growth I have seen in her in the 5.5 years we have been at the school is tremendous.  She has learned so much academically, but also emotionally and socially.
Would love any new updates on this school! How has it been since the comments 2/3 years ago?

Yay Linda! We're very excited about the Mission Be program she mentions. We're hoping to make this kind of thing a permanent part of the school culture across grades as a way to help kids develop empathy toward others as well as the ability to manage the stresses of daily life for themselves.
PS 295 Principal Linda Mazza lists compassion as a top school priority. Read more here.
Teachers at PS 295 and other city schools explore how to make the best use of 80-minute Monday professional development sessions mandated by the new UFT contract. Read more here.
How's the new principal?

Linda is the perfect combination for being the principal of 295—a small, leaning-towards-progressive, community oriented, arts-focused school. She is a thoughtful and reflective instructional leader who works collaboratively with teachers, students and parents. She is a warm person who makes every student feel known, understood, listened to and loved. She has innovative ideas for how to accomplish the school's educational goals, and she keeps the school's good practice and progressive pedagogical vision in the foreground even as she tries to balance it with the often contrary demands that come from the DOE. She prioritizes enrichment opportunities like the arts and respects the different learning styles that naturally occur among a school full of children, particularly a population as diverse as 295. Her goal seems to be to think deeply and reflect continually with her staff in order to provide enough range that all children can find ways to learn and thrive. We are thrilled she is our brave and out-of-the-box thinking principal—particularly in this difficult time where the DOE is trying to impose so many directives that expert educators agree are not child-centered or good learning practice for elementary school children.

Linda Mazza is our new principal, but she is definitely not new to PS295. She's been there for over 10 years in a variety of capacities (teacher in both Gen Ed & ICT classrooms, ELA coach, afterschool program coordinator). She was my son's 5th grade teacher (he's now in 7th), and we loved her as a teacher. We like her just as much as principal. Because she comes from within the school, she knows the staff well and has a solid relationship with the teaching staff as well as our Assistant Principal. She fully supports our mission as an arts-focused school, and has been super responsive to and supportive of the parent community. Linda also clearly loves the children, and is working extremely hard to help them meet the new academic standards that are being set for them, in the warmest and most supportive environment possible. I'm completely confident that my 3rd grader will get an excellent education, as well as have plenty of exposure to art, drama, music & creative movement. We give Linda an A!

I'm a fairly new parent at PS 295 and have found Linda to be quite amazing. She's super supportive and open to new ideas, but toes the line too. I feel like there's a true spirit of collaboration with her and her classroom experience definitely shows. She loves our kids!

Hi Christine,

PS 295 is still going strong! We just held our 
third annual Touch-a-Truck fundraiser last weekend, our student-run 
Farmers Market is re-opening for the season this Thursday afternoon, and
 we'll close out the week with our Outdoor Dance Festival on Friday 
morning. It's events like these that show our community at its best.

As
 far as core academics go, we're still in a great place: experienced, 
effective teachers with low staff turnover, and a continued commitment 
to a workshop classroom model and Teachers College best practices. Our 
kids didn't enjoy the state tests any more than any other school's, but 
they seemed to handle the stress well and feel as prepared as they could
 be. Our learning environment surveys show high satisfaction among 
parents and a real sense that the school is responsive to the needs and 
priorities of parents.

One thing we're excited about is our Arts 
Committee, which is taking a holistic view of arts programming across 
the school, from classes to after-school to field trips and such, and 
looking for new opportunities to bring in outside groups and incorporate
 new kinds of experiences into the school day. Our band and choral music
 programs continue to be popular among kids and their parents, and every
 child in the school takes music classes of some kind every week. 

We're
 currently going through a transition in leadership as our principal, 
Deanna Marco, is leaving to start a new school on Staten Island--a 
lifelong dream for her. We're sorry to see her go, but the process for 
interviewing new candidates involved a lot of thought and discussion on 
the kinds of things that make PS 295 as successful as it is, what we 
care about most, and what we want for the school in the years ahead. It 
was inspiring to hear the commitment and enthusiasm for the school 
showed by both parents and staff, and to feel like we're all part of 
something special together. We're confident that our new principal (who 
should be named in the next few weeks) will share our vision and build 
on the strong foundation laid by Deanna and those before her.

Feel free to post any specific questions you might have, too!
I would love an update on this school!
Raising the price of a cupcake from 50 cents to $1 has caused dissension among parents. Read more: It's Never Just About the Cupcake.

For what it's worth, the "dissension" aspect of this much-told story has grown as it has traveled through the media. There was a spirited discussion at a single PTA meeting about the balance between fundraising and community-building at events like these, which ended up being really worthwhile for helping people understand the importance of both goals (especially at a small school like this), but it's not like the episode opened up any real rifts among parents or groups of parents.

We have had a wonderful experience at 295. My daughter attended 295 from kindergarten through 5th grade, and my son is now in 3rd grade at the school. PS 295 is a small, supportive, and diverse community, a place where all of the teachers at the school seem to know all of the children by name, whether they've had them in their classes or not. My childrens' teachers have been exceptional: attentive, dedicated and skilled at addressing students of varying abilities, and my daughter was extremely well prepared for middle school. 

Like every other public school in the city, PS 295 has weathered budget cuts. But the administration and staff have done an excellent job of maintaining a strong arts focus in the school, with visual arts, movement/ dance, and drama classes woven into the curriculum. And though class size has not been as small as when we first came to the school, I believe that the same is true for public schools across the board, and the administration has done a good job  trying to maintain a small class size when possible. 

The PTA at the school is a very active, dedicated and welcoming group that has worked on a number of fundraising initiatives -- including a grant that brought a music program to the school -- as well as a string of community events that bring families to the school to socialize. In the 7 years that our family has been at the school, we have found it to be a welcoming community and a place where students are treated with respect and encouragement.

We came to 295 from our zoned District 15 school - because at that school although the teachers were strong -  the administrative leadership ineffectual/bad.  The PTA was well meaning but brought in less than $2,000 a year.  Our family has now become a member of the 295 community and we could not be happier.  My twins are in K - with smart and engaged teachers.  These consumate professionals make the the "work" of learning fun.

The principal is an exceptional and accessable leader.  She welcomes parental feedback and participation and takes great care of her staff.  

The PTA is thriving, with duel goals of comminity-building and fundraising.  The PTA is diverse mix of caring, hard-working - dedicated people who have kids sprinkled throughout the grades.

Our whole family just went to the 4th and 5th grade drama production of Charlottes Web.  Inclusive, well-rehersed - sweet- and really - darn good.

Our family is now at 295 - and what can I say-- it's an amazing place!

I have to write in to support the drama teacher and 295 in general.  Ms Cat has been wonderful for my daughter - really helped her to grow and become comfortable performing.  I'm really sorry to hear about kids being yelled at by any teachers, that should never happen.  But, I haven't heard anything about that kind of behavior in the drama class.  We've found the teacher to be very interested in our daughter and willing to help her outside of class to prepare for her role in the play or an audition for middle school.  

I agree with other posters that 295 had more "stuff" when my first child started there - there have been a number of years of cutbacks since then and while the PTA is active in fundraising the school has definitely felt the loss of funds.  I imagine many schools are in similar situations.  The music program has been a great plus recently as are the after school instrument lessons.

As for bullying, even one kid being bullied is too many and the school is definitely responsible for controlling the environment to prevent that.  But, I wouldn't want readers to think it's a common problem at 295.  I've been a parent there for 9 years and I don't think it is.

No school is perfect, and I know that 295 has its troubles - I'd point out the loss of small class sizes in the upper grades and not enough outdoor time as some of my pet peeves.  But overall, it's been a wonderful place for my kids to grow in and I will be sorry to leave when my daughter graduates.

I'd be interested to know what kind of outdoor time other schools in this area get. 30 min per day (what the 295 kids currently get) seems pretty good to me. I am sad too that the 4 & 5 grade classes are not 24-5 kids as they were when my child started K 6 years ago; another frustrating product of several straight years of budget cuts.

I feel the same way about the class sizes--the teachers are great, but upper twenties is just pretty big. The good news is that the first and second grade classes are bigger, and there are four Ks now, so hopefully as more kids roll up through the grades we'll be able to sustain three nice-sized classes per grade instead of two big ones. I think my son's year (third grade) is going to be the last one to have to deal with it. Still, I like it here better than the other school we were going to with smaller sizes--other things make it worth it.

PS 295 is a great school, my daughter went there and is now in 9th grade.
It felt like a small school where everyone knew each other. I feel like she got a well rounded education. She went to Mark Twain for middle school, some kids went to 51, other to new voices upstairs and now a lot of them are in LaGuardia! We were very happy and she still comes back to see her teacher every years :-)

We love this school. Our daughter attended Kindergarten and is now a 1st grader. She has loved all her teachers. She has excelled at art, learned about drama, and they have a great music program in conjunction with the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music. I've been impressed with the leadership at this school and how it keeps getting better and better. On top of the arts focus we've seen our daughter receive a great education in math, reading and science. She's genuinely excited about learning and loves going to school. Our family has been welcomed into this school's community- we feel so lucky!

This is not the school anymore that is described above.  We started going to ps295 because it was our zoned school and it seemed to make sense and we were impressed with what it was when we went on the tour.  
When we started going there in 2005, there was a full dance floor and students in the 4th and 5th grade were learning choreography notation. There was an extra teacher paid for by the magnet grant who was teaching the teachers how to integrate art into the curriculum.  There was a fabulous drama teacher who had specialized in Shakespeare and was aspiring to teach that to the kids.  

By the time we left this was all gone.  After my son had been in Kindergarten, the fabulous dance teacher left.  We had a not so good teacher for a year during which the dance floor that was fabulous was cut in half to make two rooms.  We got a great dance teacher again for 2nd and 3rd grade but she had to leave because of conflicts with the administration. All the kids literally loved her.  Due to budget cuts, one of the existing teachers became the dance/fitness teacher.  Don't need to say that she was definitely not a dance teacher. Student teachers were hired to get some dance in which was great but still not what it was.  

The same year the great drama teacher left because she was made to have the kids perform musicals instead of Shakespeare and unfortunately the really fantastic science teacher who my son loved and was a true science teacher and (again) was replaced with a teacher who had already been totally uninspiring and was not much better when she was a science teacher.  The drama teacher was replaced by a real drama teacher who was unfortunately regularly pretty cranky. 

There were times when I picked my son up and he would tell me that either the drama teacher or dance teacher had yelled at them that they were no good at all.  The daughter of a friend of mine is terrified to audition because of this drama teacher even if she loved the theatre.  

On top of it my son got bullied and even if some attention was paid to it, I don't think it was enough. And truthfully, I believe the over-discipline that is currently applied in the school could be the source of the bullying.  Kids have very very little freedom and start doing things more secretly.  

The teachers were all really great people and that was our saving grace really.  If the classroom teachers wouldn't have been so good, I think I would have really made my son leave and we would have gone somewhere else.  He is in the charter school now and doing great, his grades are way up, and he loves the school.  

My advise though is, think twice before you go to this school.  It is not anymore the art school it once was.  Totally not.  Testing has become more important than art.
