** A friend of mine at the school had technical difficulties posting this reply so I'm posting it for her:

As a
parent who currently has 2 children at PS 295 (1st & 5th), I feel like I
need to respond to the comment above. Many of the hirings and leavings referred
to happen 3-5 years ago, and are basically old news. It’s also important to
understand the larger context. A lot of us who have been part of the NYC school
system since 2005 or so have seen many programs, jobs & resources cut
drastically in the past 4 years. This is not the fault of the schools, and in
my opinion, PS 295 has been incredibly creative with every dollar they have at
their disposal in channeling it right back into smaller class sizes, boosting
curriculum, and the arts!

For example, when the dance room was cut in half, it was done so in order to
give the drama program its own dedicated room. The “student teacher” is
actually a dance educator who just happens not to be certified by the DOE. She
is paid for by the PTA, because (as the original poster noted) budget cuts made
it necessary to cut the dance teacher. To my mind, this was a clever and practical
way to keep dance instruction in our curriculum in the face of huge financial
cuts. The dance instructor teaches the kids AND she does professional
development with our Creative Movement/PE teacher. 


 


The
uninspiring science teacher is no longer at the school. Our current science
teacher is wonderful; my 5th grader comes home talking about the
exciting experiments they do, and wants to replicate them! I’m not sure it’s
fair to say that the “great” drama teacher left because she couldn’t stand
doing musicals instead of Shakespeare (and for what it’s worth, my 5th
grader had her too, and complained that SHE yelled all the time. He never says
that about our current drama teacher.) This year, the kids performed
Charlotte’s Web. The whole school studied the book and talked about it in light
of friendship, and it was a wonderful performance. I’m not sure Shakespeare is
really the best way to get 4-10 year olds excited about drama, to be honest.
There’s plenty of time for 400-year-old tragedies in middle/high school. 


 


I
can only speak from personal experience, but I have not seen actual bullying
happen at PS 295. It certainly could have happened, but I don’t think it’s a
widespread problem by any means. I’m not sure what over-discipline means. I do
know that the school uses positive behavioral reinforcement in and out of the
classrooms, and that has helped my son develop empathy & reflect on his
behavior, instead of feeling defensive or unfairly punished. I would not agree
with the statement that kids have very little freedom; personally I’m not sure
what freedom they are supposed to have at that age, during school time. 


 


One
more thing: “Testing has become more important than art.” Here are the facts:
3-5 graders get one 10 week cycle of test prep as part of the Academic
Intervention Services (tutoring) that the whole school receives. That’s three
50 minute periods a week for 10 weeks; it seems reasonable to me given the
importance of the tests for their own academic future. No one loves tests
(okay, everyone hates them), but that’s the reality we all face now, and it’s
also a change in the DOE system since the olden days the original poster was
talking about. 


 


On
the “arts” side, kids get three 50 min periods a week for the entire year:
drama, creative movement & art; plus another period/week of music for 15
weeks. That’s not counting the band program for 4-5 graders (the school
supplies a wide range of brass & woodwind instruments), the drama
performance, or the school lunch clubs, of which several are arts-related. Every
foot of the school building is decorated with student artwork, and the Spring
Arts Festival is still one of our biggest events of the year. You do the math
and decide whether arts are still important at PS 295. 


 


My
point here is that everyone’s experience is different, and no school is perfect
for every child (or family), but there are two sides to every coin. I think
that both sides should be looked at and considered before judgments are made. My
family’s experience at PS 295 has been wonderful; both my husband and I are in
creative professions, and love the school’s dedication to the arts alongside its
academic rigor, and the teachers’ and administration’s clear devotion to the
kids. My two very different children have had two different experiences, as
befits the individualization of teaching that goes on at PS 295, but the arts
have been a huge part of their daily school lives in both cases, and I am
thankful for that in this era of cutbacks and reductions.
PS 295 gets questioned for deciding to have a separate class for special education students. Read more: For Some Special Ed Students, Inclusion Is Deferred.

Something important to clarify is that the school's 12:1:1 class doesn't advance through the grades--it's only for K/1. The goal is for every student to transition back into the mainstream (either gen ed or ICT) after that year; if they're unable to do so, they'd likely go to District 75 instead. As a Title I school with a long-established ICT (CTT) program, PS 295 has always been committed to an inclusion model; my son is now in his third year in ICT there and I've known a lot of the special needs kids there, and I've always been impressed with how well integrated they are into their classes and the school community. The article linked above was informative in a lot of ways, but it was a little vague on this point.
Chancellor Walcott visits schools on the first day. Listen to the report: On the Road With Chancellor Walcott.

Both my daughters attended PS 295.  Both attended competitive high schools in Manhattan, with one still there and the older one at a great private college in the Midwest.  PS 295 was a great foundation for their continued learning.

We moved from out of state to South Park Slope with this school as a key reason why we choose the neighborhood. We have not been disappointed and greatly appreciate how embracing the school, parents, teachers, and fellow students have been to our son. Moving to a new school is such a trying experience, and while there have been ups and downs, overall we could not be more pleased. We are especially grateful for: a.) solid communication (including a willingness to meet outside of regular conference times) from our 5th grade teacher Mr. Pang; b.) The school's focus on the arts and enthusiasm to include our son in the school play; and c.) the incredible diversity of cultures and socioeconomic classes that make up this community. We feel that you cannot place a price on the value of experiencing diversity as a young person.

This is our third year with PS 295 - I have one daughter in second grade and another in Kindergarten. I feel they're both receiving a great education in a diverse but tight-knit community.  Even with budget cuts that all public schools are facing, the administration and the PTA work closely to ensure that our children are still receiving the best quality education with some exciting enrichment programs as well - a partnership with the Brooklyn Music Conservatory, an amazing edible garden, a 12-week dance program with a dedicated dance instructor, science fair, drama sharings, and more. I look forward to "Bagel Bits" each month, where parents are welcomed into the classroom to see first-hand what our children are learning.  It's such a friendly atmosphere - between students, parents and teachers as well.  We're so glad to be a part of it!

We came into PS 295 by way of its CTT program, which wasn’t offered by our zoned school. Our son is now in his second year at the school, and both the first and second grade CTT classes have been outstanding: both good Gen Ed teachers and good Special Ed teachers, as well as dedicated paraprofessionals in each class. Although the classes have been fairly large, we’ve never had the sense that our son had got lost in the crowd. The same is true for the school in general—its small size means that pretty much every adult in the building knows his name, and we couldn’t ask for a more supportive environment for him.  He’s made great progress on his IEP, both in the classroom and in his services. His teachers really “get” him, and we feel he’s both well-supported in areas where he needs it, like staying on-task and improving his writing, and consistently challenged to work beyond grade level in his areas of strength, especially reading and math. At a time when CTT can seem like an endangered species in District 15, we take a lot of comfort in the school’s consistent commitment to the program. 

Meanwhile, our daughter is currently in her first year at PS 295, which she entered for K after spending pre-K in our zoned school (primarily to have both kids in the same school—she’s not on an IEP). She’s having a great time, and has recently turned the corner in learning to read. While we hope she’ll end up in the school’s CTT classes in future years (as a Gen Ed student), since we like that classroom model, we’re confident in the quality of education she’ll get no matter which class she’s in.

We LOVE PS 295! Our daughter is in second grade and has been there since Pre-K. My initial impression was that the school is alive with art; everywhere there are collaborative murals, paintings based on the work of well-known artists, illustrations that accompany both fiction and non-fiction writing. My daughter has learned to love math, reading and writing from her dedicated teachers. Learning is FUN here; she knows all the major bones (something I didn't learn until high school biology!!) by pasting a skeleton onto a Halloween drawing and identifying each bone by writing its name. PS 295 is one of just seven NYC schools to receive a grant from Slow Food, which was used to build raised beds and to plant all kinds of herbs and vegetables; what a great learning experience... kids from every grade level tend the garden, which thrived over the hot summer thanks to volunteer students and their parents. The PTA's first meeting this year included pesto and lemon balm tea made from the garden. The PTA is welcoming to newcomers and is comprised of dedicated parents who do everything they can to make the school even better. We are very happy with the principal, a talented administrator who is open to parents' ideas and input and manages to maintain the school programs and level of greatness despite budget cuts. In short, education here is engaging, holistic and top-notch!

PS295 has been wonderful for my family. My fourth grader has been there since K, and the staff, administration and teachers have all worked together to give him a supportive learning environment that attends to his special needs. My kindergartener plays with blocks, pets the class rabbit, and goes to art several times a week. He also has a reading buddy in 3rd grade, adn the class gets the New York Times every day, which they read and discuss on an age appropriate level. Many of the adults at school already knew his name on the first day of school because he is a little sibling. This is the kind of school 295 is; a real, caring, intimate community. Parents collect in the courtyard before and after school to chat, teachers and aides always have a smile for your child as he or she enters the building, and it really seems as if the teachers all love their jobs, clearly work extremely hard, and truly enjoy being part of this school community as well.

“I really like the integration of arts with academics,” said the art teacher, Carol Rapp. “I like that there are legitimate arts educators here, teaching artists from our area. Everyone is truly an artist. We each have a passion for our own art form and we can transmit that to kids.”
“I just feel like it [the school] gets better and better,” a teacher tells Insideschools.org.  “We’re all learning how to integrate the arts.”

"I couldn't be happier with a school," writes parent Katharine James. "My daughter loves the arts and dance program, and the school has a very warm, friendly family atmosphere and there is a lot of parent involvement." This parent adds that the school makes a "tremendous" effort to involve parents from diverse backgrounds by holding English classes for non-English-speaking parents and Spanish classes for non-Spanish-speaking parents. Finally, this parent praises the school's "Peace Games," which help students "look at how they treat each other," and the "welcoming" library.

A parent, now teaching at the school, said "My daughter said, 'it [the school] is just like a big comfortable bed'. She loves to come to school." This mother said the administration is very open to parent involvement." "The school is better than it's ever been," said a dad active in the PTA for many years. He said the family chose PS 295 over their zoned neighborhood school because "we liked the teachers here. They're more vibrant."
An art teacher praised the "supportive" administration and PTA. "I have lots of supplies," she said, and "there are a lot of dancer and actor parents" who help out.

A parent writes: "The school is great. The diversity and community spirit is very strong. It doesn't have the elitist flavor that the New School does." However, she adds that the school " could use a stronger conflict resolution program."
P.S. 321's School Leadership Team is advocating for the elimination of screened middle schools in District 15 in an effort to better integrate these schools, DNAinfo reports.

Award-winning journalist, Nicole Hannah-Jones examines her search for a school for her daughter amid the inequities of pervasive segregation in NYC Schools, touching on how well-regarded schools including PS 321, 8 and Academy of Arts and Letters experienced a "brief period of transitional integration" before becoming more segregated. Read more here.

The school leadership team of PS 321 unanimously voted not to administer "field tests" (practice questions for future state tests) to students this year, and instead will opt for a day of regular instruction, DNA.info reports.
This truly is a fabulous school. Just wish they'd crack down on number of people who game their way in through fake addresses and such
In a DNAinfo ranking of schools in District 15, PS 321 was the leader in ELA scores for 2015 and second in math. Read more here.

After Columbus Day, the Brooklyn Flea will shut down its market outside of PS 321. Aside from providing shoppers with unique finds, the market is an important revenue generator for P.S. 321's PTA. Read more here.
Thirty-Five percent of students at PS 321 opt out of the state's English and Math exams. Read more here.
Teachers at PS 321 have written a public letter to families requesting their help to oppose Governor Cuomo's proposed changes to teacher evaluations. Read the letter here.

The numbers of children receiving occupational therapy in New York City schools has increased in recent years. A parent of a PS 321 student is interviewed for a New York Times article about this trend. Read the article here.

Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced 73 schools selected to join the Learning Partners Program, an innovative and collaborative initiative that brings schools together to share practices to improve learning in the classroom and raise student outcomes. Through the program, one host school with strong practices in a particular focus area will support two partner schools seeking to strengthen their own practices in that area. PS 321 William Penn was chosen to host P.S. 009 Teunis G. Bergen and P.S. 159. Read more here.
While some schools embraced the new lead teacher raises and leadership roles as part of the UFT contract, others like PS 321 refused to participate in the program. Read more here.
PS 321 4th-graders were among the city's top performers on the 2014 English language arts exam, reports DNA.info, although doubts about the test's content remain. Read more here.
PS 321 principal blames kindergarten waitlist on address fraud. Read more here

New York Magazine explores the race and class divide in NYC through the lens of public schools in Park Slope, including PS 321, where the majority of students are white and just one in ten gets free or reduced meals. Read more here.
Hundreds of parents protested state ELA tests at PS 321. Read more here.
PS 321's diversity committee is hosting a panel discussion on gentrification, which has led to a shift in the racial makeup of the school that is now over 70% white. Read more here.

can anyone help? I'm confused about where my second grader will go to school next year if I move into an apartment that is below Fifth Avenue on Carroll. The new school is only taking K and 1st grade next year, correct?

Your child will be able to stay in the school where he (or she) is currently enrolled even if you move. So if he is enrolled at PS 321 now, he can stay through 5th grade. If you are moving from a different school zone and you want him to change schools, I would check to see what the zoned school is for your new address. You can call 311 to find out or search by your address on the DOE's website: schools.nyc.gov. Or check with the District 15 office.

A group of teachers, parents, and administrators at PS 321 will present a petition to Mayor de Blasio on January 15 to demand an end to linking grade promotion, middle school admissions and school report cards to standardized tests. Read more here.

Hello, I am curious what the "culture" vis-à-vis special needs children is at 321.  I see that they offer a wide range of programs, but what I'm really getting at is, how much are these children made to feel that they are an IMPORTANT part of the 321 community?  The fact that the school has only about a 10% special ed pop - considering its huge student body - seems a little telling, but I don't want to jump to conclusions without being better informed ...

There is a serious bullying problem at 321 that is not being addressed. It is most serious in the 4th and 5th grades, but begins in K. The school should urgently adopt an anti-bullying curriculum and be a leader in keeping kids safe in school.
That's not true. I think they have a very successful respect initiative and zero tolerance for bullying in practice and curriculum.
Does anyone know if 321 is hosting a pre-k for fall 2013?  They're not listed in the DOE directory....
PS 321 hosted Park Slope's first-ever dog show, according to DNAinfo.

I went to 321 and loved it soooooooo much! It's an amazing school that was fun and had me learn a lot. I loved all the arts classes especially music, and enjoyed after school chorus in 4th and 5th grade.I made tons of friends and am still in touch with many of my teachers. The teachers were super supportive and amazing, and helped me become the person I am today. Writing and reading are the school's specialties, but science, math, and social studies are great at 321 as well. The one big fault I noticed in this review is that it mentioned middle schools kids go onto, but it didn't mention MS 51 which is the school that more than half of the graduating class goes onto! I went there and so did most of my friends from 321.

I used to be a student at PS. 321 and I'm glad I got out. The real reason I hate this school was my fourth and fifth year there. In the fourth, my teacher was basically, a bully. She yelled at me when I made any simple mistakes, she humiliated me in front of my classmates when I so much as got one question wrong on a math worksheet and frequently denied me Recess, because she could. Worst of all, I wasn't the only victim. Two others had permanently attained her wrath, getting the same punishments for doing basically nothing.
Although 5th grade wasn't as traumatic, I still was the victim of this bulking kid, afraid of his body image and willing to take out those fears on me. He didn't beat me up, but those insults really hurt. When I told a teacher, they didn't do anything, due to a "Lack of evidence" supporting his attacks on me.
That is why I hated that school.

I am a 5th grade student from 321 and I completely disagree with any one who bad talks it. It is the most amazing experience that i have ever been through. Adults only see 321 from the outside, from the reviews, grades, and numbers. I guarantee you can go up to any student or former student of 321, an they will tell you they love our school. Our school is a community, and you parents, just because you read some bad reviews by someone who has never been in the school, probably never even seen the school just read a state test about a tree talking. And that, that drives you to try to mold, modify our community that is so unique, and special.
   Many people comment on our size. 1402. Yes, sometimes its a little noisy, but I knew a kid in a different school who was in a gifted class and had stayed in that class with the same kids for her whole elementary experience. She was popular and had maybe five friends.
I am normal and I  have maybe twenty five friends, and I know almost everyones names, and faces.
     So send your kids to this school. Don't listen to what adults have to say. Listen to the students.

PS 321 parents were among those protesting field testing outside the midtown Manhattan headquarters of Pearson, the testing company. Read more: Brandishing pineapples, parents and students target Pearson.

PS 321 Principal Elizabeth Phillips wrote a letter to the State Ed Commissioner John B. King Jr. urging him to "carefully review" the 2012 ELA exams. She expressed shock over the poor quality of this year's exams in light of the high stakes nature of the tests. Read the letter on Ed Notes: http://ednotesonline.blogspot.com/2012/04/test-protests-grow-as-brooklyn.html
Liz Phillips also spoke to the Daily News about an unfair test policy for the 4th grade math exams: http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/education/mistakes-york-state-tests-article-1.1066649

One of my children is graduating this year. My second one will be entering k next year. As I think back at my first child's experience, I cannot but think that the school has still much to improve. It is by far better than our average NYC public schools, but it does suffer from many of the same ills. The majority of the teachers are fantastic. Most are creative, student-centered and sensitive to the children's scholastic and emotional and social needs. But some, a minority, are so horrible, they scar children for years. One such teacher, who probably looks great on paper because her students' 3rd grade test scores are high, is so abusive, mean, and ignorent, it makes one wonder if the school's promise of a progressive education is genuine. No matter how many parents complained and how many of her students experienced humiliation and threats did not seem to have mattered to this teacher's superiors. The over-crowding is getting worse. Even the most skilled teacher cannot possibly do her best with 34 kids in a classroom. There are wonderful things about this school that I an excited for my second child to experience, but there are others I dread and fear.

You complained a lot about 321 amost exactly 2 years ago, writing a similarly worded, rambling monolgue back then.

My youngest is graduating soon, and my oldest, who is now in high school, went here as well. I'm also a teacher in a different school. 321 is head and shoulders above every other school I have seen in NYC. 

Is it perfect? No, but then nothing is ever perfect. If you go through life looking for perfect, you will miss the best in life. 

I don't expect anything to be perfect (though I don't know what third grade teacher you could possibly be talking about. My kids mostly had very sensitive teachers. I've certainly never heard of a teacher that "many parents" were complaining about! And I can't imagine Liz ignoring "many parents". 

I do think that Liz, and the rest of the staff at 321, try to figure out what isn't working well, and try to come up with creative solutions to problems. That's pretty good, in my book!

You are confusing two people.  I wrote the comment two years ago, but not the one six months ago.  However, I do object to your calling my input a "rambling monologue" since I used 166 words in my original commentary, but you used 170!  Who's pithy now?
GrowNYC awarded 29 NYC schools a Grow to Learn grant for creating garden classrooms.

I have two children at this school and I have noticed their class sizes increase steadily over time. My family is zoned for the school, it makes me angry to find out how many families cheat their way in using a fake address. I don't have the choice to send my kids to a different school, and I wish all those families who lived elsewhere would send their kids to their local schools and get active there. There are so many children that dismissal takes place out of all four sides of the building. Lunch/recess time is an exercise in "moving the masses" and an assistant principal uses a whistle or a bullhorn to quiet the crowd. It is very unpleasant. Also, many of us parents are upset that the school closes the back yard after 3 pm when there is any snow on the ground "for safety". It is the only time many children get to see and play with friends not in their class.
Maybe you should look at other schools around the area!
"I'll be honest in saying I'm not terribly happy with the school this year. The classes are too big and there's no special help when needed."

"I am currently in 8th grade, going through the high school process, and I really miss PS 321. It was an amazing experience that couldn't even compare to my middle school, of which I despise. PS 321 had such lovely teachers and a pretty good community, despite certain problem children. I had so many great times there, and I look back on it very positively. It shaped me into who I am today, and I am incredibly thankful I was able to go to PS 321."

"I have two kids at 321 and another soon to be there. As the graduate of 12 years at an elite Manhattan private school I was unsure what to expect from a public school, but all in all I've been thrilled with 321. Academics are strong although the math is generally speaking uneven. The reading and writing however more than make up for it; I can't imagine a more inspiring literacy curriculum. The school has turned both my older kids into eager readers who revere great authors and write prolifically on their own .There's a cult around reading at 321. The community of the school is fabulous: lively and involved (sometimes to the point of excess-- there seems to be another summons to join a parent activity every other day!) The downsides are that the school is big and while the teachers are generally speaking terrific, they can't teach to each child's specific needs (though they surely try.) One of my sons is advanced in math and after a few frustrating years, his last two teachers have arranged for more challenging math for the advanced kids in their classes. It's not a demanding environment, which in elementary school, seems appropriate. It is, however, an inspiring one."

According to an April 2, 2007 article in The New Yorker, the school offers an '"Ad-Busters' class as an after-school program, intended to impart radical skepticism in kindergarteners." A parent at the school teaches the class, and on one day took students to a local grocery store. The parent, Susan Gregory Thomas, taught students to look at nutrients list, about saturated fats, and why some macaroni and cheese have characters on their boxes.
A parent complains that "PS 321 systematically places up 28 kids in the inclusion class," diminishing the quality of instruction and making the school "crowded and unsafe."
"PS 321 is a very nice school with very nice teachers and very nice students," writes a student. "The teachers are very supportive of our learning!"

A parent writes to report about the overcrowding situation at PS 321. "There are now 25-26 kids in each of the 8 kindergarten classes -- that's 4-6 more children than were in the kindergarten classes two years ago," writes this parent. "Three weeks after school has begun, my daughter still doesn't know the names of all her classmates, and the dedicated teachers must now work yet longer hours and may be that much more exhausted. The teachers and the resources of 321 are impressive, but they are being stretched beyond capacity."

"I think this is a great school," writes former student Juan, who attended the school immediately after he came to the United States. "They helped me with my english when I didn't understand anything."

"As I look back on the experience at 321 I can't find any flaws," writes recent graduate Anne. "The teachers always cared so much and always found the most fun and creative ways to teach.They always had a great program that included extras, such as music, art, science, and my personal favorite, the fifth grade enrichment program."

A parent, who is an educator at another school, said she is happy with 321 for her child although she finds it "kind of a factory-like" and "not the most progressive of places" with its'  "strong commitment to traditional education" and "traditional 40 minute periods."  "Parent involvement is very strong," she says, and there is "strong teaching."

A parent writes: "We moved to Park Slope for PS 321 based on its reputation alone and have not been disappointed. I was intimidated by the size of the school at first -- well over 1,000 kids. But it is so well organized and the efforts at communicating to parents are so strong that it feels like a small, vibrant community. The teachers are, on the whole, bent on doing their best -- and are encouraged to do so with professional development programs. There's a sense of camaraderie and support among the staff that helps bolster the community feeling of the school." She adds: "Although PS 321 is strongly focused on literacy, my child, who is much stronger in science and math, is encouraged and given extra work to keep him challenged. This was done by his teacher without any prompting by me! What more can I say?"

A former student writes: "Even though I only spent one year at 321, it was my favorite year out of all my school years. The atmosphere was great, from the couches in the classrooms, to being let outside for lunch, it was very relaxed and a great learning environment. I actually wanted to come to school everyday. The teacher I had was dedicated and I learned alot. I made a great group of friends who all lived in the neighborhood. I participated in multiple extracurricular activities. While the workload may not be that difficult, and the math curriculum was at best mediocre as I recall, I think the other aspects of the school more than makes up for it."

In response to a previous comment about the school's demographic makeup, a parent writes: "PS321 actually does exhibit a fair spectrum of Brooklyn's racial diversity. A more telling point is that the population tends to be on the wealthier side." He adds: "On what I consider a related note, many parents are overly critical of the teachers here. No school has perfect teachers across the board, but the majority at 321 are capable, responsive, nurturing professionals. And the administration is extremely proactive in supporting those who might need a little extra help. This is an excellent school."

"This is an academically strong school for the most part, even if a little inconsistent its math program," writes a parent. "I felt they were trying out different approaches, conducting an unofficial experiment using our children, to see which math model helped the school achieve the best results. PS 321 seems to be score oriented. We did have mixed experiences here, depending on which teacher my child got from year to year." She writes that she had one bad experience with a teacher who made her feel "ignored then patronized." Still, she writes, "It is an unquestionably good school. It is popular, overcrowded, high energy, lots of parental involvement, competitive, though not a true representation of the diversity of NYC, being mostly white."

This school is more than school,is a family the staff was the best and the principal great friend all working together and help me to much ,my kids cry when  they leave this school my boy was graduated in 2013 and my daughter 2016 I'm surprised my kids everyday happy in the school and after school very fun and warm ,my daughter in prekindergarten al the time said "mom I want to stay in after school" unbelievable my 4 years old more the 10 hours in the school happy every day ....some teacher  we never forgethank you very much The Children School.
Dear parents if u looking for something more than school a place for you kids be safe and love and teach whit love and compression this is the school 
The best school in district 15 😘
A teacher and a parent write about how The Children's School began to diversify the admissions process. Read it on Chalkbeat
That is not true. Every class has recess everyday. Only play time before the start of the school day at 8:20, which was not supervised, was cancelled as it was unsafe.

Maybe not done in the best way, but meetings are being set up to come up with safe solutions. Parents were droping their kids off at 7:30 and leaving without supervision before the school was even officially open. Not safe. As for the 8-8:20 "play time" it is beloved but not supervised and therefore not safe. The previous administration had turned a blind eye.
New principal has definitely set a harsh new tone for this community. Her first administrative decision was to cancel recess. Surprising yet true.
I don't think this is true; my son still has recess every day.  I think it's just morning drop practice that has changed.

As part of a pilot program to encourage diversity, 33% of kindergarten seats at The Children's School will be reserved for students who are English language learners or qualify for free or reduced lunch.

Principal Arthur Mattia (known to students as Mr Artie) says the Children's School is so popular because of its belief that all children can learn regardless of their disabilities. Read an interview with Mr Artie here.
The city has approved requests to change admissions policies at several schools, including The Children's School, with the goal of encouraging diversity. Read more here.

Their website is messed up, but they have a pretty nice PTA site that explains everything about the school.

http://inclusions.org/

In October 2014, twelve New York City public schools, including the Children's School, submitted detailed proposals about ways to promote and preserve diversity in their school communities. Nearly a year later, these schools are still waiting on a response from Chancellor Carmen Fariña. Read more here.

Hello, our non-IEP son was offered a seat here and we're still trying to decide whether to send him here or elsewhere. We did the open houses but what does that really tell you? Can anyone chime in with their recent experiences, good or bad?   Thank you in advance.

The statistics for the Children's School are extremely confusing.  It says 187 children attend, but in fact it's closer to 500.  And if you look under special education it says N/A for ICT, whereas in fact every class in the school is ICT.  The challenge is that the Children's School is actually a partnership between district 15 and district 75, and the school actually has two DOE numbers -- I believe 15K418 and 75K372.  This is why it's so hard to get stats for the full school population.  I'm a potential Children's School parent, and this district split is making it impossible to find accurate data on demographics, on test scores, on anything.  Is this something Insides Schools can look into?  It seems like a really wonderful place, but I'd really like the full picture. Thanks.

My son attended PS 372 from Kindergarten through Fourth
grade.  As a teacher I know that one sign
of a successful school is whether or not the teachers want their own children
to attend the school. I know of several teachers who have their kids in the
school.  In my experience for the most
part the team teaching model worked. Sometimes it was amazing and some times it
was good. The plus is that there are two to three adults in every classroom.
The negative is that there can be students with attention or impulse control
issues who distract the class. Keep in mind that those students can be in a
“regular” classroom as well. The arts programing is wonderful. There is music,
dance, art and some grade levels write, produce and perform an opera.

 

As the parent of a student with an IEP I would say that the
OTs are great and that there seemed to be more trouble with the Speech
Therapists. You will need to continue to advocate for your child and be sure
that everyone is aware of any accommodations for teaching or testing that are
needed. Honestly, I did hear of a few teachers who were not very good, but that
will be true in any institution. I would highly recommend the school.

Would anyone be so kind as to provide feedback regarding PS372's ASD site on Adelphi Street?  It would be great to hear from parent(s) who have children there i.e. program, teachers, facility, safety, etc. Thank you.
P.S. 372 holding a dance open to the public in the hopes of raising funds for a safer dance floor. Read more here.
After a lengthy quest to add a middle school to the Children's School, Principal Mattia has withdrawn the request to the DOE to add grades 6-8 for the 2013-2014 school year. Read more here.

The Department of the Education gave the greenlight for the Children's School to grow to include a middle school but the DOE has not helped the school find new space to expand. Read more: Park Slope parents want middle school that was promised by the city..
Some kids have gentle learning problems while others have serious psychological or educational issues. Some have high intellect and alternative conduct.
I used to go to ps 372 from 1997 to 2003 and i can say that the teachers there are caring and really nice and also that this school is one of the finest public schools in brooklyn

The school's scores are good, but the "mean teachers", a few, remain an issue. Insideschools needs to identify blurbs by a school's PTA officers, as their children are guaranteed "nice teacher" spots, probably the same all over the city. I am not married to a big salary, and don't have time to be on the committees. The stress over teacher assignments, which are secret over the summer, is a sure thing if you don't have clout. Getting your child through a year with an insensitive or critical teacher is no picnic. Comments from PTA officers should be taken with a grain of salt.
Can someone please give me an estimate percentage of the school's diversity?
About: 59% white, 20% Hispanic, 13% black and 9% Asian
Sounds like this will be like the next ps 6 or 41 or 234 in Manhattan.  Families with means will flock to this school (which is a good thing)

also its not really a good thing for only families with means to be able to access the best schools in the city (as a graduate, I know that this truly a great school largely due to its highly individualized attention and great teachers)

I'm starting to think parents with means should gather to improve their own school district, rather than descending on a school and, essentially, helping themselves to resources that took other parents and teachers time and effort to establish.
Some parents support this school’s decision to replace recess with activities and clubs. Read more here: At Top Public Schools, the Arts Replace Recess.
Alison Bowers (parent): “Everything is about inclusiveness. Children see that behavior isn’t necessarily related to capability. We are very sensitive to judgments.”
Felicia Eve (parent): “My child has become more sensitive to the fact that everybody doesn’t learn the same way.”

The curriculum is good, as is enrichment, and there are some terrific teachers. However, I have to agree with the parent who observed that, yes, there are some teachers who seem stressed, tired and burnt out, and also yes, they seem not to even look at your child's IEP if he should have one, or be willing to talk much about parent concerns or new ideas in this respect they can be rigid. They also seem to like conformity both in parents and kids there, which I wouldn't have expected in a school that purports to celebrate individuality. It can also be clique-ish; there is almost a family dynasty feeling about the place. They are not doing well with diversity concerns. Finally, for the entire year the principal seemed to lack the motivation and wherewithal remedy the closing of the early childhood playground, which is too bad.

"I am a former student from the Children's school, and I have to say that my education there helped lay a foundation for my progress since. I was admitted to NEST+m, where I got a 96 average and perfect scores on both Statewide tests. The Children's School taught me social skills, ethics, and the ability to work with others even when we are very different. All the kids love the teachers, and the school is rich with clubs and activities. The Children's School Community still holds, even three years after I graduated. I made all my best friends there, and I think it's the greatest elementary school in the City."

"Ten years ago our son started Pre-K at The Children's School and went all the way through to fifth grade. When he graduated, he was very well prepared for middle school, had no trouble with the transition to sixth grade, and is now on his way to a top high school," writes a parent. "I credit The Children's School with giving him a strong foundation. Now, in a couple of weeks, our daughter will graduate from fifth grade and is moving on to a highly rated middle school. That makes ten years our family has spent, in total, at this very wonderful school. Both my kids have been happy there all the way through. My son hated to leave, three years ago, and now my daughter also feels sad to move on. I remind them how lucky they have been to have experienced such a consistently excellent school and warm group of teachers and administrators. I can't recommend this school highly enough!"

"Our family has been at the school for many years. Although there are many fine teachers and my children have had many positive experiences, the school has some real issues," writes a parent. "First of all, one of my children has special needs, and in our time at the school, never once has the IEP (Individualized Education Plan) teacher met with his teachers to advocate for his needs; her position seems to be mainly bureaucratic. Also, for an inclusion school, some of the special education teachers are notably uneducated about classroom strategies, and reluctant to provide the support that my child needs. Lastly, there are a few mean teachers at the school, and the administration seems willing to tolerate or excuse their behavior at the expense of the children. The school means well, but staff development is needed."  
Principal Arthur Mattia responds to the comment above: "As always, The Children's School remains committed to working with parents to address the needs of all our students. Since our inception, administration has had an open door policy to listen to any parental concerns."

"The school has some extraordinary teachers, some just-fine ones and very few true duds. Having so many teachers per class means there's usually at least one your child will connect with," writes a parent. "The school is very close-knit and nurturing and the kids seem to get an excellent education for the most part. And as far as I know, the majority of last year's graduating 5th graders got into their first-choice middle schools."

"Having at least 3-4 adults (two teachers and one to two paraprofessionals) in each class really allows for each child to get a lot of individual attention," writes a parent. "There is a major arts foundation (with art, drama, movement and dance - the upper grades even create thier own operas!) but also wonderful science teachers and a multimedia class to round it all out. A combination of the caring staff/teachers, wonderful kids/parents really make this a fantastic school!"

A parent writes: "Our two general ed children have benefited from being in an inclusion class. They have become more tolerant and aware of the range of talents and gifts around them," a parent writes. This parent notes that while the school "does not tend to cater well to children with stronger academic skills, especially in the higher grades" and is not as diverse as it could be, the school is making efforts to address both weaknesses.

A parent writes: "Sometimes I find it very hard to believe that this school is actually a NYC public school. The staff qualifications, competence, and dedication would certainly suggest otherwise! Everyday I am deeply thankful that my child is able to attend The Children's School."

Parent Coordinator Darlene Vanasco writes: "The Children's School is a unique and amazing place that breeds a culture of respect among students. The academics are rigorous, while still meeting the needs of individual learners. The families and staff are wonderful, smart and nurturing people. It is truly an honor to work here!"

Parent Claudia Reyes writes: "The Children's School is the best decision that I made for my kids. The teachers are caring and in tune to your child's needs. They always have time to discuss whatever is on your mind. The parent involvement is amazing here."

"The school is house as of September 2004 under one roof," writes Myrta Echevarria, a parent. "I believe that the scoring in reading and math should be reviewed, our children did quite well last year."

I am an 8th grader at this school and uniforms 
are required

My daughter, a mixed-raced child (Chinese and Latino), is an academically high-achieving, science-obsessed, computer-programming, shy and reserved child, who has been bullied before in her school and other programs (for being shy or Chinese). We have been interested in MS 442 for its technology-based curriculum and diverse student body. Now that it is located in Windsor Terrance, it is a particularly attractive option. We are concerned about its test scores and its fit for our reserved child. I would be very interested in hearing from current parents, students, and teachers their thoughts.
Please also comment on how effective the Mastery-based learning system has been at MS 442 and give us the list of high schools that students are most frequently accepted into.

I toured MS 442 and had an opportunity to speak at length with a few teachers. I was so impressed by their dedication to helping kids learn. From the outside, at least, this seems like a school with a really smart approach to public education: accepting a truly diverse ranging of learners and challenging every single one of them to push themselves and move forward. I'm strongly considering this school for my son.

MS442 Brooklyn - School for Innovation has moved to the Bishop Ford HS building in Windsor Terrace - a great new space with the same great teachers led by the same great principal.  Highly recommend the school!!
MS 442 moved into the old Bishop Ford Central Catholic High School, which administrators say led to an increase in enrollment at the school, DNAinfo reports.

MS442 is one of eight New York City Schools schools that voluntarily implemented a Mastery-based learning program without traditional letter grades; the program will serve as a model for other schools across the city, the New York Times reports.

This school ROCKS!   I am the parent of a 7th grader, so this is our 2nd year.  Here's what we love about MS442.
 - The teachers are great, they are really interested in what they do 
 - The environment of the school is kind and encouraging, the teachers and other staff really like the kids.
 - Mastery-based grading, this means that grades on assignments and school work allow children to know if they are meeting the standard/goal or maybe still approaching or even exceeding.  For real, when kids are "approaching" the standard they are given many opportunities to gain mastery. And they feel good about it.
 - Great after school programs
 - Diversity, a wonderful mix of kids from all backgrounds
 - Most importantly, our daughter is happy in school, interested in what she is learning!

You have probably seen that the school is moving to a new location next year (The old Bishop Ford High School building) - we're confident that the transition will be smooth and they will continue to have a great program.

For September 2017:  
MS442 Will be relocating to the former Bishop Ford Catholic School site, located on 19th Street in Windsor Terrace.

The Department of Education has not yet announced a relocation site for MS 442. The school's ASD NEST program for students with Autism had been a large draw for parents, but the uncertainty of location kept many from applying this year DNA info reports.

My son started 6th Grade at MS 442 last fall. He has just started 7th grade last week and he is actually happy to be back to school! This from a kid who never really enjoyed school before he came to MS 442. I love that the school community is small enough that we can get to know each other, the admin and teachers are accessible and responsive, and the learning is individualized so that each student can be both nurtured and challenged as needed. MS 442 is an inclusive and diverse school and that is part if the reason we chose it, I think it's important for students to work together and be exposed to difference as part of their school experience. That is happening here! The students are encouraged to take responsibility for their own learning  through mastery based curriculum and always have the opportunity to improve their grades which can be a good motivator. We have had a great experience so far at MS 442 and feel we made the right Middle School choice.

hi Heather - i just visited MS 442 and am very interested in the school for many reasons.  I have some hesitation though because of the system of points used for discipline which includes the concept of detention.  In general, the school doesn't sound like a punitive place but I think a system where punishment is part of the equation is a problem, particularly in a school that puts value on diversity.   Also, my friend is concerned that there isn't enough time for recess/free play.  Any thoughts on these issues would be appreciated! Thanks!
Parents are concerned that a plan to co-locate MS 442 with Cobble Hill School of American Studies will have negative impacts for both schools, reports DNAinfo.
Parents are demanding to know more about Department of Education plans to relocate MS 442. Read more here.

My son is a 6th grader at 442 and the schools ROCKS. He is genuinely HAPPY everyday! He is thoroughly enjoying his learning experience. Project based learning is the best thing that ever happened to this kid! He has completely opened up as a student. For a kid that has trouble focusing, he's making his way in the world with the help of these amazing teachers and staff. He gets the attention and individuality that is needed to help him succeed, learn and grow. We couldn't be happier than we are about our decision and placement of MS 442!

We chose 442 because:


1) they are inclusive from different backgrounds and levels BE TOGETHER but at the same time they are all STILL CHALLENGED through individual lesson plans/goals


2) the teachers have energy and enthusiasm when engaging with the kids, I think as a result of a relationship with Teachers College


3) they dont make homework the focus but rather it is more about the individualized learning plans/goals 


4) the deal they have with Apple and how to use tech, but not all about tech


5) my son comes home happy and talks about school in ways he hasn't before


MS 442 has found a great formula.

My son is a sixth grader that was very happy to apply and get into 442 !  it offers specifically a Curriculum in the Arts and my son plays acoustic and electric guitar he gets the support he needs to expand his skills, the size of this school was important to us, it was not as big as many other schools we visited and he is comfortable getting along and around at 442. It is important that my son is in a school that is ethnically diverse with students and the educators and it is !   Although homework is a big part of the students responsibility, 442 is thoughtful how to manage the load and be creative in allowing the students to work on collaborative projects to learn and assess the work they are learning. 442 has a great parent coordinator that has been hands on and very helpful with all aspects of the school process since the very beginning ! My son really enjoys Chess and Guitar clubs offered before going to an after school program that is offered as well .  We are happy with 442 and All it has to offer. When the school is relocated as long as DOE relocates 442 into a space that allows them to grow and build and replicate the unique and innovative programs it offers, we will continue to travel and support 442 because overall the programs and curriculum are why we chose the school in the first place !  Rosemarie Maldonado- Wright

My son is a sixth grader coming from PS10 and we have been so impressed with the teaching and hands on learning happening at MS 442. He comes home completely lit up about science and math. We just had parent teacher conferences and the teachers talked about what a science kid he is and were shocked when we said that we hadn't actually known that until this year-it's something that they've inspired (lots of hands on experiments and really cool collaborative projects across the curriculum). They pull them out in small group intensives so they have the chance to focus on things they need more time with or alternately explore something on a deeper level if they're ready for more. I loved that during the conference each subject teacher had a plan specifically for my son-this is what we think  he's ready for so we're planning to start him on this, etc. it's so individually geared to each student. Definitely room for kids to stretch intellectually and they're encouraged to do so. My son is on the quieter side and I had been worried that he'd sit back in a bigger school and potentially get lost-442 has been great about encouraging him to put himself forward. He  loves it and is so comfortable and happy and motivated there. In addition to ELA they have three periods a week of basically free reading which I think is huge for literacy. And in addition to math, they have another class called problem solving. And very cool afterschools. My son loves running club and is also doing a really cool (free afterschool) filmmaking class at 442 with BRIC. And there's a partnership with BEAM and sixth graders will have a rotation there this year as well.

I am current 9th grader, and I currently go to Frank Sinatra School of The Arts High School. I attended MS442 and I still come back to visit because it was such a great, supportive community, Because of the great relationship I had with one of my teachers, I my first a summer job at New Country Day Camp. For students who are interesting in performing arts there is a Broadway Jr. program here. Also I went to High School knowing how to make power point presentation, websites and iMovies. The program is very supportive and I suggest having your scholars attend MS442.
Chalkbeat calls the school a "hidden gem" http://ny.chalkbeat.org/2015/11/13/what-it-took-for-a-brooklyn-school-to-shed-an-old-reputation-and-get-some-new-parents-to-give-it-a-shot/

Science is my favorite subject at school.  In 6th grade, we worked in groups and independently on different projects from my classmates.  I got to share with my friends during class what we each were working on.  It was awesome and kind of like I was learning from my friends.  

I also really love being part of the basketball team.  I feel like the small school is a really close school because everyone can be part of a club or team that interests them.  I am looking forward to basketball again this year because I make new friends that I can hang with both at practice and at games, and off the court completely.

I love the basketball team. It is ran by some of my teachers and I feel like basketball has helped to make my middle school experience.  

We are required to check in with our coach in the morning to have a good academic day.  We are student athletes at our school and I need to do good in school to be able to play on the court.

Our school has a mentoring program which helps me stay connected to my academic, athletic and social self.  I work on different things when I'm with different people.  It is important to me for my teachers to consider me a good student because I am a student athlete.

Mentoring is awesome! I love having a staff member I can trust. The staff here always asks if I'm okay and I'm grateful for their guidance.  I get to see my mentor weekly for 15 minutes each week.  We set academic and social goals that help me focus my time at school. They really value making individual relationships with the students at the school.They are willing to do anything to keep learning fun and original.  

I made a lot of friends in Cheerleading I didn't know any 8th graders in 6th grade but when I joined cheerleading I found that they're actually really nice. This helped to make me feel much more connected to the school at large. There are so many after school clubs to choose from ALL ran by the teachers here.

I have made lots of friends through the clubs i were in like Cheerleading, Dnace team and Theater. Especially in theater because I got to do something i am interested in while also meeting new people. The students and the teacher adviser, Mr. Jones really made my experience that much better. That also made me keep my grades up because I need to keep up my grades to stay in the clubs i am in.  I know that any of my teachers would be willing to help me with my school work if I needed it because I know my success and happiness is important to me and them.  It's helpful because the school community is so tight knit, I love being a part of it.  I have found my spot here and I am excited for my 7th grade year.

When I was in 601 I loved how close everybody was and how we were all good friends. We always had a good time and the year was full of laughs. I also love how my school has so many after school clubs that you can join because everybody has different hobbies and I like how this school appreciates that.

I love how the teachers know how to make learning fun and interesting by including things that students will pay attention to. I love it when in 7th grade ELA the teachers put the lesson on singers and actors that we know but they make us actually learn something that we wouldn't have really noticed.
I found myself with Wediko from my guidance counselor. They have helped me so much with my problems and I have grown into being a better person

MS 442 has been selected to showcase how the school supports all students through innovative instruction in the inaugural year of Chancellor Carmen Fariña’s Showcase Schools Program. The initiative is designed to promote collaboration and sharing of strong practices. Schools that excel in a specific learning focus area will host educators from other schools to share their successful structures and strategies. Read more here.

This school is negatively horrific. Trust me, I'm an 8th grader attending at this school and let me tell you this; it's academic efficiency is horrible and pretty flawed. Me and a few other classmates are specifically the ONLY ones passing the grade with an 3.6+ GPA. That's only 10% of the students in general, me included. But the other 90% of students are failing the grade with an approximate 1.9 GPA, which is negatively stunning and pretty disgraceful towards the education system. I can do my work easily and accurately, very quickly without assistance from the teachers. But the other 90% of students ALWAYS need help from the teachers. If your a parent of an extremely intelligent child, don't send him or her to this school. If your a parent of a child who usually needs help from his or her's teacher(s), this school can assist them well but the child still needs to have accurate positive independent capability, meaning he or she should be able to complete their work correctly on their own. Other than that, this school is still flawed. I give this school a 3/10, in terms of rating. Deanna Sinito needs to spend more time inside her office so students can get a more comfortable adjustment to the school, contibuted with their independence; this is my advice for the principal in the future.

P.S.- The teachers need to give the students more homework, I study and give myself work at home but the other kids aren't going to academically keep up if their too busy listening to rap music and being on social media sites for hours while their home.

CGSI is a great school. My 6th grader has come out of his shell and his academics have improved. The staff really invests in and sincerely cares about the students. I love the high level of communication between school and home. I also like the variety of extracurricular activities. Small class sizes give the students the attention they deserve and an opportunity to flourish. Our 1st year at CGSI has been great. I'm looking forward to 7th grade!

My daughter attends MS442 and I am pleased to say she is very happy there. I was initially, not interested in her attending "NEW HORIZONS" because of neighborhood rumors. I am happy I did a little research before sending her off to another school. I believe with its new Principle and some new administration, it has come a long way. Mrs Sinito is a very active, reasonable and outgoing principle. She is a lovely woman and does a great job making all of the children and parents feel welcomed. The staff is competent and engaged in your child's everyday successes. I got the sense from our first parent teacher conference that the staff is truly there to provide the support your child needs.I am amazed at my daughters new found confidence in herself and her studies. When my daughter started, she was not a happy fluent reader. I forced her to read every day for an hr. Now, I walk in the room and shes just sitting there with her book open, ready to share what she has read.  It is her first year at MS442. In the 6 months of being there she has blossomed into a very opinionated, open minded, empathetic, courageous and sympathetic human being. I am also a fan of "the not so much homework" rule. I was a little worried in the beginning, but I guess if they need if they are learning what the need to learn in class, why not!?!

I initially chose MS442 because of it's beautiful location, its small size and its proximity to home.  I was pleased to find that the teaching and support staff consistently provides my daughter with the encouragement and motivation that she needs.  It has only been about several weeks since the beginning of school, and I have noticed a positive, unexpected transformation in my child's behavior and attitude at home and towards school.  This is how I measure success.  In addition, the school offers a variety of interesting afterschool programs that my daughter enjoys.  I feel the afterschool programs balances her need for independence and creative expression.  This school is certainly worthy of serious consideration especially for parents with special needs children.

Hi - I'm a neighbor in the hood, and no disrespect intended, but I was just walking my dog and passed by box-loads of 8th grade mathematics books (looked in great condition) on the curb ready to be picked up by sanitation.  Is there no local, city, state or world-wide school or tutoring program that could use them? Seems a sad waste of resources and money, even if for some reason the specific curriculum for that book has changed or is outdated.

ms442 is a horrible school the students are disrespectful they treat the teachers like trash not to mention how mean they are to anybody who is different then them. When i went to school here i was scared to go there everyday because of the fights that would brake out most days
Why

MS 442 is a great school. It has school plays , clubs,great teachers that care and don't give up on you.They have sports too like soccer, basketball, baseball, and football but I wish they had a track team or a track club because I would really love this school and behave , and do my work more if they had a track team or club. The teachers are nice, cool , and make learning fun if we are doing a activity we would still be learning. They come up with new ways to teach math or science. They teach in ways you want to learn it because it looks like fun.
                                                                                                           The bad about MS442 is that the school is sometimes very hot because they don't have a.c.Then we have to wear hot uniforms all the way to 8th grade until you go to high school.

This school is a great place to learn .At MS.442 teachers and students will know each other beacause this school is small.Also this school has new equipment like new calculators , new computers and new smart boards.There's no bullying because MS.442 has expensive uniforms.MS.442 also have clubs like girls group, art club music club ,sports club,etc.At lunch the boys and girls have seperate lunches.Also since this school is connected to PS.32 the older student gets to see little kids this is why this school is great.

My 12th year daughter is currently (2011-2012)
attending MS 442 and is thriving in the sixth grade. In part, I give credit to
the nurturing and “thinking outside the box,” education pedagogical environment
that MS 442 created, and the herculean dedication, patience, cultural-economic sensitivity,
innovative, and tolerance of the teachers, and all staff.  

Due to the encouragement and support of her Art/Music,
ELA, Math, and Science teachers at MS 442, my daughter was accepted and will be
attending the American Museum of Natural History’s (in NYC) Wildlife Forensics
Institute and Evolution Institute for this Summer 2012 and Fall 2012. She is
striving to be a Doctor of Veterinarian Medicine when she grows up, just like
her great grandfather in Mexico.    

Moreover, my daughter has maintained a 95% grade
point average or above at MS 442 as she did in the past at PS 29. Both her grade
point average and test level scores, earned her an invitation to take the
Hunter College High School, Anderson School exams, participate in the DREAM Initiative
(sponsored by the DOE), and had been accepted to the Brooklyn Friends School
for two straight years. Her 4th grade and 5th grade State
scores in New York and Florida State were all perfect 4s in all subjects. 

In all, I am both appreciative and I am grateful for
MS 442 attitude towards creating a better and accepting world towards others
(of all educational needs) through social and educational integration. 

As a Mexican single parent (by choice), university
professor with a Ph.D. in Anthropology-Gender and Development, and a person
with Adult Attention Deficit Disorder (ADD), I count and
expect the faculty at MS 442 to work in partnership with me in keeping my
daughter curious, inventive, safe, hopeful, and strengthening her critical learning
skills. To date, the teachers and staff have managed to keep their doors open
to any new suggestions and ideas.

I am sorry you and your child had a negative experience at MS 442. My daughter graduated last year and the 3 years she spent there were enriching, fulfilling and nurturing. The teachers are amongst the best and the brightest . They are interesting, interested , caring and concerned. There were interesting things happening ; green roof,  and solar panel project.  The parent co-ordinator is one of the most competent and capable people I had the pleasure to deal with.The Principal is the best, she knows all the children by name and has put together an amazing group of teachers and is always available for parents and students.

My son attend MS442 in 6th grade and graduated last year. This is a great school the teachers support students in every way. My son did great here he goes visits every once in awhile teachers loved him. Alot of programs to get involved in. Teachers make phones calls to parents to give updates on your child which I love.

My son was just recently notified that he will be attending this school. I was not sure if we put this on his list and I was a bit worried. He is really one of those students who has SO MUCH Potential, and just does not utilize it. I am a single parent and try to assist him in every way possible, but I have to admit that somedays I am just plain tired and school was so easy for me that it can frustrate me when he doesn't "get it" like Math. He placed in the gifted and talented for his 4th grade scores, but I knew he was not ready. he needs determination and motivation and me talking about college and life does not work. 

I have read through these reviews and while I thought based on testing this was not a great school, I actually think this may be the perfect environment for him. I am hoping that he can instill the motivation he so desperately needs, and the fact that there are other activities, such as chess and drama, available to him. He stays after school on Thursdays now for the chess club at the library. 

My only question is what happened between 2009 and 2010 to make test scores drop so low? I have researched and cannot come up with anything. I have signed my paper and this is where he will be going, and I hope with collaboration from teachers and the support staff, my son will be able to thrive, as I know he can!

This is the year that NYS decided to increase the rigor of all state exams, across all subjects and all grades. If you look at other similar schools in the city and across the district, sadly you will notice the same trend in many school. This was the first year that NY State introduced challenged based problems on the exam, more aligned with the national Common Core State Standards. This had an immediate effect on our tests scores for the year in question, but has propelled us to be ready for the complete roll out of the National Standards for the 2013 - 2014 school year.

I am sorry your child went through this experience- However not all experiences are the same and it is unfair to the school, the children attending and their parents to be labeled as a "JURASSIC PARK EXPERIMENT."  Unfortunatley bullying happens everywhere AND anywhere- Im glad you son feels safe and have to express his anger physically anymore. 
I, too, had to transfer my child with an IEP from another school to 442. Prior to transfer, my son was depressed, dismal, grades failing and all you described your son to go through. 
Upon admission to 442, along with attentive teachers and smaller classrooms, my son was able to improve his grades and now taking accelerated science. Also, The recent implementing of UNIFORMS have instilled a sense of responsibility, TEAMWORK and Proudness for the school.
This "GHETTO" you speak of? Its CARROLL GARDENS, one of the best neighborhoods in BK. I live in Carroll Gardens- There are OTHER JHS in the area, BTW.
ANd with your comment about teenagers "Just walk with the students on any given afternoon as they leave the school and walk down to the subway stop at Carroll Street. You will hear every single curse word in the book and more". I havent heard any of that when walking my dog to pick my kid up, but
ITS CALLED BEING A TEENAGER- TEENS VENT/CURSE.

Parent
My son attend MS442 in 6th grade and graduated last year from MS442 my husband and I could have not picked a better school for our son. Teachers are great that I call them my family.My son got alot of attention at this school and he loved it, he wishes he was still there. My son goes to visit and we even went to the play they had this year. He was in all the plays. Everyone in MS442 is caring.

I am a parent of NYC public school child and I believe this school is wonderful. The staff really knows the children well and they support them academically and emotionally. There is consistent communication between parents and teachers. Teachers will make a "check in call" with parents to discuss their child. There are many different clubs and programs for children to join. With two teachers in the classroom the children get lots of attention.

I am currently a parent of a child that attends MS442.  I also live in the neighborhood and have gotten to know the staff and students at both MS442 and PS32 quite well. I adore these two schools!  I suppose one's experience at a school is a personal one and some experiences are better than others but as I also live in the neighborhood I can tell you that this school, and the school it shares a building with, works tremendously hard at creating a wonderful learning environment for the students that attend the school.  I love walking by and looking up at the Green Roof and hearing from my daughter that the vegetables they grow help provide both the school and local restaurants with vegetables.  I also just attended the school play and it was delightful to see the collaboration between both MS442 and PS32.  My daughter really enjoys the attention she receives at the school and I, as a parent, always feel like I can make an appointment with her teachers.  They are very accomodating and very caring! If you want a school where your child gets lots of attentions (and parents do too!) send your child here!!

Expand I entered into my son's middle school era with the misconception that I would have to pulled teeth to get the services I needed for him. With a new IEP in hand I began my process. Since that first day in 2009 and everyday, anytime , for whatever reason I have been agreeted, assisted, encourage, and amazed by the staff. I thank every member of MS442 for their support.

Right now MS 442 is at the very cutting edge of developing 21st century citizens.  The "rooftop garden" described in the review is actually a small, urban farming, multi-faceted project.  Elements of design, farming, food chain, sustainability, measurement, water cycle, native plants and animals, environmental responsibility and service -- as well as hands-on instruction -- provide direct links to numerous standards. Our teachers' expertise at differentiation benefits all students, including, but not limited to, those who perform above grade level.  As we approach the new school year we are excited to provide unique opportunities for students to prepare for high school, college and future careers by focusing instruction through the STEM subjects.

Expand I am a teacher working at MS 442 and I truly enjoy working there.  The staff are amazingly collaborative and deeply caring towards students.  Most students can't tell the difference between their special education teacher and their general education teacher in the room because both partners are so strong in meeting both the academic and social/emotional needs of the child.  I have seen major improvements over the last four years including more after school programs (track, chess, photography, drama, poetry...the list goes on) and more rigor in academics.  Students are also involved in projects that serve the community including donating vegetables grown on their green roof to a local soup kitchen, studying the school's impact on pollution and local waterways, reading to elementary school students, and upcoming plans to serve a local community through a trip to Peru.

Do not send your child to this school. This is a dumping ground for kids the Board of Ed. wants to pull out of their neighborhood schools for disciplinary and learning disability issues. It is the classic "Ghetto" for troubled students, and the vast majority behave worse in 8th grade than they do in 6th. Just walk with the students on any given afternoon as they leave the school and walk down to the subway stop at Carroll Street. You will hear every single curse word in the book and more. You will see students seething with aggression and negativity.

The whole concept of the school is flawed and it needs to be closed. Do not listen to advisers who want to trick you into placing your child there. They all work by quota, and God help you if your child is one of the unlucky "mainstream" children corralled in as window-dressing. My child was previously in Special Ed. classes, but was mainstreamed by 2nd grade with an hour or two of therapy a week and a one-to-one paraprofessional in the classroom. These supports were pulled in 5th grade and he did tremendously well. He listed 442 as his sixth and last choice for middle school, mostly to appease the guidance counselor who kept trying to steer him there, and that's where he ended up. 6th grade was a disaster from beginning to end. His grades plummeted, his behavior deteriorated, his entire attitude became dark and morose, just like nearly all the other students there. I cannot emphasize what a nightmare it was. In 5th grade my son won awards for most improved student and best student in two subject areas. By the end of sixth grade, he was nearly failing all of his subjects except gym, and the last day of school he punched a student who had been bullying him all year and threatened the staff. We rode home together in a police car. Everyone was telling me to pretend he was hit by another student to get him transferred but I didn't. I fought honestly, I raised hell, I talked to everyone I could, I wrote letters, emails, made phone calls went to offices...until they tired of seeing me and let my son transfer to his neighborhood school a week before the start of 7th grade. He is doing wonderfully there despite the regression he suffered at 442, has no Special Ed. services at all, no disciplinary problems and an average above 80 in his courses. All of his problems in 6th grade were a direct result of being placed in MS 442.As my son himself said, MS 442 is like Jurassic ParK: an experiment gone wrong. If they aren't treating the kids like prisoners by using collective punishment, they are making accommodations for every infraction and academic difficulty, such that no one is challenged to improve and any sense of justice is completely absent. My heart goes out to the kids who are stuck there. Society has given up on them and warehoused them in a segregated waiting room for prison. Don't let this happen to your child. Don't list it on the application. Not 4th, not 5th, not 6th. Don't list it at all. And if your child is there already, go to war on your child's behalf and get them out. The damage can be reversed if you act quickly enough.
