I recently read the article posted by Inside Schools. I am disappointed that they had to search for something negative to say about this school. Students economical background does not define a school especially when a pre-schooler was named the grade and district winner of this year science competition. Nor does it show that their fourth graders attended the first ever cross curricular STEM program at Medgar Evers College a true college career pipeline. Secondly,1/3 of the teachers on a survey does not account for the 2/3 of teachers that work hard EVERYDAY to made sure that EVERY student receives the educations they deserve. The principal does a great job in developing systems to help students and staff maximize their effort to work together as one.  
        Lastly, this school is not perfect and children who have a difficult time adjusting have a guidance counselor they can see when needed. There are also classroom routines and parent communication that are used to help students who are struggle with behavior. However, the school is far from students ever being out of control or mayhem. Maybe Inside School should of asked instead of looking up that information. Also please keep in mind that like this post their article and the survey is based on someone opinion. I offer anyone who would REALLY like to know more about this school to GO VISIT. There doors are always OPENED!!!

PS 5 Dr. Ronald McNair had the highest increase in English and math scale scores in the city, rising by 14.7% in both subjects this year. Chalkbeat reports.
"We have an open door policy," said Principal Gates. "Parents are allowed to come into the building to view classrooms or meet with teachers. They just need to give the school notice."

The Department of Education website (http://www.nycenet.edu/OurSchools/Region8/K005/default.htm) states, "The Dr. Ronald McNair/Public School 5 affirms as its central mission that every child has the right to a quality education in a safe and secure environment which reflects high expectations and high academic standards; that literacy is the first and most essential goal; and that every child can, and will succeed in ways that mirror his or her own aptitudes; interests and culture."

My daughter transferred to this school mid-year and struggled to adjust, but the staff of the school was extremely supportive of her and immediately recognized her potential. She is not going strong in 7th grade honors class, and has just completed a special program that prepares middle school students for auditions to the performance high schools.

Ms. Douglas is an impressively dedicated principal, and knows each and every one of them. Ms. Williams, the parent coordinator, makes every effort to keep parents well-informed of school events and activities, and the assistant principal, Ms. Johnson (lovingly referred to as Ms. A.P) works very hard to help students and parents give their best. It is a shame that this school does not receive more recognition for their steadfast and unwavering support of their students.

In a district of almost forgotten children, Ron Brown Academy stands out as a safe, involved, caring and supportive community for students and parents alike. :)

Love,
Ms. Douglas' #1 fan!

"Ron Brown Academy has changed drastically over the past two years, with the addition of Ms. Douglas," writes a teacher. "We are now seen as one of the best middle schools in Bedford Stuyvesant. On this year's quality review the school earned a 'well developed' and we are now frequently visited by staff from other schools to see how we've developed so much, so quickly. Ms. Douglas's energy has been contagious and students and staff are now far happier than in the past."

"JHS 57 has turned around a lot. My daughter is excelling and the school has an honors program," writes parent L. Bryant. "It offers the children the opportunity to push themselves. Ms. Douglas seems to be making a difference and the children love her. The only complaint I have is that some of the teachers are very childish."

"With the change in principals came an entirely new feel, and a mostly new staff," writes a parent. "The test scores skyrocketed in 2006-2007 and the energy and attitude in the building has changed dramatically! Ms. Douglas has transformed this school from the troubled one you see reported above, to a tightly run, uplifting, educational machine."
A student writes that even though "reading and math scores are low... [the principal] focuses on behavior and attire more than she does education."

Student Ashley complains that while many teachers do their best to make school fun by assigning themed days such as "Crazy Hat Day," MS 57 suffers from lots of fighting. She also complains that the principal is "harsh" on students by not listening to their concerns before suspending students who misbehave and by "making us do gym in the freezing cold without coats."

"I'm better off here," said one teacher, comparing MS 57 to the unruly school where he used to teach. "I'm here by choice. They need strong African American male role models."

"The school is micromanaged," said a teacher. "Everyone is expected to be on the same page, but half the kids are on Level 1 and half the kids are on Level 3." This teacher says the emphasis on standardized test results leads to a lot of pressure, but adds: "It's gotten better. Teachers are showing that they can be trusted."
PS 81 Parent Coordinator Judith Daniels is nominated for the Hometown Heroes Award in Education for her unwavering commitment to PS 81, the New York Daily News reports.

I love this school! From the security guard, Ms. McKee, to the principal, Ms. Ault-Barker, these are such warm, caring people, working so hard to give their best to kids who are so eager and interested in learning. I have been coming to 81 for six years, first as a literacy tutor, and, now, as the executive director of an arts education nonprofit (InspireCorps). Librarian Ms. Hunter started a weekly enrichment program last year that offers kids choices of amazing workshops run by the creative teaching team and from InspireCorps artists, among them songwriting, dance, visual arts, tennis, yoga and new toy building. I have seen a growing collaboration between the faculty and the local parent community that is really exciting, and I am thrilled to be part of this thriving can-do school!

The Weeksville Lady is still the school's longstanding icon. The Weeksville Warriors refers to the school's basketball team.

I am hearing that the longstanding icon for The Weeksville School has changed from "The Weeksville Lady" to the "Weeksville Warriors".  Change is good, however, I believe, history trumps change in this case.  The Weeksville Lady reminds us, as a community, as a race, from whence we came!  Weeksville was the first black community in Brooklyn.  This community was comprised of professional blacks as well as those that made their living from sweat and their hard working hands.  Our children need to remember their ancestors, and those that paved the way for them.  Unfortunately, I am too far (distance wise) to have a discussion with the powers that be, those who decided to make this most radical change for the members of The Weeksville Community without community input.

PS 308 has been added to the state's list of schools needing improvement under No Child Left Behind because of inadequate performance on the state tests in science.

"This school has to be one of the most welcoming and helpful school for students with high expectations," writes student Afrin, who is headed to Brooklyn Tech. "I would have never gotten this far without this school."

Joy, a former student, writes: "I went to 308 for only two years and I was going around waiting to graduate, but when the time came I felt very sad. [The year] I graduated, I had the honor of playing with the Lady Tigers for one season and was given the MVP [award]. The students at 308 like to have fun and are always ready to work. That's [what] makes me proud to say I am a former student of the 308 family."
Farzana, a student, writes: "I have been going to this school since 1st grade. I love being in this school. The teachers really care about you, they know what's best for [you]."

Veronica, a student, writes: "I have been going to 308 since 1st grade. Now about to graduate I am honored for someone like my principal and teachers to let me know that for the rest of my life, my [fellow] pupils and I would be the "best of the brightest!""

Kai, a former student, writes: "Now that I look back at my times at this school, I see that all of the criticism I received was extremely helpful, and no matter what anyone else says, the staff was very helpful for the 6 years I attended this school, and I will never forget anyone."

Shannon, a student, writes: "I've been a student at this school since kindergarten and all that I can say is the teachers really care and make sure that when you graduate you have the knowledge you need."

Kadeem, a student, writes, "I have been going to 308 since the 1st grade and I am now a graduate that will dread leaving this school with [its] outstanding staff and students who are willing to go the extra mile to succeed."

Dion, a student, writes, "PS/IS 308 is one of the best schools in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area. With the principal reminding us every day that we are the best of the brightest, it's hard not to succeed. We have wonderful teachers and a helpful guidance counselor."

My son has Autism and it was very scary for me and wanting to find a school that would support all his needs. I met a parent who told me about P.S. 309 and called the school to scheduled a tour. Its was amazing small classes and children were smiling. We spoke about my son and his needs, I was able to spend the day in what would be his new class. I really felt good about his teachers and  the class; print rich and lots of hands on activities, that was 5 months ago. I still feel the same way and my son's social and emotional growth has improved tremendously. Check the school out for yourself and see why this is a great school for all children.

What can I say about 309, this small school has it all. Teachers go above and beyond for the student right down to the support staff. They have partnerships with great organization the have helped me put food on the table for my children. I cried when I received  a care package from the school. They are here to help our community.

I am a parent and I have three children that attend. I must say its amazing. All my children say they have a great at school every day. Teachers listen to them and make them feel important. My children all have IEP's and they love the attention they get from their guidance counselor, Mom she really helps me. PS 309 is the best!!

P.S. 309 plans to incorporate units into their curriculum crafted by Anna Switzer, former principal of P.S. 234 and longtime leader in creating and implementing “project-based learning,” The New York Times reports.

This school rocks!!! I have a nephew that attends P.S. 309, and I have to say that learning is fun and exciting in his eyes.  He is thrilled and driven to go to school on a daily basis.  He loves the Principal ... Ms. Bryant. He says she makes school fun.  I thought it interesting that he stated that he loved his Principal, because it is usually the teacher that comes to mind when you think of learning and fun. But, he also gives his teacher Ms. Valerio praises too.  My point is that P.S. 309 is conducive to learning and the school is filled with the culture of "learning is fun".  To hear my nephew discuss his daily learning activities with enthusiasm makes me wish it was that exciting for me during my elementary school days. Lol!!!! Thank you to Ms. Bryant the Principal and her teachers.

My son is in Pre-K at 309 and the school has an amazing new principal who is changing the direction with more socio-emotional training for teachers, a focus on peer-to-peer high-level discussion, and enrichment. We have been very happy with the music teacher, the science teacher, and the great pre-K teachers and aides. Class sizes are still very small, so individual attention happens at every grade. The school is warm and loving. Every classroom has a "peace corner" for kids who need to take some time out. The principal is accessible with a "chat and chew" once a month. The kids go on lots of field trips, from the local firehouse to the Museum of Natural History to see the butterflies. Older kids are getting BAM Dance Afrika, debate, circus arts and ballroom dancing.

We live in D16 and this is our first year at 309.  
Our son comes home telling us that he is a scientist!  He loves Science with Mr. Dennis, Art with Ms. Ava from Studio in A School, and playing with blocks in his homeroom with Ms. John & Mr. Josh.  His teachers have been very supportive in his social-emotional growth.  There are worksheets sent home that we work on, but don't always finish.  I like that preK and K have a dedicated playground just outside the classrooms.  I also like that they go on a lot of field trips.  As with most city schools, enrichment is often funded by grants.
We have been very happy with the administration and their vision and dedication - and how warm and welcoming the school is.  I was thrilled to learn that the entire school is moving forward with Responsive Classroom training/approach (they have a website if you want to learn more).
Looking forward to the rest of the year here!

My son is attending PreK at 309 currently and we are very happy with our experience. The staff is very responsive and accessible and parents have the chance to actively participate in the school. With a very involved parent group and thoughtful staff, PS 309 is a very welcoming community. One example of this is the holiday concert that the school had in December. Parents and staff came together to create beautiful stage decor and the music teacher taught each grade two holiday songs which students performed for the school, it was a wonderful community event. My son is always happy to go to school and is having a really great time there. The classrooms are spacious, full of light and very clean with student work displayed everywhere. This is a very exciting time to be at 309, and if you want to be involved with a great neighborhood school, it really is a terrific choice.

My son is in PreK at 309 and we couldn't be happier. We have a lovely new principal (Mrs. Bryant) and the staff at this school is top notch. Everyone works together, has vision and it feels like my child is loved here. 309 is working hard to add enrichments like, studio in a school, preK afterschool, a garden, chess and yoga. We have a very involved group of parents at the preK level and are reaching out to parents with kids in upper grades as well as the parents of kids looking to start PreK next year to make all these dreams a reality. If you are looking for a neighborhood school to invest in, consider your search over.

This is an AWESOME school. Our daughter loves it and we do too! The Spanish dual language program is great - we are in 3K there and love the teachers (Ms. Villar and Ms. Washington) and feel like our daughter is learning a lot! Us parents are all on an app where we get pretty regular updates and photos and it's such a great way to stay involved and see what they are working on all day. Also, Mr. Daniels, the principal is the coolest guy who is really tuned in to making Brighter Choice a wonderful and warm community. He's even there on Saturday's for Skate Club! Ms. Deittra, the parent coordinator is also wonderful and helpful. We've had a great experience in our first year here and we couldn't be happier. Would highly recommend BCCS!

BCCS is a wonderful community school.  Principal Daniel always listens to parents’ suggestions and concerns, and has brought in some great new programs.  We are even at school most Saturdays for skate club and to see friends.  
The children get a really complete education including literacy, language learning and STEM, lots of enrichment both in school and afterschool and a new social emotional learning program.
Really GREAT school! Principal Daniels knows and loves his students. My son has excelled in the dual language program and after-school enrichment programs are spectacular.

Fifth grade math and science teacher Kim Nunes of Brighter Choice Community School was recognized for her consistent ability to raise her students' attendance rates and scores on the New York State math exams at the 2019 Blackboard Awards.
if you love your child please stay away from this school horrible staff ,too much favoritism

Brighter Choice is a warm, dynamic school headed by the fabulous Principal Fabayo, who is a powerful force for change. She wants the best for her students and for her school and is always working to strengthen the community, the programs, and the academics. The dual language program is really exciting and the teachers seem passionate about it and I suspect it is one of many great, progressive programs Principal Fabayo will bring to Brighter Choice over the next few years. 

This year more parents than ever have stepped up to help fundraise, event plan, and bring the community together. These families are committed to making this the best school possible for our children. It is an inspiring place to be.

Parents tell InsideSchools: "[The principal] is a change maker. She’s created a dual language program and developed the culture of the school. There's an expectation that you will be involved as a parent."

"Whenever I come in with an idea it’s always been a yes."

A mother who came from Young Scholars which merged with Brighter Choice in 2016, said: "The whole merger project was a bit nerve-racking for me but the principal is warm-hearted and welcoming.”

One of the school's founding parents said, "It's small, inclusive and more personable [than larger schools]. Every day is college-bound. It's been a blessing. The principal and staff are always attentive."
Brighter Choice principal Fabayo McIntosh-Gordon says her strategy vision for growth includes "starting with love" in her profile as DNAinfo's Principal of the Week.
Parents are enthusiastic about the new dual language program at Brighter Choice, which they say will make the school a "pace-setter". DNAinfo reports.
Brighter Choice is set to become a Spanish English dual language school from the start of the 2016-2017 school year. Read more here.
The Department of Education has proposed to merge Brighter Choice Community School with Young Scholars' Academy for Discovery and Exploration. Read more here.
Brighter Choice 4th-graders earned the highest marks in Bed-Stuy on the 2015 State ELA exam, although its math numbers dropped, according to a DNAinfo analysis. Read more here.

My son was a part of their first graduating class. He's been student from the beginning. He did attend first grade in the failing school 304 and i entrusted them with my child to expose him to a better education, and they Have! Ms. Fabayo is excellent in instilling confidence in the children and my son has done an academic 180! The children all passed the state exams and are moving forward to bigger and better things. She is my hero. Please take time to meet with her if you are considering enrolling your child in a welcoming and encouraging academic environment. She shed tears of joy at that ceremony, It was beautiful. She is like a second mother to those children. The small size of the school provided for a tight knit relationship between the student and staff. Thankfully my daughter is in the 1st grade and i intend to let her follow in her big brother's footsteps.

I used to attend 304 back in 2003 and I have to tell you that back then, the school was out of control. It was a kids worst nightmare. I was teased everyday and there were fights mostly everyday. Girls in the fifth grade would tease and jump this young Muslim girl and no one did anything to help. I live right around the corner from this school and I haven't noticed the changes but I am extremely glad things have changed for the better because 304 was certainly not a good school. I think itsgood that it's only little kids going there now.

The Daily News reported that 2nd-graders from Brighter Choice Community School visited Medgar Evers College to help the students see college as part of their future. The day trip was planned in keeping with the school's motto: "Every Child, Every Day, College Bound," according to the article.

This is my sons 3rd year at TBBS and we are very happy with the school. Principal Brunner is great at returning phone calls or messages and is very involved in students day to day. The teachers are also very open and communicate well. Teachers work had and create their lessons plans so that students can succeed in the State Exams. At the beginning of the year my son was not doing so well but at the end of the year and for the State Exam his progress was shown and I was very thankful to his teachers. TBBS uses Class dojo for communication to parents, I wish there was a little more communication through email as my son always forgets to give me the flyers/paperwork needed for me to review. TBBS is working hard to add more workshops for parents and students in addition to creating more fundraisers for their school wide events. In terms of school safety, the security guards are always visible and are very friendly to students and parents. I believe the lunch aide's could be a little more professional when addressing students. Extracurricular: in the 2nd grade they had students go to the YMCA for swimming classes which was great. I would deft recommend the school

I just have to say something because the most recent comments are so old. It’s been an interesting year (2018-2019) with  principal Brunner taking over. It does feel like there are a lot of moving pieces in the school schedule especially with repairs going on at the building, that have made certain extra-curricular activities feel inconsistent, and though I love love the activities offered by the afterschool program, the lack of focus on academics and homework is frustrating, however - the teachers make this school what it is. And it is great, according to my daughter. She is motivated and involved in class. She has learned so much and I feel she is on par with the neighbor’s child who is at a demanding charter school. The HW isn’t always an hour and a half - it depends on the teacher and my daughter has only been required to read 15minutes a day (she’s been in the school since pre-k and is going to 2nd grade next year). She is reading at nearly 3rd grade levels (2-years above) as a result. She learns so many amazing things in music and art and I believe she is becoming quite well-rounded which is what I want most for her. I want her to find her niche and her love and I think there’s room for her to do that here - and still be a great overall student. I’d highly recommend it. Her teachers have been highly involved and responsive. And my daughter is always anxious to do her best to please them. I like that. Small class size also means a lot to me. No school is perfect and i know that the school is working with a much tighter budget because the income levels in the neighborhood have risen so they get less government support. Parents must stay involved and support fundraisers to keep the school strong. I’m hoping more of the bumps will get worked out as the new principal finds his legs but he’s a great guy and very hands-on so I’m sure it will happen.

I have two kids in this school.  I really like Ms. Haskins, and have nothing but positive experiences with the teachers who are all deeply dedicated educators.  The limitation: I am very much against homework, particularly at this age, and there's a bounty of research now indicating it's not productive.  In fact the National Parent Teacher Association recommends no or nominal homework prior to first grade and then 10 min. of homework for each grade level so 10 min. for first graders, 20 for second etc.  Last year we found ourselves doing 2 hours or more of homework each night with our first grader and quickly grew disillusioned.  When I objected to the volume of homework Ms. Haskins and my child's teacher both took the time to meet with me and work out a fair compromise.  I think my only issue with this school is their obsession with performing on the annual standardized tests.  I feel like everything is geared toward the very narrow goal of achievement on the narrow range of topics on a handful of tests generated by politicians, bureaucrats and consultants, not educators.  The effect in my opinion is an overly narrow curriculum focused strictly on the topics tested and not a well rounded education.  I think the kids would be better served by a school where the educators are more willing to question the current system and put education above rankings but that's probably a bit much to ask of BedStuy during the current era.   Compared to most of the schools I toured this one was a dream but we might move next year since I intend to opt out of the standardized tests which will become applicable to my older child next year.

The complaints I have heard about Ms. Haskins all have been in response to her holding parents and students accountable for poor and/or disruptive behavior. I am delighted to have a principal who works hard to create a serious and supportive academic environment for the students and who expects parents to be involved in their kids' learning. If you want a school in district 16 in which your kid can be in  a co-operative environment, work hard, learn, and aspire to a great middle school, this is it.

as a parent in D16, I am mortified by the poor school options. I have heard some good things about the school, but no so great things about the Principal's demeanor and attitude, but I can only hope that does not affect the dynamics of the school. It seems like a great option minus that issue, but are there after-school programs for pre-k students?
QTPI, I responded to your post with a new post above.
Brooklyn Brownstone principal Nakia Haskins wants her students to have a wide-range of experiences and be "jacks of all trades." Read more here.

The mayor chose Bed-Stuy’s Brooklyn Brownstone School as the setting for a press conference to announce the latest test results of NYC public schools students because of the school’s marked student achievement over the past year. “this school is a trendsetter for something that is happening citywide", said Di Blasio. Read more here.

Brooklyn Brownstone is an extraordinary school, the elusive
“diamond in the rough.” When looking for a school for our children, we visited nearly a dozen schools in Crown Heights and
Bedford-Stuyvesant and none compared to what we saw at Brooklyn Brownstone. The key here is that the school is small and therefore a community. Not only do administrators and teachers know all the students by name, children across all grade levels know one another and support one another. Another distinctive is the school’s commitment not only to academic excellence but to character
development. Students learn early to behave respectfully and responsibly. In addition, the school has stellar art and music programs that include regular showcases were students can express themselves artistically and build confidence in their public speaking and performance skills. Academically, I have seen teachers do the impossible – helping students who were struggling thrive while helping academically advanced students grow as well. Parent
involvement here is significantly higher than other local schools as well and parent involvement is not only welcomed but expected. It cannot be easy to build and sustain a thriving New York
  City school but Brownstone’s administrators and teachers
have done it. Where else in Brooklyn will you find a teacher who will attend a student’s birthday party or baseball game on a
Saturday afternoon? That’s the kind of family you will find at Brooklyn
Brownstone!

Absolutely disgusted with this school.  If only I read the reviews on greatschools.org, I would have NEVER registered my child here.  Pre-K was a dream and Kindergarten was a complete nightmare and please, don't let elaborate on the horrific principal.  When a professional administrator can tell you "if you don't like it here, send your child to a different school..." as a resolution to the issues that you address, find the nearest rock and let that rock teach your child instead of this school.   At first, I thought it was just my attitude so I asked my husband to talk to her since he worked for the Education dept. but even he didn't get any results.  Then I met a group of parents...angry, bitter and fed up parents and I realized how far from alone that I was in this battle.  In this year, I let myself get talked me into getting my child evaluated and when the Bd. of Ed. said there was NOTHING wrong with him, the teacher AND principal walked out.  After that, every little thing that my child did was wrong including being excluded from trips unless I attended every single last one of them.  I gave up and decided to keep him home every time and taught him on my own.  A month later, I pulled him out of the afterschool program because it was hinted to me that my child was labeled once he got there.  I even took it a step further at times:  watched from my window to see the behavior of the kids on school trips on my days off, talked to other parents (specifically people in my son's class), received feedback from other staff members and at the end of the school year, I came to the conclusion that the teacher that I gave such a hard way to go wasn't the complete problem..They're looking for donations every time I turn around for everything from the copy paper, tissue...you name it.  Technology is a joke because you have to wish upon a star that it works.  One of the grades had THREE substitute teachers in one school year and then wondered why most of the kids were promotion in doubt.  If you 're not part of the PTA, good luck to your child.  If he/she is not one of her "favorites", then forget it.  I really thought highly when I enrolled him in school but somewhere along the lines this year, something went completely wrong.   I encourage you to talk to so many parents and if you're lucky, to some teachers who will be honest (there's a few) and then maybe you'll get a better idea of this school.  The school is a hit or miss...it depends on what teacher you win from the cracker jack prize.

My daughter attends pre-k at TBBS, and I cannot speak highly enough of her talented teacher and teacher's aid. They are well supported by the principal, who is a smart, involved leader. The whole school is open to parent involvement, and my daughter is very happy here. The art and music instruction are fantastic, and the teachers from other grades strive to know who all the kids are (not just the kids in their own classes.) There is also a community ethic (school hall come togethers for all grades are called "community meetings,") and there is a constant theme of inter-relation and helping throughout the grades. I'm grateful we won the pre-k lottery and got to attend!

The Brooklyn Brown Stone Elementary School is one of the greatest  school for Bedstuy. Keep up the good work in making a difference in our community. Thank you principal & staff for your dedication to seek the best interest in our children's education, discipline and code of conduct. It's hard work...

Love the small class instruction. Teachers genuinely have the students' interests at heart and go above and beyond to give them the attention they need. Principal knows all the children by name and maintains open door policy for parents.

I chose this school for my 8th grader and he's about to graduate.  He's had a great year at Madiba academically, and I know that he had a lot of fun there.  At Madiba, the teachers seem to care about the children.  The school has a good amount of activities, and the communication with the parents is outstanding.  If there was a parent coordinator of the year award, Ms. Patterson would win without a doubt.  I also have to say the D75 unit at this school is exceptional. Ms Horowitz told me before the year started that her students become like her kids. She has definitely both pushed my kid to be his best AND looked out for him this year along with Ms. Alvarez. She was quick to let me know if he got out of line.. definitely appreciate that.   Must give a special shoutout to Mr Martini, the guidance counselor.   All in all,  I feel like I made the right choice to sending him there.

I cannot say anything bad about Madiba Prep or the staff there. In 6th grade my daughter took the wrong bus to school and ended up in Queens. When a stranger called Principal Malcolm she got in her car and drove to Queens to get my frighten daughter while reassuring me everything would be okay. Every time I call the school Ms. Patterson is always available to assist. My daughter loves the school and I'm sad this is her last year since she will be graduating. She loves all the partnership programs of music, dance, fencing, double dutch, step and the stem lab. She loves her dance and Science teacher. You cannot please everyone and there will always be teachers who aren't there for the kids. I love the Madiba Staff and this school is on the up on up. Everyone currently there is doing a great job. Numbers don't always show the true story.

1) The administration is not to be trusted: only 67% of teachers say Principal Anne-Marie Malcolm is an effective leader. That's BELOW the city average of 84%.
2) Teachers do not believe the school is good enough for their children, why would you send yours? Only 67% would recommend the school to their families, WAY BELOW the city average of 83%.
3) Students report bullying as a major issue: 58% of students report it happens most or all of the time, which is ABOVE the city average of 50%.
4) Even teachers admit that order and discipline are not maintained: only 55% responded positively, which is FAR BELOW the city average of 79%.
5) The student achievement numbers speak for themselves. It is clear that much more is invested in the appearance of the school and the scale of the partnerships rather than on new teacher development and student intervention.

As a parent on the PTA, I can only say great things about Madiba Prep. The principal is always welcoming, the staff is hard working and my son loves it there. Madiba focuses on social justice, community service and preparing the students for high school. Last week the Madiba Prep students took a 7 day trip to Barcelona, Spain due to the dedicated staff there who raised enough money. Last year our students was selected to go to Alaska. Madiba also has French and Korean Langusge.  Come by and visit the school. Ask for me Ms. Williams or any other PTA member that will show you how wonderful this school is. Great new staff and leadership.
The students and staff are amazing at Madiba Prep. I love this school and seeing the difference I am making. We are headed to our first international trip next week. How awesome is that!

Madiba Prep is an amazing school because current staff care about students and focus on their growth. It is unfortunate that some former teacher that worked there three years ago did not embrace the vision and leadership of the newly appointed Principal Malcolm and made a personal decision to work at other schools, but now choose to post hostile unsubstantiated comments. Hopefully, these former teachers will focus on their current school and improving their teaching craft to offer the best to their current students instead of misrepresenting the truth. Here is our truth: In the past two years, Madiba Prep has secured over 1.5 million grant funding, built advance science lab, upgrade outdated technology, partnered with numerous agencies, business, community partners, elected officials to provide the best educational resources/programs to a student body which has grown by 30% and hired qualified dedicated staff. It takes time to get the most qualified staff which has been successfully done in the past two years, which dramatically lowered our staff turnover rate to under 10% in 2018. All these accomplishments occurred while  we work hard to come off the focus list.(Principal Malcolm was not the principal of Madiba when it entered the state focus list, but she accepted the challenge to turn around a failing school ). Under the leadership of Principal Malcolm, we are a strong community with amazing staff and students. Come see for yourself how amazing we are and hear from current staff and students about our school community. Lastly, personal attacks are useless, insignificant and petty when we have the privilege and responsibility to service the lives of our children; let's be the example of dignity, grace and wisdom always for our children. I'm so humbled and proud of my work and the work of my administration, collegues, partners and students to transform Madiba Prep into a stellar school.

I'm so sorry that the disgruntal former teach is upset. But let tell the truth. 

Fact 1. Madiba has grow greatly in both numbers and teacher growth since Ms. Malcolm has been the principal.

Fact 2. Her goal is is has always been the very best for her students (they are top priority and will always be top priority) 

Fact 3. There has never been a 100% turnover rate under Ms. Malcolm.

Fact 4 If you are willing to learn, student or teacher, Madiba is the best place for growth period.

Clearly Malcolm’s minions are at it again! All one has to do is look at the performance of the school to see that something isn’t right at Madiba. Our community deserves better. Anonymous former teacher is right (as someone who also taught under Malcolm at Madiba and had to run for the hills). Funny how there was no TJ working at Madiba in 2016 (I was there) yet, this “TJ” comments about the growth of the school? Ha! What a joke! The administration is corrupt. Malcolm had low enrollment at her previous school that shut down and the same is true for Madiba. I wonder why? How can a school have a gifted and talented program and failing scores? If you want your child to have a great photo opportunity then Madiba is the place for you. You want your child to be challenged and developed? Please look elsewhere! If Madiba is so great, why is the teacher turnover rate nearly 100%?
Tameko Jackson aka TJ has always worked at Madiba. Are you sure YOU worked there?

As a current teacher at Madiba Prep Middle School, I find the school quite awesome. I’m not just saying this because I’m there either. The administration and staff are totally vested in the well being of the whole child. Totally the environment I was looking for hen I started teaching some years ago. My only regret is not coming to Madiba much sooner. Me Malcolm is kind and sweet, but at the same time only accepts the best for Madiba’s scholars. I must admit, I’m glad teachers left so that teachers like me can evolve under great leadership that Ms Malcolm provides.
Excuse the typos as I was doing multiple things at one time. 😊

I have worked for Madiba since 2016 and I have watched the school grow and transform from a stagnate setting where the students weren't growing to a place where the students are growing & improving on a daily basis.  Ms. Malcolm is one of the most caring, patient & loving administrator I've ever worked for in the DOE.  Her goals are to grow and develop the staff under her to be there best so they can service the students and prepare them for college.

I'm not sure why the former teacher is so disgruntal.  But if you truly care about your child's total wellbeing Madiba is the place to send your child. The teachers are fantastic and truly have your child's best interests at heart.
Facts! That post is riddled with lies. MS. malcolm wasnt even the principal there during all that time.
She came in 2016-2017 school year. Signed, someone who knows what they’re talking about, which clearly you do not.

My concern is that every year teachers are leaving the school in droves. From the first year I sent my child to Madiba to the second year there was no consistency as far as teacher retention is concerned. What is going on at this school that over 90% of teachers leave every year?!?!?!?

I must say that my experience is completely different from yours Emily. In the span that my child has been at Madiba Prep has been an amazing experience. Ms. Malcolm has always maintained a sense of transparency with us parents. Whenever we are in the building we are always aware of what she is doing. Ms. Malcolm has ALWAYS had our children’s best interest at heart. Her open door policy allows us to visit the school, volunteer throughout the day, and allow us to sit in our child’s class. I’ve spoken with a majority of the parents and we are all extremely happy with Principal Malcolm’s work ethics and vision for our scholars and this school. Let’s us as a parent community come together and volunteer and help out during the day, instead of tearing down the administration. So few parents are involved in volunteer service! As a parent I completely understand we have jobs and have to support our children but, in order to maintain the success of our child we must be the driving force of the schools success. The staff has always been supportive and helpful to us parents and our students. I hope to see more of us parents lending a hand and helping in the success and growth of our child’s school. Madiba CAN and WILL be one of the best and brightest Middle Schools in District 16, and it’s up to us to be a part of growth.

My son has attended Madiba Prep school for the past two years and its the best decision I could have made. We transferred him from charter school and was worried about enrolling him in public school. From the moment I met the principal Anne-Marie Malcolm and the Parent Coordinator Sharon Paterson I felt at ease. My son feels happy in an environment that supports him academically and emotionally. The principal is doing a great job in our community and she cares about the students.

This school started out as a wonderful vision of community-based learning and growth. However, under the new "leadership" of Principal Anne Marie Malcolm the quality of the school has diminished significantly. Ms. Malcolm is rarely ever present in the building and spends her time prepping for photo opportunities instead of investing in the professional development of teachers and building relationships with students to assess their needs. The staff consists primarily of first-year teachers who are still learning the profession. The secretary is wildly unprofessional and every time I have ever visited or called the school building she is eating, laughing, talking loudly or being generally inappropriate. I regret sending my child to this school and will be transferring my son out before the school gets closed down for poor leadership and under enrollment. Yes, they have amazing partnerships with other schools and organizations, but much of it is just a facade, another photo opportunity to keep the school from closing down. We deserve better in this community!

I am sure most parents and the beautiful children at this school would greatly disagree. I have never met a more dedicated leader as in Principal Malcolm. Otherwise,  my right scholars would never be attending this school. She is committed to the success of ALL students.
Madiba Prep will have a gifted and talented program next academic year, DNAinfo reports.
A District 75 school may move into the building shared by Madiba Prep Middle School and PS 26 from the 2016-2017 school year, reports DNAinfo.

This school is named after Nelson Mandela.  It is a small learning community. In addition to fantastic hands on academic activities that blend science, math, and engineering they get scholars excited about learning and being in school. They also have extra curricular activities such as fencing, step, track, music production, robotics, flag football, volleyball, basketball and chess. They visit college campuses and meet with professionals to learn about their occupations and prior study.  This is a real hidden gem.

This is an awesome school for our scholars in this community. It nurtures each scholar individually. The teachers in this school are a group of dedicated teachers who look forward to coming in the school to show and to help our scholars become the leaders of tomorrow. Schools are still fighting to keep charters out of their buildings. Read more: Lawsuits  target charters in Brooklyn.
State Education Commisioner Richard Mills announced in August that the MS 2 has been removed from the state's list of "persistently dangerous" schools for the 2008-2009 school year.
MS 2 has been added to the state's list of "persistently dangerous" schools, meaning that for two years the school has reported a high ratio of violent incidents to students.
Student Akiema writes that almost all students wear the school uniform. She complains that students are often left on their own to raise money for the school because parental involvement is low.

Assistant Principal Linor Castro speaks of "a movement towards a quieter, more respectful culture," thanks in large part to Principal Spencer's "transformation of our physical plant" and "insistence on over 90% attendance."
"We try to educate a well-rounded student body, both academically and in their outside lives," says social-studies teacher Rick King.
A student, Shohneique, said students sometimes skip class without anyone stopping them.

"This is a horrible school," writes a parent. "This school has a security issue. Children can sneak out of the school and run around the neighborhood... While there are teachers who are willing to work with the students, the lack of discipline and chaos is not worth spending 5 minutes here. This school shares a building with a special ed school. The children from that school are loud, rowdy, and spend their time running around the first floor and lunchroom. Do not send your children to this school."

The Daily News reported that at least three students were diagnosed with viral meningitis and "some staffers and parents are outraged they weren't informed sooner," according to a June 10, 2004 article. The school's principal gave students a letter about the outbreak only after the Daily News called asking if parents had been told, the article said. The letter said, "an individual at your child's school was diagnosed with a form of meningitis that is not contagious."
Through the district's participatory budgeting process, DNAinfo reports that PS 6 will receive funds to upgrade the school's computer lab.
Ellen Carlisle, Principal of P.S. 6 was honored at the Harvard Club by Education Update as an Outstanding Administrator of the Year 2014. Read more here.

Uhm...I am going to have to question the principal Ellen Carlisle intent for the children.  I recently moved into this area from NJ and was that my child wasn't zone for this school. However, the Sec. Hick..told me to come back to talk with the Principle to see if she can work something out or ask if I could be placed on the waiting list.  

I returned back to the school the following Monday and asked to speak to the Principle reagarding this matter.  Mrs. Ellen Carlisle did not attempt to come out of her office nor did she wanted to speak to me . 

Mrs Hicks stated here is the form to fill-out for the waiting list.  We will call you if we have opening.  

How rude.  Mrs .Ellen Carlisle could have taken 2 mins  out of her time to come out of the office to explain to me the process...which she failed to do so.

"I love P.S.6. The teachers are nice and helpful," writes former student, Josnica. "The teachers break formulas down so that the students can understand it easier and faster and get to the next formula."
A former student who attended the school from 3rd grade on writes: "I still love that school. ... I love the teachers [and] want to say hi and [to] keep doing a good job."

PS 12 is one of twelve NYC schools that host the Playworks program, which provides an active, healthy recess and play throughout the day in low-income elementary schools. A recent study shows that the program reduces bullying, enhances feelings of safety at school, increases vigorous physical activity during recess, and provides more time for classroom teaching. Read more here.

As a person who works in the neighborhood and interacts with many of the schools, I can say that Ms. Dixon is extremely dedicated to her students and implements many great programs.  She strongly believes in music and finds a way to keep music as part of the regular curriculum.  She has implemented a school store where children can 'buy' items with points earned through good grades, good behavior, attendance, etc.  It not only works to improve the community and student attitude, it also teaches students economics, self-control of saving, and reward for hard work.  Ms. Dixon is definitely turning this place around and the school deserves a fresh look.
PS 12 and New Dorp HS share strategies for turning struggling schools around. Read more: Principals outline the strategies they used to save their schools.
The state released its list of persistently dangerous schools, including 9 NYC schools. Read more: Now it’s beatin', riotin' & 'rithmetic.
"The staff works together very well. When we develop workshops for families, they are good at knowing what each student's family might need," says parent coordinator Gladys Thom.

I know this school well, and sad to say, most of the negative comments here are absolutely true.  My heart breaks for the parents and students who have no other options, and the staff, who tries so hard but has to contend with daily schedule changes, unrealistic expectations, constant harassment, limited resources.  The climate in the building is frightening. Discipline is negligible, parent participation is not encouraged.  Gym time and art programs have been eliminated; instead, children sit in the auditorium watching movies during their free periods, or running the hallways, destroying whatever they can.  I pray that the students here will make it into decent middle schools and learn that PS 91 is an unfortunate anomaly - that learning can be a positive experience, that they don't have to be afraid all the time of being beaten up by out of control classmates or screamed at by overwhelmed, overworked and under-appreciated teachers.

I am 54 years old now and some of the best memories of childhood were when i attended P.S. 138 from 1966 to 1973.  K-6th back then.  I fondly recall the teachers back then were all young Hippies and we would learn about the ongoing civil rights struggle.  I also recall how when Martin Luther King was assasinated the school closed for several days as the area of Nostrand Ave/Park Place was ground zero for riots.  The school and its after school program served as a safe haven for many children including myself back then.

Principal Marie Chauvet-Monchik comments on PS 138's positive discipline policy for PBS Newshour; meanwhile in the same building, Success Academy logged 44 suspensions for k–1st graders last year. Watch or read more here.

As the school year winds to a close—and many people wonder whether teachers and students have "checked out"—many schools like PS 138 use this lower-key time to make way for fun projects, presentations and assemblies. Read more here.

Councilman Albert Vann said moving the Success Academy Charter School into the PS 138 building is detrimental to the school, which has computer, science, reading and math labs, 2 English as a Second Language rooms, a music room, an art room, a dance studio and a library. http://prospectheights.patch.com/groups/council-member-albert-vanns-blog/p/bp--we-must-protect-psms-138-join-the-fight-against-f6150cb9786

The Daily News reports on a plan to move a Success Academy charter into the school. But just two years ago, the Education Department determined the school did not have extra room for Explore Empower charter school students. Read more: http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/brooklyn/eva-moskowitz-charter-school-moving-crown-heights-building-room-students-article-1.1219822

P.S. 138 is a participant in the Wellness in the Schools Coach for Kids program, which places a trained coach onto the recess yards of public schools to get event the least active students moving, build self-esteem and teamwork skills, and actively combat schoolyard bullying. The Coach for Kids program  fosters a sense of excitement and engagement among children around fitness and exercise. You can find out more about programming from Wellness in the Schools and see a list of participating schools online at www.wellnessintheschools.org

PS 138 is a "well-developed" school according to the Department of Education's quality review report, which lauds its principal as "an outstanding leader who knows the school's strengths and weaknesses well." The report noted, however, that the school needs improvements in "raising the quality of instruction and the education provided for special education students, and enhancing technological facilities to enrich the quality of the learning experiences for all students."
The school's parent coordinator said, "The teachers here are excellent, some of the best."

The things that were posted April 2009 are true. The writer failed to mention the fact that this is the best public school in the area. At least PS 161 has a Principal who loves her students, gives 100% and supports her staff. The parents are very envolved at PS 161. The teachers are good. The school offers steel band, African-Dance, has a Step Team, Jazz Band, Boy Scouts and Chorus. Some of these are paid for by the PTA while others are conducted because of volunteers. The school doesn't have money but ONLY because of the dedicated parents and teachers does this school continue to be one of the best in the neighborhood.

"The information posted on this school is completely outdated. First, the Crown School is no longer a sought after program where the children need to pass a test for admission. The middle school has open enrollment and has lost most of the jewels in its crown. Second, the children do get gym a half a year. Yet, as the same with all extras such as art, music, library, or technology the children are not meeting the standards set by New York State. Third, the schools behavior issues are out of control and the understaffing is making this school a dangerous environment for children. The heart is there for the children not the money which effects all decisions made, including overcrowded and underfunded classrooms."

"I think the school's concentration on the 'three R's' is brilliant! My child completed kindergarten in day care and upon leaving the day care she still did not recognize basic words. Since school started in September, my child can now read not only basic words, but level 1 and 2 books with minimal help," writes parent Tiffany Mensah, who adds that school staff members are always there to answer questions.

"While this school is great on paper there is a lot of room for improvement. The morale of the staff is really low, and I can't help but think about how that is going to be passed on to my kid," writes a parent. "The administration has created this atmosphere where there is no care shown to teachers. How can the school stay on top when teachers want to leave?"

In response to the above comment, Principal Deborah Barrett says that staff morale is high, and there are only two reasons why teachers leave: retirement, or they moved. She also notes that each school year the staff comes together for a breakfast, where staff share personal stories, and the principal reads positive letters from parents, who express their joy for a particular teacher. The principal also gives "treats" to staff who arrive early to school. Additionally, the principal notes that the school is overcrowded and that "everybody wants to be here."

A parent writes: " While there are a few good teachers, the school is overall disorganized, over-crowded. The students are sent home with practice test packets for the end-of-year citywide assessments, but the material is not being taught in the classroom." She continues: "Children in 3rd grade are doing 1st-grade work -- spelling words such as 'red' and deciphering between odd and even numbers. 5th graders have been discouraged from writing in cursive." She also complains of dirty bathrooms, teachers who disrespect students and fail to submit grades on time, and administrators with very little time to meet with parents.

A parent of a 6th grader in the middle school said "I like the way he's learning journalism and law. The students are going to Washington DC for a mock trial." She praised the small class size and the house system. "He loves that housing system." Kids get rewards for community service and demerits when they get in trouble.

"This school is still a jewel among others in the community," writes a parent. "However, it would benefit the students greatly if there was art integrated into the curriculum. 'All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy,' is a statement that the administration needs to take seriously. In addition, many parents who will like to enroll their children in arts outside of the school are unable to do so, since students are overloaded with homework and extra work during holidays."
Please elaborate.

A teacher writes with corrections to our profile: "P.S. 189 is NOT a magnet school. The average class size is well over 28, and the majority of classrooms are overcrowded with more than 30 students. A large majority of the students scored at levels one and two on the state exams."
Student Kingsley cautions other students not to take the school's many opportunities for granted.

"The principal is a friendly person when you do the right thing, and the teachers ensure that all students are doing the right thing at all times," writes student Jeffrey. "This school is clean, safe, and like one big family."

Parent Natanael Valenzuela writes to disagree with many of the comments about PS 189. He writes that "not two, but many" students gained admission to specialized high schools, and notes that students have participated in regional competitions in math, language, music, and dance. He also writes that "most of the students wear the uniform and the discipline is very good."
Stephanie, a former student, writes: "PS 189 was a great school while I was there and I still think it is a great school. The only thing I don't like is the uniform thing."

"Sorry to say, but the PhD is long gone from PS 189, if he ever existed," writes a current teacher in reference to our review. "The wearing of uniforms is still very random and, in fact, non-uniform, yet it's still enforced each day with much more alacrity and seriousness than class discipline or homework. More importantly, a dozen years ago the school sent 30 graduating 8th graders onward to admission in specialized high schools. But this year (2004) it will send exactly two (2)! And if our school has ever been designated a 'magnet' school with a required exam, that comes as a complete surprise to this new staffer."

I remember that PhD teacher when I was a teacher for almost 2 yrs at PS 189 back in early 2000s. I am certain EVERY critical thing you say is
true of this school, which always thought much too highly of itself. Low expectations coupled with high tolerance of poor behavior tend NOT to produce an excellent school.
Mediocrity long replaced true objectively measured excellence in New York City schools, & PS 189 is not alone as a sorrowful example of declining standards.

I worked as a teaching artist at 191 and it was the most difficult school I ever had to deal with. The teachers are so micro-managed by the school administration they should be applauded for the amount of work they are able to get done. Teacher morale was very low during my time there - the principal would make long announcements berating the teachers; at times these announcements went on for fifteen minutes and including the reading of emails to the entire school. Teachers would avoid making eye contact with the administration. Because I was not aware of the school environment my natural inclination to include teachers in my lesson planning was viewed as a threatthe administration sat in on my meetings and openly insulted me in front of the teachers if they didn't like anything I proposed. The sad thing is this all effects the students who are being stifled. The hallway walls are covered with State standards, not children's work. This school desperately needs change.

I was borned and lived in Crown Heights all my childhood life. 921 Montgomery St, right up the street from the school was my residence from Pre-K to high school.
P.S. 221 was my elementary school in the 70's, glad it's still around!!! I remember when the annex of P.S. 221 was being constructed. We students could wait to walk across the path that led to the annex grounds from the main building through 3rd or 4th floor.
Mrs. Lubark was my kindergarten teacher, she was pretty, patient, taught and spoke well!!  She laid fertile soil for my public education in NYC. I also remembered Ms. Jenkins, she was the janitor! Yep, the janitor. In that era it was unusual to see a female (black and older) doing such a manly job! She wore dress uniform, was very clean, very polite and took pride in her work! But after a while I didn't see Ms. Jenkins anymore and heard she had pass away. I was very sad, she always had a nice/encouraging word to say to you and little young people need that so much today. Thanks to all my teachers from back in the day and to all the teachers today, you help shape the community one child at a time every time you step into a students 
After graduating I went to Roy H. Mann JHS, and Clara Barton HS. Later I relocated out the state, finished college and have been working as a visiting nurse with the elderly and hospice patients for close to 30 years. 


Love, Peace and Happiness!!!

i love this school thank u
PS 221 is working with a Park Slope restauranteur to offer an etiquette class for students called "Fork, Knife, and Spoon." Read more here.

Heads up! PS 221 is Seeds in the Middle's pilot Hip2B Healthy School. We are proud to brag that in spring 2012, 87% of our focus 4th grade class - Ms. Fearon's class - scored at or ABOVE grade level on math (27% scored "4s". In literacy, 69% scored at or above grade level and check this out! 96.2% scored at or above grade level in science!  

Those students ran our Seeds in the Middle Hip2B Healthy Market, grew edible gardens, composted, cooked healthy with professional chefs, played soccer or ran or enjoyed other physical fitness, engaged in the arts - like singing with the Metropolitan Opera Guild! They went to Manhattan to shop at Whole Foods for their healthy market, attend a dress rehearsal at the Metropolitan Opera, were guest workshop leaders at the Brooklyn Food Coalition Food Conference, presented their market as a model healthy FUNDRAISER at the Department of Education and Health's School Healthy Fundraiser Expo. They helped run the Crown Heights Farmers Market, worked with Farmer Rodrick Brown to grow in an indoor Green Room, toured their neighborhood to highlight food disparities between Crown Heights and wealthier nabes, attended a lecture by SUNY Downstate Cardiology Club on the link between diet and exercise and heart disease and diabetes. These students led "No Sugary Drink Week" at PS 221 after Mayor Bloomberg cracked down on sugary drinks, making fresh lemonade and limeade and comparing sugar content between their beverage and soda. Then they taught other students to make it and its benefits! 

Most of the classrooms, from prek to grade 5 at PS 221 are Hip2B Healthy Classrooms, where students create rules: "No junk food here." "We run."

Students at PS 221 grow edible gardens, run a Hip2B Healthy Market selling healthy snacks for 50 cents or less, cook nutritiously with professional chefs (Buddakan), play soccer, run and get fit, engage in the arts: every child studies music with either the Metropolitan Opera Guild or keyboard with Music in the Brain curriculum. Our students have cooked with the Yale Club chef, visited the Met Opera, conducted book readings at Book Court, Cobble Hill or Barnes and Noble, Park Slope. 

They are ambassadors of change. At PS 221 - a neighborhood with one of the highest rates of obesity, diabetes, heart disease, asthma in the city - where many children only have one parent at home, or come from other countries  - we are saying, Yes, we Can!

We are a model for other schools! Our dedicated, talented teachers can tell you how they are raising achievement by integrating gardening, composting, healthy cooking, market math, food justice and literacy, arts, fitness. They face many challenges with families fighting tremendous obstacles many wealthier Americans know nothing about.

PS 222 got an "A" in spring 2011 after Seeds in the Middle began its pilot. But by fall 2011, Principal Kirkland lost 11 teachers - some of her best - due to budget cuts, forcing her science teacher to go back into the classroom as a partner in a CTT classroom. Class sizes were doubled. Last spring, the DOE quality review team gave this veteran principal, who grew up in the neighborhood, a devastating "D." 

No one looked at how a key model class of Seeds in the Middle had tes scores rivaling any top-rate public school in a much wealthier neighborhood. By the way, nearly 100 percent of PS 221 students get free and reduced lunch and are minorities. 

Their promise is why Seeds in the Middle chose this school in the obesity epidemic in central Brooklyn as its pilot in 2010. We knew that our model at PS 91, discontinued after partner Principal Solomon Long retired, rocked!

PS 221 students have the option to arrive at 7 am three days a week to walk/run with volunteer teachers, led by Barbara Zam, plus outside running volunteers. Sometimes, they get certified soccer coaches or flag football coaches at recess. They buy and sell fresh, healthy snacks for 50 cents at their own Friday morning and Tuesday afternoon Hip2B Healthy Market. Thank you to generous donors like Whole Foods Market, Santa Cruz Organics, Justin's Nut Butter.... and now offers from Peeled Snacks!

Our students help found and run the Crown Heights Farmers Market, opened in 2011 to address the lack of farm fresh produce in their neighborhood. Thank you, co-founding farmers Jamerican Farmer Rodrick Brown and RH Farms, Roy Hildebrant, who died in August. Both farmers donated and mentored students. Rodrick still does! Roy's spirit lives among us, and his wife and six children are dedicated to our PS 221 and Crown Heights community. All share the wonder and joy of growing and mentor the children. Home Depot built indoor planting tables, where last spring, students grew seedlings for a joyous Mother's Day plant sale. They made $85!

SUNY medical students, university students, athletes, chefs, educators, NYU, Yale Club, builders, Home Depot, Whole Foods, and a multitude of generous volunteers dedicated to equity in education step in to support these underserved children at the request of Seeds in the Middle. We are creating a model for replication - successful because these students and teachers shine!

Parents - if you are in this neighborhood and you haven't heard - this is a gem. Check out this school. This is the truth. Get in the game with PS 221 - let your children lead the way to a healthy, joyous life full of opportunity.

I am currently a parent of a 7 year old general education student and a 4 year old special needs child who will be attending kindergarten in September (2013) and will confidently say, no matter how good this school grades are, no matter how close I live to the school (school is directly ACROSS THE STREET FROM ME), I WILL NOT BE SENDING EITHER ONE OF MY CHILDREN THERE. They allow children to go out in sub-degree weather (under 32 degrees) to play, most of these children come out without hat, gloves, or coats. I have 3 friends who have children in that school and when I viewed this, I called the main office to ask what the cut-off temperature for banning the children to go outside. The woman on the phone responded, "Do you have a child in the school?" I answered no but I do have friends that have children there. She responded, "Well, that's none of your business." Then she hung the phone up. Now when these children go home, become sick and are out of school, the same school will start calling your home, calling ACS on parents, creating all kinds of unnecessary havoc. These parents now are forced to stay home, miss work (some of whom are not paid for sick days, unfortunately) and try their best to keep themselves and others from getting sick.

I also went to the school just to view their hallways and classrooms...let me just say that the "frontline" (adults that you meet upon entry) are more than condescending and rude. Additionally, some children directly disrespect staff and the staff return the favor and respond (not by using profanity but they might as well since what they say can easily be translated). As we know the children may have their individual issues, however, adults should NOT be TIT FOR TAT...that is just plain ridiculous.

This is my zone school and I will NOT be sending my children to the Twilight Zone. For those of you former students who made it out, kudos to you. You should all be either extremely tolerant future law-abiding citizens or future ticking-time bombs.

P.S. 221 now has chorus with the Metropolitan Opera Guild and keyboard two times a week for all their kindergarten, first and second graders. In addition, they are a pilot school for the Seeds in the Middle's Hip2B Healthy Project. Children are growing gardens and run a market selling healthy snacks. Chefs come to the school to teach cooking with kids, and also conduct demos in the school kitchen in the evenings for families, who all sit together and dine and then take home ingredients and recipes to repeat at home. We've also added the first ever youth soccer program and Zumba for adults - welcoming in students and adults from the entire community. The arts and the Hip2B Healthy projects excite students and teachers, and have boosted the students' academic skills in math, science, literacy and social studies as the teachers integrate lessons into the curriculum. P.S. 221 is an exciting, positive, nurturing place to learn for every child. Soccer and the chef's nights are beginning to lure more parent involvement. To learn more, reach out at seedsinthemiddle.org.

Students' 2008 letters to Santa revealed their impoverished circumstances, according to a story in the Daily News. Many of the letters asked for food or a safe place to live.

M.S. 246 Walt Whitman is among 40 middle schools selected for an extension of the Middle School Quality Initiative, a program that increases professional development with Common Core-aligned literacy strategies and gives targeted funding for literacy training and materials. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

A parent praises the "large amount of artwork" displayed in the school and notes that an arts academy is planned. "The school has at least 3 computer labs, 2 arts studios, a television studio, a darkroom, and two music studios," this parent writes.
A music teacher says, "I've met some beautiful people in this school. They've been behind me." He adds, "I've been blessed with talented kids."

A 7th grader says of his training in the school's television studio, "If my dreams don't work out, I have something else to fall back on."
"This school is the best school ever," writes student Jennelle.
