Read more: http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/education/city-rejects-top-rated-canarsie-middle-school-proposal-expand-article-1.1050606#ixzz1qKi2EAD2

I am a student at this school and i just love it. My mom however wants to change schools because she thinks there isn't enough safety at  the school. I guess she doesn't know that they teach us well and because of the teachers we get good grades and move on in life. Even though the school  has it's ups and downs, its overall a good school and i feel SAFE there. Even though this is my first year in the 6th grade i don't feel a certain way i feel just right.
im now in 8th grade and i love this school.

Principal Buffie Simmons-Peart received a 2008 Cahn Fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and continue serving as principal at the school.

I am thrilled to end the school year at IS 211. A parent writes: " I was able to be involved with the many different programs available at IS 211. The Principal is the first principal I have seen in years to come to be a part of something so rewarding: "children and education". Ms. Simmons is always in the school vicinity during the arrival and dismissal part of the day. I find Mr.Williams- Parent Coordinator, is like the school crossing guard. I asked him: 'Why are you crossing the kids daily after school?' He replied: 'These are our babies and until we secure a traffic light on the corner of E 100th St. and Ave J, I do not want to see my students injured by a fast driving motorist.' That is the dedication we need in our schools to move toward the success arrow. I am proud to have my child attend IS 211. The school has this parent/teacher contact system called: HIP schools. The parents and staff are given User ID and Pin numbers to retrieve and send student messages from the school, teacher, principal, and parent. I was impressed to find the School has a manicured "mini garden"."

A parent writes: "IS 211 has many new bright spots. The principal and parent coordinator are genuinely involved with the school and the way the school runs. From the parents to the students, to the teachers needing additional support they were very impressive. The school has secured a grant from the Leadership Academy, which will provide after school clubs for the students at IS 211. They have many groups: Young woman's club, the chess club, they even have the video club re-creating the teenager hit: "Degrassi." The parent adds: "I am so proud of the nice things going on at IS 211."

A parent writes: "I am proud of the hard work the staff at John Wilson is doing. I went to the school recently to follow up on a fight/disagreement my child had with another student. To my surprise the school had handled the situation [and] the incident was squashed." He continues: "The tone is very welcoming when you come into the school. The parent coordinator is always available to assist with my concerns. The Academy APs are available also. I notice that the administrative staff is always outside at dismissal to insure safety of all the children." He adds: "The school was able to have two SES programs. When [I asked] about this, I was given an honest answer of, 'All children need to get extra help.' I think [it] is very supportive for the school to work like this. The school had a spring recess academy to prepare the Grade 8 students for the New York State math exam [and] the after-school programs are awesome. If you need help, you get help."

A student writes: "I graduated from 211 this year and yes there is violence and yes there is conflicts but let us not forget the warmth of 211. The teachers push you to do better. ... I graduated with a 91.8 average, something I thought I could never accomplish." This student adds: "211 gives you a sense of pride and dignity. They express your heritage and culture and that's what I loved about it."

An staff member writes: "The school is turning things around. The tone is completely different in the building. The staff is all proactive when dealing with school related issues. The school has afterschool programs to support student learning. The grade 8 students are receiving additional ELA preparation. The school conducts a Saturday Academy to help sharpen ELA skills required to pass the test in January 2005. The principal has scheduled a holiday test review for Grade 8 student considering the test is around the corner." He continues: "The school has also acquired a family worker to do the necessary outreach to parents to follow up on many concerns at IS 211. The school is using Education Station (formerly Sylvan) to provide afterschool SES tutorial. The school is using a math coach and an English coach to support the staff teaching efforts at the school. This is all in the right direction of a good school. The parents are supportive of the proactive stance the staff has taken to support their child's success."

Ashley, a student, writes: "I love this school! I'm going to miss IS 211 so much when I leave. I love the support I get from Ms. Moses, Ms. Patrick, and Ms. Simmons. I love the way my school year is going now!"

In June, 2004 the NYC Department of Education announced that Principal Iris Crystal was one of 45 public school principals "being removed from their positions for poor performance." According to the department, Ms. Crystal will return to a position she previously held.

A May 3, 2004 article in the Brooklyn Skyline reports: "Three students were slashed and a teacher was hospitalized as riot-like conditions broke out inside Canarsie's John Wilson Junior High School (IS 211) last Wednesday. ... The chaos prompted the immediate resignations of of two teachers and a school safety officer." The article quotes a former Parents Association vice president saying the administration is unresponsive to violence in the school.

Mark, a former student writes, "I am a graduate of this school and the only truly good thing in this school was Mr. Bostic and Mr. Checchi." He adds, "I now attend Brooklyn Technical High School and see 211 as a stepping stone."

According to a Feb. 16, 2004 article in the Brooklyn Skyline, some parents and other observers have alleged that the principal recently fired popular Parent Coordinator Wayne Harris for being "too involved" in school affairs. People interviewed for the article credited Harris with working to "break up fights" at the school and initiating "an extensive outreach effort to get parents involved in the PA, where attendance had been severely lagging in recent years."

My son started at PS 233 in the 2nd grade and will be graduating this June.  In the almost 4 years that he has been therel I have been more than happy with the quality of teachers he's had and I feel that Principal Spellman is doing the best job she can under the circumstances.  There is still room for  improvement, but I believe they are heading in the right direction.  Where the school lacks is in the area of parent involvement.  The same parents year in and year out serve on the PTA or the SLT or volunteer at the school.  More parents need to take time to share their knowledge and expertise with the school not only because their child attends but for the betterment of the community and those that will follow.  I wish them all the best as my son leaves this June, and hope that the new parents coming in will take the opportunity to do right by the school.

A parent writes that "PS 233 is a good school [and] only getting better." I was a former student in the 90s. As a matter of fact, the current principal (Ms. Solitario) was my 3rd grade science teacher! : )       15 years later, I returned as a student-teacher and then as a regular substitute teacher for 5 years. Every moment that I spent in this school was the best years of my teaching career. Administration was always very supportive and confident in their staff. They had such a keen eye to spot great teachers which reflects the success of this school. This school works not only closely as a community but as a family and supports each other as needed. In all 3 school buildings, the staff is so goal-oriented, set high expectations for all, and keeps the students' best interest at heart. 
  The gifted and talented students in the main building and Lenox Academy were the brightest and most well-behaved students that I've every worked with. I miss everything about that school.  Although I left for a little while, I plan on returning in the near future. The most enlightening experiences of my career were all at PS 235. P.S. 235 is an excellent school. Academically, it is one of the best elementary schools in Brooklyn. My daughter graduates this year from their Soar program and has been accepted into two of the top middle schools in New York all thanks to the great education she received at this school.

"I'm a proud parent of a 5th grader and a 2nd grader who attends P.S. 235. My children attended private school all their lives. My first encounter was with Ms. Thompson on the first day of school in the school yard. Ms. Thompson was very polite. She is understanding and always willing to help me with whatever my concerns and inquiries are. I also had an unfortunate situation with one particular teacher but I must say Ms.Solitario along with Ms. Thompson handled it quickly and professionally and I was very pleased. When my 5th grader was graduating and I needed help filling out middle school applications Ms. Sosis was very patient with me and knowledgeable of what I needed to do and steps I needed to take to make sure my son took advantage of all the opportunities that was out there for him. "P.S. 235 is the best school in Brooklyn" The Teachers there Really Cares."

"I love this school for my 9 year old. The curriculum includes out of the box thinking class work. My child is learning so much and enjoys attending classes. I send my child to school everyday thinking that the school aides are pleasant and respectful staff. Unfortunately, Mrs. Dabney proved me wrong. As a parent, I would appreciate a decent conversation from the parent coordinator when inquiring about general information regarding my child's education!"
A student in 8th grade at the Lenox Academy said she likes the fact that the school is small and that everybody knows one another.

"I love my school," writes student Afiya. "I get a lot of attention from teachers and my knowledge has expanded. I really enjoy the lessons taught. Not only the students are gifted but the teachers are gifted as well."
Student Vivienne writes that attending the Lenox Academy has "opened a lot of doors for me," including to Prep for Prep and help preparing for the Specialized High School Admission Test.
Student Crystal notes that Spanish instruction is particularly strong, and students graduate with high school credits in Spanish.

Student Kaionna, who has been at the school for several years, writes that she likes the school. "Teachers seem to care but find a balance between their friendliness and strictness," she writes, adding that the uniform is not burdensome. She complains that the school can be cliquish, noting that some students can feel "overlooked and lonely," and notes that overcrowding is beginning to become a problem. Still, she notes that the administration is usually responsive to students' concerns, for example adding lockers after students requested them.

"The school is much like a family. Any school is expected to have problems, but this school's issues are on a very minimal level. If this school were to be offered more money, we would surely be top. After all, we deserve it," writes 8th grader Kershema.

Shante Bailey, a mother of twin girls is please with both the soar and universal pre-k programs at the school. "I drive in all the way from Queens to take my kids to this school. As a parent I want the best for my children and PS 235 is just that!"

"The teachers are great and care about the students and one does learn things," writes a students referring to the Lenox Academy. "The only problem is that it is overcrowded. There is only there classes in one of the grades and but 32-34 students in a class. It sounds more like a lunchroom then a classroom. Last year there was a lack of internet service and computer access."

My son attends PS235 and is in the soar program, "I think the school is great," writes a parent of a 3rd grader in the soar program. "The work that the teachers give is very challenging. The teachers in the annex building are doing a wonderful job."

PS 272 is a good school. My little sister goes here, Ms. Keyes is great with the students and the students learn a great deal. They also have a terrific after school program.

The principal did not respond to the comment above.

She writes: "They force you to study so hard for the practice test and when you take the real test you do badly."
Ryan, an alumnus who was in the Astral program, complains that the school focused too much on tests and not enough on "regular subjects," but writes that the school was "good overall."

"I was in the Astral program and loved it a lot," writes an 8th grader who is now at Bay Academy. "I had a lot of fun and became very close to my teachers. In fact, I still talk to and visit my third grade teacher!"

"I moved into District 18 two years ago," writes a parent. "My son needed to continue his speech therapy, and PS 279 was the school he was assigned to." Although she originally intended to send her child to a private school, after touring PS 279 and meeting the security guard, Guidance Couselor, PTA President, and Speech Therapist she decided to send her child to PS 279 instead. "My mind was at ease knowing that my son would be in the hands of such caring professionals. For a single mom who works in Manhattan, my first concern was my child's safety and well being, and the people that would be interacting with him. My son is currently in kindergarten and is doing very well. His second report card scores were 3's and 4's. I am a proud parent of a child that attends PS 279."

Initially I was impressed with Meyer Levin, believing that having Mr. Underwood at the helm would garner great results for the school and the education my son would receive. I had heard nothing but good things about the school. My son came into Meyer Levin a straight A student and was unable to graduate his grades were so poor by 8th grade. The decline was gradual, but was unable to be turned around without summer school.
I thought Mr. Underwood would be an ally in assisting me with turning my son's grades around, but he seemed to perpetuate the problem. He would give me his word, and then fall back on it. I am a hands on parent very vocal and on board with my child's education. Yet no matter how many times I went up to the school I felt as though my son were under attack. I will say there were some teachers and an Assistant Principal that recognized the talent and potential in my son. However, having placed him in a class where kids were not on his academic level just seemed to pull him down.      
Behavior in this school during the day was quite surprising to me; some students were very disrespectful when spoken to by teachers in the hall. The girls with their flippant remarks, the boys with their sagging jeans it was really a sight to see.
With the help of George Leonard my son was able to redeem himself. I am just thankful the worst school experience for my son is now over. He is embarking on a new journey as a freshman in HS.
At the end of the day a team/school can only be as strong as their leader….

It is my understanding that principal Underwood brought George Leonard to the school to help under-achieving boys. My son not only benefited by this program but Mr. Underwood also help us find him a summer job. I was one of the few parents that came out every Saturday to volunteer to help the teachers and Mr. Underwood with their Saturday program. I felt it was the least that I can do, to volunteer my time for a free program designed to assist my child improve. If more parents stop blaming the school and the principal for their problems and work to make a difference instead, they would also have a success story to share.

Make no mistake Mr. Underwood did bring in Mr. Leonard for assistance, but you have to ask yourself with a school that is supposed to be in such good academic standing why did he need George Leonard?

The answer: because there is a disconnect between what is being reported and what is actually taking place in the school. I did not send a struggling student to this school I sent a"straight A" student, and in the end wound up with a failing student that with "George Leonard's" help succeeded.

I participated in a group interview at the Science and Medicine Middle School after having been offered a job at another school. Had I been offered a job at this school, I would have not accepted the position. I was ready to walk out of the interview mid-way. The principal came off as rude, disorganized, and not knowing what she was talking about. During the interview process, the rest of the staff portrayed the student body in a horrible light. I never heard faculty members speak so poorly of their students. Having spent a considerable amount of time waiting outside the building and coming across many students participating in a recreational activity, I was shocked to hear the staff speak so poorly of children that appeared well-behaved. At the end of the interview, the entire group of highly qualified teachers being interviewed was told by the staff that they didn't feel anyone was ready to handle their students. I was greatly disturbed by my experience with this school for the staff came across as the coldest and most pessimistic I have ever encountered.

East Flatbush Community Research School is among 40 middle schools selected for an extended learning day pilot with 2.5 more learning hours in the school day for all students, and daily literacy tutoring for high needs students. My daughter just graduated from 8th grade with honors...This is a pretty good school once you want to learn.  The teachers care, the principal, Mr. McNeil is awesome and very hands on, he actually cares, which I loved.  He was involved in the day to day.  This school is definitely a work in progress, I had great communication with the teachers, all the teachers on a week to week basis and they were ALWAYS available to me and ALWAYS got back to me when they were not available.  Once you are on top of your child and their education and don't just sit back and expect the teachers to do everything, then you see the wonderful outcome.  In my experience with the teachers, I find that the 8th grade teachers were the absolute best, they wanted to see the kids pass, they wanted to see them progress, they wanted to see the kids succeed and do their best.  In the 3 years my daughter spent there, she did not do well on the ELA's at all.  With the help of Ms. Denis, the guidance counselor, we got her a tutor.  Not only did she finally pass the ELA in the 8th grade, but her grades increased significantly, she went from a C student to honor role (80s and 90s).  I didn't not give up on her, Ms. Denis, did not give up, the teachers did not give up so therefore, she didn't give up and now I am the proudest parent.  My only problem with this school was the neighborhood, other than that it is a good school.  If you want to go to a school that  is hands on, this is the school for you.

I have never suffered bulling here and I have found my group of best friends. There is a lot of diversity and I will really miss this school. It is very clean, and has a homie feeling to it, with a very panoramic view in the fourth floor. We also have a greenhouse which the younger grades visit and help take care of and also a peer mediation program where the peer mediators help students solve their problems and come to solutions. We also have a medium sized library where my love for books came from, the librarian Ms.Marla is super nice and helpful and she can recommend you any book you want. This school leaves you feeling prepared to enter the "real world" with inalienable experiences, knowledge, and friendships. The only thing I don't like is that this school is a participant in the Wellness in the SchoolsCook for Kids program, which replaces the traditional cafeteria menu with a healthy menu, which is very unappetizing for us but  I usually brought my own lunch. Other than that I LOVE PS89!!!!!!!

called WITS Labs. You can find out more about programming from Wellness in the

Parents say new leadership is turning IS 171 around and the school just needs more time. Read more: Parents want their struggling school to get more time to improve.
The DOE has begun discussions with 20 NYC schools, including IS 171, that are at risk of closing for extremely low test scores. Read more: DOE Begins To Consider Closing 20 More Public Schools.
"The kids are rude to teachers and the police are at my school almost every day," writes a student.

Melanie, a student who has been at the school for six years, writes that the teachers are "nice. You can talk to them about your problems." She bemoans the school's small gym/lunchroom, but adds, "I think that it is good for the 8th graders to eat at the last period because then they can just go home."
"Our teachers let us do work in a more laid back way. The teachers try to make you laugh within the lessons," writes Ashonia, who has been at the school for four years.
"My school isn't that bad," writes student Akeela. "I've been coming here since the 5th grade and all of the teachers have the relationship to talk out your problems and to not feel bad."
A student who has attended both IS 171 and another middle school, IS 113 in Fort Greene, prefers 113, believing that it is the safer of the two.

"It is inhumane to force 8th grade students to wait until the last period of the day (2:10pm) to eat lunch," writes a teacher. "If this is the only way that the school can accommodate the overcrowded lunchrooms, the school should provide students with snacks free of charge."

Sharin, a former student who attended from 2000 to 2002, writes that she thinks IS 171 is "by far the worst middle school in Brooklyn." She claims she left the school after a boy in her art class used scissors to cut her pinkie finger, and her teacher did not respond appropriately to the situation.

A student writes, "I've been in this school for 5 years, and the teachers aren't bad, but we don't have enough supplies. I think we need better books and supplies. He also complains that although he thinks "the janitors do a good job, the school still gets really dirty."

"The school is okay, but it could be a lot better," a student writes. "The problems are the bathrooms and some of the students. They think they're very grown when they aren't."

An article in the Oct. 17, 2006 New York Daily News describes changes at PS 273 after it became one of the city's 331 new empowerment schools, a designation which grants the principal "more control over isues such as hiring staff and managing her budget," the News reported. The article reports that Principal Melessa Avery "moved quickly to bring in new teaching tools: She reintroduced phonics into the classrooms; added a computer tutoring program for special needs students; and even issued a 100 booking reading challenge to her fourth and fifth graders."  Avery is also mentoring nine new teachers at the school, the article by Tanyanika Samules notes. The News reports that 50% of the students are reading at grade level and that Avery's plan is to increase that to 70% by June.

"There's good communication here," says the parent coordinator.

A veteran teacher says, "There is more organization and accountability than there was before."

Principal Willena George received a 2008 Cahn Fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and continue serving as principal at the school.

"I call this building Grand Central Station, because it's always open to parents, and it's always going," said the mother of a 5th grader who is in his first year at the school. "He enjoys it. There are so many activities here that he didn't have in his other school. He's on the basketball team. He's in the Kaplan program. He does arts and crafts."

"My daughter likes it here," said a 5th grade parent. "She gets a lot of homework. She has an organizer that has assignments; they get four or five a day. I was a student here 17 years ago, and it's gotten a lot better. I don't know if it's the principal or the city, but they have gotten tougher on students. There is more that they have to learn."

"I love teaching here," said a 5th grade teacher. "The staff is supportive; the administration is fair. They have tailored programs to meet individual student needs. There are so many resources: books, CDs, study guides, and reference books that kids can take home. I wish the classes were smaller. I have 26 kids. I'd like to see 20."

"We have a lot of new teachers," said a 5th grade teacher. "This is a good place to start. It's a supportive staff, and the kids behave. Everyone has a helpful attitude. I'd like to see more community service projects, because the kids do so many great things, and I'd like the community to see them."
"I'm content with what I'm seeing here now," said a teacher who joined the school in 2001. "We work as a team. I see us moving forward."

"[Principal Willena] White is a caring person," said the literacy coach. "She's very hands-on. She's here every night until 7:00 p.m., and her attitude trickles down: The teachers are here nights, too. I've been in a lot of different places, and this is the hardest working staff I've ever seen. The administration is very organized. The teachers don't have to deal with things thrown on them at the last minute."
Joel, an alumnus, writes: "PS 290 has given me a lot. My senior year was the best. Mrs. Fransisco was my preferred teacher."

Little Brats Kicked Out Of 9/11 Memorial For Throwing Trash Into Reflecting Pools
http://gothamist.com/2012/06/24/little_brats_kicked_out_of_911_memo.php

Ray Kelly and the NYPD were worried that the 9/11 Museum and Memorial might attract suicides—but on Thursday, it was bratty little kids who were causing all the trouble. According to the News, students from Junior High School 292 in East New York who were on a trip to the site were kicked out of the memorial for throwing baseballs and trash into the reflecting pool. “They kicked us out because of littering in the water. Kids were throwing baseballs in the pond thing,” said 14-year-old Anthony Price, who added he wasn’t one of the troublemakers.“They were making jokes and throwing stuff in the fountain. It didn’t seem like a big deal,” said another student, who wished to remain anonymous. In addition to the baseballs, witnesses reported seeing empty plastic soda bottles and other garbage in the water. I was a student here as a freshman from 2008-2009 and I immediately transferred to another high school because of my experience here. I would like to share it with others who are considering to attend this school, though I know that it has been many years since, it sounds like things haven't changed much. First and foremost, the teachers that taught while I was there were the best teachers I've had. They genuinely looked after the students and tried to teach the class as best as they could, it sounds like they are much different now; though the issue is the students. 
Most of the students were extremely rude to teachers and staff, they bullied and antagonized other classmates including making racist jokes to minorities, had physical and unnecessary drama amongst themselves. I was one of the few students who had high grades because I actually did the work, which was not hard nor challenging at all, (one of the reasons why I transferred). At the end of the year, people near me groaned and 'tisk-ed' at me every time I received an award for my grades, which, as others have said, causes disrespect from others to students with high grades,thus discouraging them from    excelling.
For me, the students and the level of education given at AFYW is what makes the school have a bad reputation. For the first time in my life, I honestly wanted more challenging work given to me because the education there was disbelievingly easy and laughable. By the time I transferred to my new school, I was shocked how advanced the work was and how unprepared I truly felt, but thanks to my decision to transferring, I was put into challenging AP classes the next year and I'm now into my second year of college. 
I would not recommend this school to those who want to be properly  prepared for college and want to have a good high school experience, without the endless bullying and crude jokes.

I’d like to take a moment to address some of the deeply concerning comments listed below. 
 
1)      We take discipline very seriously at Young Writers with an emphasis on respect and community reparation.  We have extremely low incidents of physical fighting and hold students accountable for instances of disrespect to adults or peers.  We take all reports of a sexual nature especially seriously, following the Chancellor’s Regulations.  Visitors to our school nearly always comment on the positivity of our school tone.
2)      This year we offer different tracks for our math students at each grade level.  Students who enter Young Writers having passed the Integrated Algebra Regents exam with above a 75 may take Geometry right away.   
3)      Students at Academy for Young Writers must meet core Department of Education graduation requirements, both credits and Regents exams, in order to graduate from our high school.  We believe, and research supports the belief, that when a student struggles to capture credits in their first or second year of high school, making them repeat an entire grade dramatically increases their chances of dropping out all together. Instead, we allow students to take classes with their cohort while creating interventions to support them in recapturing missing credits.  
4)      No teacher at the Academy for Young Writers has ever taken any test for any student. This is a baseless allegation and is entirely false. 
5)      We have a strong college preparation and counseling program.  In addition to the CUNY and SUNY schools, we have several students thriving at schools like Ithaca College, Southern Vermont University and Skidmore College on full scholarships. 
We are extremely proud of the rigorous and supportive community we have built over the past 5 plus years as a school and the Department of Education has recognized our hard work.  I invite you to visit our school survey (http://schools.nyc.gov/OA/SchoolReports/2010-11/Survey_2011_K404.pdf)  – anonymous and unbiased feedback from our community of teachers, parents and students – to learn more about what our school is all about.  I also invite you to visit the school any time.  

Courtney Winkfield, Principal

Kristine Bennett, a new math teacher and NYC Teaching Fellow, who was a student at ENYFA from grades 6 through 12, says “Ms Richards [the school principal] taught me, [middle school Assistant Principal] Mr. Yearwood, he’s my boss now, and he taught me,”Coming back to the community where she grew up “is very rewarding."
Because of improvements in its test scores, ENYFA's middle school was removed from the state's list of schools needing improvement and is now considered "in good standing" under No Child Left Behind.
"ENYFA is a good school because it's small and the teachers are caring," writes a student. "They work to the best of their ability to help the students to pass and go on to college."
"Its a good school," writes student Jessica. "It's really small and that is better."
"I love my school and each teacher attends to all the students needs," writes student Antonique. "ENYFA has changed my life and welcomed me as family."
Mishael, a 7th grader at the school, writes: "I'm learning a lot and it's a good school."

Denisha Townsend, a 2000 graduate, writes: "When I enrolled in the school in March of 1999 I was two years behind and not really into education or in my own potential as a student or as a person. Through my teachers and the leaders at the school I developed the interest, commitment, discipline, and strength to go to night school, summer day and night school, as well as school on Saturdays for a year and a half so I was able to graduate on time. I always look back and thank GOD for the staff becoming a part of my life."

"I am currently teaching mostly homeless students in the southwest," writes David Parslow. "I spent a year with Ms. Richards, her faculty leaders and other teachers. I am still inspired by them. Without any special help from outside, they draw on their inner resources and resourcefulness to find ways to reach their students. I am still in awe of the teaching experience I had there."

I'm a parent living in Euclid Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11208 (district 19). For last few weeks, I'm frantically searching for a good middle school for my son. His 4th grade standardized test scores are quite impressive and match well to the requirement. Today (December 25, 2012) my wife and me visited the school just to get an impression of the school's physical location and surrounding, as well as the actual situation of commuting (to-and-from the school). The location is nice and well placed. But I'm little worried about whether my son would be able to commute easily between the school and our home, by taking two buses (Q8 from our home and B83 to transfer)....? Besides, I have another concern..how good the school environment and it's overall performance? I wanna love to listen from current students, not from the DoE statistics. Please, come forward and give me some feedback. Thank you guys so very much....

When Mayor de Blasio announced that NYC schools would close for the first time on Muslim holiday, Eid al-Adha, he did it from PS/IS 30, where 36 percent of students were absent the last time the holiday fell on an instructional day. http://bit.ly/1FinTea

Chancellor Fariña announced 73 schools selected to join the Learning Partners Program, an innovative and collaborative initiative that brings schools together to share practices to improve learning in the classroom and raise student outcomes. Through the program, one host school with strong practices in a particular focus area will support two partner schools seeking to strengthen their own practices in that area. J.H.S. 67 Louis Pasteur was chosen to host P.S. 30 Mary White Ovington and William Carr. Read more here.

IS 30 is piloting an extended day program that will give participating students the opportunity to get extra help with literacy and to participate in extracurricular activities. As the program gets underway, the school is troubleshooting solutions for increasing participation. Read more here.

I.S. 30 Mary White Ovingtonis among 40 middle schools selected for an extended learning day pilot with 2.5 more learning hours in the school day for all students, and daily literacy tutoring for high needs students. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

From parentsofnyteens:

A PS/IS 30 parent writes, "The teaches in my son's classes are knowledgeable, caring and respectful of students. The school communicates very well with parents, via telephone calls, sending letters home and daily emails. They don't offer a whole lot of electives, such as computers or law classes. They have daily science/health, social studies, algebra/math, and ELA. Art, Phys ED and Spanish are 1-2 per week. The school staff cares about the students. The school is really small right now, a little over 300 students. Everyone knows each other. Teachers and school staff are welcoming and know each student. I find this very important for 6-8 graders, especially for those kids who are coming from a small elementary school. The school and classes are clean, well maintained, with students' work displayed on walls. Student body in my son's class is friendly. It is a great group of multicultural population. I have not heard of bullying problems, any fights, or drugs. It is a very tightly knit school community. The homework load is manageable, although expect to do homework or 1.5-2 hours daily. The school is supposed to move into a new bigger building this coming September 2013. My son's class will have 3 Regents exams this year: Integrated Algebra, US History and Government, and Living Environment. The teachers are going above and beyond to prepare kids for the tests, both state and Regents. Overall my son likes the school and so do I."

IS 30 was named one of 20 schools picked for the city’s new Software Engineering Pilot program that will launch in September 2013. The program will include a comprehensive computer science and software engineering curriculum at each school. Read more here.

In November the District 20Community Education Council approved new zoning for IS 30, which will become an elementary school as well, admitting kindergartners for September 2013. Read more, including the boundaries for the new zone: CEC District 20 unanimously approves P.S./I.S. zoning.
Parents say the city is reneging on a promise to move IS 30 into a new building.

Hello, I see the reviews bad and good well here’s both of my pros and cons of how it’s going so far being in sixth grade there. My pros are that
1- When students need help the teacher helps the student right away, and I noticed that the student got better at it.
2- THE TEACHERS ARE NOT “bad” they are Actully very nice and students respect the teachers for that.
3- As a starter I alredy feel welcome, because they treat us like they knew us when we we’re born and they have a very good personality 
4- We have a big recess yard which makes it very fun to play in and you can do so many things!
5- (not an important pro) They have vending machines and the drinks and snacks are one word AMAZING and cheap 🙂🙂🙂.

My cons
1- students were “play” fighting in the yard and none of the teachers did anything!
2- I noticed students curse out loud and never get in trouble for it I mean I do understand they did it before but that’s not good! And I will admit I have cursed but not in school!
3- (not important con) THE VENDING MACHINE DOESN’T WORK SOMETIMES.
4- They say phones aren’t allowed out yet when school starts I’m in the auditorium and I see students playing on there phones I mean I don’t if that’s breaking a rule cause class didn’t start yet.
5- When we get up to get to our class we all always squished by other grades 7th grades and 8th grades and 6th

So this are my cons (bad) and pros (good) so both sides are reasonable so my point is the schools not bad, not the best school, but it’s an Ok school a and all schools have cons and pros.

I’m a student at ditmas jhs 62 I’m new to the school, I prefer not to mention what class I am in but this school is wonderful but people do have there own opinions, but I would say the school is wonderful because there is nice teachers, nice lunches, and students that are struggling with something or having trouble the teacher will help you. And wow the gym is huge I love it! One thing I don’t like is during lunch period sometimes the vending machine doesn’t work but that’s not the main focus, what I’m trying to say students are smart and especially if you really concentrate in class you can get a real good grade but I mean I still don’t know what’s up coming in the future.

The school feels like the place where your kid goes to fall through the cracks. The staff are not passionate or focused and they treat the kids more like parts of a horde than individuals. One of my son's sixth grade teachers seemed extremely incompetent and terrible, and when I went down to the school to discuss this with the assistant principal, she said she'd talk to the teacher. By the time I got home my son was already home and he was frantic. It had been just an hour since I had talked to the principal and the teacher had already been spoken to, and she had already confronted my son (in front of his friends!) and argued with him over what had happened. My son gave in and told the teacher that he must have remembered incorrectly, and came home frantic and worried and feeling sorry for the teacher. After this, we let the whole affair go. There was no point speaking to the school if this was how issues were resolved: by confront a kid and making them feel sorry for the teacher and worried for her job.

It's been a depressing experience at Ditmas Junior High so far, a lesson in how unhelpful a big, chaotic, uninspired school can be.

She has shown that her temper and impulsiveness at the school has tarnished the safety of the students.

IS 62 was named one of 20 schools picked for the city’s new Software Engineering Pilot program that will launch in September 2013. The program will include a comprehensive computer science and software engineering curriculum at each school. Read more here.

The exercise builds confidence and in some cases serves as a catharsis for children dealing with trauma, as an article in Feet in Two Worlds shows.

The school is very clean, the principal is energetic and always roaming around the school making sure everything is going well. It has a reputation as a tough place but it is very safe, plenty of security persons and teachers well in control. There are three areas of interest as well as advanced placement and special education classes. The teachers are very good and easy to talk to and get along with. There are four marking periods preceded by progress reports. The school offers a free Kaplan course to selected students for the Specialized HS exam as well as after school tutoring (free) and activities. Guidance counselors are on top of the students throughout the entire HS application process. The deans of each academy are involved as well. This is a great school for each and every kid to be accepted into a safe and welcoming environment. The teachers and principal are really amazing and down to earth.

"I would encourgae anyone who is sending their child to JHS to take a tour of Ditmas. Take the time to find out what is going on there. They do many interesting things with the kids to promote learning. They make it fun and exciting for them. They have programs that other JHS's do not have. Don't take the advice of others who know nothing about the school, except what has happened in the past. Before you sending you child out of the neighborhood to a "better" school, check out what is in your own back yard."
A student writes that the school is "very exciting" and "worthwhile." She notes, " if you commit to the school for 3 years they give you a Gateway or IBM computer."

Its AWESOME! I love this school!

PS 69 is among 9 schools in Brooklyn to get a tech upgrade. The projects were voted on by residents of District 38 and will be paid for out of City Councilman Carlos Menchaca's participatory budget process. Read more here. http://dnain.fo/1DWT3Qn
NY1 visited PS 69, one of seventeen showcase schools, and saw how the school's strong arts program is incorporated into every subject. Watch the video here.

PS 69 Vincent D. Grippo School has been selected to showcase their robust arts program in the inaugural year of Chancellor Carmen Fariña’s Showcase Schools Program. The initiative is designed to promote collaboration and sharing of strong practices. Schools that excel in a specific learning focus area will host educators from other schools to share their successful structures and strategies. Read more here.

"I loved this school. I was part of Mrs. Bromme's last graduating class which was back in 2006. This building is amazing and beautiful. The teachers are the nicest people. I remember being scared of going into a new school when I first learned I would be going to PS69 when it first opened in 2002, I don't regret it. The coolest part has to be the laptops they send you home with! This school prepared me well for junior high; I ended up in IS187 (Best Middle School in NYC!) and I'm having the best time in my life as a senior graduating and now I'm so excited for high school at Stuyvesant! The science teacher (Mrs. Giammarino) and the social studies teacher (Ms. Tidona, now, Mrs. Polo) teach very well and prepare you for the NYS SS and Science Exams. I would like to thank all the teachers and staff for giving me such a great elementary school experience!(:"

Parent Margherita M., who calls the school "truly remarkable, almost unbelievable," writes that Principal Bromme is retiring. "I hope whoever takes over as principal will be the kind of leader that Mrs. Bromme has been throughout these years, and continues to run it as successfully as Mrs. Bromme has," she writes.

"They support the arts here and that doesn't happen everywhere," the music teacher said.

A parent volunteer -- who was an art teacher in her native Egypt -- says, "Everything is good about this school. I like everything."

MaryBeth Meenan, 2nd grade special education teacher at P.S. 102 Bayview, is one of the 17 recipients of the 2016 Big Apple Award. The Big Apple Award is a citywide recognition program that celebrates the incredible work of New York City public school teachers. Read more here.
PS 102 is profiled in an Advocates for Children report "A is for All: Meeting the Literacy Needs of Students with and without Disabilities in the New York City Public Schools".

2 months into kindergarten at PS 102, and very unhappy.  Some of my complaints are probably general DOE complaints, but the communication with the parents is terrible, everyone (teachers, administration, etc) give conflicting information regarding student progress and needs, and actually caught a teacher in a lie regarding child's activities.  It is impossible to try and work with this school to make any improvements, with everyone just blaming someone else (I spent 2 weeks going back and forth between the district and the school, with both claiming the other was at fault for a delay).  This school makes me want to pull my child out and homeschool, that is how horrible the last two months of my life have been.

We are very happy with PS 102. It is a very large school but well kept. The garden and playground are beautiful. I wish the kids got to use them everyday or more often but kindergarten does go out in the spring. Its difficult to get into the G&T program here as they only have room for the kids with the highest scores, but we find the regular classroom challenging. The class sizes need to be much smaller (my son currently has 30) and the Common Core has its own set of problems. However, the kids get gym, music, science, social studies and field trips. My son does more than I did as a first grader years ago in the suburbs. Not perfect but really very good.
The playground is hardly ever used and kindergarten almost never goes outside and when they do they are all cramped int a tiny schoolyard. Most teachers have obvious favorites.

I have no idea why this school gets high marks. There is a very particular group of parents that PS102 works for, but very many for whom it doesn't. There is a growing group of parents of special education students who have a particularly hard time--though even the general ed and honors classes are lacking. There are a few truly golden teachers, but overall, this school feels like nothing has changed in education since the 1970s. The approach is anything but forward thinking, and the staff and administration do not reflect the diversity of the student population at all (and it shows in the "us vs. them" attitude). Sorry, but after 2+ years I'd rather leave the neighborhood than continue sending my kids here. The experience is killing everything that they (and I) loved about education.

My children really love PS102. They have both had really good teachers and have enjoyed going to school each day. Our experience of the school has changed dramatically over the past 7 years. I had my complaints in the beginning, but I can happily say I'm really pleased with the education and opportunities my children received at this school. In the time we've been at the school, the school garden has been transformed. There is a real recognition of the value of the arts. The music and art teachers are fantastic. Last year a beautiful and complex "welcome" mural was painted by hundreds of volunteers on one of the exterior walls. There are caring, resourceful teachers, parents and volunteers. A lot of positive energy here. My children have been well prepared to move on. Sadly, the school is now becoming woefully over crowded due to ridiculous budget cuts.
I graduated from this school in 2005 amazing school and the best teachers ever truly inspiring!!!
i go to this school ps102 class 2-101

Principal Theresa Dovi received a 2009 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor an aspiring principal while continuing to serve as principal at their school.

"The school is so efficently run and well orgainzied that each child is noticed and treated as an individual," writes a parent. "So far all of the teachers are real professionals. I always feel the children are safe. Though it is structured and traditional there are still many creative outlets within the general classroom and during the clusters. This place is run by a highly professional and talented staff. There is not a lot of downtime though - so far no recess for the kindergarten students."

"We continue to be impressed with the quality of teaching at this school," writes parent Kathryn McKenzie. "PS 102 is a large school and has to address the needs of many, many children. The PTA is experimenting with new ways of involving parents and trying new fundraisers to encourage involvement from a wide range of parent communities within the school. If there was one thing I'd change, it would be to add to the arts staff. The basics are well-covered here though."

"We have found that this quite large school is well run and really feels quite small," writes parent Kathryn McKenzie. "A new playground will soon open in the school yard and our children are really excited about that! The school has a good group of volunteers who really try to produce events that are family-oriented and supportive of the aims of the school, staff and children. Tonight was the first staff/parent talent show and it was a roaring success!"

A parent of a recent graduate writes that the nursing staff at P.S. 102 was very caring to her diabetic daughter. "But what made it even better was [that my daughter] was assigned a Health Para to help her along when it came time to check her sugar. Kelly was the best thing that happened to her at P.S. 102," she writes.

"The parent coordinator is a real gem and is working hard to improve family involvement" with sports nights, movie nights, concerts, seminars, ESL classes for parents, and a Grandparent's Day celebration, writes parent Kathy McKenzie. "Efforts like this give me hope that the school can become a more welcoming place." She bemoans the "limited outside free play" and the fact that "unhealthy snacks" are sold in the cafeteria, which her daughter complains is too loud.

"Kindergarten students have no outside recess until April and students in the other grades are not allowed to run around and play ball on the limited days when they are allowed outside," writes a parent. "The school has excused this failure by claiming that they have inadequate staff to supervise the children at recess." The parent also does not understand the purpose of dividing the children by gender during line-up and recess.

In response to the above comment Principal Theresa Dovi writes: "Students in grade K do not go out until the spring because we feel they need time to acclimate to the school and they would only be out for two months - October and November and then it gets too cold to go outside. All the other grades are outside and play everyday using organized games. Children are not permitted to run around because we have 400 children at each lunch period since we are a very large elementary school. We also will be participating in the peaceful playground program this year. Any parent is invited to come and observe our outside lunch recess program. As far as the separation by gender when the students play they are not separated, only when they line up to go upstairs to their classrooms."

This school is amazing and studies in academics are in a very high standard. The teachers at this school are dedicated to their work and are determined to help the kids strive towards their goals. In my assumption, I believe that this school acts as a model towards other schools. I have been in this school for nine years, and I will be graduating this year! It helps provide students with a wonderful environment to succeed in.

OK, so I am not sure whether my comments will be taken seriously or not, because I am a teacher at 104.  That being said, please understand that I have taught in a number of other schools, and that while no school is perfect, at 104 the priority is and always has been the students.  Miss DiBella is indeed a strong leader and runs a tight ship and has kept a dedicated and talented teaching staff for a number of years.  Unlike other schools, there is little teacher turn over at 104.  Not a day goes by that a teacher does not hear the administration ask, "What is best for the kids?" or "How can you get the parent involved with this situation?" We are always striving to set high goals and introduce strong and challenging activities.  In my experience, there have been countless parents and former students who have come back simply to say thank you, or to let us know how much they appreciated their experience at 104.  Is it perfect?  No.  Are there problems? Yes, but they pale in comparison to what one might encounter in similar schools.  As for the complaints about bullying, I know from personal experience that bullying is not tolerated and that each and every teacher and administrator in the building keeps a sharp eye out for any signs of bullying.  As a matter of fact, in the junior high, all teachers monitor the halls during passing (which is not required), and all infractions are dealt with immediately.  I am aware that there are PTA meetings at 6:30pm every other month.  I have attended a number of them at that time, and, sadly, with the exception of the actual PTA members, there is very little parent presence.  If I could enroll my child at 104, I would do so--especially in the junior high, because the small student population makes for a safer and friendlier middle school experience for most kids.

My daughter starts here in a couple weeks. I've read the comments, hoping many of these statements won't ring true. Thanks for all the peer sentiment, hopefully my future reviews will be positive ones.

And they dont care, they just keep going to get their paycheck.

When people don't take the time to get involved and spend more time criticizing rather than working with a school, everyone suffers.  This is a school with over 1000 students and very little parent involvement.  The principal has always taken the time to work with parents who do not simply rant and rave, but express their concerns in a reasonable manner.  As adults, we need to be kind and courteous to members of our community if we expect our children to emmulate our example.  A lunch room with over 400 children must require quite a bit of supervision and patience.  I strongly disagree with your comment.

The anti-parent attitude of this school makes it nearly impossible for parents to be involved.  They are only interested if you can help out with fundraising activities.  There are no author or class celebrations in which families are invited, very few shows that only include some children (my child has yet to be in one), few afterschool events where families can come (I can only think of 1), and PTA meetings only every other month at a time reasonable for working parents.  Teachers refuse to give emails (in my experience), making it hard to communicate.  Parents aren't even invited for birthday parties.  As far making a positive change, that would only be possible if adminstration can agree that change is needed and that is not the case. In order for there to be change, BOTH sides need to admit things are not working and work together to make a change.  You see angry parents on here ranting and raving because we see it does not work and administration is not willing to work with parents to change things.

"I strongly disagree with the previous post. I have 2 children in the school, and have been extremely impressed with P.S. 104. It is a huge school with an incredibly diverse population of learners. The staff do an amazing job getting children who come to school with a variety of skill sets to all reach the same high standardsjust take a look at the 09 test results. The teachers are dedicated professionals who go far beyond their job descriptions to help their students. (And there is no Delta class in the current kindergarten, although it is full of gifted kids.) The museum magnet aspect of the school offers exciting projects and trips that inspire children's love of learning. Is the school perfect? No. There is too little parent involvement, and yes, Ms. DiBella does not always seems approachable. But she is an excellent builder of strong teacher teams, and she has kind and caring support staff, such as the parent coordinator and the assistant principals, who are always eager to help."

"I truly regret sending my child to P.S. 104. There is a clear bias toward the "gifted students" in this school. Ms. DiBella, the principal, is in my opinion one of the coldest and least friendly educators I've ever met. The kids are TERRIFIED of her. Her methods of educating are not outdated they are downright medieval. Things like "quiet time" during lunch every day do nothing but stifle the children's creativity and enthusiasm. She encourages her staff to be tough and keep them in line. It's no surprise to find out that she has no children of her own it actually helps explain her treatment of the students. (Excluding the Delta "gifted" kids of course) The reason that Ms. DiBella and her staff are allowed to get away with this type of stuff is because there is almost zero parent involvement in the school. I would urge any parent to think twice before sending their kids to P.S. 104. It's not a good place."

"I have two children at this school and have found the academic and social aspects of the school to be excellent," writes a parent. "Teachers are responsive and helpful and many assignments are creative and challenging!"

so I'm going to be honest here. While this school does provide education that is leagues ahead of other schools in it's region, the area the have a VERY ACUTE lack of expertise are child counseling/social services and the commitment to do so. They instead much rather rely on a policy of punishment shaming to set the kids in line, which only works for the short term. In the long run, this can lead to the afflicted child to develop a self-depreciating and pessimistic attitude and fear of going to school in general. Another thing that often goes under the radar is that the Teachers here are HIGHLY biased against children they perceive as troublemakers whether that is true or not. I was a former student here and I came on the receiving end of that policy. To this day in high school I am still dealing with the after-effects of my time here in this school and the lack of proper counseling measures really make me question do they actually even care about children (ages 5-10 NO LESS) who are prone to being mentally disturbed (bullying, exclusion, depression ETC). Granted this was way back in 2012 and the staff or policies may have changed but I recommend that if your child is the type to need counseling and social support, I highly dissuade you from sending your child here.

I am a former student of this school and this school really is a special place for me. It made me feel comfortable and needed. The teachers and staff are supportive and we get to experience other things. I have been in the globe class for 5 years and i learn to dance for Chinese new year every year. they have tech teams/clubs, dance programs, leadership teams and more. I just want to say that i love my teachers and this school.

I agree with you on the lack of professionalism in this school. I was primarily interested in the Dual language program they are offering and had called to inquire about it, instead i got the abrupt answer that if i am not zoned for that school, then my child will not qualify. "I called the school last week to see if they have an open house. I was told somewhere after February 11th and the phone was hung up abruptly. Today my husband called to see if he can find out the date of the open house. He was told that they do not have an open house. We were told that if this is our son's zoned school we do not have an option anyway, so there is no need for us to see the school. Then the receptionist just hung up the phone on us. Zoned school or not, our son is not going here!"

Most elementary schools don't have open houses. They're mostly for middle schools and higher. Besides,having an open house doesn't necessarily mean the schools is good. Some schools with bad reputations like Pershing and Shallow have open houses. I think you are unwise to say this school is (As you were implying) not suited for your son.

"The only problem that I have regarding this school besides that of overcrowding is that of no recess," writes a school official. "I do not think that is healthy considering the obesity rate and that the students only have one day a week of gym. Students are overly hyper after lunch and have nowhere to let it out but by acting out in class. Students releasing all their excess energy invades class time!"

Believe me, with our economy in bad shape, one day a week of gym is about as much as we can afford. Besides, as parents, don't you think you should also be monitoring the food your child is eating and how much they are exercising? It's part if your job too to make sure your child stays healthy. Schools really can't afford to have much physical education with all the other studies.

Barbara, a former student, writes: "When I came to America from Poland at age 6, knowing not a single word of English, I was quickly assigned to elementary school PS 105. On my first day I met a very kind-looking lady at the front door, who, when she saw me, smiled warmly, gently took me by my hand and led me to a classroom. That would be my 1st-grade teacher, Mrs. Nikovich, whom I owe so much thanks for truly making me feel welcome in this country, and providing the base for who I am today." She continues: "I can really say that the 5 years that I've spent in PS 105, very important years of many firsts and new encounters, were truly memorable, not only because of my great teachers or the interesting subjects but also because of the true comfort and eagerness to learn that I acquired from going to this school. And not only am I grateful for my homeroom teachers ... but also for the teachers who expanded my interests and possibilities to learn even further. ... I can honestly say that going to PS 105 was an experience I'll never forget, and I wouldn't give it up for anything."

A teacher complains: "Teachers' ideas and input are often suppressed. A recent colleague of mine, one who's extremely bright and enthusiastic about serving children, left because of the ... administration. Hiring needs to be rethought and recalibrated with higher standards."

Readers of the comment above, let's remember his comment was from eight years ago. It is outdated. I assure you with first hand experience that the school's taste in hiring teachers is excellent. Our school average is above normal, after all; thus we are one of the very few schools who can decide our
own curriculum.

I think it is very unfair of you to say that. Keep in mind that the students in bilingual classes are new to this country and know nothing of the English language. Instead if complaining about this like a child, I think you should work even harder to educate these children that need you most.

PS 127 is a great little school.  Dynamic, nurturing and caring learning environment with a dedicated administration and active parent body.
Fifth graders at PS 127 worked with a professional artist to design and paint a mural of their neighborhood inside the school building. Read more here.

The write-up here for 127 doesn't do it justice.  It's small size makes for an easy sense of intimacy (I've noticed that teachers in other grades and classrooms who have never before taught my child know his name!),  our new principal has brought increased communication with parents as well as more transparency (Family Friday events, Cup Of Coffee and Scoop of Info session with the principal, a newsletter, Learning Leaders, etc.), the diversity is rich and exciting, and an active PTA brings enrichment to the students in a variety of ways (Messy Art Nights, Movie Nights, Spring Carnival, Magic Shows, The Bio Bus, Pumpkin Patch, class dances, A Garden Committee and Book Club, etc.).  Every room has an air conditioner and Smart Board, students are given recess each day in the new and spacious back yard with a playground, an instrument is learned by each child in music class, and art and phys ed are still part of the curriculum.  Though our school has to play into the pressures of a more rigorous, test-taking culture, teachers are willing to listen and flex according to the need of each individual child.  Parents who get involved and communicate with their teachers and administrators regularly will find that the elementary school experience can be a positive one for both parent and child.

PS 127 is the little red schoolhouse of the 21st century. This is an outstanding neighborhood school. The staff is responsive, the PTA is very strong. The academic program is top-notch. Although space is limited, the staff have utilized every aspect of the building to incorporate art, music, physical education and a host of liberal arts programs for each grade. The administration is dynamic and sensitive to the needs of both students and parents. The school community is highly active, diverse, and focused on both enrichment and curriculum training.
 
 I have two children in this school - both were G & T ranked (one got into NEST) but chose to keep them in the neighborhood and walking to their elementary school experience. Do not regret that decision for a minute. They have excelled at this institution.

"The teachers are wonderful," said a parent active in the PTA. "The way they teach and they have incentives for students such as 'student of the month.'" She also said, "there is a lot of great art work at the school," and the school sponsors contests such as design your own pumpkin, or making posters, where kids are rewarded. The PTA is "active" with alternating daytime and night meetings.

A teacher said that when she came to work at the school she was so happy she thought she had "died and gone to heaven."

Because the school is so small, the parent coordinator said, there is a lot of time for one-on-one attention, and she's able to "really know the parents."

It's been a few years since I graduated, but it seemed like the last day of school was only yesterday. I made so many memories there both good and bad.

I'll rate 9/10.

My child is in 6th grade at PS/IS 163. This school is a huge disappointment. My child is learning nothing in Science and Social Studies in 6th grade. The reason why I say this is because the teachers are not teaching. Every class the Social Studies teacher has the students read the textbook by themselves and then answer the questions with their partners while she's busy on her computer. If they can't finish the work they bring home to finish it. Every test is either in class open book test or take home. As for the science teacher,very often he goes to the bathroom twice during one period. My child never needs to study for the tests. The tests are just copying the material from the book and move it over to the test paper. Same thing with the science teacher. Lately (soon after the Statewide Exams are over), the ELA teacher had the students read the booklet and answer the questions with their partners while she's on her computer as usual. Oh, I forgot to mention the ELA teacher teaches ELA and Social Studies while the Math teacher teaches Math and science. There are only two classes in 6th grade not including the special ed and these two teachers teaches both classes. SO, you child is doomed. If you are those parents who don't care much about your child's education. Then this school is ok for you.
Is this school good

"The school based support team (IEP) does not support children with behavioral problems linked with ADHD. My son was in a 12:1:1. Your child has the right to be in the least restrictive environment. My son did nothing for two months in kindergarten. I filed my numerous "know my rights letters" and "filed a discrimination complaint" with the state. I finally changed his school and he is now at PS 176. Three weeks have past and he knows all of his letters (sight and sound), reader first reader books, draw a simple story using three sheets of paper, write his first and last name, and so much more. He has a reward chart, sticker incentives, and support."
"She respects us," one teacher said about Principal Maryann Wasmuth. "She recognizes that we have a lot to contribute and she lets us."
"Wonderful school, excellent PTA," writes a parent who adds, it is "in need of more parental involvement, please stop in to visit or join us at a PTA meeting."

"This school has a wonderful PTA, but it needs help," writes a parent. "Parents should come to the PTA meeting. They are held in the morning and the evening. The schools reading has gone up and the teachers and children work very hard. I have always been well accepted when I have visited the school."

As a parent at PS 164 for the past 3 years, I can confirm the environment is very special.  It is so supportive and caring.  The children feel this and know the teachers and administrators care for them too.  The well balanced diversity (the school has 4-5 official languages including Bengali and Arabic) which means that every child feels included and special.  Differences are celebrated and welcome.  Ms. Steinberg is masterful at recruiting only the best teachers and keeping some traditional, yet welcome things like school uniforms and good attendance certificates.  Importantly, the school is small enough (compared to other elementary schools) so that needs of parents are addressed without too much formality. The school has amazing extracurricular programs/features that many schools do not have the funding to have such as a beautiful library with school librarian, a state of the art computer lab with Apple computers, both science AND STEAM classes, music, gym, art and others.  The PTA can use more parent involvement but has come a long way considering that the PTA was only formed a couple years ago.  Many of the families have 2 working parents so engaging them can present challenges and the strong work ethic directly shows in the classroom and school.  You know it's a good school when your child doesn't want to miss a day of school, even with a 90 minute a day commute.

Just want to say that Ms Steinberg is an amazing principal. The caring n nuturing environment. that she has created along with her wonderful teachers ,n staff have given my child a new outlook on school .For the first time my child is happy going to school. Iam so greatful for the hardwork n caring my child is recieving from ps164 😁

"Great school for children with special needs. Principal Culkin and the SBST is educated and informed. My son has ADHD with serious behavioral problems. Instead of suspended him to push him out into district 75 they are fully supporting him with the use of a structured IEP, Behavioral Intervention Plan, Reward system and a structured schedule. Its only been three weeks and its been slow but I do see signs of improvement. I am a parent who cares about my son and will help him in every way. I'm well versed in the IDEA law, special education rights, school discipline code and chancellor's regulation A-443. I'm glad to see PS 176 stepped up to the plate to support my son in everyway. I'm confident with time I will see a vast improvement. He is bright and has learned so much in three weeks. The last school he was in at PS 163 (see my review) did nothing for two months. I agree, the regents class placement does seem very biased. My child was told all year long that it doesn't matter if you have a hundred average or an 80 average if she did not want you in her regents class you were out.

As a student who attends this school, I believe that this school is biased and there is a great deal of favoritism, especially with selection of the Regents class. The Regents class is supposedly open to 'the 30 highest average 7th graders' but was chosen (in 2014/2015, at least) by who was the teacher's favorite. For example, students with 96s weren't getting in while 89s were, including students with lower conduct than others and lower state assessment scores.  The Regents teacher also lied about the selection, guaranteeing placement to whomever she 'liked' and then, when the placement was done, she defended with 'I had nothing to do with the placement'.    As well as favoritism in that, teachers only select certain students (usually their class favorite) to be part of school events (the ribbon cutting ceremony, enrichment, monitoring) and give extra credit for no reason. The teachers at this school, as well, lack patience and often do not grade assignments but rather grade solely on, once more, favoritism. Also, whenever a student protests something formally (not rudely or by confrontation) they are immediately lectured and reprimanded.  When a parent or guardian contacts an assistant principal, they literally respond with, 'please do not bring this up again. What's done is done'.
