I am no longer feeling the same about this school as I once did.  First and foremost, the school is ill equipped to handle the JHS population.  The lack of enough lockers have children wandering from class to class carrying backpacks that are just way toooooo heavy for them to carry.  Engrade is a system that is widely used in this school  which enables teachers to list the grades of students and all of the homework and projects that are either complete or incomplete.  My son is in 6th grade and I can tell you that only the Science teacher Mr. Amato, and the Math teacher, Mr. Xia use this system faithfully.  The rest of the teachers which include Mrs. DiClementi, Mrs. Quintana, and Ms. Holcomb do not.  So as a parent I am left wondering what my child's grades are and what assignments are due.  I am also not a big fan of allowing the children to do their homework while in class. Which many teachers seem to allow.  What's being taught in class if you are allowing the children to complete their homework in class?  Also, nepotism runs rampant in this school.  Many staff members have either their own children, or their siblings that attend this school along with some of their personal friend's children.  These children whom everyone knows in the building are the "chosen ones" who are allowed to participate in all of the activities that many other children are not chosen for strictly because they are affiliated with these certain teachers Mrs. P, Mrs. Q, and Miss. V. in particular.  These "chosen children" are the ones that participate in the Color Guard, Violin concerts (both Spring and Winter regardless of their playing skill) take first place in Science Fairs year after year, and win a seat in the studen government, etc...  It really sends a poor message that it doesn't matter what you do, whether academically or musically, you will not be chosen because you are not within the "chosen crowd." The Principal really needs to take a look at what's going on and  bring this school back to a place where students enjoy attending and are treated fairly across the board.  Looking back now I am so sorry that I allowed my child to stay in this school.  I really should have entertained the idea of attending another Middle School.  The SeeAll Academy has left a really sour taste in my mouth.
they choose certain people to play the violin and do color guard because they only take the pople that actually know how to play.. so you should relax

this is an absolutely absurd school. for my son's senior trip they went to six flags. after only a couple hours it began pouring rain. kids were scattered everywhere, freezing cold. some got lost, others got sick. to add on to that they had to walk throughout the whole parking lot to go to their bus. not only was the yrip ruined due to the weather only after a couple of hours but the buses were air-conditioned the whole ride through while the kids were soaking wet! they didnt even offer a refund. DISGUSTING SCHOOL. did they not even check the weather because if they did this would have never happened!

So far we have had an excellent experience at this school. My daughter is now in 7th grade. She absolutely loved her 6th grade teachers and is having a similar experience so far this year. There are plenty of arts enrichment courses at this school and the quality has been great. The homework has been reasonable. The projects have been interesting. The guidance counselor is great. We quarrel about the dress code, but if that's all there is to disagree about, then things are going swimmingly. I'd highly recommend this school.

There is a fair amount of enrichment ( ie: dance, recorder, French, violin, theatre etc.)  Mediocre academics. The school appears to follow the standard curriculum.  Not much creativity in teaching core subject. Crafty tasks are enrichment and considered creative.  Higher functioning children are given general academic instruction.  No differentiated instruction.  Science and math instruction needs improvement!  Administration is not so easy to talk with.  They seem to be more interested in discussing the SEEALL enrichment program than core academic improvement.  A lot of emphasis on test prep!!

I attend this school and would like to say that it is INCREDIBLE.  A lot of the teachers are awesome...they have a very good theater program.  Many kids were accepted into Specialized HS 5 children got into Laguardia.  The guidance consular s are very supportive.  The academics are well taught.  Tons of new enrichment's are put in.  My only issue is that we go in very early and come out a little later than some other JHS.  But anyway i absolutely love this school and will miss it very much.

Anyone have any comments on Ursula Annio's experience as a principal?  She is currently the principal at PS 748 and a friend of mine is considering sending her daughter there.  However, I personally did not like how the administration was run at PS 180, so of course Ursula would more than likely carry forward the same philosophy over to her own school.  PS 748 is a new school and has no track record, it just opened this past September. Does anyone have any comments on Ms. Annio, the success of the school would depend on the principal. Please advise.

"As the parent of a child who has attended PS180 since kindergarten, and now is in the 6th. grade, I am very disappointed in the way they are running the school. Many 6 and 7th. grade students do not have textbooks that they can take home. You can down load the books at home on your computer, but you cannot print it out. How do they expect students to study for their midterms without textbooks. I do not think it is approiate that a student should have to sit in front of the computer to read close to 200 pages to prepare for a mid term exam. As far as homework goes, I truthfully do not think that these students get enough homework. Then again, how can you give homework in certain subjects if they don't have textbooks at home. I would give this school a "C" rating."

"The school may be a good school for mainstreamed children, but is an extremely poor choice for special education or other special needs students. These children are saddled under a "zero tolerance" environment and are suspended for any infraction. They are not getting the services that these children are entitled to and paid for by the Federal government. A complaint is being filed with the the Federal government regarding how those funds they are given is being used."
10 years later the same problem still persists

PS/IS 180 received a grade of "C" on the city's 2007 progress report; Assistant Principal Ursula Annio attributes the grade to the fact that the school has many high-achieving students, who set a high bar for measuring student progress, the most important criterion on the progress reports.

Middle-school students tell Insideschools they have a lot of tests to prepare for but that teachers help them practice and gain confidence. According to Assistant Principal Ursula Annio, "we approach test prep as a genre," as part of the year's curriculum. Ongoing, additional preparation is "embedded in instruction. It happens daily and in context, in order to make it most meaningful for the students."

A parent writes that PS 180 does not do a good job of educating its special education students. "They have teachers who don't have a clue as to the needs of these special ed children or how to handle them and the classrooms are out of control," this parent writes. "Instead of getting teachers who know how to handle children with special needs, they just suspend the children. This is cruel and unnecessary."

"This school rocks," write student Samatha. "All the teachers are awesome especially Mrs. Fusco, Mrs. Viola, Mrs. Sapio, and Mr Nanfra. Your child should attend this school and also have these teachers. If you pick this school you have made a right choice."

A parent who moved her children into PS 180 from a parochial school regrets that she will be pulling them out when they move to Florida soon: "I hope I can find the same kind of school there. I wish I had put them here sooner -- they came from Catholic schools and wouldn't go back if I made them. The teachers are fabulous."

A 5th grader in the Delta program says the school is "very good. My teacher's very nice and doesn't scream like some."

A parent complains that the curriculum spends "too much time on the testing. They don't wait for the kids to really learn before they go into another area. They are teaching to the test."

The art teacher says that all of the federally funded arts money for the 2004-2005 school year went to pay the band teacher: "Band has become an incredible motivational tool. It was just that important."

A teacher of a class dominated by students who are learning English says, "my only gripe is class size. I'd like more time to have individualized instruction. It has nothing to do with my English language learners though -- they work beautifully together."

A woman whose friend sends her daughter to PS 180 praises both the Delta and the standard program there. "My friend had no qualms about putting her younger child in the regular kindergarten program at PS 180, writes the woman, who found the office "warm, helpful and informative" when she considered seeking a variance and enrolling her own child there. "The scores are great and the student body is diverse."
The mother of a 5th-grader at PS 185 is one of many fans of the DOE's new web service, NYC Schools Account. Read more here.
Mr. Llinas retired in June.

My
family and I recently relocated to Bay Ridge, Brooklyn from the state of
Arizona. The process of moving is daunting but the reason we settled where we
currently reside is principally due to public school 185. Despite the plethora
of information on public schools in New York I relied heavily on the Inside School
website, friends, and family members. For us, the ideal schooling environment had
to have a communicative staff, familial representations, highly educated
faculty with a curriculum that could engage the student critically (despite the
common core) along with hands on activities and a well-rounded program.  My family and I are satisfied with our school
choice and our daughter is extremely happy at PS 185. Without a doubt, this
school has welcomed our daughter and we feel as a part of the community.

My wife and I visit PS 185 and was not welcomed very friendly by the main office secretaries. The first impression I received was that the school does not have nice people working for them. The second impress I received that the school did look very clean and things were in order. We did not have an opportunity to talk to any of the teachers. I truly hope they are not like the people in the office because if they are then I am very concern about my daughter attending PS 185. Maybe it was a bad day but you know that first impressions are everything. I can only hope for the best, I will give the school the benefit of the doubt for now. Good luck to all the parents whose children will be attending PS 185 in September.
Don't judge a school by it's office staff. Principal and teachers are what matter.  This is a good school.
I hope so.. thanks.
Does anyone know what was the end result of the progress report for PS 185 in Bay Ridge. What did the Board of Education grade this school. Thanks

I Love P.S.185 so much! I am present at this school in fifth grade and graduating. All the teachers and students make you feel welcome and happy. The staff makes learning fun and enriches the kids. So far, I definitely have o say that i have gotten a better education at this school. I am going to be so upset to say goodbye to P.S.185 yet I am happy to start a new journey using my excellent P.S.185 memories. There are so many programs that make kids have a blast!!! I will never forget Mr.Grimaldi, Mrs. Perilli, Ms.Wrigley and the extraordinary present principal, Mr.Llinas. Mr.Llinas has always been there for me and supports every kid in the entire school. I will miss P.S.185 so much and I totally recommend this school for other people because P.S.185 is a special, gifted, remarkable, awesome, educational, fun, and an EXTRAORDINARY school that I will always visit in the future to bring back great memories and is a school that i will never, ever forget.

Right Now, I am in 5th grade and graduating and 185 will be a memory hat I will never forget. There are so many nice people in this school, including our present principal Mr. Llinas. In 185 there are a lot of sport and art programs. We have a track. -team, inter-murals, art contests, and our incredible art fair. You shouldn't listen to those other comments because P.S.!85 is a great school with learning made fun and very high-educated students, teachers, and parents.

As others have said, this review is very out of date. There is no violin program, no G&T program, no science or computer rooms. Remaining programs leave much to be desired. In particular the computer program, where children graduate having had no exposure to word processing or other standard software, and where children are more likely to watch The Magic School Bus than use a computer during class.

TIme for an update to the profile. My son is finishing Grade 1 at PS 185. We think it's a very good school, but kindergarten year he didn't learn the violin, or any other instrument. The science room and computer room have been convertred into classrooms to help the school deal with ongoing issues of overcrowding. Also the school will not longer offer a Gifted and Talented (or Delta) class for incoming kindergarten kids; kids in teh program at 185 will go up and out, but no new G&T classes are planned there for the forseeable future, in part to alleviate the abovementioned crowding issues.

"The last two posts are unfair and just plain wrong. Firstly, the school has a fantastic art program. Just take a look at it's halls to get a sense of the quality. Further, due the existence of one more cluster than there are periods in the day, each class goes without one such as art and another, computer and the rotation is never repeated for a given class. For the motivation behind the last post, one need look no further than the fact that it was just announced that ther will no longer be a g&t class at the school as of the coming September. Many people are understandably upset by this news (which was made well after g&t applications were submitted!) especially if they an older child at the school and are not zone. However, many feel spurned and resort to unwarranted insults. PS 185 is more than deserving of the "hype"; other top elementary schools have done the same thing such as PS 29 in Cobble Hill and PS 116 in Manhattan."

"Time for an update to the profile. My son is finishing Grade 1 at PS 185. We think it's a very good school, but our kindergarten year didn't learn the violin, or any other instrument. The science room and computer room have been converted into classrooms to help the school deal with ongoing issues of overcrowding. Also, effective June 2009, the school will no longer offer a Gifted and Talented (or Delta) class for incoming kindergarten kids; kids in the program at 185 will go up and out, but no new G&T classes are planned there for the foreseeable future, in part to alleviate the abovementioned crowding issues."

"We heard alot of hype about this school before our oldest daughter was admitted via the Delta program. However, we have been very underwhelmed and disappointed in the school based on 2 issues: 1) The administration's unwelcome attitude towards parents (e.g. I was refused entrance into the school for my own daughter's birthday because i forgot my ID, even though i had bags of party favors, a tray of cupcakes, and my daughter and the asst teacher recognized me on sight at the security desk) 2) Lack of creativity and activites for the students outside of the base curriculum (which is very cookie cutter). Often art or music class consists of watching videos about art or music. The school seems to be caught up in their own reputation & popularity which has bred complacency, and losing sight of enriching the kids experience and perhaps creating a more challenging curriculum instead of working out of canned workbooks every day."
"My son is in 3rd grade and has NO art class at all," writes a parent. "I do not feel that art is valued at all at this school. The science room is no longer in existence either."

According to the city Quality Review Report, "Very good conditions for learning have been established through strong teamwork, well-organized classrooms, and resources and students who are confident and buoyant learners."

"The staff, and especially the teachers, is extremely supportive and helpful," writes parent Dawn Faraj. "The Math and ELA programs are also terrific." This parent adds that she wishes the school offered enrichment, sports, or foreign language classes.

"My school is great!" writes a student. "And yes now we have a science room and computer room! And kids in fourth and fifth grades can monitor children in kindergarten and first grade! I am in fourth grade so I monitor First! Now I really don't want to leave next year!"

I am a parent of an ESL student.  I read that students should be getting 8 periods a week of esl in NYC but my son only gets 3 periods.  The administration of this school is not doing their job to give students their rightful ESL services. Who monitors the school to make sure they service our children? If you are a parent and are looking for quality schools for your child, do not send them here!

According to the NY Daily News, the test scores at PS 186 have risen by 10% for math and by 7% for reading since last year. School staff and parents are attributing the improvement to the school's extended school day, which keeps students in school until 5:20pm. Read more here.
Students at PS 186 won top honors for their anti-bullying PSA in a contest hosted by the DA's office. Read more and watch their winning video here.

Last year, P.S. 186 adopted the ExpandED program, which extended the length of the school day, giving students more opportunities to receive support and to participate in a variety of activities. Watch a video about the program here.

Principal Bayan Cadotte explains how teachers are implementing the Common Core standards encouraging students to do many hands-on projects. Read more:Bayan Cadotte: Have Teachers Share the 'Wows and Wonders'.

My son currently attends kindergarten at PS 186. His teacher is great but I find the school completely unwelcoming and harsh for new parents, it is impossible to get information from the school. The staff seems irritated when you call and you are not allowed in the school like it is in lock down. There is little or no technology used at the school and when I suggested an email list rather than all information being sent home in the backpack I was scoffed at. Seems like these kids are getting left behind.

"Hi. ITS a 2008 grad of p.s.186. i must say p.s.186 is a great school had great kids and some awsome teachers for example Mrs.Morano, Mrs.Setaro, Mrs.Berntstein but the school did not provide any special programs for gifted children. WELL thats it."
PS 186 has been added to the state's list of schools needing improvement under No Child Left Behind because of inadequate performance on the state tests in English.

A 2000 graduate whose brother now attends PS 186 notes several improvements, including a strong and organized chorus program and the fact that "the school accomodates the needs not only of struggling students, but of gifted students as well."

"The school is made up of very committed people. We've been able to have a very motivated staff," says principal Bayan Cadotte.

"There's an appreciation rather than an expectation by parents at this school," says the parent coordinator.

As a student of 187 from the years 2014-2017, I guarantee that Mcauliffe is a great school that educates their students and provides them with activities that enriches a student's time here. I'm going to assume that this school still has the same reputation as one of the top middle schools of borough. However, although Mcauliffe is special in my heart, this school really is like any middle class school in Brooklyn. It is important to understand the drawbacks, for example, we technically don't have clubs, though a lot of schools have them. If you are a parent, please do not push your kids too drastically to come to this school; the middle school that you go to does not really matter in the long run.
So what HS you end up attending? Did most of your classmates go to specialized HS?

Annually anywhere between 75 to 80% of IS187 students receive an offer to a specialized high school, and many receive offerse to top screened schools as well. 

The education my child received was excellent and advanced relative to other middle schools, it is very rigorous. The one drawback is while a gifted school, there is only 1 regents class - Algeba, its not not offered to everyone (test in). The Superintendents programs in D20 all offer at least Algebra /Living Environment and some US History to their 8th graders.  

There are quite a few clubs and teams since 2014 and the after school offerings by NIA.

a seat may open up here if a child of a high profile DOE employee leaves NYC....

Somehow her child snagged a seat at IS 187 when it is impossible for us regular folks
https://newyorkschooltalk.org/2019/05/its-the-hypocrisy-stupid-nyc-school-choice-for-some/

mcauliffe was a good school, emphasis on the was. they're not that great at managing schedules, and as a result, some classes have an extra course. for example, when i was in sixth grade, my schedule didn't have music, health or spanish while others in my academy and grade did. as a result, in eighth grade, my electives were health, music and civil engineering. we were supposed to have two years of spanish and one year of 3d printing/robotics, but they gave my class two years of tech, which was unnecessary imo. not to mention, our spanish teacher was absent for half the school year bc of maternity leave and the sub spent four months only teaching us the alphabet. 

i personally feel that it's ranked so high because of the title it carries, which attracts smart kids. it's not that the school's good; the smart kids that enter 187 keep the ratings high. 

i will admit that i enjoyed my time at mcauliffe and i did learn a lot of stuff, just not as much as i wanted to. if you want to enter high school prepared and ahead of others, i'd recommend schools that offer more high school courses. mcauliffe only offers algebra despite teaching earth science, life science (living environment is what it's called in high school) chemistry and physics.

I was in the Science academy. This school carries the idea of being the best while in fact the cracks in the school are often overlooked. This school lies with it states that it "allows students to take the Algebra 1 regents" because it cherry-picks the highest performing kids to take the regents course so the school can then brag how it has 100% passing grade on the regents with the lowest score being a 83.

The lunch periods are separated into academies instead of grades.

HI.  Anyone know what scores/grades were accepted into the school for incoming 5th grade - Arts and Humanities or Business and Law?  thanks.

I'm a freshman at Stuyvesant and have graduated from this school, the environment is very friendly and teachers as well and there is no doubt your child will leave with great memories, however personally this school did not prepare me well for Stuyvesant but my friends who have also been accepted into stuyvesant seem to be well-prepared, so i believe the academy influences how well the future will be. i was in business and law academy. some teachers do place very high pressure on students while others are very lenient, the substitute teachers are amazing and committed, the school encourages parents successfully and the programs that are held annually are very, very fun. my year admission was completely different than what is now, we took the olsat, i'm not sure if anything is different now that it's based on a variety of the student's record, but overall i am very glad i was accepted into mcauliffe. and if you want your child to get into a good highschool, i recommend the program A+, it really prepared me :-)

I am deeply appalled by the comments made by the
anonymous post 15 days ago.  I have two children that attend(ed) IS 187 in
two different academies and have only praise for their English Program and for
all the educators employed by the school. They are charismatic, caring,
seasoned professionals who have truly enriched my children's education.  I
have never had any issues with the teachers or the administration with respect
to my children and praise the education they were given wholeheartedly.  As
far as the allegation that children are sent to the administration without
caring to speak to them, I am absolutely shocked.  Our experience was very
different.  My children were nurtured, challenged and happy to take part
in the many extracurricular activities provided by the school.  Race is
not an issue at this school.  All Students are treated equally.

It is Middle School Open House Season!!  I have been meaning to post about my son's incredible experience at IS 187.  McAuliffe is a school that is filled with teachers who are passionate about their subjects.  I often marveled about the number of truly experienced teachers under one roof.  Although each Academy has different electives, the core subjects are the same.  Subject departments meet to discuss curricula and Academies meet to discuss how to best meet the needs of their students.  Due to the Academy system, the school is basically 3 small schools within a larger one.  This atmosphere allows students to get a lot of personal attention.  It is true that many students do a lot of extracurricular academic work; however, my son did not and was able to be extremely successful in his academic endeavors.  The majority of graduates do attend Specialized and/or Screened High Schools.  This is a school for earnest students and families who take their child's education seriously.  Additionally, the school has a strong community with Parents and extended family enjoying potluck dinners, together.  The PTA organizes Meet & Greets, workshops, High School Fairs and many other activities.  If you want your child to be successful and your family to feel a part of a community, this is the place for you!

I am kind of disappointed in this school and can't wait for my kid to finish the last year there. The school should appreciate the heavy population of Asian students and their parents. It wouldn't be able to keep good grades and high ranking without those kids' great contribution on extra studies and homework from private classes after school and on the weekends. Not from the teachers, period. I don't think most of them are good educators. The English curriculum has never really worked out. To my kid’s academy, for example, during the last two years, if without some serious writing homework from one of the teachers (non-ELA subject), I don’t think those kids could write anything good after middle school.
The most unpleasant thing about this school is that the attitude from some of the teachers, including the administration is unacceptable. They prefer to simply send the students to the administration office without caring to talk to them. If you want your kid be treated as a kindergardener, be quiet, and listen and follow,  then this is the right school for them. If not, then  you’d better be ready to hear something uncomfortable about your child, making you feel like your kid had done something unforgivable. Don’t get me wrong, my child is an honor student. But is it wrong if your kid eventually wants to be invisible in the school?

As a student of Christa McAuliffe, i disagree with the opinion of teachers not being educators. The teachers here are welcoming and warm and they have strong past experiences on teaching.

NOTE: The Christa McAuliffe School does not have a set number of accepting students in their school. As a past applicant (last year), I have experienced it. After sneaking a peek at my class' overall score (in the Scientific Academy, which has been rumored as the hardest academy- it is actually way easier than expected), many people got 4s, but if you get high 3s (such as a 3.8, which is the most minimum), and decent report card grades, and satisfactory attendance (as required by the New York State, at least a 90% attendance for promotion), you can guarantee a spot in the school.


Also, according to schooldigger.com, The Christa McAuliffe School has been ranked as #1 in the entire New York State. The Anderson School, the known gifted and talented school, is now number 2. Be proud.


Lastly, please do not ask about what is the minimal state test score is. There is NO SET NUMBER. The staff at the school DO NOT know what is the minimum. They receive a list from the Board of Education and go from there. If you have any questions, ask the Board. THE SCHOOL WILL NOT BE HELD RESPONSIBLE FOR ANY MISCONCEPTIONS, SO DEAL WITH IT.


Thank you, and good luck!


P.S. Answering Sophie Lin's questions, there are no such thing as 757s. There are 343s (4.00), 402s, (4.50), and 360s (4.09), etc. If you are talking about the combined scores, they would not do the total score, for God's sake. They would do each one separately, find the overall percentile you rank, and there you go on priority listing. (BTW, 757 combined is about a 379 per subject. Again, you might get a 2 and a 4 and that is how you got the 757. That is why they don't do the scores combined.)


P.P.S. SCIENCE STATE TEST SCORES DO NOT MEAN ANYTHING FOR ANY OF THE ACADEMIES. THEY DID IT FOR THE SAKE OF 8TH GRADE HIGH SCHOOL PLACEMENT, BUT DON'T ASK QUESTIONS ABOUT THAT. WHY DON'T YOU JUST LIVE YOUR LIFE AND WORRY ABOUT 6TH GRADE AND GETTING INTO A SCHOOL THAT YOUR CHILD LOVES AND NOT THE PARENT'S DECISION?! AS LONG AS THE CHILD IS HAPPY, YOU ARE HAPPY!!!
By the way as in 757, its the combined score and for both math and English, I got higher than 4.0. Moreover, guess what? I got into 187!

I go to this school, I have mixed fillings. Some teachers are just rude. They will seriously go up to you and say “Who are you?” Like seriously? I freakin go to this school for a while now. I am very happy for you but you may be one of the few who had a great experience at Dyker Heights.   This is my child's first year at Dyker Heights and it has not been all that great.  The feeling of caring teachers and administrators are few and far between.  In elementary school there was a sense of community, teachers and administrators that support and cared for my child's academic and social whole.  There were teachers who remember the names of their students, even the gym teachers who have more than 20 classes each.  Then you're not feeling as if you're a number, such as at the doctors office...very impersonal.  I noticed during Parent Teacher Conferences that some teachers did not know who my child was.  As a parent, I'm wondering if a teacher who does not make the effort to even remember their student's names feel they themselves are a part of the Dyker Heights community in order to create a warm and nurturing environment for the students that they teach.  I shall be optimistic that these teachers will create a feeling of warmth, respectful and nurturing environment for not only my child but for all new 6th grade junior high students.  This is especially important because all milestones are critical, it can make or break you!

I graduated from 9th Grade in 1967.  When I first entered the school in 1963 it was in the last year of conversion from K-8 to a Junior High School so I was in the 6th Grade and spent four years there.  This was Mrs. Brennan's first year.  All of the teachers that I had are retired or gone and the principal is still there.  She did a great job. I had some inspiring teachers like Mr. Spina and Sam Learner.  And who could forget the Asst. Principal, Mrs. Sitak (spelling) or the Dean, Sam Pappas.  They were tough but really cared.  I learned many lessons from those people.  Lessons that helped form my character and led to a successful life.  I thank all of them and pass those lessons on to others whenever I have the oportunity

I am a 2006 graduate of Dyker Heights, an alumni of Stuyvesant High, and a rising junior at Cornell University. In retrospect, I had a great experience at Dyker-- some great teachers and wonderful classmates. However, on the whole, the vast majority of the teachers were unqualified and many of its students--delinquents. I am amazed that I survived the pre-specialized high school school system. It abhors me every time I think about my middle school education. A plethora of unqualified and just plain bad teachers, a lackluster sentiment amongst the vast majority of its students, and an environment non-conducive to an educational environment. Don't get me wrong-- there were some great teachers there and some highly motivated students, but on the whole, I would not send my kids to Dyker. If I have a recommendation, I would send your kids to private school if money is not an issue.

I was a student at Dyker who graduated and is now at one of the specialized high schools. SP is the superintendent's program, but SM is the science & math program. Solaris Zabinska is wrong. SP is not better because the students in that program are usually not as intelligent as the ones in the SM program. The SM students take the Algebra and Earth Science Regents. The SP students usually take only Algebra, while some may also take Earth Science depending on which teacher and class they're in. The Regents scores for the SP students are lower than those from the SM ones, and the SP students get into high schools that are not nearly as good as the ones from the SM program. 

You have a better chance at getting more credits if you're in the SM program.

I went last year also and the man that spoke then was able to explain about the programs much better. I just left Dyker last june and now im in high school and all I want is to go back to Dyker. It was really an amazing experience that i will never forget. In 6th grade it was a pretty hard transition going from elementary school to junior high school, starting to take a language, and having different classes like drama, art, vocal/chorus and band. I was an the SP class for all 3 years and it was great. In 7th grade the school had every student in the SP and SM classes take every class there was so we can be open to things when it came to high school. We took our regular classes, our language, physical education and then we had to take two out of the three (drama, art, vocal) that we haven't already taken in 6th grade. In 6th grade I had drama, so in 7th grade they gave me art and vocal. We still had the same day and schedule except some days that we didn't have gym we would have one of those classes and vice versa. Out of all the years 8th grade really had to be the best. When you hear the saying "i saved the best for last" it really was true in Dyker. 8th grade had THE BEST teachers, the best activities, probably the most work but you got rewarded for it. There were dances, the senior trip, field day, you literally ruled the school, you knew all the teachers and almost everyone else in the school and you took high school level classes. I took the earth science regents and now I started high school with 2 credits already thanks to dyker. Also if you're in the vocal program, for any grade, you have performances every marking period at school and when i was in 7th grade we even performed in Carnegie Hall which was amazing. If your in the play, there's a big play for all grades every spring and it's really fun. If your in the band they have performances all the time with the chorus(vocal class) and also perform at hotels, other schools, other graduations, our graduation, the open house and much more. And if you enjoy art there's the Halloween window painting contest, for the play the artists of the school create the scenery and backgrounds and much more.
           Back to the teachers, they really wanted you to learn and wanted to help you. They were always there for you and wanted you to do well and see you succeed which is a really big part of education, if you have no support and motivation, why do it? But the teachers here know what their teaching and tell it almost like a story and not right out of a textbook because they're doing what they love and aren't just there to get paid.
            If you're reading this and looking to go to dyker heights junior high, i highly recommend it & guarantee you will have an amazing 3 year journey.
is201 is the best school in district 20

The only issue I have about this school is that it's over-crowded. I also suggest that the school make's the walls and classrooms more "colorful". These type of things raises the children's mood and could affect them in a good way.
Bare walls and not enough classrooms is not an issue here. The problem is the unsanitary conditions at the stairways, cafeteria, and sometimes even in the hallways.

I am currently an 8th grader at Dyker. My experience here has been somewhat neutral. I have been in the SM (Science & Math) program ever since I began my academic journey at the school. It may be due to my strict and overbearing teachers (more on them later), but on some nights I will easily stay up past dinner time completing homework and studying for upcoming tests. On very harsh days, there have been four tests the next day and an equal amount of homework assignments from each class. In addition, each homework assignment takes me roughly 30 minutes to almost an hour, depending on the rigor of the assignment. In the 8th grade, I have only encountered two days in which my class was not given any homework what so ever: the days before books one and two of the NYS ELA exam. I'm not sure what Solaris Zabinska is talking about when she claims she only receives homework two days a week. Perhaps it is the fact that she is in the SP program, which is not as rigorous as SM.

The description of the school is highly outdated. We do have somewhat of a law curriculum established at the school, but I wouldn't exactly call it "law." This magnet "law" program only occurs over one week, and involves students basically yelling across the room at each other over a case. There is **ONE** mock trial done for this "law" program, which Inside Schools exaggerates. Most of the time, however, the teachers are lecturing about law, forcing us to copy down notes. 

The architecture program at the school is nothing to come to Dyker for. It simply consists of 6th grade science teachers devoting a month or so for students to work on a project in which we build a structure following a certain theme. Nonetheless, it was certainly one of my best academic experiences at Dyker. I wish they would repeat it in the 7th and 8th grade.

About the teachers...oh the teachers. It ultimately depends on who you have for a teacher that will determine your overall learning experience in that subject. One teacher this year seemed **VERY** devoted in teaching her subject (will not mention names due to privacy). Unlike other teachers in the building, she seemed to genuinely enjoy what she was doing. She really has inspired me in many aspects that other teachers cannot match with. On the contrary, there are other teachers who are dictatorial and make class seem like a prison cell. I hate to say this, but there is most certainly favoritism with teachers. These are the students that don't have to earn their grades the hard way.

There are some experiences at Dyker I would like to keep. A few being the Shakespeare Festival, the school plays, the dances, the trips, the learning done in some classrooms, and the art instruction. 

And also, if you complain about the lunch, there's nothing a student can do about it because Dyker is a NYC **public** school. As a result, the city provides the food frozen to each school. It may not be the most appealing or appetizing meal, but it is food. And I highly doubt the lunches are expired because the NYC Department of Education would be breaking the law (I believe) by feeding us expired, potentially dangerous food.

I HATE SCHOOL

Before my child entered this school in the fall, I had heard and read positive things about it. Old-fashioned academic rigor, discipline, enrichment programsall of it sounded quite attractive. The reality has disappointed me greatly. While some teachers may be professional and caring, the administration is bureaucratic and non-responsive. They do not handle parent communication well, especially if you seem to challenge them for the school's shortcomings. My 6th grader has no form of art or computer instruction during the school day, and no choices were offered even after insisting. Since I escalated my query, the school finally responded that it "overlooked" the New York State mandatory arts requirements and apologizes for the "oversight." It has promised to work on this matter so that all 6th graders will get access to some type of arts instruction, which has been denied in the past through "oversight."

Does Dyker believe that basic computer instruction should be limited to smart kids only? That various forms of art should be offered only to a select group? Are we talking about a private institution or a public school here? Every school in Brooklyn has its share of underprivileged and immigrant kids who do not get exposed to computers, art, and extracurrila activities through their families. So I.S. 201 does leave these children behind? Why do schools of less fame offer these programs universally? It is scary to think that this school may have deliberately chosen not to practice the No Child Left Behind philosophyand by that, we shouldn't focus on the three R's only. Or is it pretentious to assume that middle school education should include something else besides Math, ELA, science, and social studies, and gym?
I don't think there is a single "bare wall" in this entire school!.  Students' artwork is everywhere, as well as displays of projects, reports, etc.

Why would anyone complain about a school being "overly academic"? I am a parent of 2 children in Dyker 1 in 8th grade and 1 in 6th grade and my husband and I are pretty happy with Dyker. The kids going there are happy and learning. Dyker offers language, computer, music, art and drama for children that are doing well academically and are in Superintendent and SP. These children can handle the work load because they do not need extra help in their main subjects. Even with budget cuts, this school still has after school programs for all children to attend that need help in their subjects and they have the CHAMPS program. My husband and I think the teachers and staff at Dyker do a good job with the little they are given. IS 201, Dyker Intermediate School is an overcrowded school but the children are safe, happy and learning. This is due to Principal Brennan and her caring, competent staff.

PS204 has been a good and bad experience for my family. 

Currently there are difficulties with our 3rd grade class. Difficulties are in terms of communication from teacher to students. Students all stare at a 4'x3' smart board on a daily basis and come back with partial information about homework, exams, new site words, etc. Teacher refuses to use the PS204 website to post homework. If the use of a 4'x3' smart board is for the better of the students, then why not use the website to post all homework and relevant information? We're in communications with all the parents in the class and we are gathering puzzle pieces in order to find out half of what's going on in class. Since the beginning of the year we have spoken with the teacher, administration, vice principle, and all have oppose of the use of website. Why are they holding the parents back when we want to be involve and yet the the principle is completely unreachable because the administration would not let us speak with her. Principal - Mrs. N. Tomasuolo, if you are reading this, please give reach out to me. I may not be speaking for all the parents in the class, we definitely have 10 parents who would love to see some changes for the better. We understand that kids should have responsibilities as well for getting the information, but if the whole class is having trouble following the work and the parents have no idea what to work on with them. Isn't it time for the process to be changed by even just a step forward?

Pre-K and Kindergarden has been a blessing. They have multiple programs and workshops for kids. They are interactive with kids and have been a great encouragement for my little one. The teachers that are in the class are always flexible with the kids and encourage their creativity to expand. My kid loves her class and classmates. Her teachers always compliments her for the creativity and work that she has done. The class gets rewarded for participating and toys are given as a reward. I feel like this process has open my eyes on how compliments and encouragements can do wonders for little ones.

"Schools Chancellor Carmen Fariña will attend a CEC meeting at PS 204 to meet with parents to discuss such issues as student achievement, school finances and the de Blasio administration’s educational goals, the Brooklyn Daily Eagle reports.

This school is not what it used to be. The school is overcrowded and the faculty cannot handle it. Average students are neglected. Test scores are going down. There hasn't been a teacher that I have absolutely loved or am fond of. The principle does not make herself available at all. Instead she puts all issues on the parent coordinator.

PS 204 was a terrible environment. From 1st grade to 5th, they were some of the worst years of my life. I was a student at PS 204 from 1995-2000. I was also in the "tear" program, the schools gifted program at the time. The teachers were abusive and demeaning and none of what happened back then would be tolerated now. Three of the worst abusers were Ms. Starobin, Ms. Shelse and Ms. Scala. They are the reasons I went to college for Childhood Education, to become a teacher the exact opposite of how they were. I guess I should thank them for the motivation. Ms. Starobin would throw chalk at students, insult them and encourage other students to make fun of her targets. Ms. Shelse would pick favorites and demean students having a hard time. Ms. Scala would yell at students like a drill sergeant (but worse) for the simple act of forgetting to bring something to class. These teachers (and many more) do not realize that children are just little people, not emotionless robots. Guess what? Students remember. Treat your students like human beings and find a balance between discipline and respect.
i still go to ps 204 and mrs scala is the best.
I'm glad you have a better experience than me and other students.

i was a student from 1990 until 1995. i feel that the environment was always inclusive of all students despite their abilities, and students that did very well were appreciated and recognized for their achievements. the principal and assistant principal knew who each student was and knew what they were capable of doing. the teachers recognized good work, effort , and all achievements. each assembly included the hearing impaired students and they were applauded through appropriate sign. looking back, it was a great environment to learn in. i am a child protective specialist for nyc and if i could, i would send my children to p.s. 204 if it is the same place i grew up in.

Very dissatisfied with the way the school is being run this year.  The school moral has gone down you can feel it when you step foot in the doors of the school.  The indians all have to follow the big chief even if they dont agree with the policies, fearing the reprocutions.  The big chief does not stand up for everyone only the ones she feels she has to please.  The big cheif should be more respectful of others and their feelings, our kids go to the school also!!! I could go on and on, but it really does not matter because its a waste of my time...talking to a deaf ear.  I have already spent enough time on this.  Dont go by what the school administration says, ask the parents how they truly feel about the school and if they have a back bone they will tell you the truth.

Because of the teachers, not every teacher in this school is so great, my daughter had great one only in Kindergarten and 4th grade...that is not enough.4th grade teacher cannot do all work during one school year and kids need to be prepared for NYS test.

PS 204 was identified by Standard and Poor's School Evaluation Services as having reduced the achievement gap between its students who are economically disadvantaged and those who are not.

"PS 204 is a fabulous school with so much to offer children," writes teacher Michele Ferraro. "The teachers are hard working, dedicated professionals who always give 110 percent of themselves for the children." She says that the principal is a "spectacular administrator" who keeps her door open to staff, parents and kids. "I wouldn't send my two children anywhere else but PS 204 for the best public education in Brooklyn," Ferraro says.

"This is a topnotch school," says the co-president of the parent association who praised special activities such as class plays, a school yearbook, a chorus, band and an opera program. "We do a lot," she said of the PS 204 parents.
In the 2012-13 school year, 205 started a Gifted and Talented program. The after school is now sponsored by the Brooklyn Chinese-American Association.

I went to this school from Pre-k to 3rd grade because I had to move to Manhattan. Anyways, I loved this school. I missed everyone there. I had great teachers and once they found out I was moving, they really missed me and seem to care about me. I wish I can still meet them. I miss them so much. :)

"I was in this school for only 5th grade and i fell in love with the school. I didnt want to leave 205 at all."

it is a great school i went there in 4th and 5th grade and when it was my first day i felt like i was apart of the school forever the teachers are amazing :)

"The school and teachers are great, however the principal is horrible. Four of my children attended this school and this woman is definately not principal material, she can not compare to the previous principal who was a role model. The teachers are definately the highlight of this school."

Beth Grater has been the principal for years.

"The public school choice is always an adjustment for Orthodox families. But by and large they are happy with what we are offering here. The school is very accommodating to provide [prospective parents] visitation so they are comfortable with the choice they are making," says the school psychologist for bilingual Yiddish students.
"If you set the environment and have high expectations, you will be amazed by what they can accomplish," says a kindergarten teacher with a class full of newly arrived immigrants.
"I take violin, which got me into Bay Academy," says a 5th grade finalist in the city ballroom dancing competition.
"This school is great. It has great education," a 5th grader says.
"The teachers are great and they help us with school work," a student says.
"They want us to stop eating junk food, but they keep selling it," says a student about the long line to buy potato chips.
"They say we can't run or play games, so what's the point?" says a 5th grader about recess policy. "They should let us do more stuff at recess."

Alexa, a student, writes: "This school is great! I love the teachers. I have nice friends." However, she writes: "I think that some things in this school should be changed. I think the idea of no talking at lunchtime is ridiculous. We don't get [to] talk in class, so I think we should use that time as free time. In school we should be doing more work in class so we [wouldn't] have so much homework." She concludes: "Overall, I think this school is great with the programs, the people, and the teachers."

A mother whose four children have attended PS 205 says, "it is a very good school. They have a lot to offer." She praised the orchestra, the chorus, and the student government. "There's so much going on," she said.

Great school, with U.S. History, Living Environment, Earth Science, Spanish I+II, and Algebra I. Although you might think the school is bad but, if you are gold you shine. Each teacher offers the most to help their students, giving up their lunch period and off periods to help suffering students to perform their best. Also, if you ever happens to be in honors, good for you, enjoy all the extra trips you can get. Spanish is offered to everyone, as long as if you pick it for elective, your grades does not matters it is the efforts that decides if you get Spanish or not from freshmen year. 

So if you want to know about grades here I will show you grades of my class (aver.):

ELA: 90
Math( Algebra): 86
Science(Living Environment): 88
Social Stud(U.S. History; 11th grade regent): 84
PE: 95+
Spanish: 90+

Steven Vavasis of I.S. 220 accepted a “Community All Stars” plaque presented by the Daily News between innings at MCU Park in Coney Island for excelling in his classroom and community. Read more here.

I have just graduated from I.S.220 with high honors and was one of the two people who got into Stuyvesant. Honestly, this school sucks so bad, it's a joke. Out of the many kids that graduated, approximately 10 kids (should be a little less than that) received admission into a specialized high school, that's not the worst part, the teachers don't give the attention needed to failing students, they just spoon feed us the information, they act like they care, but yet they don't (this does not apply for EVERY teacher)My class ( I can't say from the others but I'm sure it wasn't only my class) was, how can I say, lustful. This guy who got a 1 on the math state test, instead of actually realizing he's failing school and should help his grades, just disturbs the class with sexual noises with others laughing and joining him hoping to drag everyone else down with him. I barely saw the principal in my 3 years of attending this school, less than 10 times I guess? It was like the assistant principals did everything. I appreciate the dean's help on trying to discipline students when they do wrong, but she does it the wrong way. She instills fear into them hoping they would do right instead of just asking the guidance counselor for help, not like the guidance counselor does much either. We had no recreational activities to interest us to learn, no field trips (like BARELY), my class personally never had any field trips except something like six flags when we were graduating. In 6th grade our English teacher just made us feel bad she didn't take us to the aquarium and mocked us because we were talkative, like hell, she put it in our faces for a whole week before she went. There were some memorable teachers, but I do not prefer their teaching, for example, in 6th grade, our Social Studies teacher let us play on the laptop for the last 2 months before summer instead of actually learning something useful. Sure, I might have enjoyed it at the time, but I still don't agree with what he did.The atmosphere is also intense, we have certain kids trying to pick fights with others and we have others who were extremely invective. We had our 8th grade English teacher saying that 10 years ago, it was way worse, but it still is. I almost had to ask my parents to call 311 because my class and several others stayed in the auditorium because some of us kept talking and by the time we got to eat, we had 2-5 minutes to eat, which is barely enough time to have a proper lunch, which I can personally say doesn't feel legal to me, nonetheless the fact that our grade was the last grade to eat lunch, so we were hungry enough. I mean I was fully aware that some people in my class were failing some subjects in school, I was also fully aware that if I knew, I'm pretty sure that the teacher could figure it out too considering she has all the test scores and etc. And yet we were denied any REAL help with issue we have in mind. Hell, in 8th grade, I have to say my math teacher was a nice person, in times, but I felt like screaming at times when she threatened to call my parents for using the word "Hate" in her class in the context of hating group work, because at times my group was full of slackers. The ONLY, AND I MEAN ONLY, memorable teacher I had if anyone was my 7th grade math teacher, who at the time when he became my math teacher was his first year teaching, and you know what most of my class mates did? They exploited that fact, and talked all year long and misbehaved when he tried his best to help them excel in their work.
I know this school is one of the many that are not the worst, but I truly hated this school with all my heart, I liked some of my friends that I made but if I ever came back to this 3 years worth of memory in my life, I would not enjoy recalling it.

I have recently graduated from this school and I have to say my 7th and 8th grade years have been the worst of my life. The teachers I had were great and have helped me grow as a person, but the other staff and students are what ruin this school. The hallways are always a congregation of kids  standing in the middle of a hallway cursing and being rude, half the kids at the school don't even speak English which is very frustrating when you have to ask them to move out the way. The deans at the school don't know how to disciple the students and always overreact. For example every time a student comes to school late even if they were 3 mins late or 3 hours late they would get detention which is very embarrassing because you have to sit up front of the auditorium and eat last and to make it worst you have to sit at a certain table during lunch. The guidance counselors are the worst, they don't act in a professionally manner and are never there when I needed help. Overall if you really care about your educational future then by all means this school is the right place but just know that the students and staff will give you hell

I am a 7th grade honored student in this school and I wanted to transfer in the beginning of 6th grade because of all the bad comments and what people say about this school. Teachers BEWARE:  Not exactly the best place to work.  While there is one solid administrator there (not the one in charge),  you will find that this school is not managed well.  They motivate with threats ( 'motivate' is really stretching it) and do not know how to efficiently manage people.  Had these individuals been in management positions in any other sector, they would not have lasted long.  There are high attrition rates here in terms of new teachers and there is a reason for it.  They do not provide solid mentoring nor do they offer any constructive criticism.  Criticize they will most definitely do, but not in a manner that will help improve one's performance and grow as a professional.  Like most schools here in NYC, the main focus is test scores and most administration makes this their obvious priority (although they will try to claim otherwise).   There are plenty of good teachers at Pershing, but in all honesty, those in charge do not belong where they sit.  One of the assistant principals should actually be the principle himself and the others need a solid lesson in how to manage people... adults and children alike... hopefully learning that you cannot and should not treat adult professionals like children.  Unfortunately, this is all too common in our schools here in NYC.

This school is kind of a hit or miss, some of the teachers are very nice and want you to do well, so they'll give you opportunities to improve your grades. My grades got better but the students got me involved in many sittuations that caused so many conflicts each year with my own personal life and family.

"strong visual arts program"
yeah, it would be strong if they hadn't decided to up and remove the visual arts program from the eighth grade. even though every classroom is equipped with a smartboard, most of them are old and worn, flickering between being barely alive to shutting down completely. the staff is mostly nice, i'll give you that, but some just don't seem equipped to work with kids. i'll give you the full rundown of this place.

now, i've only been in the delta program 6th, 7th, and 8th, so my knowledge is limited to that section. what i can tell you though, is that they have higher standards for delta than the other classes. they'll say to the delta kids, "oh, you should be better behaved and participate more because you're DELTA."
just because.
the only reason that they can give us.
is that we're "'delta"".

completely insane, considering that the only thing changed about delta's curriculum from the original curriculum is that we go a wee bit faster and we learn algebra before the other classes.
woah. such a big difference.

with the classes, they sometimes grow to become cliques, and then there's little cliques in the class clique and uGH you get it. the 6th and 7th grade girls seem more like stereotypes of what people think high school teens are like. i'm talking instagram, tons and tONS of makeup, gathering in the bathroom, the whole "becky you can't sit with uS" cliche, jesus there's a lot of cliques, seRIAL DATERS (think about this. think very hard about an 11 year old having 5 boyfriends in a week and flaunting her nonexistent boobs everywhere. ew.)
i just don't like it.

i naturally have a lot of spite and pettiness bottled up within me, being the ~angsty~ teen that i am, but nobody has aggravated my petty side like mrs. vinciguerra, the 7th to 8th grade english teacher. she is the Worst(TM). she's gotten fired two times, eats her stupid salad in front of the class while simultaneously scolding us for eating, chides us for having a pack of gum on us and then asks for a piece of said gum, and on her instagram (which is public, mind you, i'm not actively stalking her), she does pole dancing. also, my parents (and a few others) thought she was high at the parent teacher conference. i wouldn't be surprised if she was.
wow. what a great teacher. let your kids follow her example.

aaand there's mrs. mejia, the spanish teacher. she's very loud, and her eyebrows are obviously drawn on. she also gives a lot of homework, but it doesn't really matter in the long run if you do it or not. other than that, i have no comments on her, except that a lot of people don't pay attention in her class.
including me.
what can i say, spanish makes me doze off.

mr. rosenberg (7th-8th grade) and mr. g (7th grade) are both great social studies teachers, no complaints there. though, mr. rosenberg is a bit eccentric, but he gives cool projects like going on strike and making pop art pieces. mr.g is also an ela teacher apparently, but i've never had him for ela.

mr. lovell, the science teacher for 7th grade, is chill as well, and (7th and 8th teacher) mrs. zhang's accent makes for some hilarious mispronounciations of certain names. mrs. zhang gives fairly light homework, and if you read the textbook you should be fine. she constantly reminds the class about how she doesn't need to be likeable in order to be a good teacher, which is a bit annoyingly repetitive of her.

mr. sherman, the 7th grade math teacher, is a wacky dude who tries a little bit too hard to be the "cool" teacher. he calls the class "shermanland" and his "day without math" project is extremely repetitive. also, lots of homework, oops. mrs. caban, eighth grade teacher, is really mellow. she gives us a break in between double periods, and she jokes around a little bit too. homework load is average.

mr. kelly, the PE and health teacher, is really adamant about us not sitting on the bleachers in PE for some reason. there's always a few giggles when he brings up condoms and intercourse in health, but he lets it slide.

mrs. oppel, the music teacher, is the type of teacher who will assign you so. many. projects. oh lordy, she's got a load of projects for you, but only some of them get finished. she also runs band.

oh uhhh, i think that's it for the teachers. if you have any questions or additions to this, comment them.

I must be the insane parent who they are all speaking of.  Facts: twice my son was abused/bullied and the school did nothing.  In 6th grade he was pantsed  (his underwear and pants were pulled down in class) and his entire lower body exposed!  Guess what the principal did? NOTHING!  

Then a few months later the same bullies brought in photos of guns and told my son they had guns under their parents beds and were going to kill him!  I requested a meeting with the parents Zappulla said NO!!!!! 

AGAIN guess what Zappulla did???? NOTHING!  I called the cops.  I am not going to let my child get bullied.

The cops forced Zappulla to call the parents in ASAP!

I also called the superintendents office where Mitch of the superintendents office stated to me "are you done with your rant?".  I said when the Daily News learns of this Mitch are you sure thats your reply and his attitude quickly changed.  

The math teacher does refer to his class as Shermanland...Look at the schools math and english scores since Mr Harrigan left...they have gone down!  Run dont walk away from this school if you love your child.  It used to be a good school not anymore.

If they blame your child for anything ask to see it.  They have cameras all over.  Numerous times my daughter was told she would be punished for supposedly doing something wrong.  When I asked to see her actions on their cameras GUESS WHAT?  There was no video of her doing what they were trying to blame her for!

I am sorry your children had to go through that. Did the kids who bullied your son ever get suspended for their inappropriate deeds? 

Zappulla does not know how to handle these situations. He ignores phone calls, emails, and letters of complaints or concern from parents. He does not address their concerns more often tha not, avoids starting a dialogue with the parent. Perhaps he does this to stall and buy time in the hopes that the parent cools down and forgets about the original issue of concern.  I see this as a major leadership flaw.

The Daily News reports that according to teacher surveys, Principal James Harrigan is among the top three most trusted principals in the city.

Principal James Harrigan received a 2006 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and continue serving as principal at the school.

Parent Angela Koutelos writes: "I have two children that are attending PS 229. I could not ask for a better educational experience for either of my children. Mr. Harrigan, the principal, is the epitome of what a supervisor should be. The teachers are wonderful! They far exceed their occupation's obligations. They truly care about the children. My children love their school, their teachers and their friends. What more can a mother ask for?"

"I just would like to say my son is getting the best education by being in PS 229," writes a parent. "I couldn't pay for education this good!" She describes the school as safe, and adds, "the PTA answered every question I have without making me feel clueless." She describes the teachers as "the city's best" and students who attend as "good kids."

"When my son got accepted into DELTA, I thought, ok, good learning education. I laws wrong. It is great not just good," writes a parent. She writes that her son had trouble adjusting to entering a new school in the 1st grade, and "the PTA people helped me so, so much. The teacher and principal were both informative and very caring. Now, a few months later, my son is doing very well. It also helps as a working parent to know the security guard there is on the ball. I can go to work with no fear and know my son is getting the best education."
Oof
P.S. 247 is number 9 on reading proficiency (57.64%) and number 7 in math proficiency (84.39%)in a high poverty school for 2014 city test scores. Read more here.

The parent of a 4th grader and an 8th grader who graduated, tells Insideschools: This is a great place to be. Kids get what they need. My daughter was a struggler, now she is in the honors program in middle school. It’s the support that she got here. The 4th grader gets extra activities to do so they don’t get bored. She comes to school at 7:20 to help the school aide at breakfast. She loves to be here." The parent, who is active in the PTA, says parent participation is lacking "They know they’re in a good spot. A lot of children are being raised by grandparents because their parents are working.” Parents are invited in on the last Friday of each month to play math games or read to the kids, she said.

PS 247 was one of six NYC schools to receive the 2013 Blue Ribbon Award from the United States Department of Education. The Blue Ribbon schools are recognized for their academic excellence and their success in preparing students for college and careers. Read more here.

I remember a time when I came in late because of a bus delay cause by a snow, anyways I lined up to get a late pass. I noticed how the front desk was extremely nice to the student in front of me. I graduated from Mckinley, I would say it’s a pretty decent school (academic wise), I like how they offer high school level classes and professional teachers. However, there are many students that are extremely racist, during the start of the COVID pandemic, many students made racist and hurtful comments. I wish they would make the superintendent program admission more difficult. As a former student at this school, I feel like the academic environment is also crucial. But in this school, many students get discriminated or called as “nerds” for trying harder at school. I honestly think students go to school for education, and the fact that this school couldn’t provide me with the best environment for learning leaves me discontent. Furthermore, this school leaves me more insecure about myself each year, I often feel like I have to act or dress in a certain way to be accepted by my classmates. Also, I feel like I matured during my three years at Mckinley, I slowly realized how not everyone is going to accept you for who you are. Overall, the academic in this school is better than most, but the racism really causes a stain on you, it really pinpoints that you’re not the same.

I’m a 6th grader at William McKinley. This school was generally amazing. Some teachers may be strict but honestly the stricter they are, the better you’re get. I had Mrs. Zogby as my ELA teacher and though she is strict, she helped me so much and I improved so much. For the first trimester, I had a 87% average but now I have a 94% average. My math teacher, Mrs. Georgalas, is such a smart math teacher. Don’t be shy to ask her if you have problems. She is strict in her learning but kind. Join a club or something because there’s so many things to do. Also, due to my amazing teachers, I got into NJHS which is a honor program. Hope this help any incoming 6th grader.

I, myself , am a six grader in William McKinley. I really love this school and I receive top grades in class. I’m not trying to say that the work is easy but hard work pays off. The teachers in this school are very nice but I have to admit that sometimes, kids get away with things too easily. In my opinion, the best teachers I’ve had to far are Mrs.Kim(science), Ms.Livi(French), Mrs.Georgalas(Math), Mrs.Zogby(ela: strict but helpful), and Mrs.Soriente(social studies). I love all my teachers and I know in the near future, I will continue to love this school. I highly recommend this to school to any applicants applying for their middle school.

I just graduated this school and I now attend Stuyvesant High School. I personally loved McKinley, it was whee I learned to be my self and opened up to speak my mind. I loved most of my teachers to name a few Ms. Gillen(math), Ms. Dixon(ela),Ms. Basile(social studies), Ms. Blank(Algebra I), Ms. Coughlin (U.S. History), ms. Turner (living environment). These teachers knew how to handle kids and they taught us in the most effective way possible. If you get them you are really lucky. Especially Ms Turner, she was like a second mother to us because she would always help us when we were upset. The kids were nice and even I there was bullying you could always count on others to stand up for you. I myself hadadebfriend with a sixth grader and a seventh grader when the were getting bullied by crappy people. Yes there are crappy kids bug what school doesn't. Here we learn to embrace ourselves and not care what others think. The guidance counselors were really nice to me and helped with family problems or when I had a bad experience with a teacher. These three years were the best in my life I met the best people in the universe that I can trust and love with all my heart. So thank you mckinley I will miss you.

I am an 8th grader in McKinley myself. Personally, I don't think the school is that good. I've had both racist and sexist teachers who have allowed certain students to get away with missing homework. Besides that, the troublemakers hardly get punished. In fact, they are apparently the "cool kids" and are free to curse at teachers while also physically bullying other students

As a parent, you here about students committing suicide so often and you sit back and wonder why the school didn't do anything to stop it. From first hand experience, I realized why kids commit suicide. This school is the worst ever. My child was bullied for four months straight and all the deans and guidance counselors did was just entertain it and just keep taking statements about the incidents. It finally got so bad I had to remove my child since the students received no consequences at all. To all the parents thinking of sending your child to this school, think very long and hard about it. Kids should be going to school to get an education and not worrying about being bullied. Adults are the ones our kids turn to for help, not for them to sweep things under the rug as they say.

I work at McKinley and completely agree with your sentiments. There used to be a strict dean's office for years, one that knew how to get things done. Then 2 years ago the principal put one of her cronies in the dean's office and everything went down hill. The teachers are in an uproar because they refer problematic students to the dean (and guidance) all the time, but nothing ever comes of it. The principal has received a raft of complaints that troubled, even dangerous students are misbehaving, yet the deans just sit back--and she refuses to do anything to change it. The story we hear from the dean's office is that troubled children need "love and understanding" rather than punishment. What's even worse is that the deans have turned their office into a lounge of sorts, where the problem kids get to hang out, have pizza parties, go on to Youtube and play cards. The worst kids in the school are being treated like kings and queens, not having to go to classes or do work. They tell their teachers to f*** off. Obviously if they can get away with this they can get away with bullying your child. It's disgraceful what's happening there. 1700 kids and absolutely no discipline or consequences. Eventually an innocent child is going to get hurt.

McKinley's superintendent program is good, but I don't recommend coming here. The school is not that great, and the deans are not good either. I think your brother should go somewhere else. Im in 8th grade and as time goes by, I honestly can't wait to leave.

I am going into my third year in Mckinley, and i have to say it is a fairly good school.
The teachers are very good and helpful, and there are many clubs to join. Although the teachers are helpful, they tend to favor certain kids and reward them with good grades, even if the kid sometimes acts up. Also, the school is a bit crowded, making transitions from classes harder on kids. But overall, I would have to say that Mckinley is a fairly good school.

My second year in this school has come to an end, along with the stress of maintaining my grades. The teachers made it very clear that 7th grade was the year in which your grades mattered the most. I tried so hard to get good grades and i'm very disappointed that I only got a 97.92 for my overall average for the year but I still think It's certainly enough to work with. I had a few meltdowns where I cried myself to sleep because I got a grade lower than a 90, but besides that 7th grade was fun and challenging. I was able to move up to an honors class and will now be in the virtual enterprise program once 8th grade starts. My opinion that this is a great school and the fact that I would recommend it to anyone has not changed. But I cannot stress enough that my own mental state during 7th grade was not a byproduct of the teachers. It was my own perfectionist and stubborn nature which led to the crippling anxiety and stress I felt. I know many other people who were able to get averages which were 90 and above, which handled the situation a lot better than I did . After my one week break I will start studying for the SHSAT and Bard entrance exam. I know i'll try even harder next year to get VERY high grades because i'll be attempting to be valedictorian. I know my grades are not the best but I think it is a possible goal to achieve.

A JHS 259 parent writes, "Teachers, administration and staff are all highly dedicated and caring. The curriculum is rigorous and keeps the children engaged. There are always teachers and staff to help the children, whether it's a question or to help with school work. The Arts program is unlike any other junior high school, as well as the extra curricular activities offered. The entire 3rd floor is covered in murals on the walls and ceiling, all painted by the students over the last 5 years. Students are offered an elective in the performing arts and they get to choose from: band, keyboards, dance, drama. Extracurricular has: cheerleading, student government, clubs, sports of all kinds, art and drama/play. This website is no longer accurate.  McKinley recently added an extension to the building with state of the art technology and well-equipped classrooms.  This has solved the over crowding issue that for years required innovative solutions.  
Additionally, the mural has now expanded to various floors and has been covered on a variety of news stations due to it's scale and student involvement.  Additionally, while the school has been on the Schools in Need of Improvement list- it is there for two subgroups : English Language Learners and Special Education self contained classes.  Meaning that these two groups have been unable to achieve gains on the English Language Arts test.  The general education group has had consistent success.
