In 2006, students at IS 259 began a mural in the hall that captured what they learned in class.  This mural has continued to grow.  Read the story: Classes Come and Go, but the Mural Grows and Grows.
In the last couple of years, the school has introduced more after school activities, an 8th grader told Insideschools. "Now we have dance, volleyball, choir, and golf," she said.
"We can offer a lot more than a small school can," said Assistant Principal Carney Haberman. "Yes, we're overcrowded, but we can offer more."
IS 259 has been added to the state's list of schools needing improvement under No Child Left Behind because of inadequate performance on the state tests in English.
"I loved this project," says one student. "[Painting the mural] was a great experience that shows me how everything is connected."

In April 2007, the school unveiled a student/professional painted 45 foot-long mural in the schools hallway, which depicts art deco styles of the 1930's in New York City. Images include the Chrysler building, Rockefeller Center, and over 60 samples of student writings. Over 50 students painted the mural. They painted before school and during their lunch periods. According to a press release, "One mother said her daughter had never been happy as a child, but now she can't wait to talk about what she's doing in school. She loves what she is accomplishing, and is radiantly happy with herself."
Student Juan writes that he has learned a lot, "the teachers make it fun," and the "students get a chance to be involved in the school government."

"I'm in 7th grade now and I love it," writes student Andrea, who adds that she likes the school's various activities, including dance, drama, chorus, keyboard, and band. This student adds that overcrowding causes problems: "when everyone in the academy goes to the auditorium, someone always gets hurt and someone always gets in trouble." Andrea praises the school's principal and security guards and the "open mic" at lunch, where students can express themselves in the cafeteria.

"Three discrete academies (math and science, social studies, literature and art) offer some accelerated, Regents-level courses; honors track students come to school one hour early," writes Helen Zelon of BKLYN magazine.
A former student writes: "I went to McKinley for my junior high school years and I loved it. It is a terrific school. The teachers are very kind and helpful. I learned so much in that school."

Kevin, a senior at McKinley, writes that although "the school itself is good," "the flaws are unbelievable." He complains about the quality of his Spanish class, that "there are no other languages besides Spanish," and that "the gym classes aren't doing anything but running." He notes that "the school is sort of overcrowded, but that really doesn't bother kids." He writes: "The good traits are the drama and dance classes. The teachers Ms. Cooper and Ms. Applegate take time to get to know students. The teachers are good teachers and give you the work that is necessary, instead of pointless busywork."

The staff at McKinley is generally responsive and the school has been a good place for her 13-year-old son in the two years he has been there, his mother writes. One gripe now, however: his Spanish class has been taught for more than three weeks by a substitute.

Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced 73 schools selected to join the Learning Partners Program, an innovative and collaborative initiative that brings schools together to share practices to improve learning in the classroom and raise student outcomes. Through the program, one host school with strong practices in a particular focus area will support two partner schools seeking to strengthen their own practices in that area. I must tell you.  I love PS 503 for my daughter... I had such a hard time finding the right school for her, and her mediocre grades showed it. But once finding PS 503 when she was entering the 3rd grade, we all knew it was the one. Every single day, when I ask her about her day, she said, " AWESOME!"

She improved her reading and writing levels dramatically in a matter of months. The teachers are a perfect blend of gentle and firm! Very effective. They encourage their students, and see their potential. They meet the students where they are and teach. I love it! 

The principle is present and available. She meets us, greets us, has coffee with us, listens and encourages us. That's right! She encourages the parents to stay involved in our children lives. Parents as Partners with our children and their teachers.

There is much more to talk about, but you gotta just see for yourself, as I did. A school full of life, color, achievement, understanding, lots of smarts and creative ideas, and team playing.
Julia Garland, the performing arts teacher, writes that "many (25) of the classes at 503 also take performing arts once a week!"

"This is the first time I've had the experience of being respected as an educator," writes a teacher. "Mr. Weiner is supportive in every way from how we teach, to providing supplies and encouraging professional development." She notes that parents at the school are "very supportive," with most attending parent-teacher conferences, and that teachers volunteer to lead Family Fun Night and after school clubs. "We are encouraged to be creative to meet our students' needs."
Through initiatives such as workshops that explain the curriculum, teachers show parents how they can help their children at home, a Spanish-speaking mother tells Insideschools.
A Chinese-speaking mother says the teachers are good and conscientious, although sometimes they are strict.

The parent coordinator says Principal David Weiner has figured out a way for parents to "be in the building more" by having them volunteer at lunch or inviting them to bring brown bag lunches to eat with their children in school.

PS 506 is among several schools in Brooklyn to get funds for new playground equipment. The projects were voted on by residents of District 38 and will be paid for out of City Councilman Carlos Menchaca's participatory budget process. Read more here.

Principal Elizabeth Waters received a 2011 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor an aspiring principal while continuing to serve as principal at their school.

Principal Waters commented on the operations and programs at PS 506. "Things have really changed quite a bit since the split from PS 314. We now have a journalism teacher and two technology teachers, and a large majority of the students are in one of those programs. We have a school newspaper that the journalism program works on; it publishes twice each year. We've also got a Young Violinists program, along with drama, arts, and dance, and each of these activities have a literacy thread in them. The literacy focuses on reading, writing, speaking, and listening." She also commented on sharing the building with PS 503. "The shared space was worrisome at first, but it actually works out very well. We have weekly meetings to talk about what's working and any problems. We're happy with the arrangement."

After doing research and hearing all the wonderfull reviews I find this school to be among my top choice for him, however my only hesitation is the schools diversity. With the school being 65%white 4% black 11%hispanic 19%asian does anyone know how the school is handling there diversity problem. My sons previous school offered such a great diversity of children I would be concerened that he would look around and have no common identity with anyone that looks like him which could and does lead to insecurties and shyness that could impact his education. Concerned mom

The school cant do much to control the diversity since parents have to choose the school and then admission is by lottery.  I am latina and my kids are mixed. My son is in 2nd grade and in his grade aside from other mixed kids, there are kids from arab descent.  I think there is diversity in the school in the sense of there being kids varied cultural backgrounds and relgion. For example the group of kids he is closest with all come from different backgrounds irish, italian, asian and latino/white like he is. Plus with the school having integrated general and special ed classes that is another form of diversity.  I think the kids learn to appreciate each other. This is our 3rd year and i have never seen any issues in regards to the kids mixing. The kids dont even notice the differences. i speak to my son in spanish and he has never shown being ashamed of his heritage. If you have not take a tour.

We are researching schools for our child who will be entering Kindergarten next year. All the reviews I've read have been wonderful; the teachers, the principal, kids, parents, new math program... So I was a bit surprised that it had a low grade on the 2011-12 NYC DOE progress report. I understand that it is a new school but was wondering if any familiar parties could offer any more insight?

Take the DOE grades with a grain of salt. It's a requirement for nyc to receive "race to the top" funding and is generally accepted as extremely flawed. For example, a school's grade can be pulled down if most of their kids are 3s and 4s and they don't move enough high 3s to 4s (equivilant of moving B+ to A). Meanwhile if a school's students mostly make 1s and 2s (the worst grades) they have more room to "improve." Kids are also graded more harshly based on their race (seriously!). The factors that go into these grades is also an evolving process and I wouldn't be surprised if it changes completely in the next year or two.

This is my 2nd year at the school and we have been active on the PTO.  I think there are a number of factors. One of them being that it is new.  Each grade is small, therefore just a couple of students can really throw off the %.  The students tested had attended school elsewhere.  We received a great score from the district - Well Developed.  This article does a good job explaining why some schools are well liked but get a low score http://insideschools.org/blog/item/1000472-is-it-a-b?-or-a-d%3F-im-confused

I am continually impressed by the quality of the parents and students. My children attended a private pre-school and to me the kids/parents here are on par.  Many of the parents are teachers and choose to put there kids at TAOTS vs their own school. There are parents with kids both at BSI and TAOTS.  Some parents travel for the kids to attend. At this point I feel secure that the scores will be better next year.

This will be our 2nd year at TAOTS and we loved the school.  The school environment is well maintained and one of the best you can find in the neighborhood.  From the welcoming smile and greeting from the guards at the door to the attentativeness we get from the teachers I am more than satisfy with the school.  One of the disadvantage is that since the school is so new, the adminstration is picking up and learning as they go.  So far I think they are moving towards the right target at least it's in my opinion.  

The quality of the TAOTS families are very good.  Parents that I interacted with have pretty high standard for their kids education.  The enrichment cluster class is an A+ idea that the school incorporate!  It introduces many different prespectives and learnings for our kids besides the core curriculum.

The teachers in this school are amazing!  They are a great group of young and energetic teachers who know how to make the students progress.  However, I question the administration's decision-making, specifically with the special education population.

We are entering our third year at TAOTS and couldn't be happier, my child is an ASD NEST child and it has been amazing to see his progress since he entered the building two years ago.  Combined with the great benefits of being in the NEST program along with the Enrichment Model, it is a great school with a hands on approach and a focus on the arts.  What exactly is your concern B_Mom?  Special needs children are everywhere, you might as well get used to it, they are not in the closet or sent away any longer....

My concern is not in regards to integrating students with special needs in the mainstream population, such as the NEST program.  If the NEST program is the least restrictive environment and the most appropriate environment for a child then I think that's great.  I am more concerned with compliance issues and a limited lack of knowledge of due process and parental rights.  The administration does whatever they want without making sure that 1) mandated services are being met, 2) they understand the implications of the special ed reform, 3) parental rights are not being trampled upon.  In the end the students suffer because the decision-makers have limited knowledge of special education.

Can you (or anybody) elaborate a little on the issues you see regarding the SN population?  I'm specifically looking into this school as a public school option for my SN kid.  We would not get into NEST (not ASD), so I'm interested to hear how well the school educates kids with IEPs in integrated/CTT (don't know if it's the same).
I am inteested in their special education services/programs. What are your concerns? Please share. thanks!

Dear Taots parents: we just got accepted to the school (K) and desperately seeking some current 2011-2012 reviews. Please please provide some info. How large is the class? Are your kids happy? Anything bad at all about this school? Many thanks for any feedback!

Welcome Tori,
The class size varies, regular class is about 25 kids, but we're blessed to have teacher assistants. My kid loooves the school. The only bad thing I can think of it is not K to 8 :(

I feel so blessed to be able to send my son to a choice
school.  I have been very impressed with
the quality of the kids and parents. There has not been one day where my son
has hesitated to go to school.  The administration has always been responsive to our questions and needs. The teachers are friendly, approachable and work with us to "customize" the work to fit our son's needs. I also
really like the after school program offered. It is so convenient that it is
held within the school. I am not sure what I would do if PS 682 was not an
option for me. - Kindergarten parent.

TAOTS is an awesome school with awesome teachers. My children started attending TAOTS in 2009. We have had a very good experience at TAOTS. Our children have done well here and gotten what they needed academically and socially each year. The parent community here is fabulous and works hard to support the staff.

I have two children at TAOTS.  The experience has been fantastic.  What has impressed me the most is the level of responsiveness on the part of the teachers.  My son was experiencing a challenge with reading.  I emailed the teacher and he was immediately reassessed and given adequate materials and assignments.  Today, I was confused about my daughter's field trip.  I sent an email and within minutes had a response.  The children love the enrichment clusters and I am amazed at the sophistication of the material to which they are exposed.

It's our second year in TAOTS and so far it's being an amazing experience. My kid loves it there and learns a big deal at a very consistent pace. The school strives to have the best enrichment programs, including enrichment clusters that incorporate kid's acquired knowledge into real life projects: theater, cooking, journalism, fun science, archaeology, ballet, taekwondo, movie making, costume creation etc. The school is also adapted Singapore based math curriculum, one of the most progressive math programs in the world. The principal(J.Sportella) is young, energetic and very progressive has highest standards and makes sure everybody upholds them! Exemplary school! Go TAOTS!

Our son is in K at PS682, and we LOVE the school. When selecting the school in the beginning of the year, we were worried, since no one really knows how the new school will turn out. Putting our son into this school was the best decision we could have made. The director knows all the children by name; she has a vision for the school that she's carrying out well, her heart is in it. The teachers take time to understand and address each child's needs; they use innovative teaching methods and respond very quickly to parents' questions. Unlike many local schools, PS682 has an outside playground, gym, beautiful art and music rooms. Healthy food choices are offered in the cafeteria. And the kids are just good, well-behaved kids who are eager to learn. The afterschool program is on-site; great program w/ awesome staff! This school is a hidden gem of Brooklyn. (And no, no one asked me to write this - it's just a great school! :-)

Our son is in K at PS682, and we LOVE the school. When selecting the school in the beginning of the year, we were worried, since no one really knows how the new school will turn out. The US Department of Education designated PS 748 a 2017 "Blue Ribbon" school for having test scores in the top 15 percent in the state, with students in all demographic groups scoring higher than at least 60 percent of students in their state, according to a US Department of Education press release.

The US Department of Education designated PS 748 a "Blue Ribbon" school for having test scores in the top 15 percent in the state, with students in all demographic groups scoring higher than at least 60 percent of students in their state, Chalkbeat reports.
Fourth-graders at PS 748 were among the city's top scorers on the 2014 English language arts exam, reports DNA.info. Read more here.
P.S. 748 is number 6 on reading proficiency (92.16%) in 2014 city test scores and number 10 on math proficiency (94.12%) Read more here.

PS748 is a great school! But now the department of Education wants to close the G&T program this year. Please keep this program open. My son is in Kindergarten and i can see the difference in the education he is getting with the G&T Program.
I just called them and the staff told me they are a zoned school, not by lottery, can someone tell me if this is true?
Yes, they are a zoned neighborhood school with a district-wide gifted program.
Iam so proud because my child in ps 748 the school is more than good and it prepare the kids for the future

Your detailed opinion of PS 748 is very persuasive. I am interested in sending my child to PS 748 but was wondering it they will be offering a general education 1st grade this coming fall in the event that my child does not make it into the G & T program. Are the general ed students offered the same educational opportunites (use of smartboards, enrichment programs, etc.) as the G & T students? I tried contacting the administration but was only given abrupt and terse answers and that there are no available slots thus conversation ended and i was not able to find additional information. I I could honestly say that the curriculum sounds impressive but i found the staff to be unhelpful and to me that is the first line of communication and they are sending very unimpressive signals with their lack of professionalism. But Dusty711 it is your post that makes me think otherwise and to overlook the administration lack of professionalism. i truly beleive that the staff should adhere to a higher representation and pride with the school instead of brushing potential students off. I found them very unwelcoming and this is not the first time i had called.

As both a parent and an educator, I can honestly say that The Brooklyn School for Global Scholars has surpassed any and all of my expectations.  The second I walked through those doors, I knew in an instant that this is where my children belonged.  Ms. Annio has created a safe, nurturing and welcoming environment from the administration and staff to the beautifully decorated hallways lined with children's work.  The curriculum is academically rigorous and is designed around meeting the needs of all students. Units of study are also designed around the interests of the children in the class.  My child was so excited to be reading, writing and learning new facts about the NYC subway system because it was so interesting to him.  I feel that the students are challenged everyday and I know my child is so excited every morning.  One of the unique qualities that the school offers is the Enrichment Program.  The students have an opportunity to participate in yoga, sports, acting, chorus and dance.  It is actually embedded into their week.  Not many schools offer such amazing programs.  I can go on and on from the technology, including Smartboards and Netbooks to Family Literacy nights, to the in-class publishing parties to the weekly newsletters!  This school has it all!  Ms. Annio is a wonderful leader dedicated to providing the children with a strong foundation, a well-developed self-esteem and the tools they need to be successful.  Her vast knowledge and dedication is evident in everything she does.  I am so grateful to Ms. Annio!  Thank you for the Brooklyn School for Global Scholars!!!

Is your child in the G&T program or general education?  My daughter has been accepted to the school but I am hesitate to send her here because it is so new and there is no track record for the Statewide exams.

My daughter is attending the first grade G&T class at PS 748.  When compared to her old school (when she was in kindergarten), this school lacks experiences and professionalism.  Even thought this is a new school, it could have been more organized.  The administration staffs are confusing and ill-mannered.  I regretted sending my daughter to this school.

My son is currently attending Kindergarten (G&T) at PS 748.  This school is absolutely amazing.  Ms. Annio, the principal, is a dedicated educator who is committed to the school.  She loves her job, and she loves the kids.  She is incredibly organized and incredibly dedicated.  The teachers, too, are absolutely fantastic.  My son's Kindergarten teacher is extremely talented, caring, kind, and absolutely efficient when it comes to achievement.  Under her tutelage, my son turned from a reluctant reader to an avid one.  He is reading well above grade level, and is excelling in mathematics as well.  The enrichment modules at the school are also wonderful, not to mention the Spanish classes that every child takes.  What's most important to us is that my son loves going to school.  He can't wait to leave the house every morning. PS 748 is a wonderful school, and I am so pleased that we picked it.

My son currently enrolls in PS 748 and I can tell you that it is a great place to be at.  The staff (security guard, office aides, paraprofessionals, teachers and Ms. Annio) is extremely supportive and pleasant to deal with.  If you like an environment where the prinicipal knows who your child is and can greet everyone (including the parents) by name, this is the place to be.  Ms. Annio and her team is great and their main focus is the children.  The teachers are truly putting the children first and they care about their academic performance as well as their emotional growth.  With very limited resources, they provided a lot of activities for the children.  Just in Oct/Nov 2010, we had literacy night, pumpkin patch/fall festival, thanksgiving events and class trips, just like any schools.  The school also found ways for our children to give back to our communities: Penny harvest and food drive.  At the same time, the school also encourages parent involvements and I am impressed at how involved the parents are.  We can discuss what we think with Ms. Annio freely, just like a family.  She responded to our e-mails and requests since the G&T enrollment period in April 2010.  We continued to e-mail her throughout summer and she responded to us.  I can see that she is dedicated to the school and the children, so are the teachers and staff.  Everyone works hard for the children and my child loves to be part of PS 748.  The PTA and the school leadership team is very thoughtful.  When we have night-time PTA, they came up with a brilliant idea: shared toddler sitting service.  If my examples above cannot convey how great this school is, I encourage you to stop by and check out the school.

I'm a substitute paraprofessional (Teacher Assistant) in special needs classrooms. My job sends me all over, I've been in many neighborhoods and classrooms. I've had the pleasure of working in this school on several occassions and in comparison to a number of schools, I think this one is great. The staff is really helpful and friendly and it shows in their instruction with the children. I've spoken to Ms. Annio on a couple of occassions and I recieved "good vibes" from her. One can tell that she loves kids and her job. Hope that helped!

I worked at PS180 for 1 year, and left to go with Ms Annio to her new school.  The problem at 180 was not Ms. Annio, it was Mr. Williams, the principal.  He has antiquated ideas of how a public school should run and was resistant to any new philosopies of teaching.  He has set education back 30 years by implementing a basil reading program.  If you want a forward thinking educator to teach your child, send them to PS 748.

Anyone have any comments on Ursula Annio's experience as a principal? She is currently the principal at PS 748 and a friend of mine is considering sending her daughter there. However, I personally did not like how the administration was run at PS 180, so of course Ursula would more than likely carry forward the same philosophy over to her own school. PS 748 is a new school and has no track record, it just opened this past September. Does anyone have any comments on Ms. Annio, the success of the school would depend on the principal. Please advise.
PS 971 second graders won a city-wide ferry naming contest; a New York ferry will now have the name "Sunset Crossing," WNYC reports.

My son was the first graduating class at P.S. 971. He just graduated a few days ago from the 5th grade. My whole experience from K-5 had it ups and downs. My son is currently reading in a 7 grade level. I love how my son is so advance in all of his classes. When the school first opened up on 2010 it was a rocky start very unorganized and no communication from staff most of the time. But as the years went by the school did improved but can do better.. The teachers was excellent. The principal I liked she was always interacting with the students. My son cried during graduation that is how much he will miss her and staff. I m not a fan of the A.P. Her attitude is very nasty at times. 
During the graduation it was so unorganized, parents didn't know what side to enter thru,
So many many parents including my self worked around telecommunications HS 3 or 4 times until one of the staff members lead us to the correct entrance. The ceremony was beautiful and very very unique I loved it.. 
But what upset me was the fact that students and parents was promise to receive a yearbook that was a part of the senior dues fees but the students never received one because it was not ready.. We are currently waiting for the school to mail it to us.

Overall I loved the education my son received during the 6 years in PS 971. But the school still needs to work on communication, and need to be more organized.

I gave this school a couple of months, but I'm done. My child's teacher was okay, but the communication from the administration was awful. We'd get little to no notice about things that required us to change our schedules, after two months there's still no parent handbook, the website is rarely updated, etc. Our family has felt brushed aside and disrespected since we enrolled (With the exception of Mr. H (math), Mr. A parent coordinator), and Ms. Kary (science). They tried. The front office, including the principal and vp, is the cause and location of most of the problems). The final straw was them losing the emergency card. My child sat there for two hours, and they never asked for alternate contact info, but I'm supposed to show them respect?? For what, not doing their jobs?! So we're done. I don't trust them with my child, and I won't send  my child some place I'm not comfortable with. We'll homeschool for the rest of the year.

Wow! first I wish that inside schools would visit this school again just to update some of the information.  So now its three years later and ps971 is still standing strong almost up to grade 4 with great results and yes still a waiting list in PreK AND K.  Still going strong with the diverse staff that educate the great students there everyday! 971 is a progressive school that consistently explores new areas to enhance the learning of the great students that go there. Ms. Ruth is the only principal that actually walks the halls and talks to ALL the children everyday along with welcoming ALL her parents with warm arms. 971 is one of the best schools in the area who truly has the interest of all their students at the heart and isn't that the point of school!!!! Go visit!

My daughter is going to PS. 971 and must say I am worried about this school by reading these reviews. I guess I will find out and see what happens. @ Sarah, can you give some of the teachers names so that I can observe if what you are saying is true. You were a little vague in your comment. @ chickdumpling 717, I didn't like the comment where you said she wants to get spots for her child. You don't know who it is and is already ASSUMING. Your comment is prejudiced. Like I said I am worried now. But I will see for myself. I plan to be very INVOLVED!

Who is this lady and where was she, if she had a child in the school, when notices were sent home asking for parent involvement?  What is she talking about when referring to”racism" at the school?  The school is as diverse as our neighborhood is.  I am one of the parents that showed up unannounced at the school and never had a problem or saw any yelling as her post states.  My son’s teacher was always available to speak to me even by email.  As an INVOLVED parent, I can SAY that the school is GREAT and has one of the most creative and innovating curriculum in District 20.   Ms. Ruth and the teachers are on top of their game.  My son loves his school and has learned so much.  This is the fact that counts.
Yeimi Korsberg

So why can't you respect my opinion. How do you know I am not involved in my child's education? You don't know anything about me. I talk from experience and from what I heard from the teachers and the parents mouths. In fact one teacher told me that a lot of parents yanked their kids out from this school, she also told me to run. She said there is a lot of things going on that even the principal has no clue. Time will tell. Case closed. My comment is not negative it is FACT!!!!

Unfortunately, it is only opinion until such time as you can present your case with documented evidence, at which point, I would accept it as fact. Until not, you have done nothing but say "other parents say" and other such speculative statements... Support your argument with fact. The fact of the matter is that among the other posters on this site, you sound like only one parent who has a negative opinion of a great school. Again, if you feel so strongly about how the school is run, then join the PTA and voice your opinion there.

Reading these comments again and say they are a big JOKE!!!!! I am not lying. Anyone with common sense can see that all these positive comments are coming from the same person. So what a waiting list that is because this school takes advantage of the non english speaking people. I am not hispanic or black. I am white and can tell you that there is a bit of racism that comes from the parents. I never said the principal was really bad it was her dressing that was a problem. She would wear a nice suit but then wear fishnet stocking with stillleto heels.

You must be working for the school. Please give me a break. I have experienced these teachers screaming at kids. Listen you will find out when u put you kids in here. I am telling you the truth. You are probably the same person posting all these different posts. You notice they all posted the same day.

Trust me... I don't work for the school.. In fact, normally, I wouldn't respond to such a negative post. I would typically chalk it up to a parent who has very little involvement in their childs development and just chooses to complain rather than do something positive. If you feel so strongly about how the school is run, then do something about it. Get involved with the PTA and make your voice count rather than hide behind your computer monitor and spout off... As others have said here, and no, I have not been the one to post all of these comments, I have better things to do with my time, PS 971 is a fine school with an excellent faculty that needs the support of the families that attend.

PS 971 is a new school. Yes, at first, the school seemed a bit disorganized, but you have to remember, the teachers and students were new to the building, procedures within the building were new, and in many cases not even created yet. Yes, there were the basic policies and procedures afforded to any school within the DOE, however, there are many site specific policies that needed to be created as the need arose. I can say, as a parent, and as the PTA president, I am truly proud of the staff at PS 971 for getting things together so quickly. If you remember at the beginning of the school year, the construction workers were still working on various aspects of the structure while Ms. Ruth and staff were trying to conduct classes. Not a simple task when working with 4 and 5 year olds who are naturally curious about their surroundings. The school is still learning it's role in the community, as does any new neighbor. Give them time... from what I've seen so far, things have improved drastically and they will continue to enhance their programming and community involvement! Way to go PS 971! Ruth, keep up the good work!

Peter Korsberg
PTA President

My grand daughter is in PS971. I have never experienced such nice people. The feeling of respect is all over the building . from the guard to the principal. Every one in the neighboorhood is saying positive things about Ms. Ruth and all the teachers. All of the children are treated the same. This parent wants you to stay away so that she can get all the spots for her family, I have been in the area fort 42 years and if it is who i am thinking of she has a big family. 
 
just a grandmother

I totally disagree .PS971 is by far one of the most innovative schools i've come across and i've been in the school system for some 13 plus years .I can see why everyone is trying to register their children there.
Stay away!!! This school is not organized and the teachers are unprofessional. There was a lot of parents who removed their children from this school.

Wow this comment is unfounded and does not appear to have any experience in this school.  My son attended pre-K at 971 and because we were not zoned for the school we couldn't enroll him for K.  I'm unhappy at our new school and just found out there is a spot for him back at 971. We are RUNNING back to this school.  I love everything about it!  I'm a teacher in the DOE and have been for 8 years and Ivy league educated.  I feel like I know a good school when I see one and 971 has such amazing potential.  I'm literally ecstatic that we can now continue to be part of such an amazing community.  The teachers have such a wonderful understanding of what is developmentally appropriate for children and I have never once heard any kind of "yelling".  Maybe this poster is thinking of the other school that is co-locating at the moment, but I have no experience with them so I have no idea.

I completely disagree. I concur that there was a ramp up period in the beginning but things smoothed out. My kindergartener is reading at a 2nd grade reading level and educated me about dinosaurs.  My one wish would be for more parental involvement in the PTA. 

Christine C.

If you are going to shed such a negative light to P.S. 971 school and teachers, maybe you should explain why. Otherwise, I find your comment w/no basis and unfounded. I have dealt w/the teachers and principal and can say that the faculty of this school actually have the best interest and intentions for the children. The principal is amazing and works diligently for her children as such do the teachers. For P.S. 971 only having one year under their belt  - they have done a tremendous job w/the school and kids. My daughter is very happy with her teachers - and that's the opinion that counts.

This person must have the wrong PS971. The PS971 in Bay Ridge has the best staff ever. There are schools that have principals that make the cover of the Daily News. There are schools that lose 25% of their staff annually. There are schools that can’t fill the seats that they have available who are underdeveloped. This is really sad. PS971 in one year has already become a staple in the community and will continue to be successful and fantastic.

I believe that it is truly a shame that someone would write a blatant lie about such a great school. The school has 99% occupancy, and a waiting list that has more names than seats available. The school had 100% of the parents fill out the schools survey. All the facts will come out once the survey is published. Ruth is an Amazing principal and the staff is awesome.

Students from PS 90 got on their soapboxes during a public speaking competition called “SoapBoxNYC” at the New York Historical Society on Monday. Second grader Jamie Torrez recited a poem called "Stop Racism," according to AM New York. Others "orated on social problems that mattered to them and shared what they thought were possible solutions. The issues included climate change, racism, homelessness and even sexual abuse."
PS 90 principal Greta Hawkins has been reassigned pending a misconduct investigation by the DOE. Read more here.
Greta Hawkins was cleared of all charged of misconduct, and reinstated as principal of the school, according to the District 21 Superintendents office.
PS 90 received $25,000 in federal grants to expand its dual language Spanish program beginning in September 2015. Read more about the city's new and expanded dual language programs here.
According to reports from last year, PS 90 still has no working fire alarm in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy, DNA.info reports. Read more here.

Where is the school board?  Where are the parents.  They should deal with this teacher immediately.  Since this is second offence, and she has ignored training, she has a personal agenda.  She should be fired without retirement benefits, without a layoff "with pay" while sorting things out, and without a recommendation.  The people in that district should be ringing the phones off the wall. Here's what the newspaper said about her: "Born and raised in Bay Ridge, Janet always aspired to be a teacher. Janet fulfilled her goal of becoming a teacher immediately after graduating from State University of New York Buffalo with her bachelor’s degree in Education, when she landed a job as a third-grade teacher at Public School 9 in Prospect Heights. While teaching there, Janet earned her master’s as a reading teacher and reading specialist for corrective reading at Hunter College.

"Janet then became a teacher of Public School 13 in Rosebank, Staten Island. On the Rock, Janet was a classroom teacher, reading teacher, and literacy coach. With the support of her family, mentors and school administrators, Janet aspired to become a school leader and received her advanced post-master’s degree in school leadership from the College of Staten Island. She then became the assistant principal of Public School 13 for four and a half years.

"In January 2011, Janet was named principal of Public School 95. For the past four years, Janet has proudly worked side-by-side with the dedicated and hard working assistant principals, teachers, staff, PTA, parents, and students of the Public School 95 community. I'm guessing that like most people who have kids in school, you don't pay much attention to anything other than getting your kids to school on time (hopefully), and then picking them up.  I'm not trying to be insulting, because I know how busy lives can be, and my life is busier than most peoples.  But despite that, I worked my a** off to get my kids out of this awful school.  I agree with the comment below about the two faces of the new principal (who's been at 95 for two years), and though there are some teachers who are very good, most of these are in the Sigma/Gifted and Talented program; if your kids aren't in that program, you're screwed out of a good education.  Most teachers at this school are very dispirited, and very sour and strange.  Unless you're involved, and observant, and ask your children tons of questions, you'll never question the nonsense the kids are involved in; or notice the rampant bullying at the school.  Both of my kids got into Sigma, and I switched them to PS 215 as soon as I got their test results.  PS 215 is a stone's throw away from 95, and it's a 100 times the school that 95 is...I don't know how you came about with your opinion, but most of the parents I know were very disappointed and disgusted with this school.  All of the parents I talked to wanted their kids out of this "prison" like environment.  Take a really good look around at the school, judge how much your children are learning, and really put an effort into what you really want and expect for your kids.  For many years this school was in the toilet, and because this was such an embarrassment to Superintendent DiMola, they worked on a huge campaign to convince adults at this school that things are improving; and most of the people in the neighborhood aren't educated, and this worked.  You kiss people's a**'s, and you get results, and there's nowhere to go but up when you're at the bottom, so though test scores have gone up, they're still very low, so that change is a *postitive* one...this school is terrible...and notice, notice clearly how the kids leave in droves by the end of 5th grade, and how most of the kids in the upper grades are bussed in.

I graduated from Seth Low 63 years ago in 1952 when it was a junior high school.
My parents were immigrants to America as were many other kid's parents.
Most of us used Seth Low to learn enough to go to High Schhol (Lafayette, in my case,) and then go to Brooklyn Colllege which was free at the time.
The New York City school system gave us the opportunity to get into the middle class and feel good about ourselves.I don't remember any mean teachers. Most were good professionals who cared about us. 
I still rmember our Music teacher, Ms. Luni who taght us the music from The musical "The Red Mill,"  I can still sing some of the songs) and Mr. Gordon, our History teacher, who taught us about politics and what was behind the scenes, and not reported in the news. Mrs. Pacini and Mr. levi who taught us French. Mrs. Gordon who taught Social Studies.
I suspect that none of these teachers is still alive but the legacy they have left us is still with me and my calssmates.
Some of the things we learened have now been passed onto our kids and grandkids. So, the good that they did is still with us.
I hope that there are still some students who are having the same sort of experience at Seth Low now, that I had so many years ago.
Gene Silverman,
Class of 1952

An article in the New York Times on Jan. 3, 2007, profiled Seth Low as an example of how middle schools often struggle to find a balance between meeting their students' academic and social needs. The article described Principal Barry Fein's efforts to take care of his students -- spending an evening counseling a student who had harmed herself, searching for a runaway student, and advocating for a suspended student against his superiors. ''You handle stuff like that and you go, 'O.K., now you want me to raise test scores?' '' Fein said in the article. ''[Middle school students] don't really think past tomorrow.''
A student says of her science teacher: "She makes learning fun. She lets us use everything in the lab."

Principal Gail Levine writes that since she was appointed principal in June 2003, real estate value in the neighborhood has soared. "We are a HIGHLY innovative school driven by high energy, edge, dedication, and commitment. The staff is relatively young, youthful and hard working. The parent coordinator is an integral part of our family. The PTA is a complete partner in the school, as is the Leadership Team." She continues: "There is a multimedia lab with a studio connected to every classroom and wireless internet access in every classroom. Teachers use the internet as a component of their regular instruction. There is a large screen television to make viewing by the students easier. This year and last, a Project Arts After Schol Program in drama, theatre, and dance was established. Last year and this, an after school program, WITH BUS SERVICE, was provided for students with special needs. This year, there are four after school classes for ELL students and one class for parents of ELL students. There are, in total, 245 students enrolled in our after school programs. We are hoping to establish a multimedia after school program in the spring of 2005." Finally, she adds: "We were named as one of the Chancellors' 'best' 209 schools. Since we are all quarantine, our upcoming sixth graders may not be able to get the hang of the building, but I will give my experience here (so far). 
I am in the sixth grade, going into the seventh grade next year, and my experience her is mediocre so far. This school is very big and the halls are crowded every day. When you transition to your next class, there are no lockers. You will need to bring your backpack mainly EVERYWHERE with you, they do have a locker room for gym, however. Please do not go up the down staircase or vice versa, it's incredibly dangerous (since it's packed) and the older kids will yell "WRONG STAIRCASE!" There is a feud between the 6th and 8th graders, but I noticed that all of the grades merge together in the afterschool program. I heard that your expectations get higher each year, so DO NOT SLACK OFF! There are many ways to improve your grades, such as small groups during lunchtime. Kids in this school mainly care about appearance (like if you wear Gucci) and even though we have a no bullying policy, there is bullying.
You will find fights occurring occasionally in the hallways, which will become normal to you. In Latin, you don't learn Latin, it's basically another English class. Yes, people vape here, but it's really rare. School starts traditionally at 7:45, so the schoolbus will usually come as early as 6:00. That's all I can think of as of now to talk about.

The Bay Academy is really an amazing school. You don't have to stress that much (unless you're in a regents class in 8th grade, then the stressing might come a little but that's it). The teachers are absolutely wonderful and will make this building feel like a home away from home. I graduated this year and I'm devastated that I have to leave! If you got accepted into Bay, just have fun! The best advice anyone can give is do all your homework, study for tests, be respectful, and you'll have a perfect experience. A little shout-out to the science and computer math departments, you guys were my favorite! <3

If anyone is going to Bay, you don't have to stress too much. The first year is where teachers try to help you the best they can. That's the year you try to adjust. But, There are a lot of things you should know. For Latin, its not like you are actually learning Latin, you're only learning the prefixes and suffixes, not the actual language. For gym, the teachers honestly don't care how well you play or how talented at playing a certain sport you are. If you aren't having as much fun in this school as you thought you would, there are many different afterschool activities for you to join. If you like science, join Science Olympiad, where you get an opportunity to compete against schools and win medals. If you like sports, you can join the soccer team, boys basketball team, and/or the girls volleyball team. If you like cooking, there is a cooking club. There are other things that the afterschool program provides like music, dance, art, and the school is even introducing a student newspaper. Then, you get into 7th grade, where teachers will be very tough on you. They expect high 80's and 90's. This is because most schools like Goldstein, Midwood, and Beacon want those kinds of grades. If you are into art and you are really good at it, start making your art portfolio in order to apply for art programs for LaGuardia, Murrow, and other big schools. This also applies to people who are into performing arts (music, vocals, dance, drama). You should also find a shsat tutor, if you haven't already. The shsat gets you into specialized high schools, like Brooklyn Tech, Stuy, Brooklyn Latin, and Staten Island Tech. 7th grade is also when you should help monitor for teachers in order to get credits to get into arista/archon. Then, there is 8th grade, the year when everyone cries. Not just crying over the fact that it is their last year, but over other stuff as well. This is the year when you apply for high schools, when you get you results back, and when you graduate. Don't slack off in 8th grade, because your acceptance can be revoked. You should try to apply for arista/archon again and try to get very high 90's in as many subjects as possible. This is because you many receive an award during senior awards ceremony. On graduation, bring your arista archon pins from the past two yeas, bring you medals (Olympiad and Senior Awards), and be happy as you walk down to your seat. I hope you enjoy Bay Academy as much as I did.

Bay Academy dance and movement teacher Nicole Kasbar is a recipient of the 2015 Big Apple Award for excellence in teaching. Read more here.

Bay Academy, is by no means a bad school. However, as I graduate this year I cannot help but feel unfulfilled. The Bay Academy provides a comfortable environment, and has several opportunities for students. However, the curriculum is not challenging and it is fairly easy to achieve high grades. Several teachers (mostly those assigned to low level classes) teach poorly and slack off on grading work etc. I do not recommend the Creative Writing program! Very little actual creative writing, rather just a sweatshop of  students constantly fulfilling deadlines for contests. There are great teachers in the school, but only high level students qualify for their classes. The guidance counselors are fantastic,and are very dedicated to the high school process and students! If you are looking for an easy school with a low workload and a personal touch, the  Bay Academy is fine, but those looking for a school in which to develop academically may leave bored and unsatisfied.

Hello! Just graduated here!
Im sure you will love Bay Academy. No, there are no lockers. They have this thing where you leave your coat in your 1st period class and come back to get it after your last period class. When you first start out, you'll find it pretty big, but then it will start to feel small, as it does get crowded in the staircases sometimes. It is a very pretty school, in my opinion. I really love the science classrooms especially, because they are well decorated. Homework depends on the teacher, although I didn't feel as if I got a lot, (there were days when none of my teachers gave homework) some kids say they get a lot. Though there will be days where you will be working on them for a while, so try not to do them at the last minute. So the amount of homework could range from nothing to a lot. The teachers here are absolutely remarkable. They push their students to do their very best. Plus, they always help you out when you have a problem and they are amazing people. Just never get on their bad sides to have a good time. Oh, and they just adore teachers' pets, haha! Which teacher doesn't?
Good luck, and I hope you enjoy this school as much as I did!

I am an eighth grader in Bay Academy and will be graduating this June. Overall, it IS a pretty good school. I've managed to make so many friends while maintaining my old ones. I feel that many of the teachers actually care about teaching the students, which is a good thing. As a student in science talent, i have to complain. In sixth grade, us being a relatively noisy bunch, learned a suitable amount about Forensics from Ms. Musoff (who is also in charge of builder's club). In seventh grade, we had robotics with Ms. Katz. It was a completely student-oriented thing, with us getting little to no instruction on how to build or program, only getting tasks from her. It was basically survival of the fittest and we had to go to the students who actually had the expertise to build and program well, while we few not so strong in these skills, struggled along. In eighth grade, we are supposed to be building bridges, but Ms. Katz and our other talent teachers want a lot from us this year. Such as a virtual bridge that costs under X amount of dollars, a scale model bridge that's stable, and a research report, leaving us to figure out how to do each ourselves with little instruction, like in seventh grade. Even though my talent might be the hardest in the school (i can only speak for myself), I do admit that i like it and i've enjoyed my time at this school. I favor it over Mark Twain. Oh, and one more thing, the budget cuts HAVE affected our school slightly but one thing doesn't make sense to me; they can't afford to buy air conditioners for each classroom filled with sweltering heat in the summer, yet they CAN afford to hire new teachers, pay for Edline, AND supply each classroom, even the auditorium, with a highly unnecessary Activ/Promethean board? Some things just don't add up. We are also required to learn Latin instead of opting to learn Spanish, Italian, or French. Any incoming sixth graders, i have this to say to you: Don't waste the years you have here, they'll be some of the greatest of your life if you spend them well. Good luck.

Oh, you are so wrong. Most citywide g&t programs stress critical thinking, problem solving and working collaboratively. P.S. 100 stresses prepping for tests.  The kids learn how to be good test takers. Any joys of learning is taken out of equation.  Just because P.S. 100 has good test scores does not mean it has good quality of education.

The school puts too much stress on tests. They start prepping in Kindergarten. During the curriculum orientation, the teachers spent very little time describing and explaining the curriculum, they mostly talked about the kinds of tests the children will be taking this year.  The children at P.S. 100 learn very early on that the whole point of education is getting ready for tests.

The review mentions that the school is using balanced literacy.  It is not true.   They use workbooks and a lot of them!

The reviewer didn't mention that the school does not have outside recess.  Ever!  The school has a yard, but apparently the administration does not think it is important for the youngsters to play outside.  Every time parents try to voice their concern regarding the lack of outside recess, the administration skillfully silents them.

"I have seen the change in our school the moment Mrs. Catalano came to us," writes parent Madeline Feiss. "She truly has made a huge difference in the lives of all our children. I can only see great things for the future of our children at 121."

"I am insulted and appalled regarding your article about PS 121," writes teacher Rosemarie Santoro. "I was appointed to the school in 1982 and worked under several administrative leaders prior to Mrs. Catalano. As a senior teacher I can assure you that during those years, the quality of education was excellent. Our qualified and talented teachers always worked hard, and were never 'apprehensive' or 'scared' to try new instructional approaches! Our instructional materials were current and in alignment with the New York City Department of Education's Standards. PS 121, along with many other city schools, first implemented the Balanced Literacy Program in September 2004, prior to Mrs. Catalano's arrival. Our teachers have always addressed the educational and emotional individual needs of each and every student in the building without the newly required assessment binder. (There is no social/emotional component within this newly designed binder.) Thus we named ourselves 'The School that Makes a Difference.' We upheld that statement and prided ourselves in making a positive difference in the life of each and every child. In previous years, PS 121 had the support of a very active parent population. However, parents are now reluctant to get involved. Why? Our most recent principal, who retired in January 2004, was loved by our students and their parents. He supported his staff and genuinely cared about the well being of each and every member of our school community. He had an open line of communication and positive working relationship with local city officials and religious leaders. We did not appear to be a 'family,' we were one. The picture you have presented of PS 121 is inaccurate. I do agree that the school is decorated nicely. However, although cosmetic changes do improve the 'look' of a school, they do not necessarily improve the quality of the emotional and educational environment in a building."

Not really sure who "Angelina Defazio" is, but she must be dillusional.  The teachers in this school respect and care about each other more THAN any other school I've ever been in.  How many schools do you know of where the teachers get together socially on weekends and during the summer?  Marcia has an open door policy and any teacher in this school can go to her at any time on a professional OR personal basis.  Disgruntled staff or parents should know that if they have a problem, they can go to Marcia and she will address it.  Teachers work amazingly well together at PS 128.  I suggest you find a new school if you're not happy with this one.  Good luck trying to find better!

P.S. 128 is a small family-like community school.  The administration and teachers work together to create a safe learning environment for all students.  The teachers work well together on each grade level.  There has not been a big turnover in teachers in the last 5 years as just this year a few retired and in the past year or so a few teachers that may have left for family commitments or had moved -  have returned back to P.S. 128.  Many dedicated teachers and the Principal, Marcia Robins, can be seen at movie nights, pajama dance party, story night and other school functions such as the Columbus Day Parade - volunteering their time for the students after school.  They have many workshops and programs for the parents to get involved.  The city as well as the nation is undergoing many changes in education, and Marcia Robins keeps her teachers in touch with these changes so the students at P.S. 128 will be ready for whatever their future holds.

Special-needs teacher Michele Communiello says "some parents were apprehensive about labeling their child [in CTT], but now they understand they get double support in academic areas," thanks to the far smaller student-teacher ratio than found in a general-education classroom. Different learning styles and teaching strategies help kids find unconventional areas of success. Students who struggle with writing, for example, often shine when offered a chance to write poetry or script their own puppet shows.

English as a Second Language coordinator Sandra Geller says that long-term, "we bring kids up to grade level in language," and short-term, the focus is on helping new kids, many of whom arrive at school, and in the United States, during the school year, "function in the classroom."

It's a good school, good teachers, etcetera.  But what I hate now is the
 my grandchildren are jammed into classes with more than 30 kids in

value of the school.  I like what's going on in the upper grades with

And

It's a good school in comparison to some of the others in the district, but be honest, this school getting a 43 percent in reading, and a 59 percent in math is not something to be that proud about.  There's a school in district 20, PS 247 (http://www.ps247.org/), that scored higher, and is overall a much better school.  If you live in that district, your kids are lucky, and parents actually move into the district, to have th
their kids attend the school.  You work with what you've got, and in district 21, PS 215 is the best from what's available.  Which means you work with what you've got.

PS 215 has a great reputation. The school offers a variety of different programs for ALL students, not just Gifted classes. The principal has made a great school even better! I called the school once to let them know I was running late, and they told me not to worry, my children would be in the office. When I got there, the principal and assistant principal were having a conversation with my children! My kids usually would be nervous because I'm never late, but they kept them occupied so they wouldn't think about the fact that I wasn't there. They were smiling and laughing when I got there. I love knowing my kids are getting a well rounded education as well as a nurturing environment to grow up in, especially in the crazy world we live in today.

Kids talk about the phaseout of the "spork", what happens during school lunch and what they talk about in the cafeteria. Listen to a podcast from Sporkful here.

PS 216 kids continue to grow vegetables, prune fruit trees and even raise chickens as part of the schools continuing program in organic farming. Students also learn to cook and sell the food that they raise. Read more here.

In October 2010, Edible Schoolyard NYC transformed a former parking lot at P.S. 216 into a half-acre organic farm and is currently in the process of creating a greenhouse and kitchen classroom. Edible Schoolyard NYC is a non profit organization that partners with schools to engage children in learning that makes the connection between food, health and how the Earth sustains us, cultivating the knowledge, skills and environment required to change the way children eat for life. 

The garden, greenhouse and kitchen will support the Edible Schoolyard NYC program that already reaches every child at P.S. 216 and teaches them how every day food choices not only affect their own health, but also the health of the environment.  Edible Schoolyard NYC lessons foster sound nutritional practices, responsible food choices, and environmental stewardship in a four season growing environment. Lessons extend well beyond garden and kitchen classrooms to engage parents, energize the school community, and transform school lunch.

Principal Celia Kaplinsky writes that PS 216 is a Schoolwide Enrichment Model school, where all students have access to enrichment activities. "Our teachers have been trained at Teachers College in Lucy Calkins writing curriculum, and we are opening a new Robin Hood Library," she writes.
The father of an 11 year old autistic child who was hit by a paraprofessional at PS 225 is suing the city for $5 million, reports The Washington Post.

Milton Parker, a paraprofessional at P.S 225, allegedly attacked an 11 yr old autistic child, after the boy didn't clean up a water spill. Parker was charged with felony assault, among other charges. Read more here.

Parker didn't hit the boy because the boy didn't clean up a water spill.  He hit the boy because the boy said "this table is for whites only" and then punched the paraprofessional in the eye.  He says the reaction was instinctual.  The judge ruled that he attend anger management classes.  The parents have filed a 5m lawsuit.

Fran Marzullo, parent coordinator, described the school as having an "easygoing atmosphere." She said school officials encourage immigrant parents to become involved in their children's education and noted that the school celebrates an International Peace Day in September and that interpreters are available to parents at open houses.

There have been many changes at the school since Insideschools visited in 2003, according to Principal Stephen Porter. There is no longer a "mishmash" of teaching styles and curriculum he said, noting that the school now follows the America's Choice instructional program as the recipient of a Comprehensive School Reform grant. Many eighth graders take the math and science Regents exams, he said, giving them high school credit. The lowest score that an 8th grader received on the Math A Regents was an 85, he reported, and the lowest science Regents test score was 90. For students with special education needs there are now two collaborative team teaching classes, taught by a special education teacher and a general education teacher, one in kindergarten, and one in 1st grade, he said. There are six classes for special education students only and "we try to mainstream" those students, he said. In the arts, the school has "teamed up with Lincoln Center Institute and with MOMA (the Museum of Modern Art)," Porter said. Elementary school students learn to play the violin and cello in "a full music program." Middle school students play wind instruments, he said. The 8th grade class is small but students go "all over" for high school, including specilized high schools such as Stuyvesant, Brooklyn Tech, and La Guardia, as well as Madison, FDR, New Utrecht, and Lafayette high schools, Porter reported.

Congratulations!  This school is not that good, but not too bad.  I graduated this year in the most unpredictable way.  I will say that these three years spent at boody was the best.  The teachers are very kind, and are always there for their students whenever they need help.  There are teachers who are a little more laid back than others which isn't always good, but now speaking on assignments, the assignments are not always as challenging as I first expected in my first year at boody.  Some assignments will be challenging depending on what teacher you have, I had the easy teachers.  This school also provides honors classes, and again, my expectations were nothing like how it turned out.  As a student who has been in honors for three years, the work isn't always more challenging than the work regular classes get.  The work only changes when you reach the eighth grade, if you get put into a regents class (instead of just 8th grade math, you get a combination of Algebra 1 which is high school level math, and regular 8th grade math.  Instead of 8th grade science, you take a combination of Living Environment which is also high school level, and regular 8th grade science.  You will also get Earth science if you choose to be in a science magnet.)  8th grade will be challenging, but it really isn't that bad if you put the effort in.  If you end up taking those classes in 8th grade, good job you'll earn high school credits!!  Enough of assignments, I'll speak on bullying!  The bullying in this school is not that intense, but I feel that most teachers and staff can't really do anything to help.  To avoid trouble and bullying, find good friends to hang out with, you can go for counseling, or you can join STOMP to have a chance to make new friends and have fun with staff!  It really is a shame that you won't be able to experience that full first year of middle school feeling, I'm sorry.  Alright, I hope this gave you a little insight of boody.  I hope you will like this school as much as I did!

I'm going to be a 7th grader at Boody this September. So far this school is okay. Most of the teachers care about their students, and go out of the way to make their classes enjoyable. The 6th grade classwork could be slightly more challenging, but that's just my opinion. The dean isn't the greatest, but you get used to her. At lunch, they separated boys and girls on different sides of the cafeteria(meaning you could only eat lunch with your gender). The transition to remote learning was a chaotic but manageable one. However, only three of my teachers would host zoom meetings for help on the classwork, so kids who needed extra help didn't get much of it.

Bullying happens in this school. A friend of mine was targeted by a nasty group of girls that talked about her behind her back. We students don't know how to use the anti-bullying program BRIDG-IT to report incidents. Occasionally, there were fist fights.

Overall, if you stay with the right crowd and focus on academics, you'll have a great experience at this school. Good luck in the fall!
So am I! Nervous but excited. So sad that it will probably be remote learning though.

A recent show, performed by David A Booty students, showcased the schools dance and music programs, as well as the school's internal and external collaborations, as reported by Brooklyn Daily.

My daughter attended David Boody from grade 6 to 8 till 2017.  She has always been a straight A student since young age with all her grades above 95. She is a good kid and plays piano at a high level Mozart and Tchaikovsky. Now let me tell you about this school David Boody.  This is a good school only if your kid doesn't required the school staff or principal to provide extra attention to your child who is in the general education. Maybe because this school is overcrowded so the staff can't be bothered if your general ed child needs assistance.They took my daughter out of some of her programs and placed her in programs that she and I did not want her to be in without my consent or informing me. My daughter was miserable. Even after I wrote the school a few letters to have her switch back they said no and it wasn't due to because my daughter had bad grades. I guess because the school was crowded so only certain kids get "better seat" and my daughter her skin is not white. Nor do I have any inside connections or belong to their parent teacher association.  
When I requested David Boody office staff and the teachers from their music department about the NYSMMA program from the New York state, they have no clue what I was talking about and told me they have nothing to do with it. They didn't provide me any help and were extremely incompetent. Very unprofessional.  New York state and the NYC board of education required the child's public school to provide information and application for  NYSMMA when parents make the request. I almost wrote a letter to the Board of education and district 21 to file a complaint against David Boody for their incompetent teachers and staff.   
Their school security guards are the rudest workers I have ever seen and one of the security guard even argued with me because my daughter arrived at their summer program at 7:30am instead of 8am for their breakfast which starts at 7:30am. He refused to let my daughter in and  told me my 7th grade daughter can't go inside for breakfast because no adult is supervising in the cafeteria and she should come back at 8am when class starts. I told him then the school should assign an adult because kids who attend summer school do eat breakfast at 7:30 provided by the city.  This went on the whole summer the guard was very rude to my daughter and me because my daughter wanted to eat school breakfast. I called the main office but they didn't do anything to rectify the problem. 
These are just a few examples what is like being a parent with a child who attends David Boody. Your child in the general ed program doesn't  get any help unless the parents fight for it... even something so simple as eating school breakfast.   The school is located in a good neighborhood and the students most of them are from that neighborhood which is one of the two reasons why it is a good school. It's safe in a safe location. The second reason why it is a good school it's because David Boody gets lots of funding from working class taxpayers like me and you. They have good art,dance, and music programs. They have good afterschool programs. To get into programs that your child wants require the parents to put in efforts either get inside connections or be part of their parent teacher association. Try to get to know the staff to get inside info. The good programs get filled up quickly.  Don't expect the teachers, staff, and principal in David Boody to be excellent and go above and beyond. They are there because that's where they work.  In David Boody you should rely on yourself as a parent that your child is getting a good appropriate education and don't rely on the school staff. Some of the classes my daughter was put in the teachers can't teach and my daughter ahd to teach herself from reading text books and online on her own with my help. People have different perspective and experiences.

This school is O.K. instead of particularly good or bad.  Most of the academic teachers are very nice and teach well though many are young and lack experience.  School of One is the math program the school uses which entitles the student's use of laptops to learn math with little teacher interaction.  It teaches but has many bugs that mess around with student's grades and screws up the learning experience.  I personally remember having tests with questions drastically harder than the practice the lessons gave and sometimes  being assigned lessons that were two years ahead of my grade level because I was an advanced student.  However, the honors math program is great and most of my class received high scores on the math regents. The teachers at this school definitely made the learning experience fun and memorable for the most part.  However the magnet department lacks many strong and caring teachers.  Other students have complained to me about their magnet, but I, who has never taken these courses cannot verify this as true or not.  The instrumental department has two great and hard working teachers that create a wonderful magnet experience, but I don't know much else about the other magnet teachers besides the vocal/musical theater magnet.  The vocal teacher has been shown to display favoritism among her students and often yells at them, especially nearing the time of a show date.  Nearing the time of a show date she also pulls children from classes for day rehearsals, though the number of day rehearsals she's had has been declining.  She really doesn't measure a child's talent by their ability to perform and more so by how much she likes them personally.  She acts much more like a strict director than a professional teacher.  I also wouldn't expect many special offers or awards from the school unless you as a parent like to show up to the school to complain every now and again.  The office and guidance counselor are also very nice and caring.  Overall. the school has great academics but shows many cracks in it's magnet courses.

It's a beautiful school, however I am skeptical when it comes to the teachers and their credentials. The principal hires many per diems (subs) to teach classes instead of hiring licensed teachers. The school is typically known for coddling young teachers as per diems who are struggling to pass their teacher credential exams. Many of my college's present and former graduate students are employed at IS 228, and in my opinion, not competent to teach junior high students. Of course, this not reflect the college's ability to educate upcoming educators, because there are numerous students who have gone on to do wonderful things in the education field. Still it does not take away that IS 228 takes on prospective teachers who might have made unwise choices when it comes to their preparation in becoming educators. As a former teacher and now an education professor of 7 years, it bothers me to see many intelligent and qualified young teachers who are struggling to find employment in today's economy, because principals like Mr. D'Angelo prefer to save money and hire per diems who are not certified. Finally, all students are entitled to have certified teachers who demonstrate skill and knowledge.

As a parent of a rising 6th grader who closely followed the waitlist, I'm left to believe many schools didn't make waitlist offers, as my child's movement was negligible at all but one school. I don't, however, believe that means there aren't spots available at those schools. It's simply inconceivable that in a year when many NYers are choosing to leave the city that spots aren't opening up. If you aren't happy with your offer (we did take our one waitlist offer and are happy), you should contact the Family Welcome Center--and contact it often between now and Sept. 10. If there are spots, the schools are no longer in control of them. The FWC is.

Hi
My son got a 100% on math! 
And we didn’t do any tutoring! Point is if your child is smart there is a 95% chance he will pass with flying colors

That's great, but honestly, your son didn't just absorb math.  There are rules to learn and apply so given that this is the age of the internet--despite no formal tutoring, he must have learned enough to do well.  My daughter (who graduated from MT last year) had math talent friends who also got in with near 100's--and they learned the math by themselves through the internet.  You must have some training in math to do well.  For the test you need to know algebra (Pythagorean theorem), geometry (circumference of a circle, area of a circle, vertical angles, right angles and the "triples" of the Pythagorean theorem), coding (you NEED to know the basics and a free coding site like Scratch will give you what you need).  All these math, computer disciplines were developed by geniuses and there's no way just being "smart" can prepare you for the math talent test.  You have to study, learn, apply, and practice.  So, kudos to your boy, but it's misleading to say that your son didn't have any tutoring and somehow discovered that the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter is pi--your boy may not have had any tutoring, but I'm sure he studied a lot.
I am sure he will be the captain of the math team! Good luck!
When the time comes I’m sure he will Score 1600 on SAT without any tutoring.

Congratulations to your son Ben for getting in whether you did any tutoring or not. Passing a test and being offered a seat are 2 different things. As with any competitive screened school there are much more qualified students than seats available so to say that a smart child has a 95% chance of passing with flying colors is just not true. Not every smart child tests well and not every child that "passes" the test and offered a seat ends up doing well in the school. Best of luck Ben.

20 questions on the test are computers and 30 are math. Plenty of "smart" children take it and score below the cutoff.  Your son is an outlier--and I don't believe that he was able to get all questions correct without putting in a lot of time working on math problems and learning about computers and technology.   He could have learned it on his own, during afterschool, or you.  I doubt that he didn't do any "tutoring."
