My son is in 7th grade at Twain in Winds talent. He is very happy, he had a great 6th grade year. He had amazing and engaging teachers in all subjects, but particular standouts for him were Social Studies and ELA. The homework load wasn't bad at all last year; anecdotally, I've heard it will ramp up in 7th grade, but he's prepared. In 6th grade, he was expected to practice his instrument a minimum of 30 mins daily, and he also had probably 30-45 mins of reading, writing and / or math. There were occasional projects that spanned multiple weeks, but nothing too onerous. It's a very big school compared to his elementary school, but the cluster system and getting to know the other ~35-40 kids in his talent has made it seem smaller and more manageable.

For the 2006-07 school year, IS 281 is newly identified by the State Education Department as "in need of improvement."

"This school, thus far, is more impressive than I had imagined," writes parent Lorraine Charlesworth. "The school has a mediocre reputation in our neighborhood, but most of what I heard pertained to the antics outside of the school and not inside the building. The teachers are honest and tough (in a good way) - they care a great deal about their students. The Principal is quick to deal with problems, has an open door policy and gets very involved with the students' issues. The assistant principals and deans are also fantastic. It's just a shame that parents don't get more involved in the school activities."

"The Scholars Academy challenges students to perform at a high achieving level," writes parent Bibiana Thomas. "Most teachers are supportive and there are hardly any disciplinary issues. The workload is heavy in the Scholars Academy where students take three Regent Exams. The Principal is an outstanding administrator and takes time to greet students in the morning and respond to phone calls. The downside is that the Scholars Academy is mostly Asians and White and there is little diversity. This school should get more recognition for its award winning journalism newspaper and many other achievements it attains."

"The Brooklyn Studio Secondary School is a combined middle and high school based on inclusion, the integration of students receiving special education services with those in general education."This is in the description above. Would someone explain exactly what this might entail. What percentage of the class would be "special needs"?

Up to half the students in the class, 15 of 30 have educational plans that recommend a Collaborative Teaching Team CTT which means the class has two teachers one general ed and one special ed.  Teaching general ed students with special ed techniques makes learning more interesting and increases long term memory of information taught.

A parent writes: "Placing my son in Brooklyn Studio was the best decision I've ever made. I wish I had known about this school when we were looking at intermediate schools; my son dreaded going to his intermediate school so much that he was frequently sick in the morning. Since he's been at BSSS he feels safe (I'm not talking about physically safe) so he's willing to take risks, like reading out loud in front of a class."

A parent whose son is a freshman writes, "While the school is small, I believe that one of the benefits of the school is that my son feel safe as opposed to how he may have felt at a larger school. The other benefit is the mixture of students. I feel that it's important for my son to have friends and acquaintances of all races, and this school allows him to befriend students from all different backgrounds. The disadvantages include the lack of after-school activities or sports that would make this small school shine even more brightly!"

The parent of a sophomore who has special needs says, "What I like about this school is that they're very on top of the students if they fall behind. They give them the attention they need," she said. The staff is "very understanding" about kids who have learning disabilities that they "don't want everyone to know about." But, she cautioned, "it's a small school and there aren't many extras activities and clubs." Although there are Advanced Placement classes, the school might not provide "enough of a challenge" to top students.

Dear Ms. Maffeo,

The experience was rich at Shellbank.  I have no complaints from the teachers who started working with Emanuel in the sixth grade.  They were awesome.  And to have two of them in the seventh was simply awesome.  While his final year was a challenge he rose to the occasion because Dr. Gill, Ms. Gonzales, and others were not having it.  Especially Ms. Gonazales who seem to understand much of Emanuel's needs.

At first I was so skeptical because of the distance and the location but I have found that some of the best teaching is areas where you least expected.  Well, enough of that.

Summer Emanuel got into The Trio program which will mentor him throughout his high school years.  I am grateful because it takes some of the pressure off of me worrying about this journey.  However, I plan on being as active as I can to support.

Well enough your summer and come back ready to begin a new school year with joy and excitement.  Our children need you.

Glenn McMillan, DMA

Shell Bank has come along way since I was a student there many years ago. When I attended the school, there were 1500 students enrolled. J.H.S. 014 Shell Bank is among 40 middle schools selected for an extension of the Middle School Quality Initiative, a program that increases professional development with Common Core-aligned literacy strategies and gives targeted funding for literacy training and materials. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

The school follows the NYCDOE Discipline code and applies them according to the Chancellor's Regulation, always and without exceptions. Do your homework, learn the regulation and then pass judgements and express opinions. EVERYTHING in the school is done strictly by the book. When in doubt, school staff confers with the powers to be to make sure that everything is done in equitable and legal way. The school has some great staff members, some weak members and everything in between. Those who complain too much, not carry their load and are always blaming someone else are part of the problem rather than a solution.

continued:

I think the problem mainly lies in the students themselves. If the students showed a bit more respect, I would consider this a very good school.

I am an 8th grade student at this school. While my school has some students who are hardworking, disciplined, mature, and responsible, the majority remind of undomesticated animals with a bloodthirsty nature and absolutely no respect for the people around them. Me and my friends are constantly getting picked on or physically harassed by other students with no help from teachers, even though there are some we can trust. Another problem would have to be the gym curriculum. The girls have to take written exams on basketball, volleyball, and soccer positions and rules while the boys don't have any specific lessons. They are allowed to run free, play basketball, and do as they please. Some other problems I have with the school are the amount of violence, (I've seen children being arrested, along with many fights each day) the filth, (many bloody feminine napkins on the floors of bathrooms, bugs, etc.) and favoritism. However, despite all of these problems, I got through my quite memorable 3 years at this school without being harmed, had lots of fun, and met some wonderful teachers and students who made me feel happy and safe.

A 7th grade student was arrested and charged with the sexual assault of an 8th grade girl, according to a report on 1010 WINS radio on May16, 2006. The radio report said the boy was taken from the school in handcuffs after assaulting the girl in the stairwell at 8:30 a.m. This incident came six weeks after two sixth-grade boys were arrested for bringing a loaded gun, a .45 caliber semi-automatic handgun, into the school, in an incident reported in the New York Times on March 30, 2006. The WINS news report said the school's principal, Jennifer Canton, had been "replaced". The interim acting principal is William Woods.

A December 6, 2004 article by Joanna Bonfiglio entitled I.S. 78 Kids Causing Mayhem on Avenue N, published in the Community Gazette for District 46,  reported on a meeting organized by state Senator Carl Kruger with police officers from the 63rd Precinct, education officials, and "fed-up Mill Basin store owners" to discuss the middle school students from Roy Mann "wreaking havoc" at dismissal time. The article quoted Kruger as saying that  "residents and store owners have been screaming to anyone who'll listen that rowdy Roy H. Mann students are trying to destroy the community. "  Most recently, a store owner was hit on the head four times with his own flagpole, the article reported,  "when approximately 35 students tried to steal four chairs from in front of his store." According to the article: "Police officials and storeowners both believe that the students causing trouble are not getting directly on buses after school and walking along the avenue, picking up the bus at other stops." A suggestion was made to instruct bus drivers to only honor student metrocards for those students who get on the bus directly after school.

Went on a school visit recently, PS 119 appears to be a very accommodating and warm school. The staff were friendly and accommodating not just to me as a prospective parent but to each other and that speaks volumes! Kids seem engaged with what appears to be long tenured staff. Recess time is quite subdued which is quite an anomaly.  It is not a modern school but the staff  appears collaborative and the school does try to incorporate various enrichment activities for the kids (outside of the typical once a week art and/or music); although not as much as other schools with higher parental involvement and stronger PTAs but there is a effort and that is important.
Due to new zoning regulations, a smaller student enrollment at PS 119 is shrinking the budget and they now have to cut 7 teachers: East Flatbush school to lose seven teachers due to zoning regulation
New zoning rules from the DOE that would redirect some students from PS 119 to PS 326 have upset some Flatbush parents. Read more here.
New York Daily News profiled PS 119 teacher Frank Jump, whom they call a "true Renaissance man."

PS 119 is a wonderful school. I am the parent of a current 4th grader and alumnus (my oldest son who now attends a specialized HS student). The school has grown and improved a lot in the past years. Programs such as media art, music instruction and after school which were not offered in prior years are now available. Partnerships with outside organizations have also helped to provide students with elective options. Though the school is coed, the recent addition of an all boys academy was a wonderful idea. Bridge classes also serve as a wonderful resouce for students who additional help.

Hande, a former student, writes: "I went to PS 119 for four whole years. I loved it so much. It is a great school." This student, who is now in junior high, adds: "Sometimes I go to visit and I see that a lot of the teachers I knew are not there" anymore.
"I love the fact that we all work together for the children," said Regine Millien, a guidance counselor.

"There is respect for each other, from the principal to the teachers and school aides," said the chapter chair for the teachers' union, Gail Gill. "There's camaraderie. Teachers share ideas. We support each other. Discipline is very good."

A parent of a former student writes: "The school is very structured and organized. My daughter complained about the strictness of her teacher. [She] was in the Eagle program. However, my daughter is now attending a junior high school [and] the teachers in her current school are not as strict ... and she misses it. She does not feel that she is learning as much as she would if she was still at 119." This parent adds: "The staff is very helpful at 119."
A student writes, "i am really proud of my school."  He adds, "right now i am wishing god that i would never have to leave this school. i love p.s. 119."

i wanna visit this school i went here lat year

I'm confused by the comment that in 1999 the school became 134. I am a member of the 1955 class and the school was 134 long before that and before it was the Midwood annex.  What a grand place it was to grow up in. What gifts that old building and its wonderful teachers gave me and my friends!!! Bless that house!

Hello Alan - I too attended PS 134 and graduated when you did. I believe we were in the same class as I can recall your name. Was it Mr. Ostrow's class or Mrs. Benjamin's? How about Mrs McNulty, Mrs Sidienberg, My Kindergarten teacher in the late 40s Miss Lane, Mrs Wexler?? David and Linda Kallor. The Assembly with those moving walls on the top floor!! The 2 outside candy stores on each side of the school loaded with all kinds of goodies!!

My daughter is in pre-K at P.S. 134 and we are very happy with the school so far. We were nervous about it at first because no tour was offered and we had a hard time getting in to see the classroom, but once you're in the door, the office staff is very welcoming and receptive. After a few visits, they knew my daughter by name. Our daughter's teacher, Ms. Kelly, is excellent. We especially like the way she communicates with parents via a classroom letter each week. She's always available to talk to parents at pick-up--and even stood outside in the rain talking to us one day! The pre-K students have homework (colors and letters worksheets) and are encouraged to read at home. The student population is international--half of the pre-K class is Bengali, and the other half is Mexican, Sudanese, Polish + more. The playground is just a concrete yard, but the pre-K-first grade annex is small and cozy and non-threatening. We can't speak for the upper grades, but so far we think this is an overlooked gem in the neighborhood.

Could you tell me please how was your experience in the upper grades? Is your daughter still in this school? 
Thank you!
This is a school that should be better known among Ditmas Park parents looking for an alternative to PS 217 and 139 (also good options, especially 217).
would 134 be your first choice, or 217?
Not sure yet--will post an update once the kindergarten year is underway. At this point, 217 has more of a reputation, for sure.

Could you please post an update on the school? It would be greatly appreciated!

Sure! My daughter is in 3rd grade now, and my son is in kindergarten--and I'm now the president of the Parent Association, so I'm not entirely unbiased :). Feel free to write me at paofps134@gmail.com with any specific questions. In general, we're very happy at the school. The teaching is strong, the atmosphere is warm and welcoming, and parent involvement is small but growing.

Principal Beverly Lynch received a 2006 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and continue serving as principal at the school.

My son came home yesterday and told me that his lunch teacher blew a whistle at the class and he had to cover his ears because it was so loud. My older daughter backed up his story that the lunch teachers all blow whistles in the cafeteria. Why are grownups blowing whistles at little kids? And so close that they have to cover their ears? This is an elementary school, not an army or prison! Who approved this as how to treat  little kids? If this is ok with the administration I have second thoughts about sending my kids back next year.

Call Ms. McDonald out on this. The school alleges to be using the Responsive Classroom approach- in this model, chimes are used to gain students' attention. The chime emits an audible, yet soothing sound. Directly inquire as to why chimes aren't being used.

My oldest son is about to start second grade and my youngest is about to start pre-K here.  We have been thrilled with my oldest's experience at this school.  Like another poster below we turned down a G+T spot in another district (they're thin on the ground in this district if you don't live further down in Midwood), and hoped the value of a neighborhood school and the commuting saved time would outweigh any weakness in the academic instruction.  We needn't have worried.  He has been challenged and interested since day 1, has become passionate about Chess, competing regularly in the national-class program run by Mr. West (expanding dramatically this year), and he's made great friends.  He's in the dual-language program and his teachers so far (Ms. Gioia and Ms. Colina) have been fantastic.   Principal McDonald was outside the school gates on our first day to greet each new student and has been a warm and responsive head ever since.  

This site gets a lot of traffic but not a lot of comments.  As you read down this list you quickly get to 5 year old complaints that don't have any bearing on the school we've experienced.  I understand the closing of the mini-schools was controversial at the time - and I imagine I might have been conflicted were we parents at the time.  As someone who's only seen the combined school however the result is a cohesive, diverse school that's a great reflection of and advert for the neighborhood.

My son is a Kindergartner in Ms. Zafra's dual language class.  In our school search last year we looked at multiple programs at charter, public and private schools across  several Brooklyn neighborhoods.  We chose PS 139 not only because we think it's important to invest our time and collaborative energy in our local zoned school but also because we found that the school environment and philosophy is aligned to what makes young learners thrive: a child focused environment that is both  progressive and collaborative.  When I went for a tour and a classroom observation at PS 139 back in Spring 2016, I found a welcoming atmosphere where children felt special and parents were engaged as partners in building a positive culture.  Every classroom that I saw that day and since our enrollment this past fall is characterized by collaborative learning and small group instruction.  Teachers are energetic and professional.  They do not prioritize standardized testing but they do use intentional assessment so that they can differentiate instruction.  Teachers meet kids where they are so that they can develop confidence and grow.  Since joining the School Leadership Team, I have learned that enrichment through purposeful play, arts, movement, and the sciences are a school-wide priority.  Teachers integrate play, inquiry and creative expression through the core subjects (Math and Literacy) and every class schedule features at least one enrichment activity taught by a specialist every day.  There is an active core of diverse parents who serve on various committees as leaders and key decision makers in conjunction with teachers, counselors and administrators.  Parents collaborate to drive in external resources through grants and donations as well as lead community events and celebrations.  3 months into kindergarten, my son has a big roster of friends who speak multiple languages and he is embracing the challenge to become bilingual himself.  This December, he is obsessed with the sequential story telling skills he is practicing in his Reader's Workshop.  He is also singing in Spanish and learning to solve problems with pictures and logic.  I was worried that his profound love of play and his curious nature wouldn't be nourished in a large classroom....that he would be lost.  So far, I find that he is flourishing.  His teacher is keenly aware of his strengths and challenge areas and is always willing to give me a summary or a quick anecdote at the end of the day.  We have about 15 minutes of homework each day.  Just enough for me to connect to what he is learning and help reinforce some good learning habits at home.  In addition to teaching children to read, write and speak in 2 languages, Ms. Zafra uses a progressive games based math program and makes sure that there is a purposeful play period that integrates hands on social studies and science exploration.  In summary, my son is having fun while learning in a caring environment.  I would recommend this school to every parent who wants their child to develop a strong sense of empathy, appreciation for diversity and a lifelong zest for learning.

This is my daughter's 4th year at ps 139 ( started in preK-she's in 2nd grade now.) We really like the school and the community.  She enjoys learning and going to school. We love the clubs and her teacher's every year have been great.  I have found the administration to be caring and helpful. When we had a issue last year the school and the assistant principal for her grade helped us navigate through it.  The school welcomes active parent involvement and the PA is great, and all the events, ranging from Harvest Fest to curriculum nights are always so fun! They emphasis physical activity and play with going outside everyday for a recess period, and every day of the week my daughter gets a different specialized class be it science, dance, music, or gym.

I am the parent of a student at PS 139, and I do not recognize the school in this review and in the comments.  We have had a very positive experience at PS 139.  We actually turned down a G&T spot at another district school in favor of PS 139, even though the mini-schools have been discontinued for incoming students.  

The school has a very strong community, and I appreciate that the principal is very present and attentive. I'm also pleased with my child's progress and I feel that he is being challenged. He LOVES school. He has joined the chess club and is in one of the many after-school programs on the campus.  As a working parent, I appreciate the excellent after-school options and the flexible schedule of PA meetings.  There are many opportunities and invitations to be involved in the classroom for parents who are able.

PS 139 has had low test scores, as this review mentions. However, the school saw a huge improvement in 2015-2016, and I feel that things are moving in the right direction.  Academics receive a lot of focus in the classroom, but not at the expense of play, exercise, or field trips.  

I am so grateful for this school community, and encourage other parents to tour PS 139 and talk to community members about their experiences with this outstanding school.

My daughter is a current student at 139.  I find it to be a warm, welcoming and diverse environment.   Her classroom teacher is fantastic. She's kind, progressive and places a strong value on play. The classroom is big and bright. It's filled with books, blocks, artwork and student writing. I've been impressed by the approach to reading and writing. Students are encouraged to be "brave" readers and writers. They're taught to put themselves out there to try and spell a word and not worry if it doesn't look like adult spelling.  This approach works well for my daughter, who in the past has been hung up about making mistakes.  I also like that it acknowledges this type of learning can be difficult and scary for kids, and empowers them to be strong together.

Outside the classroom, each week my daughter has science, dance, art, music and gym.  All children go outside for recess first and have lunch after.  Parents are encouraged to participate in classroom activities.  It's not yet December and there's already been three invitations to take neighborhood walks with the kids (for example to study trees, or look for geometry in the "wild"), a visit to a firehouse and a field trip to a farm. Once a month, there's a Family Visit day, where parents may sit in on an hour of class or activity. There was a Thanksgiving show (kindergartners singing and dancing! The cuteness!) and a classroom feast for kids and families.

Despite lousy reviews here, we were hopeful about sending our daughter to 139 based on the feedback of a few friends and a promising school tour. It has surpassed our expectations and then some--we feel so lucky to be a member of this community and to have found such a great and caring school for our daughter.
Through the district's participatory budgeting process, DNAinfo reports that PS 139 will receive funds to upgrade the school's computer lab.

PS 139 will no longer accept kindergarten applications to its gifted and talented program, SOAR. Principal Mary McDonald says the decision was made to boost diversity. Read more here.

Baffled on these comments. How can anyone thing positively about this school given the atrocious scores? Is it a matter of not knowing any better? Whether the fault of the administration, the teachers, or a community of broken homes, this school should be decommissioned, deconstructed, and salt should be poured on the ground where it once stood. Start over ... this school is lost.

The school is not lost.  The test scores are heavily influenced by students who only recently arrived in the country.  They are well behaved, good students who are still learning English and test poorly.  Native English speakers enroll more in the mini schools.  If the scores were broken down at the mini school level you would see a lot more people interested in 139.  Having said that, the office is a mess and Principal McDonald totally fails to inspire both the teachers and the parents.  A visionary leader could do wonders here but in the meantime the staff cares enough that each year more parents chose to send their children here instead of choosing the charter option.

I read my comment again and really didn't take in any of the nuances that I know to be NYC public education. You sound a lot more cogent, or at least in a better frame of mind, when I was reading the numbers. Good luck.

I completed my college work at P.S. 139 for my graduate degree . I worked there for more than four years as a substitute, hoping to earn a position as a regular teacher, while having all the mandatory certifications necessary to practice. To my surprise, the school had an overwhelming amount of TEACH America and FELLOWS teachers working. i was not offered even an interview (by my own request to have one). After all my educational experience, since it was easily replacable with an individual who majored in philosophy out in the midwest and couldn't find a job in it!  All of this,  while not having the slightest amount of experience. During the course of my per diem work, (4 years) more than 12 teachers from fellows and teach america have been hired. I purposely did not send my own 6 year old to this school, because through my experienceI know that the thoroughness is not there. Some of the teachers have very little background knowledge in thier field. and they cut corners by hiring less qualified people to teach some of these classes. I opted for a charter school close by, although i was wait listed for quite a while. A lot of the teachers there are afraid to talk to each other or say too much in front of everyone. The atmosphere is very tense.The positive  attitudes are very artificial and smiles are plastered on. Everyone is afraid of each other. In the end, i got sick of it and left.
I have to say that your spelling/grammar seems rather remedial for a teacher.  Perhaps that was why your candidacy was not considered?

As an involved parent, I am very happy with PS 139.  My daughter (1st grade) loves going to school.  She is learning a ton and having fun.  She loves her teacher, who seems dedicated and happy to be teaching, and same with her kindergarten teacher.  My daughter has dance, gym, music, art, science, goes on trips, and of course learns the 3 Rs as well. The administration seems very involved and caring.  The only problem we've experienced, which seems to be city-wide, is that in bad weather when the kids can't go outside to play, they go watch movies in the auditorium because the gym is always being used by scheduled classes.  So we make sure she gets playtime after school.

It's amazing how different the comments are about this school.  My child is in first grade at PS 139 and we are very happy there.  I've had only good experiences with the principal and PA, and the teachers we've had so far are dedicated and wonderful with the kids.  My only complaint is that if the weather is wet they don't get to go outside because of space constraints.

I have 3 children at PS 139 we have been at the school for 5 years now.  They are all in the mini school.  I think the program is great as the children stay together as a class from K to 5th and stay on the same floor.
The teachers my children have are smart, caring and well rounded teachers.  I have been very happy with the quality of the teachers my children have had.  I like the fact that they have also been the same teacher for all 3 of my children which has allowed me to build a great relationship with each teacher. Have a good line of communication with them. I am able to email them with any questions or concerns. They have always been very accessible to talk to when I need to.
The mini school offers a open door policy, which lets parents come into the class room and volunteer and help the teacher out.  This was a very important factor in choosing this school, having access to my children class room.  I enjoy coming to the class and getting to know all the children in the class.
All the class rooms have Smart Boards.  Kids get gym and go outside every day with lunch. 

Enrichment:
PS 139 offers plenty of enrichment programs.
Art
Studio in the School
Music for the Brains - Keyboard
Recorder
Dance
Cook Shop 
Science
Chess
Gym
Computer


Plus great after school clubs:
Chorus
Band (Guitar, Violin, all the Brass instruments)
Extended day for those children in need of extra help in school
plus a 5 day a week after school program

They have a nationally ranked Chess Club.  The school has a full time chess teacher, each child gets chess in the school, plus there is a chess club 3 days a week after school. The children go to weekend tournaments and travel to State and National tournaments.

I have been very happy happy at 139, the teachers are good and we have a great PA who works hard in fundraising. They have planned great events at the school, such as science night, Fright night, and a Halloween pumpkin patch.  

Good Luck in finding a school for your child.
Shouldn't you mention that you are a member of PS139's PA as a disclaimer to the above commercial?

This is my family's second year at P.S. 139. I have two children in this school and I LOVE it. Both boys are in The Flatbush mini school. Their teachers are warm, caring and attentive. I am allowed to go into the classroom to help out, my mother is welcome there  as well. The administration is very open to parental involvement and are so supportive of the children and teachers. The kids have so many enrichment classes: gym, dance, keyboard, chess, music, studio in a school art classes, theater, after-school violin lessons. For older kids, there is guitar, chorus and band. The music department puts on shows by grade for parents. It is a truly amazing and very special school.

A few years ago, I applied for a teaching position with this school. The secretary called me the morning of the interview with the Principal to confirm our appointment. When I arrived, I was told the Principal left for the day. I spoke with the secretary who had called me, but she didn't remember confirming my appointment. When they called a few days later to reschedule, I declined.

On the first day of school Thursday, September 8, 2011 my daughter who is in the second grade was lost due to a substitutes teachers negligence and ended up in the playground for an hour alone. Thankfully a parent saw her and escorted her to the main office where they called her mother. This school is very over crowded and not managed very well. Thankfully no harm came to my daughter. I hope this doesn't happen to someone elses child.

THANK YOU FORMER 139 TEACHER FOR TELLING THE TRUTH ABOUT THIS SCHOOL!!!  The CULTURE OF FEAR you describe does not only exist for teachers but for students and parents as well.  

For parents, one way this fear is acheived is via the administration's copious reports to ACS for the tiniest infractions.  Parents also become very susceptible being terrorized by this administration if they voice any disagreement.  I know cases in which wildly bogus charges were leveled against parents, most single moms, resulting in these parents being afraid to challenge anything about the administrations decisions for their children.  BTW, one of these moms told me that the ACS investigator told her not to panic about the report as the PS 139 administration's reports have earned them the reputation of being "Drama Queen Central" down at the local ACS office!  (Thank you 139 for distracting our already overwhelmed ACS investigators with bogus claims.  Somewhere in the city some parent is truly abusing a child while a city worker has to work out your grudge for you.)

The PA in no way functions as a bridge between parents and the administration but as some other parents have described - as principal Mary McDonald's "spies."  Really, I didn't believe this before I witnessed it but all evidence seems to point to this.  

Finally, please note that not only are many teachers ignorant of administrative know-how, some seem to have trouble putting together a sentence in proper English.  Many of these teachers are those hired in the late 70s and early 80s when anyone with a pencil qualified for a teaching job in NYC.  (Few wanted teaching jobs in NYC during the era of race riots and student walk-outs...So we hired the worst...and they just won't leave!)  Now these same unqualified teachers march around the halls of 139 with a huge chip on their shoulder because they've been employed for so long.  It's a disgrace with a 40 year history!

Ok.  I said my peace.  Parents be forewarned.  Unless you really dig drama and want to join the bogus PA so that you can bully other parents, PS 139 is not for you.  I pulled my kids out because after witnessing the mess at 139, I realize I'm interested only their education and have no desire to have them under the dictates of PS 139s fascist regime.  SANE PARENTS BEWARE AND GOOD LUCK TO FORMER PS 139 TEACHER.  YOU ROCK!

Totally rocks!!! I replied with the same enthusiasm. Thank you for elaborating on the conditions of the school. So it is not only the teachers being treated unfairly, it too is the parents. Wow!!! Now I really won't apply to school. Thanks a million!!!

Hey Inside Schools! Update this page: the Parent Coordinator is Maria Caridi and has been since January 2010!
Maria is SO wonderful. She makes herself available to all the parents and children. She is a tremendous asset to the school.

This school has some great teachers and some not so great teachers, but the administration is completely incompetent and creates a culture of fear. Two of the Assistant Principals have very little experience with the subjects and types of teaching they are in charge of overseeing. And the Principal runs the school through fear. Teachers are forced to change classrooms with very little notice and written up for tiny infractions - or given unsatisfactory ratings - even after years and years of meritorious (or satisfactory) service. A teacher who vocally disagrees with the administration becomes very susceptible to being written up or given a low rating, hence a culture of fear is created which is not good for the students. Most of the talented teachers leave due to the administration's lack of knowledge and support. I would know - I'm one among many.

I really appreciate true and honest comments like this. As the Open Market season approaches, I'm preparing myself to seek  schools to transfer to and I was going to select this school. Insightful comments likes these prevents me from walking into a school blindly, not knowing the atmosphere, and having to endure torture for a whole year until Open Market reopens. 
Currently, I am running from the same situation. Inexperienced administration who runs the schools out of fear, sudden mid-year changes in schedules, unfair ratings, untenured union reps being preyed on, etc. Seems to be the new wave of the DOE. I think this is how Bloomberg wants it. Anyway, just wanted to let you know I really appreciated the comments. I will stay clear from this school. Thanks!
I went to this shcool last year and it was an great 6 years

We moved to the neighborhood because of the school and we are very happy to be at PS139.  Our daughter  is totally happy in the minischool class in Kindergarten, has wonderful friends, is learning to read and write and loves it.  Parents are involved and make a great community.  Our daughter's teacher told her she was "an artist" and now she draws all the time. The principal knows every child and family and is a constant, energetic presence. There is terrific school pride in an incredibly diverse environment.  I am looking forward to sending our next two children there in a few years.

Your instincts are right! 5 year olds learn through play and hands on experiences. If they are forced to be reading when they are not ready the effects are more negative than positive!!! A literacy rich classrooms means lots of time for children to make choices, language around the room should be practical and useful- eg, choice chart (with pictures) agenda of the day (with pictures) teacher facilitated/ child made graphs, dramatic play where children are making sense of their world through play and language, picture books read to children every day and available in a warm, cozy inviting reading area, Be an advocate for your child- remind your principal and teachers to read the books about child development. Most children learn to read somewhere between 4 and 7, with 6-7 being peak. Why force those not ready to read so early!!!!!!????They should be learning socialization skills, problem solving, the world of discovery and wonder.
PS 139 has been added to the state's list of schools needing improvement under No Child Left Behind because of inadequate performance on the state tests in English.

"I was extremely disappointed when a favorite teacher was let go in the middle of the year and I was not notified until months later," writes a parent. "My child was attached to the teacher and his behavior suffered for the loss -- he thought she was in meetings and would return but she never did."

Principal Mary McDonald received a 2007 Cahn fellowship, a 16-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize and develop outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor other principals, while continuing to serve as principal at their schools.

A parent writes that her child's teachers are "usually dedicated and make major efforts to teach to the wide range of learning levels in overcrowded classrooms." This parent also notes that the school's "active parents association and dedicated parent liaison" improved school spirit, but that the principal is often inaccessible to parents and does not always respond to phone calls or emails.
"The teachers work really hard, but lack patience with the children in the classrooms," writes Ghira Weber, a parent. "The teachers are given a large class in a very small room. "

"Parents are in the building all the time," says former Parents Association president Michelle Benoit, praising what she called the school's open door policy. Parents help in the classroom, organize after-school sports, participate in hiring new teachers, run bake sales and book fairs, and write grants to fund new programs.

"The principal is completely dedicated to the children," says staff guidance counselor Sophie Krevsky. "She is invested in each individual; she will go the extra ten miles for the kids."

A parent writes: "Overall the school is not bad. I have 2 kids currently in this school and one that graduated. The kindergarten program, I feel, is very tough for kids just learning to be independent. They are expected to read sentences and [the program] really discourages my son from learning with the extensive homework given to a 5 year old still trying to adjust. I understand the kindergarten kids are under pressure to compete with other countries but it is a big transition for these youngsters and they are expected to learn what I would think are lessons taught to 1st graders. Overall, if I had another choice for my child I would send them somewhere else."
Children learn to play musical instruments in an after-school program run by the Harmony Program. Read more: City kids play together in perfect "Harmony".

Tonight I attended a presentation by Dr. Rhonda Farkas on DOE Common Core Standards for Teachers. As a member of the District 22 CDEC I have seen many such presentations on other topics. I was totally and delightfully surprised by her demeanor. She is obviously committed to educating children and her passion is apparent to anyone who listens. She is warm, engaging and a pleasure to deal with.  Alfred Digrazia
i love this school i got my educatin from this school the teachers are great

I was not imposed by the school. My daughter's experience was sub-par. Her fourth grade teacher was aloof and built relationships with only a few of the students in the class. Her fifth grade teacher spoke to friends on the cell phone during class time and described a Principal unliked by the teachers. Kids weren't allowed to play after lunch even though the school has a playground. She had one field trip in the fourth grade and zero field trips in the fifth grade. There was no "connection" to Brooklyn College other than student teacher observers. We tried to get our ARIS password from the Parent Coordinator unsuccessfully for a year.

PS 152 has relieved their overcrowding with the establishment of an Early Childhood Center, which is only several blocks away. After six months of occupancy, PS 152 was recognized by New York State as an Outstanding Early Childhood Program. This award was the result of true collaboration among the staff, parents, and students.

Principal Rhonda Farkas received a 2009 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor an aspiring principal while continuing to serve as principal at their school.
"The math coach, Ms. Manfreddi, is great. My daughter's been getting 95s in math thanks to her," says Michelle Guzman, the mother of a 4th grader.

"Parents and teachers are getting more involved than ever. I have gone to other schools, and I can honestly say there's a drive to make sure kids get their education. We have a strong sense of community," says Sapphire Greaves, whose daughters are in 2nd grade and pre-K.

"I recently toured the school in anticipation of enrolling my son in kindergarten for the fall," writes a parent. "I was very impressed& PS 152 was neat and orderly. Children seemed well behaved and attentive in class. Those who aren't are sent to a teacher mediator who seemed to be a very nice, very patient woman. The parent coordinator, who led the tour, was well informed and very helpful. Breakfast and lunch are provided for each child free of charge. The 'virtual Y' afterschool program helps children with homework and to play games until 6pm. I witnessed several children receiving ESL, speech/physical therapy in quiet areas in the halls. There is a mandatory uniform policy though most students weren't in uniforms. The school is overcrowded, about 27 kids in a class, but it's not ridiculous. The school is adjacent to PS 315 with whom they share the auditorium & gym. But 315 is a separate school. I really liked the school. It's not perfect but fits our needs well."

Brooklyn Father Arrested After His Child Denied Bathroom At School Again!
February 24, 2016

Baseball player Gil Hodges represented the best in Brooklyn, the best in Baseball, and was known to demonstrate the best characteristics on how to treat people, especially during that particularly tumultuous time in the country.

Unfortunately, the school bearing his name on Avenue L in Midwood, Brooklyn can no longer be associated with the same stunning attributes.

Over the past three years, since Principal Tami Flynn was gifted the top job at the school by then Superintendent Rhonda D. Farkas, there has been a culture shift for the worse. The much loved and heralded school slogan of "Be respectful Be Nice" was removed and now many parents and children have documented instances of bullying, retaliation, and false charges and accusations all lead by the Principal Flynn. Many of the programs that made the school highly sought-after have been removed without explanation. The highly coveted Gifted and Talented program at the school is being taught by teachers that do not hold the required state license. Only two (2) out of the six (6) teachers in the program are currently licensed.

While today began no differently at PS 193, it surely ended with a very clear picture. If parents ask questions, they will be arrested. Parent volunteer and school advocate to many, Vinny, was the target today (as he is most of the days). Yesterday, his 7 year-old second grader asked to go to the bathroom and was denied by staff although there is a directive on file that Vinny's son must be able to go to the bathroom. He was not permitted to do so yesterday, and soiled his clothing. This also happened earlier in the school year, where he had an emergency, was denied access to the bathroom, defecated on himself, and was forced to sit in it all school day long. His parents were not contacted, his clothes were not changed and were only made aware at dismissal when the child informed him of what transpired.

Fast forward to this morning. Vinny saw the teacher who denied his son access standing on the sidewalk escorting students off of the school bus as usual. Vinny approached the teacher and informed the male instructor that his son has a mandate that he can go to the bathroom at anytime. The Principal who was also on the sidewalk jumped in and began berating the parent. The parent walked away and went to work. At about 1PM this afternoon, the parent received a call from officers at the 70th Precinct who informed him that he needed to get to the school now. Vinny was nervous, but his gut instinct lead him to believe that something was not right. He left work, picked up his wife, and headed to the school.

Once there, he waited in the school vestibule with other parents and two other officers as it was nearing afternoon dismissal. An officer who was already in the school entered the vestibule directed Vinny to remove his hands from his pockets, asked if he had any weapons on his person, and then instructed Vinny to put his hands behind his back. The office proceeded to cuff Vinny and make him do the perp walk onto the sidewalk in front of his son's school.

To make matters worse, the police officers lead him into the patty wagon. With his cuffed hands behind his back, the officer nudged him into the van, where he fell and hit his head. He laid out on the sidewalk in front of the school until a parent called for EMS services.

While parents stood on the sidewalk in complete and utter shock, the police yelled that parents would be arrested if they did not leave the school block or go across the street.

Parents have repeatedly reported the sick pattern of abuse of power at the school to the DOE, District 22 Superintendent's office, and anyone that would listen to no avail. Parents have long requested the Principal's removal.

Today is Vinny's child's birthday.

This is a wonderful school and the readers should not be deterred by the school rating.  My daughter attends CIG and is getting a wonderful education - French, art, reading and social studies focused on the medieval times -all in third grade.   The CIG classes attract a diverse and international group of children from District 22 and since the children travel from k - 5th grade together they form close friendships.  However, the school ensures that all children, not only CIG students, partake in enriching programs.   The PA is dedicated to ensuring that the children receive special treatment - they are active, man the library which has an amazing collection - and have interesting activities surrounding the holidays.    The limited nature of the art and music programs are due to the City's defunding of the public schools and obsession with charter schools. Although not in a gentrified area, this school is the "jewel in the crown" of District 22.

My daughter attends Gil Hodges and is in the 2nd grade. She loves going to school daily. The work that she receives is challenging enough for a 2nd grader. The complaints that I have for this school would be true for any PS in any borough. It would be great for students to have more music, art and physical activity. These things don't exist in most schools because of budget constraints. I like that the principal keeps the parents informed on most academic issues happening in the school and is a face that all children see daily in the building. Cudos to him for that. An active principal makes a difference. I am concerned about the slipping grade for the school. The school used to be an "A" school and it is slowly slippling to "B' and now "C'. Parents, teachers, principals and admin need to make it a priority to get the grade back to an "A'. The school is worthy of an "A'. 
Lastly, the PA is very active and I am grateful because I need to be a more active parent in the school.

I am very pleased with the education that my child is receiving.  I am also pleased with the level of experience of the teachers.  The principal is very hard working and accessible.  However, I am dismayed at the culture of the school, which seems to encourage a lot of yelling at the students.  The environment in the lunch room is especially repressive.  Students are frequently denied recess based on bad behavior.  They are required to put their heads down on the table and be quiet on a daily basis.  And the monitor yells into her megaphone at them daily.  My child reports to me that "they don't know how to treat kids".   This is such a shame, because the school has so much to offer in terms of academic excellence.

The fact that children are denied the opportunity to eat their lunch as a punishment for other children's misbehavior or even their own misbehavior is in direct conflict with the pressure on the children, teachers and parents to push these kids to pull the school up from the "C" grade it recently received.  

Also, Mr. Cimino practically admonished the CIG kids directly in the first paragraph of his missive to the parents explaining the poor grade for the school.  Aside from that, CIG is barely given acknowledgement as a specialized program for kids who tested as gifted.  There is a culture of providing enrichment for all or enrichment for none.  In a competitive, dog eat dog world, and that world is what NYC is when you leave the cloistered environment of elementary school, one must accommodate the fact that there are those who have chosen a program for its enrichment purposes.  Had I known the CIG would be treated almost no differently from the gen ed, I would have chosen a different school or scrimped and saved for private.

To that end, the principal is un-interested in any attempts by engaged parents to effect change or add enrichment programs.  Even if said parents are willing to shoulder the burden of cost, time and effort.  It's a real shame.

With that said.  My child has forged strong friendships and bonds with classmates and since the CIG class moves together each year (only one CIG class per grade) I know they'll be together for the full 6 years of K - 5th (aside from attrition).
Maybe some of the cafeteria staff should be taught to "Be Respectful and Be Nice". I abhor yelling as well.
I think Mr. Cimino should also learn to live his own credo - he yells at staff and children alike in completely unacceptable ways.  It's embarrassing and unprofessional.

Gil Hodges is a great school. Mr. Cimino is very responsive to parents and does an exceptional job of making sure the students receive the best that the school budget can offer. He and the staff are always readily available for parents and students. The staff is truly outstanding. The family environment can be felt from the good morning smile you get from the crossing guard, to the welcome you get from the security guard Ms. Murphy at the front door. There are always parents from the Parent's Association at the front door throughout the day. My son started at Gil Hodges in grade K and is now in grade 2. His teachers Mrs. Abell and Ms. Rouse are absolutely fabulous. They pushed my son beyond expectations and he excelled in Reading and Math. His reading level is four levels above his grade level and his math skills are very strong as well. My son enjoys participating in annual shows. I don't think he gets differential treatment compared to the talented and gifted students. I wish Gil Hodges didn't lose funding for the music teacher, librarian and other programs. The ripple effects of the loss are significant and are evident even here by parent's comments about feeling left out and not having access to the same resources as the students in the talented and gifted program. In summary I give PS 193 Gil Hodges School 4 stars!! With additional funding - they can get the 5th star.

The staff at this school is great, along with the Assistant Principal and Principal.  However, I am a little disappointed in the curriculum taught at this school. There are a few schools that are exposing their students to more challenging work but, of course, those schools are hard to get accepted in, due to their programs. Three of my children attend PS 193. From the moment they walk into the school, they feel welcomed, supported and respected. Each child performs on-stage with their grade singing and dancing around a common theme. Often the lyrics and music are original compositions based on literature studied in class. Art ,Music and Dance programs touch the lives of all the students. The credo of "Be respectful. Be nice" is taken very seriously by staff and student alike. I found that my children are encouraged as individuals and the school staff make a true effort to know each child in the building. My older children qualified for a city-wide program. PS 193 was the best choice for our family. It is a jewel right here in Brooklyn.

"PS 194 - The Academy of Musical Theater Arts has so many exciting events planned for this coming year. All children from Pre-K through grade 5 will be receiving classes in the arts. We once again will be giving out our school t-shirts with our new name and logo. Also, each of the grades will be performing this year. Kindergarten will be creating a show about the continents in January. Grade 1 will present their information, songs and dances about the Native Americans in November. Grade 3 and 4 will present their original dances created through a residency with Alvin Ailey and grade 5 will present plays they have written with Making Books Sing in May. Also, our dance studio is now fully equipped and being used for all grades and our Orff instrument program is in full swing in our lower grades. Former paraprofessional Grigoriy Zagerson was fired from PS 195 in response to claims that he kissed two 6-year-old girls and an 8-year-old girl on the cheek.
