I am in love with my kindergarten teachers who loves and treats their students as their own kids. THANK YOU PS 52."

"The teachers were helpful if we did not understand something. My favorite thing about the school was being in the bridge class (a special experimental class where first, second and third graders were in one class and fourth and fifth graders were in one class). Because of that I had the same teacher for 3 years in a row," writes Ian Buksunski, a 2004 graduate who also enjoyed the school plays and is now at Mark Twain.
Jaqueline, a 2004 graduate, writes: "This school is the best. ... The teachers really care about you."
Our 4th grader is new to PS 197 (she transferred out of a local parochial school) and she really enjoys her new school. It is well run and the staff is very nice.

A parent of two students in the Eagle program writes: "In grades K & 1, my children learned to love learning. In grades 2 and 3 they were taught how to be active learners, and now in 4th and 5th grade, they are learning how to learn effectively and be an active participant in their future."

Parent Paulette Mezrahi, who sent five children to the school, calls Principal Nicoletti "caring and competent" and says with her arrival, "new life has been infused all around." She praises the parent coordinator, Ms. Gray: "No matter what the problem or concern is, she is always ready and eager to help with a smile and sincerity!"
A parent complains that some teachers who assign a lot of homework do not check it daily, making homework a "burden" for children and not a "fun or learning activity."

Parent Marla Edmonson writes that "most of the teachers are welcoming and approachable" and the PTA are "constant figures in the school [who] definitely go above and beyond." She adds that "it is too early to comment on Ms. Nicolette's administration, but she has a lot to prove and is under a lot of pressure from the parents to continue with increasing test score, and to bring unity to the teachers."

A teacher calls P.S. 197 "small and intimate" with "a great environment for learning." There are after-school programs and homework assistance, as well as programs for sports, art, and music, she writes.

"Since Rosemarie Nicoletti became principal the morale amongst the staff has greatly improved," writes teacher Rosemarie Rizos. "This is a very positive place to work and learn. We have small class sizes and dedicated teachers."

A parent, Myrna Sarp, writes that PS 197 was once a "gem of a school" but is suffering now because of friction between the principal and staff. This parent said a number of the school's most popular teachers have quit. However, this parent praises the parent coordinator, Katherine Gray, as someone who does her job in a way that is "sincere and caring." [The admininistration did not respond to Insideschool's request for a response to this comment]

"It's a great place. I wouldn't send my son anyplace else," a longtime parent at the school said, adding that "it's a very progressive school." This mom said that there are many parents who don't speak any English but "everyone feels comfortable. The principal is willing to help anyone."
A parent commended the school's music teacher: "She pushes but she's an artist."
A parent whose child is in the Eagle (gifted program) in the school said, "I like that it's small and intimate. It's not overwhelming."

A parent noted that "quite a few" people left the school because of "dissension between longtime teachers and the principal." She said "there are people who feel that their ideas aren't being utilized." However she added that there has been "a vast improvement. It's getting better," she said.

I was student when Mrs. Bassi came for the first time after Mrs. Miller left. Now that i look back, I realize how disrespectful we were (Sorry about that!) I loved the school and its teachers, all but one. I'll never forget how in fourth grade(The Gifted and Talented class) my teacher used to pick on me or make me feel like i was dumb. I remember how we sat in groups and we would always compete with each other to get the highest score. If you got a question right, your team would get a point. One day, the teacher(I wont say her name) realized my team was in last place, so she moved ME to the winning team; team 4. I didn't understand her questions when she called on me so i ended up losing points for our team. Eventually team 4 lost the lead and the teacher said, "Before (I) went to team 4 everybody wanted to be on that team, now nobody does because they are doing horrible." It was one of the worst days of elementary school for me, the kids at my table all scowled at me, one even said, " I wish you would leave our team! We'd be beetter of without you."other said, "I'm glad she's not on my team!" I almost cried that day. I felt unwanted and I really didn't want to go to school anymore because I felt that everyone hated me (thanks to the instigator).
    My point is, this school was great, I never forgot it after I graduated, but even one bad teacher could ruin a child's self-esteem. Trust me, I have tons of other bad things that happened to me that year, but that day was when everybody started to see me as a nuissance. I hope that NO child will ever have to be in my shoes again, so i think that P.S. 198 should keep a close eye on their teachers.

Furious in Brooklyn
0 minutes ago
The principal, Joy Ann Morgan, is a self-centered tyrant, rude and unprofessional to parents, students, and teachers. Why the fact that 30 students transferred out after experiencing her leadership for not even one year,
complaints are stacked high against her, and students are allowed to run the halls, abusing other students, even throwing feces is beyond reproach. A once-wonderful school, granted in a tough urban area, that still has great teachers, has fallen into the clutches of Bloomberg and Leadership Academy, a private organization that teaches it's administrators to "cut" the fat, as they see fit. My child is not a number, and if Ms. Morgan HAD children, maybe she would understand. Anyone who defends this principal's ill begotten position is either seeking to promote their own interest or is totally misguided. It is a shame that parents do not unite to have her removed and replaced by a REAL principal, one that everyone respects, not fears, as they have in other schools. Your child's future is in your hands. Get them the educational justice they deserve.
r

"My daughter's reading was greatly improved at P.S. 198," writes parent Anna Forrest. "The school has a great intervention for children who are little behind in reading. Also Mrs. Eagle was a great Pre-K teacher. In general all the teachers were involved with my daughter's progress but the parent does have to show concern and initiative."
The school librarian praised the "wonderful new principal" who makes "kid-centered decisions."

One parent calls PS 198 "an absolute disgrace." This parent believes that teachers treat students too harshly, and also does not like how the administration treats parents. In addition, this parent says, the gifted (Eagle) program "is wildly lacking supportive staff."
i dont think that cause ms bernstien was nice. and miss faella

this school is atrocius i attended this school for the end of 4th grade and it was atrocious there is a terrible fighting problem i was jumped by 18 girls at lunch and no one really did much about it the principal is never available to the parents there is no ethnic diversity and heaven forbid your child comes in during the school year

I attended this school when I was younger (I am now 14) and I had a very good time there. I'll admit there were often times where I felt the staff was unfair; (for example once a teacher still working there today forced me to clean my own vomit when I got sick in the 2nd grade...) and the boys always seemed to be treated more fairly, however the majority of teachers were very kind and good at their jobs. My younger sister goes there currently and seems to enjoy it very much.  During my time there there were LOTS of behavioral problems, but that seems to have decreased within the last few years. While this school certainly isn't the best, I still miss it very much and can assure children will do well there as long as they put the effort in and don't cause problems.  I rate it a 3 out of 5.
the teacher is very great
A parent writes: "The parent coordinator is very helpful and respectful to my family. [The] teachers are ok too."
A teacher said there is "not enough follow through with discipline by the administration."
A teacher said the "best thing about this school are the children."
"The principal is easy to talk to," said a substitute teacher at the school. "This is basically a normal school."
"The principal is very hands-on so it's great. They all know her," the parent coordinator said.

"Things are all right," said one parent. "The principal is open to ideas. I would like to see more shows. Bring back the arts and dance festival." She also said there has been an improvement in the lunchroom: "If you went into the cafeteria a few years ago [the noise] would be enough to give you a migraine."

This school is "open," said a parent. "Parents can come. I've done just about every job here," she said. Now she is teaching a crochet class. "Fighting is a problem," she said, but added that at every school "there's always a handful of kids with problems."

This school is a total disgust! There's only a handful of teachers/staff that is willing to do their job. 
Most teachers (it started with us when my kid was at 1st grade) don't check homework but assign other kids from the class to do that. Class work is often done same way - kids work in groups checking each other and making comments what should be done to improve. 
A kid that passes state tests at the 4th level gets a report card filled with 1-2 grades having most of the home and class work done. A well advanced reader gets 2 in the report card for reading. 
Teachers are highly neglectful and show total disrespect towards parents just saying "I have 30/32 kids in my class, what do u expect?!" When I was at school thee were 38 of us but teachers actually did their work (we only wished we could check our work ourselves).
The only thing they care is lunch forms and attendance (because school funding depends on attendance too).
For our 3-rd  grade state tests we were told that school lost its funding for test prep materials and we had to chip in for books ($15 each, better get both). It was in October. We got the books at the end of January given the fact that April is the test month. 
The program is weak. Even their "enrichment" class' one. Kids are bored. Try to avoid doing any work as it gets repeated over and over again. It's been three years so far that I see teachers practice working on one essay for 5 weeks just rewriting it and adding more details and small moments to it. 
One of the years they didn't have any gym for more than 2 months because school didn't get the gym schedule right. Was fixed by February. Another year they had gym twice a week and would often miss it as "gym was busy". But at the same time school provides parents with requirements kids have to be able to do physically for their PEd test.

I have been at this school for a very long time. A new principle has replaced Ms keys (rejoice!) and we have gotten new teachers. I'm in middle school (8th grade) and have gotten new teachers. All of them are helpful (although, watch out for the tall sassy science teacher. She does 6/7 grade and will ''forget'' or ''misplace'' student hw and will take points off even when you explain the situation with her)

We have ap classes and teachers dedicated to helping us understand the content. I'm not too sure about the lower grades. Is your child in the lower grades? I've heard that some of the teachers are lazy (there's a really strict one too >.< 5th grade, if I recall correctly.)

Although, the hallways are crowded due to all the classes moving. There are lots of friendly students here. Some of the ruder students (mainly 5/6/7) push other students.

Ms Quigly seems like a good principal. I hope the school recovers from the horrible things Ms Keys did to our school.
Teachers at PS 206 and other city schools explore how to make the best use of 80-minute Monday professional development sessions mandated by the new UFT contract. Read more here.

There's no regard for the children or the parents. This school is falling and nothing is being done. The teachers curse at the lower grade students and the JHS students. The board of Ed needs to investigate this school. There is  also racial tension between the students and the teachers.

the school does not have any music programs for the middle school. mrs. keys is not fit for the job at all. the year i was there she forbid my science teacher from giving vocab tests and she felt the need to tell the middle school teachers how to teach. however, she did not care about the middle school at all
they now have a great music teacher Mr O. My kids love him. He teaches to play guitar and other instruments, they also have bands and other fun activities.

some defining characteristic from my years was carletto's predecessor, Dr. Armada, someone who spoke 9 languages,who you would often see several times a day, running and disciplining the school, keeping teachers and students on their toes who liked and respected him. There was also Mrs. Stellahunt the music and chorus teacher,   you didn't have to be in the music program or the chorus to find your class rehearsing for the very frequent assemblies, usually organized and prepared by the very active PTA, everyone performed one time or another.  The library, gyms, and computer labs were very adequate.  Shelves of books, giant notepads, carpets, decorations, and teachers were plentiful in every classroom.  The atmosphere and texture inspired a very rewarding work-ethic. I would have to side with the first two posts.
class of '61................does ms. keyes still haunt here?.......sorry, i mean work here.................

I thought it was only me.  Principal K doesn't sound educated to me.  Wonder how she even got that position.  She changed lots of rules of the school since the old principal left.  For instance - she changed how the students will be entering the school on the 1st day (when she was the 1st year principal), it was a MAD HOUSE!!!  The funding shouldn't go to the school yard.  It should go to the after school activies and music activities. She also cutted out or going to stop any more talent gift classes.

INCOMPETENT.  school notices have mistakes and are always late so there's no time to be prepared and make other pickup arrangements.  they printed my son's name under a girl's picture in the yearbook - it's embarrassing.

this school was great before some of the nicer staff and principal Carletto left.  now, it's filled with problems which the new principal ignores.  she spent great amount of money sprucing up the school yard, meanwhile the music program was cut because of lack of funding.  one teacher, in particular, is forgetful, gives punishment before finding out the facts, and blames the kids for her own mistakes.  she gives students the "look" which terrifies them.  very glad i'll be out of there soon.

206 has gotten worse and worse. It all started when the new principal came. Now all the old assistant principals are leaving and very bad assistant principals are replacing them. All the teaches hate their jobs and there is no help at all from them. The teachers are very mean though and seem quite happy to give out punishments. The principal gives no discipline at all and gives silly rules: you cannot defend yourself if someone is beating you up and she says no electronics in school while she is playing on her ipad.

from someone a bit older and wiser than you.......in general, society has changed for the worse...teachers can only do what the enabling parents set the ground rules for............teachers are educators not friggin baby sitters; and, your average parent is such a loser.........society is screwed from the modern immigrant............this country has turned to crap....well, because we allowed crap into this country.........class of '61................the best way to handle this is take away affirmative action and stop giving money and being enablers to these immigrants and professional breeders

TOTALLY AGREE!  206 is going downhill.  principal K rarely shows up for school functions and never greets parent/child.  very disorganized - staff are nasty & unhelpful.  teachers deliberately pick on students they don't like.  assistant principal N unfairly placed students in detention for listening and obeying their teacher, even after teacher informed assistant principal it was teacher's idea and that students did not break any school rules.  school notices always came home very late, like the day before a meeting was to take place.  school very reluctant to help resolve problems between students.  I am very happy my child is moving out of this horrible place, which in the past 2 years has given him nightmares.

This school has seriously gone down since the new principal came. She has no idea on how to run the school, and how to deal with children. The discipline is a mess, and kids are running array. She needs to go ASAP before they start gun violence there.

"I really don't like IS 206," writes a student. "Between periods, it is so difficult just to try and get through the halls to get to your class, and when you get there, you are considered late. Our principal doesn't seem to care about the intermediate school students; she never makes a visit to our classrooms. Most of the students and teachers are rude and it's really hard to make even a couple of friends in this school. In this school, the teachers don't care if you are failing or passing; it just seems that they are unhappily forced to do their jobs."

"There are no extra-curricular activities or after-school activities for the students," writes a student. "There seems to be little funding for this school, and we have shortages of textbooks all the time."
"206 is my childhood!" writes a recent graduate. "I loved it and it couldn't have been any better. It's everything you could ask for in a terrific elementary school experience."
Student Kak writes, "Almost all the teachers are helpful and kind. Making friends here is very easy with friendly people."

I attended P.S. 207 in 1957 & 1958. The school's namesake, Miss Leary, was the principal. Miss Grill was the ass't principal. Teachers included Miss Langan, Mrs. Emerling, and my favorite, Mrs. Abernethy. I had Mrs. Abernethy for both the 7th & 8th grade. P.S. 207 was/is a good school: I went on to finish grad school w/ M.S. in Engrg Mechanics & a successful career.
PS 207 students put on a performance of the musical "Bye Bye Birdie," as reported by the Brooklyn Daily.
they did not prepare me for high school.
It seems where that 9 months ago you posted that you are a parent with child, now you are a student in high school with no preparation... something is fishy

we used the same blog ID as one used for other sites at the time...it's not a conspiracy - my child wanted to comment as well and after the first year of high school, was way behind on Math than students from other local junior highs.  That's how we feel - I was happy there was a willingness to share that,if anyone at the school reads these comments maybe they will try and make some changes. all the things said by the bot of us are true & BTW same issue again with teachers out long term and not replaced just changing substitutes for months.

This school is a good school...but it has not distinguished itself at all.  The principal is not engaged and there isn't open communication with parents that are NOT on the PTA.  The Assistant principals run the show but they are spread way too thin. They Reference a music & Art program but last year when both teachers were on Maternity leave they never replaced them so 3 months with no art no music.  Also no prep or help with HS admissions like other Junior HS do.  Guidance counselors are barely engaged, we mapped the HS admissions process on our own.  ELementary school standards for getting into the top class change year to year with no public details on metrics.  This school could be great if they were willing to be open to actually hearing that they can improve.  As a parent with kids in both schools I have to constantly ask for information...and often it is given with a reluctant tone.
PS 207 students show off dance moves learned at school at annual Memory Day event. Read more here.

PS/IS 207 was part of a pilot project to introduce Common Core math and ELA standards in the middle school. See this Teaching Channel video for how the Fillmore Academy, the school's middle school, is incorporating the ELA standards: Common Core: Middle School.
I've never understood how parents can complain that their child gets homework.  My kids gets a lot of homework and they learn from it.  Teach your kids the value of hard work and stop complaining!

The school banner proudfully mentions The Fillmore Academy and The Earlychildhood Center but there is no mention of grades 2-5.   THAT IS THE PROBLEM!  Since it went to 8th grade, grades 2-5 does not use the gym, library, or go outside for recess.  What little the school has to offer goes to the middle school.  There are terrible teachers that give so much homework and tests that the kids are burnt out and hate learning.  The princiapal says that they are on staff a long time and is waiting for them to retire......that is all she has to offer parents in this situation.  My son gets so much social studies and art homework in the 5th grade that it takes him hours and hours.  The classroom teacher also assigns a lot of homework on top of this.  Homework does not make kids smarter, it just makes them stressed out and hate school.  No one cares about happy kids in this school.  No one will listen to me and try to understand that all this busy work takes away from the time kids can spend reading books they acutally enjoy.  The leadership is poor so the teachers do not care and in the end the kids suffer.  Someone who knows how to run a school needs to take over this place.  I sold my house for less than what it is worth so we can start elsewhere in September.  I am not alone!  Many neighborhood families have left the school because there is so many things wrong they know it all cannot be fixed while this principal is there.

I currently have two daughters in P.S. 207.  I can't say enough wonderful things about the school.  I disagree with the comment written about the principal being unavailable.  She is present at every PTA meeting, and has added a "Meet the Principal" meeting before every PTA meetings.  The Parent coordinator is an absolute gem, and will go above and beyond to reach out to parents.  I receive weekly emails about programs offered at the school, as well as the local libraries, parks, etc.  The principal is very active in the classrooms, and knows each and every child by first name.  The school is clean, organized, and very safe.  The PTA does an incredible job organizing functions for both the children and parents.  The money raised is always allocated in useful ways; a new school piano, test-prep books, fans for the classrooms, etc.  As in ANY school, each teacher has his/her own "style."  I think the teachers at P.S. 207are professional, approachable, and caring.  The school offers a wide-range of curriculum.  I like the way the school has adopted some "new" teaching methods, yet, they hold on to the "basics," such as cursive writing, memorizing multiplication facts, and using the steps in the writing process.  My daughters have been blessed with amazing teachers, and I thank them every day... Ms. Manzo, Mrs. Burns, Mrs. Laboska, Ms. Kelly, and Ms. Carriero.

Third grader Jennifer O'Brien is one of 12 winning artists in the fifth annual Heinz® Ketchup Creativity™ Contest. She won $1000 and her artwork will appear on ketchup bottles next year.  Read more: Student Artwork to Appear on Ketchup Packets Nationwide.

The school has changed greatly since the review.  The principal has virtually no interaction with the parents and parental input is not welcomed.  Kids run wild outside the school in the 20 minutes between the breakfast program and outdoor line-up in the morning.  The school's stance is that they are not responsible for their behavior.  Since turning to a K-8 school, the school is overcrowded.  Many of the lower grades have gym in the auditorium.  Literally, the children are playing dodge ball in between the seats!  Due to the total amount of classes in the school and teacher contracts, some grades do not have art class, some do not have gym class, some do not have music class, etc.  It is sad to see the downward spiral of this school.

I just wanted to add, since the review doesn't mention it, that this is a K-8 school now. The middle school is called the Fillmore Academy and is only open to students already enrolled in the school. It's a wonderful program and I'm so happy my son was able to spend his middle school years here instead of a huge middle school.

The New York Sun reports that PS 207 will not be able to use classrooms in a nearby closed Catholic school due to funding cuts across the city's schools. As a result, the school will not be able to add a 6th grade in 2006, leaving many parents in the lurch because this decision came down after the application deadlines for some middle schools.
"To me this is a second home," said a longtime school aide and former parent at the school. "It's a very orderly school."

Fran, a parent, writes, "I moved into this neighborhood from a rather affluent area with an ADD child. To say the least I thought I would have concern. Instead within two weeks we had a special needs placement evaluation that put my son in a smaller class with excellent teachers and he has excelled far better than when he was in our old home." She says PS 207 is a "great school" that is "safe and bright" with "caring teachers and staff."

I graduated PS 217, class of 1950, having started there in kindergarten,1941.  For nostalgia's sake, I thought I'd take an on-line peak at the school almost 70 years later.  Education has certainly changed so much for the better and so has the teaching environment.  Yet, most of what I have drawn upon/used in my successful career and life has been what I learned in PS 217; reading, writing, arithmetic, geography, music appreciation, shop, science. At that time, the school was k to 8.  Not to discount high school or college, yet  the basic skills learned early in life that have had the most practical application, it seems.  The classrooms and teaching environment certainly seem more pleasant and conducive to learning than the rows of desk with inkwells in the upper right hand corner, which  were extant when I attended.  Back then they were still filled with ink  . . .great for dipping the braid of the girl sitting in front of you :).  I still remember the school song. . ."Oh 217, dear 217, those days of yore will come no more, but that golden haze of student days is roundabout us yet" ... went something like that.

Good luck to all faculty and students of dear old 217.  Keep the torch burning bright!

Richard Paley

Hi,
Can anyone speak on their experience with the school more recently. I love the diversity of the school and overall it seems like a very well loved neighborhood school. Being that it is quite large, do parents feel there is a strong sense of community in the school for kids and families? Are you children making friendships that extend outside of school and with kids that come from backgrounds different than their own? Are the academics consistently strong across the board? Do parents feel their children are doing deep learning that is exciting and challenging no matter their levels? Thanks!

Hi E.F. - Both of my children attend 217 - one in kindergarten, the other in 4th. There is a strong sense of community, and the parents are consistently looking for ways to both celebrate diversity and come together. The academics are very traditional, but my kids are happy and making friends. My older child is in the Eagle program, but I'm not missing it with my younger one. The Eagle class was consistently less diverse (read: mostly white), and I'm not sure it was a stronger academic environment. My younger one loves her K teacher, and is having a great first year, and is making friends with kids of different backgrounds.. To get more of a sense of how parents feel about the school, I would recommend posting your question on the Ditmas Park Families Facebook page -  https://www.facebook.com/groups/509793569115884/ Good luck!

My son was in the last Eagle class (it has since been disbanded) and it was definitely not "mostly white." There were only 2 white kids in his Kindergarten class. At this point it does not matter as the program is done.

Big mistake phasing out Eagle. Just a stupid move on the part of the new principal. Perfect example of breaking something that didn't need to be messed with. Eagle sent a lot of kids to the top middle schools in the area. That will end. Dumbing down the curriculum.

Not a stupid move at all.  If you research, you will find that PS 139 also got rid of the "gifted/eagle program."  Honestly, it is just another form of segregation.  Students labeled as "advanced" or "talented" students do better when integrated with other students.  Mentoring others is a big part of learning.  And most "gifted" programs just cram more academics at a faster rate leading to burn out by the time students reach high school.  You also don't need a special program when you have established a school wide curriculum which challenges all students at their individual level.

Both our children were in the PS 217 Eagle program, and in both cases the demographics of the class mirrored the school at large.  Both thrived in the Eagle program, neither "burned out" or anything close to it.  Ditto for their friends who came through the program. It is unfortunate that the school will be phasing out the program.

This is a real misconception about G&T programs, which is unfortunately being spread by the current chancellor. If, indeed, a school has the resources to differentiate and challenge kids at their individual levels, great. However, that is often not the case. Families don't opt to send their kids to G&T programs because of the racial makeup; they opt to send their kids to these programs because it is how these particular kids can feel challenged, and not bored.

The presumption that """gifted" programs just cram more academics at a faster rate leading to burn out by the time students reach high school. " reveals a real bias against these kids, and a lack of understanding. Many kids ARE motivated to do more/a higher level of academic work, and they get bored and turned off if they aren't challenged during the school day. To say that all the G&T kids are being forced into a program that will inevitably lead to burn out just isn't true. Some kids LIKE the additional work. It will be a sad day indeed if the public schools cease to provide opportunities for these kids, and the only ones who will receive such educations will be the kids who can afford private school.

The elimination of gifted programs around the city, particularly at schools like this with large poor populations, is a big reason why diversity at the 8 specialized high schools (and other magnet schools) is so pathetic. Brooklyn Tech was nearly 70% black and Hispanic when I went to high school. What is it now? Gifted programs in the borough fed many black and Hispanic kids into the school. They are gone now.

217 is a fantastic neighborhood school. The children are happy, the parents are dedicated, the school is economically and racially diverse, the new principal is energetic and open to new ideas. Our community engagement committee helps bring our diverse community together. Our wellness committee is helping us prioritize healthy eating and physical fitness. We have yearly theatrical productions and an afterschool enrichment program. We have fantastic outdoor space with a track. We have a beautiful garden cared for by parents and used by students. We are a Title I school with over 1200 students so there isn't as much $$ floating around as there may be some of the more well-monied schools in district 15 but we have energy and passion and moxie and momentum. It's really a models of what public education in NYC can be.

I have one 217 graduate and one rising 2nd grader. My kids' experiences have been consistently wonderful, with devoted teachers, committed community support, active arts. As a parent I feel endless gratitude to have landed in this community--which has also generated such love that the school has an external 501c3 nonprofit set up to raise support from alumni and the wider community.
PS 217 Parents expressed discontent about a district rezoning that would affect six schools in district 22, New York 1 news reports.

I have confirmed with the administration that PS217 sill have 2 full day Pre-K classes for the 2015-2016 school year. If you have any questions, please contact the school Parent Coordinator, Mara Dubovici.

Can anyone confirm - is pre-K being removed from PS 217 starting in 2015-16 academic year?  I just checked the DOE map for pre-Ks near our address, and while other public schools nearby are showing up as options, PS 217 is not.  We've been counting on sending our child there and can't believe this option may not exist just as it's time for us to take advantage of it!

My child will be starting at PS 217 in the fall and I am concerned about the lack of after school options. I am a working parent, and the school-based program through FDC only takes a limited number of students. Schools in other neighborhoods seem to have more options. Hiring a babysitter or nanny is too expensive. What are working parents with children at 217 supposed to do?
Urban Martial Arts, around the corner, also does an afterschool program that  I think is reasonably priced.
Welcome to being a parent in the NYC DOE. They really don't care how you figure it out.

Graduated from this school 6 years ago! Although, Mr. Brown was a strict teacher, he is the reason why I am so advanced now.Thank you for encouraging me and pushing me forward. & Mrs. Traghetto, my 3rd grade teacher, will always be my favorite, you are my inspiration still to this day, owe you loads love you and thank you.
lol
just Graduated at 6:50
Graduated from PS 217 back in '72.
wow

Our sons thrived at PS 217.  Now both in college, they still have their friends from 217, also in college, who come from a number of different countries. I'm always skeptical of reviews such as this, you've got nothing to substantiate your claims, and likely, like most parents assume that you know what is best for your child at all times, and that you know how to teach better than the teachers because, afterall, it is "your" child- which is clearly a teaching qualification that knows no rival. "a few years ago when i went to 217, i thought it was a great school. currently, my brother is in 139, just a few blocks away. his school has great teachers and countless afterschool programs. when i was there, it was to strict."

"P.S. 217 is a great school with very good discipline, teachers and staff that respect parents and students and give their hearts to the students," writes parent Tetyana Boyko. "Special gratitude to the 5th grade teacher-Mr. Dugan. He is a real teacher, not only because he is an educated and an intelligent person, but because Mr. Dugan loves all his students like his own children trying to understand them, help them, to give them advise and be their best friend. I have never seen children who love and respect their teacher, as much as children love and respect Mr. Dugan. My daughter enjoyed her 5th grade and looked forward to every school day."

"Our child could not be happier!" writes a parent. "She loves going to school each day and has really grown academically and socially. The school is warm and welcoming and our daughter feels very comfortable. My experiences with the principal have been extremely positive. She seems focused on doing what is best for the child. The teachers really seem to care. My daughter loves gym, the science teacher, the music classes taught by the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music and recess in the playground."

"PS 217 was awarded a three-year federal magnet grant," writes a parent. "The grant will enable the school to enhance the art, music and theater programs as well as to focus on the writing curriculum. The school will be known as "The International School of Arts and Letters," emphasizing both the incredible diversity of the school as well as the increased emphasis on the arts."

A parent writes that PS 217 has "a lot of potential but needs work." This parent praises her child's teacher, the school librarian, the parent coordinator, and the overall atmosphere, which she calls "welcoming." But she writes that "oversight is lacking during the lunch period" and "complaints from parents to administrators fell on deaf ears." She writes: "Despite the opening of a beautiful new playground my son rarely gets outside to use it. Instead--all the kindergartners watch movies on a daily basis. Many of the movies are not age-appropriate. Watching 'High School Musical' four times during school hours is disgraceful."

Principal Franca Conti responds: "I appreciate the praise for our school, as we work hard to provide a nurturing, welcoming, and educational atmosphere. It is our policy that lunch supervision is very tight, while still allowing the children some important time to relax and socialize with their classmates. We, as a community, appreciate parental concerns and listen carefully. While we might not always be able to do things exactly as every parent wants, we always take their concerns seriously and respond expeditiously.

"With respect to outdoor play, I encourage it as much as possible. Weather permitting, we have physical education classes outside in the new school yard, and get the children out at lunchtime as much as possible. Currently, different grades go outside two or three times per week, and we are actively seeking parent volunteers at lunchtime to allow the children to go out even more often. I wholeheartedly support the need for children to get as much physical activity as possible, and asked the teachers to take their students outside to play after the state tests so the children could let off some steam. I believe in letting kids be kids.

"When the weather does not permit outdoor play, we do often show movies in the auditorium. Some children watch, while others read or talk to their friends. The movies have been screened by parents and staff members, and sometimes they are 'educational' and sometimes they are shown simply because we feel the children will enjoy them. We try to tie movies into the curriculum - e.g. we showed Beverly Cleary and Dr. Seuss films to celebrate these authors' birthdays, and our school librarian has a large collection of films based on books. Because the children only watch the movie for approximately 15 minutes per day, we do show the same film on multiple days until it is completed."
A mother says that although "students are incredibly well coached for exams, teachers do a great job of mitigating the pressure."

NEWS: A school aide at Cunningham, Maria Ivaliotis, 67,suffered a severe head injury in an incident in the school lunchroom on March 23, her daughter, Jennifer Ivaliotis, https://bklyner.com/serious-injuries-for-school-aide-in-cunningham-middle-school-lunch-incident/ told BKLYNER. Ivaliotis was reportedly injured when she was knocked to the ground during an "incident" involving two students. A week later, she remained unresponsive and in intensive care. The Department of Education confirmed that the incident had taken place but did not provide further details. Ivaliotis' injuries highlighted worries about safety in Cunningham's cafeteria. BKLYNER said two teachers and a dean were supervising 500 students when the incident took place. Noting that Ivaliotis had been injured in the cafeteria in November, her families has expressed concern "that safety and proper staffing protocols are not being followed at the school," BKLYN said.

NEWS: Longtime principal Susan Shaeffer announced in late January that she would retire, effective at the end of February 2018. In a letter (https://drive.google.com/file/d/1IZagicZNLiDNkWqXQ2wNUfqQOvKgcUbk/view) posted on the school’s website, Shaeffer reflected with pride on her decades at Cunningham but said, “After a tremendous amount of reflecting, despite my ambivalence, I have decided it is time for me to retire as principal.“

 According to the Bklyner site (https://bklyner.com/former-p-s-193-principal-flynn-likely-replace-retiring-cunningham-principal-schaeffer/), Tami Flynn, onetime principal of PS 193 in Brooklyn, has been named interim acting principal. This reportedly dismays some Cunningham parents who noted that Flynn’s tenure at her previous school had been stormy and ended in 2016 following a controversy over the arrest of a parent who had confronted a teacher. The parent said  the teacher had refused to allow the parent’s son to use the bathroom and the boy then soiled himself.

 Comments on Inside Schools during Flynn’s tenure at PS 193 were sharply critical of her, and in the 2015-16 school survey, Flynn’s ratings
from both teachers and parents were substantially below the average for city principals. 

Cunningham parents whose children used to attend PS 193 told Bklyner they were dismayed that Flynn would be in charge of the middle school.

So far, Bklyner said neither DOE nor Flynn have responded to its requests for comments.

Cunningham is an exemplary school with a long standing tradition of providing a safe and nurturing environment for its students. How said if it will be compromised by a principle who does not share its values. http://nycitylens.com/2016/03/a-school-divided-ps-193s-dangerous-war/

Parent of an 8th grader and thought I'd share my views.  We chose this school because we were zoned for it and everybody seemed to be trying to get into it. We didn't apply anywhere else. Overall, it's been fine.  Pros: Most of the teachers have been very good, my child is having trouble with math and the teacher this year has been very good about helping me help my child.  I like that the counselors follow the kids through their entire time at school - the class has had the same counselor since 6th grade and they've formed a good bond.  The parent coordinator is very good about responding to email and helping me address any concerns I've had. They organized an in-house high school fair that I found helpful.  There are a lot of opportunities for trips and the trips have been fun. My kid got a lot of music classes (the band teacher and chorus teacher were great) and they have a wonderful dance teacher.  Cons: We still have absolutely no idea how classes are assigned. Initially they said they try to keep all the kids together throughout middle school, but for 7th grade my kid was moved to a different class, and then he was moved again for 8th grade back to his 6th grade class. We never figured out why. We were told that my child was in an honors class, but at this point I suspect that they just tell every parent that their kid is in the "honors" class. My kid has a very strong interest in visual art and had absolutely no opportunity whatsoever to take a visual art class. We're trying to get into an art-heavy high school but are now at a serious disadvantage. There have been some enrichment classes of little value - like digital citizenship and some kind of "invention" based career readiness course and another computer course that initially sound good but somehow devolved into them watching a bunch of movies by the end of the semester. After-school activities are somewhat limited. Since I work I have very little time to get involved with the PTA - meetings seem to be held during the day. Still, I tried to volunteer a few times and was ignored. Overall it's been fine, and I think this school does a good job preparing kids for high school, but in retrospect I wish we'd investigated art offerings more, and understood how kids classes are selected.

From parentsofnyteens:

A parent writes, "The CIG program [at JHS 234] is challenging and children must test into it. It has been a mixed bag for us; my daughter is not bored, but is very stressed. The school has kept her class together for all three years. Again, its been good because she has made close friends (both boys and girls) but the same students win the awards year after year, while mixing them up a bit might give someone else a chance to shine. She has qualified for Arista, the honors society, for the past two years, but doesn't want to go to the awards ceremony this year; last year she left in tears because some students get to light candles or make speeches while the rest just sit there. Afterschool help is available if your child is struggling but for a CIG student to go in for it would probably be social suicide. There is sometimes a great deal of homework, even on vacations. Although the school is very large, the Guidance Counselor stays with the class for three years so he does know them, and ours was very helpful with the high school process. She will leave with a High School Regents exam behind her, and high school probably can't be any more pressure than this was."

Look at the facts, the overall grade the school achieved last year with the new principal went down to a C.   I have to say, I am a working parent and I do not get involved with the PTA, or know many parents.  However, I had 2 children graduate under Ms. Barton, and I loved, LOVED the school.   Now with my third child I see such a decline in the school.   I never seen such a rapid decline in  a school before. My son tells me Ms. Nelson never once talked to him or said hello to him.  I certainly do not have any personal dilemma.  However I totally agree with the problem with bully's in this school.  The school does not properly address the issue, and tries to change the child who is being bullied instead. 
Good luck to all the kids in the younger grades who will be in the school for years to come, if this principal stays on

I apologize for my error but I meant to write "Ms. Nelson", instead of "Ms. Barton".  I had a telephone conference with Ms. Southard and Ms. Nelson a few weeks ago and they did absolutely nothing for me.  Ms. Barton was the former principal, and I wish she would come back and clean up the mess Ms. Nelson has made of her school--this was once a school that it was an honor to attend.

I'm the parent of a 5th grader who has been bullied for 3 years by the same student while the administration-Ms. Southard and Ms. Barton did nothing but defend the rights of the bully.  It wasn't until I took this matter into my own hands (I took off from work and spoke to the mother of the bully after school)that the bullying finally stopped.  Please note that the mother told me she had never been informed by the school about this issue.  The administration at PS 236 including the Parent Advocate, Ms. Salli from District 22 have been a huge disappointment!!  They did everything to accomodate the bully and when I requested accomodation-they suggested my son be allowed to use only the tiny school yard because they did not want to inconvenience the bully who loves to  play basketball.  Shame on them for having their priorities all screwed up!!  When I asked Ms. Salli for clarification on this matter-she said "since the matter seems to be under control for now--we would leave the matter alone and revisit it if it becomes an issue again in the future".  I expressed my disappointment and my desire to understand the reasoning behind their inaction towards putting an end to the bullying.  The final suggestion by Ms. Salli was to have the children sit down while she mediated a discussion to make sure the issue was really resolved-but she called me back to state that the administration at  PS 236 were not willing to allow this because they did not want the  bully to feel singled out.  When I asked for clarification on the new anti bullying legislation and how the school could use this legislation to help my son-I received no response.  In addition to this, my son is finished with his homework in 30 minutes each afternoon--I fail to see how 30 minutes of homework will help him in JHS next year but I will be addressing this with his teacher on 11/15 during parent teacher conference-wish me luck! I have been an active parent in this school, serving as class parent, attending most school trips, taking many days off from my full time employment to volunteer in the school, and have always been very generous with fundraisers-- My name is Mrs. Galarza and I have had a very disappointing experience with this school.

Two of my children attend this school.  One is within the gifted program the other receives extra help.  After school is available through CAMBA 5 days a week.  In addition, the new principal has brought chess into the school and wrestling.  The school has calmed down significantly compared to years ago.  There is a growing multi-cultural population in the school. The area is pretty safe.  I would advise parents to keep their children away from the Junction (where Flatbush & Nostrand Ave intersect) as it is too busy for middle school students. The immediate area around Hudde is residential with businesses on Nostrand Ave. Parents should always know where their children are.  I recommend this school to concerned parents.  I would suggest that parents attend Parent Association meetings and sign up for text messages and emails to keep informed about school events.  If parents would participate more often, the school could bring in additional programs.  The principal, Mrs. Votinelli, is receptive to parent's suggestions.
An 8th grade graduate told Insideschools that the culturally diverse Andries Hudde was "kind of like a second home, the teachers would help you a lot."

Andries Hudde is piloting an extended day program that will give participating students the opportunity to get extra help with literacy and to participate in extracurricular activities. As the program gets underway, the school is troubleshooting solutions for increasing participation. Read more here.

Andries Hudde is among 40 middle schools selected for an extended learning day pilot with 2.5 more learning hours in the school day for all students, and daily literacy tutoring for high needs students. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

Doesn't matter in what program or grade you're in, this school is not good.
There is frequent altercations (such as fighting) on a weekly basis, and there has been many close encounters of me getting involved.
The classrooms themselves aren't good either. The desks are all filled with gum, candy wrappings, sticky substances, and leftover food. Not to forget to mention that the desks are all scratched up and littered with graffiti.
Staff constantly YELL at students to enforce rules, in which I believe in unnecessary and it shows hostility.
Special Education & Mainstream classes are just downright ridiculous. Yelling, screaming, cursing in the hallways most of the time, trying to grab attention and possibly even cause an altercation.
Not only that, but the teachers aren't even that good when it comes to teaching. Some have "favorites" in which won't punish at all or as severely as he/she would punish other students. And the methods of teaching aren't very effective, as many people don't understand and such.
The sanitation in this school is mediocre. You can come in the morning without a problem, but throughout the day, it gets pretty bad. Candy wrappers and bottles on the stairwells, etc. In a rare occasion, you can see a giant cockroach under the heaters in classes.
I've been in the CIG for almost 3 years now, and I haven't seen one MAJOR positive thing in this school.
Overall, this school isn't good. I'd rate it a 6/10.
If its over 5/10 it is considered an ok school

I'm currently an 8th grader in this school. This school is not the best, but it does fine. Many of the mainstream classes are noisy, disrespectful, & occasionally roam the halls. As far as education goes in the CIG program it's adequate. We're currently doing high school algebra & living environments, planing to take the regents for high school credit. The work in this program is not exactly difficult, but It does require you to study a adequate amount to pass test with a high grade. They're are some great teachers in this school such as Ms. Louison (7th grade), Mr. Kaidas (7th - 8th grade), and Ms. Burns (7th grade). The staff here is not the best in keeping authority. Many of the students are disrespectful to them, and I rarely see any actions being taken for it. However, being here for 2 years this school is safe. There are NO gang members in the school as far as I've seen. No gang activities within the school. No gun fighting and what not. Just make sure to keep your kids away from the wrong people.There are plenty of bad eggs in the school that could lead your kid's down the wrong path. Overall this school is ok.

If you can do not send your child to this school. As a former teacher I can tell you first hand that the school is not very organized and if your child is a good student they will not do well here. Students are all over the hallway. There are fights in this school and they are not taken care of. Students are the ones in charge of the school. The Principal does not have control of the school and the students know this and the get away with everything. Many students in this school cannot read well or do grade appropriate work. This school needs to be broken down and rebuilt with an administration that can take charge of the school and work with their teachers. Most teachers at this school are scared to speak out because then know if they do there will be retaliation, and there maybe the lost of their jobs. Some students do not feel safe in this school and they fear that during the questionnaire about the school that their answers will be changed. There are real problems here.

As a former teacher at Hudde Jr. High School I can fully agree with parents when they say the administration at the school is lacking. O'Sullivan needs to be replaced along with her AP's. I have witnessed firsthand one AP verbally belittle students and teachers. The mainstream classes especially the 20s classes cannot complete grade appropriate curricula. I had to modify my lessons to a 5th grade level in order to have the majority of the students understand the material. The students walk around the halls and there are no consequences established for students who come into class late or who are disrespectful. As a teacher you can file as many referrals as you like but nothing is done. The students are in a uniform school and it is not up held by the administrators. I worked for a school that was a uniformed school and if a student did not come in uniform they were sent home to change and parents were called by either the administrators or by the deans. The deans are over work\ed. if a fight breaks out in the hallway or in a classroom that is left unlock and no one teaches in that classroom nothing is officially done about it. Reading and Math scores while it is reported as improving. I have seen where testing has gone on and is not up to the mandates of the State. I had students who could not read or whose reading skills were well below average. The gifted and talented program is a joke. While there are students who are in the program who could do actual gifted and talented work, others are in there just because they know how to behave in a classroom. The school needs to be broken down and restructured starting at the top which is O'Sullivan. If you do not cover up what is wrong with the school or help cover up the many violent problems in the school, you as a teacher are harassed and found unsatisfactory no matter how many things you do for the school and students.

Our son had some excellent teachers, but the overall environment of the school was awful - kids running through the halls, School Safety Agents screaming at the kids, and the kids screaming back, kids breaking light fixtures, etc. In the 3 years my son was there, he never had any specific problems, and made some wonderful friends, but if I had it to do over, I'd never send him there. My son had some specific emotional/academic problems having nothing to do with the school, and we received next to no help from the guidance counselor or other staff. Many of his teachers were great, and went the extra mile to work with him, but the guidance counselor very candidly told us that his problems were nothing compared to the other problems she was dealing with. Luckily, we had the resources to deal with his issues on our own, but I don't know what we would have done if we couldn't afford to.

The CIG program used to be the gold standard for gifted and talented middle school students. Kids from the brownstone neighborhoods used to charter buses to come to Hudde. That was in the past. The program was very watered down, the famous Johns Hopkins Math program was eliminated, the classes got larger, etc. The District de-funded the program. The parent coordinator is, well, she didn't even attend the first orientation meeting we attended, or most of the other parent meetings. What does that tell you? The only reason we didn't transfer our son out was that he had lots of friends, some wonderful teachers, and due to some of the emotional issues he had, transfer to a new school would have made things worse for him, even if it was a better school.

As a 1963 graduate of this school, I am horrified and outraged by what has become of it.  The Paerdegat School was an outstanding, world class educational institution, and it has turned into a disaster.
PS 251 has been added to the state's list of schools needing improvement under No Child Left Behind because of inadequate performance on the state tests in English.

PS 251 is a "well-developed school" according to the Department of Education's quality review report, which points to the school's development "from a very traditional curriculum to one following dynamic, active learning programs where parents are welcome at anytime." The report also says that PS 251 needs improvements in "raising attainment levels in English language arts to match those in mathematics."

"PS 251 is one of three schools in Brooklyn that this year offers an in-school ballet program taught by professional dancers from the fledgling Brooklyn Ballet, which is based in DUMBO," according to a Daily News article written on January 22, 2004.
Students at PS 254 will participate in a live conversation with astronauts on the International Space Station, via NASA, as part of their STEM curriculum, Cision PR Newswire reports.
There was not enough room for all zoned students in the school's pre-k program, according to an article about the mayor's pre-k for all initiative in The Atlantic.
Tests of water samples in the drinking fountains at PS 254 showed elevated levels of lead the New York Times reports.

PS 254 was one of six New York City schools that earned US Department of Education Blue Ribbon honors in 2014. Read more and see the full list of schools here.
"This school rocks! Teachers are nice and the school is pretty big.," writes a student. "Best school ever!"

A mother of a kindergartner in the gifted program says that PS 254 "is one of the best schools in Brooklyn. Most of the [other schools in Brooklyn] don't have good ratings." She adds that even though her child could not read before kindergarten, she "now reads a lot and can even write long sentences."
PS 254 is a "well developed school" according to the New York City Department of Education's quality review report.

"When I was in P.S 254 I was very close to all the staff," writes a former student who is now in high school. "The teachers make you feel at home. This school has been in my family for a long time. Three generations of my family have gone to this school. Every kid from my block has gone to this school and we all have or are going to graduate from P.S. 254."

A recent graduate writes: "My years in P.S. 254 have been great. All the teachers I met are nice. I'm sad because I'm leaving the school to go to junior high school."

I actually think that P.S.255 is an excellent school, but only if you started at Pre-K and went all the way to 5th, like I did. I even graduated as valedictorian and was on the Yearbook Committee. It was really fun. I think that the best thing to do to be a good student is to accept everything, ask questions, don't be afraid to be curious, and try to be active in activities, like after school, extended day, and school events (dances, sports, etc.). Teachers are very fair, and they DO encourage thinking out of the box creativity. When I used to be in Pre-K and Kindergarten, sure, it was kind of hard to accept everything, like being given a role in school, such as attendance monitor, or participating in class. Good students were not those who "sit still and remain quiet in class", I actually did that for a year, and only turned out to be the invisible person, not even a good student because you actually get conduct comments for that. But, if you are curious, and attentive, most likely you will be successful in the P.S.255 society. The teachers are fair, gentle, and polite about everything, they don't scream, they just wait, and everyone gets the idea that someone has done something wrong. Students admit, and realize their mistakes. The faculty encourages kids to think out of the box, and try to look at things in positive ways, and different points of views. I think that P.S.255 is truly a great school to go to, and heck, there are many opportunities for long lasting bonds and friendships with teachers, and friends. Across the street is Cunningham, an outstanding middle school that most kids from P.S.255 attend, where friendships continue and blossom. Also, there is a nearby high school about 10 minutes away, where the friendships from middle school continue. You can always come back and visit the schools even if you already graduated.

My child enrolled in Kindergarten at this school this year.  So far, we've only had one serious conversation with the teachers, which was at the Nov parent conference.  The teacher won't contact parents about how their kids doing in class.

I kinda agree with the first post by "dirparent". When the school can't resolve any issues, they'll shift the responsibilities to the kids. They will only blame on the kids. Teachers are always right in this school. Kids are considered as GOOD STUDENT only if your kid can sit still and remain silent in class. I strongly agree what the first post said "This is the kind of school where children are yelled at by the teachers, that reward teachers that are 'tough', and does not encourage free thinking or creativity." I've heard many complains from other parents who can't speak English that their kids get yelled always, and not being treated fairly. Kids will be trusted only if you are one of those GOOD STUDENT. If you make mistake once, or not behave once, they will remember, and you will not be trusted anymore. A lot of parents don't like the teachers here, but unfortunately they don't have a choice, so their kids have to stay and tolerate. I'm lucky I can switch my kid to a better school.
The so-called positive feedback posted above were all from the old times...

I had the worst experience of my life by my child attending kindergarten at this school. The administration, particularly the principal, along with the parent coordinator, do not welcome parents. In fact, parents are not allowed in the school. Questions, requests, or difficulties are dealt with through intimidation and bullying. This is the kind of school where children are yelled at by the teachers, that reward teachers that are 'tough', and does not encourage free thinking or creativity. My daughter was not safe there, I was told to ignore her when she shared disturbing events, I saw a child be sent home for crying because a peer had punched him in the stomach and he was scared. Many parents do not speak English, so my impression is that they are not able to advocate for their children and that is just how the administration likes it. They are not open to questions or suggestions.

According to the Quality Review Report, "The curriculum is rich and varied. The administration has been careful to ensure that all aspects of the child's development are considered within the learning process. A strong emphasis on the arts results in students developing creativity and imagination as well as providing an excellent vehicle to cultivate literacy skills."

Principal Linda Singer received a 2006 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and continue serving as principal at the school.
"Parents are always made to feel welcomed," says Parent Coordinator, Beth Rocco. "A smile and a handshake is 'hello' in any language."

"This place is an oasis of learning, with a strong emphasis on the arts and humanities," writes a teacher. "As of 2005-6, there's a new Special Education teacher on staff who does a good job of keeping the most behaviorally challenged kids from interfering with the rest of the student population, so the overall atmosphere is much more harmonious and peaceful than it was last year."
Since 312 does not have stand alone 12:1 settings for students with disabilities, the ICT class serves as the catchall for compliance. Thus, 312's ICT class is a special ed class.

The InsideSchools review above states: "PS 312 offers a team-teaching class mixing students with disabilities and their general education peers at every grade level and ALSO has some self-contained classes for students with disabilities."
Here's another InsideSchools article about ICT: http://insideschools.org/blog/item/1001028-inside-ict-separating-fact-from-fiction

Don you think your son or daughter is bright and deserved a great education?  If you do - like me - then Do Not send your child to this school.  The principal is reckless and not thinking about what is in your childs best interest.  Ms. Yoo is going to put your child in a Special Education class without your consent or knowledge under the pretext that she is trying - oh so hard - to eliminate the stigmas associated with special ed settings.  Any parent who sends their child to this school, which on prima fascia, looks decent, is doing themuch a grave injustice. Do not send your children to this school!  Here's why: The Bergen Beach School (22K312) forces General Ed. Students into Special Education ICT classes.  Parents who request that their child be placed in a regular class setting are greeted with hostility and altogether ignored.  The principal, Ms. Too is very calm when she tells you "this is our schools policy...all students will be placed in a Special Education ICT class, at least once, before the fifth grade."  Ms. You can no longer claim that K312 is focused on providing each student with the support and instructional rigor of years past.  Say goodbye to enrichment for top tier  students and hello to remediation for all.  Her smug disposition is shocking and horrifying as she disregards all families who advocate for their children to be in rigor and high performing settings.  K312's leaders have failed to recognize the harm they are causing their students.   The principals shameless disregard for each individual students aptitude is disgraceful.  No educated parent can - or will - sit idle as Ms. Yoo subjectively determines which students she is going to force into Special Ed.

An ICT class is not a "special education class." It's a regular class that includes a certain number of students with a disability (no more than 40% of the class), and it has two teachers, a regular teacher and a special ed teacher. It does NOT mean that the non-special ed kids aren't getting a great education, or that they're not being challenged. The curriculum and expectations are exactly the same as in the other classes. Many, many elementary schools use this model - it's very common. InsideSchools wrote about it a while back: http://insideschools.org/blog/item/1000728-ask-judy-why-is-my-child-in-an-ict-class And here's a more in-depth explanation from another elementary school that uses this model: http://www.ps154.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/08/CTT-2011-12.pdf

"I currently have a Kindergartner and a 2nd grader at P.S. 312. I have to say that this school is absolutely amazing! Prior to enrolling my children here, I had serious reservations about my children attending a public school. No longer do this fear exist. The staff at 312 are wonderful, committed and caring. They make it a practice of getting to know families and providing individualized attention to each child. This school truly has a "family" atmosphere. My children have schoolwork and homework which is challenging but not overwhelming. They enjoy the entire school experience, which is necessary to help to provide a solid foundation for their future educational journeys. I am very pleased with P.S. 312 and commend the school for all that it is. Keep up the good work and parents, let's stay involved!!!!!"

PS 312 was identified by Standard and Poor's School Evaluation Services as having reduced the achievement gaps between its black and white students and between students who are economically disadvantaged and those who are not.

An Insideschools.org reader writes: "I have a neighbor that sends her son to this school and they really are very satisfied with the academics and the family-oriented atmosphere the school presents. When I hear positive remarks about local schools I feel the need to let people know what good things they can find in their backyards."

My son is in first grade at PS 315.  We love the school and feels its getting better and better. The teachers, school principal, and staff really care about the kids. My son is in an ICT class with two teachers who incorporate group projects, hands on learning, discussion, and time for independent work. He's really learning to read, math, about science, and music.The school brings in arts residencies for various grades. For example, my son has dance class with the Dance Theatre of Harlem.  The school is really diverse - and we are always working to make the school more inclusive and culturally responsive. The PTA is a bright star at PS 315. Led by an amazing, committed group of parents, the PS 315 PTA bringing together families across the school. The Principal is kind and collaborates with the PTA and SLT on new initiatives. The after-school programs offer enrichment in theatre, chorus, and art, as well as homework help. A massive new playground is being built will open in the Fall 2020 and will become the best playground in the neighborhood (thanks to the fundraising from parents and local elected leaders).I encourage every parent who is zoned for PS 315 to check it out and reach out to the PTA to learn more about the school.
The Department of Education has announced that PS 315 will have a Spanish dual language program from the start of the 2016-2017 school year.

My children love this school. They enjoy music, art (two art teachers) and dance.  In addition, I think that most of the staff really care about the children.  The school shares a gym and cafeteria with P.S. 152. Every child is able to get a quality education if parents work with them.  I like the new reading textbooks and the reading program within the school. In addition, there is an operating Parent Association.  When the weather isn't bad, the children play outside during the lunch period. If this is your zoned school, you have nothing to worry about.  In addition, whenever my children need special services (speech, SETSS) they can receive them within the school.

This school is a great school because of its caring faculty, especially Principal Mary Harrington," parent Valerie Schwartz writes. "She has been a good authority figure and role model for my son, displaying fairness, composure, and professionalism combined with patience and genuine concern. This school and its principal have been the ideal combination of kindness and discipline. I'm hoping that while this school is fairly new, all involved will recognize the enormous potential and commitment it has towards directing our youth towards success and self-fulfillment."

"My son is a 6th grader in the CIG program at the school," writes a parent. "I have found the teachers to be caring, and the staff to be warm and welcoming. The smaller size of the school allows the staff and administrators to know the children personally and treat them as individuals. While we considered some of the larger schools, such as Mark Twain, we believe we made the right choice for our child who is getting probably more attention at 381 than he would have at a larger school."

My son attended this school and has since graduated. The
administration does not show any concerns for the students. Our complaints have
gone unanswered and ignored. No effort was ever made to reach out to us and
discuss our concerns. There is no special course offering or extracurricular
activities beyond the required coursework. The main office staff always seemed
oblivious and unaware of what’s happening at the school. The students’ BEHAVIOR,
DEMEANOR AND USE OF PROFANITY LEFT ME SPEECHLESS. Mr.  B, a devoted math teacher, has earned my
respect and SHOULD BE HIGHLY PRAISED BECAUSE HE EMBODIES WHAT AN EFFECTIVE
TEACHER, and ROLE MODEL should impart in our kids. He regularly made phone
calls home and kept parents informed of their child's progress and behavior in
the classroom if any...His English teacher whose name I do not recall was
exceptional. The Spanish teacher however never gave the kids the required
textbook because the children mishandled them in past semesters. It became
apparent that the students were only taught what was needed in order to pass
the NYS exams, nothing more.  My son excelled
academically because of all the extra work we put into it. We hired private
tutors to help him improve his writing, grammar and critical thinking skills. In
three years, no one ever alerted us that his organizational and interpersonal skills
were not in par with his peers or what is considered developmentally acceptable
for his age. A nurturing environment caters to students’ academic and emotional
needs. Children are multi-faceted, they may act appropriately at home because
of fear of punishment and misbehave at school. These acts of insubordination
should be communicated to the parents

This school lacks effective leadership. Ms. Harrington, the
principal should probably step down and let Mr. Norton, the assistant principal
for 8th graders take the helm.

"As the parent of a student in the CIG program, I am impressed at the level of work that my son is being given," writes a parent. "Ms. Harrington runs a tight ship, combining firmness with warmth and concern for all. My only complaint is that 381 does not have its own building."
your son most likely hated the experience

"It feels more like an elementary school, probably because the school shares the building with an elementary school," writes a disappointed student. She also says that the CIG program is "just like any other class and sometimes even the classes that aren't CIG are ahead of the CIG class." However, the CIG students face added pressure from teachers and staff who expect them to be role models, she writes.

A graduate of the school writes that "those who were in the gifted program had it much better" because their classes were better behaved. In addition, she complains, "While the biology class was taught very well, other science classes were not." She adds that students liked having the opportunity to take the Math A Regents before getting to high school.

"This school is a great school because of its caring faculty, especially Principal Mary Harrington," parent Valerie Schwartz writes. "She has been a good authority figure and role model for my son, displaying fairness, composure, and professionalism combined with patience and genuine concern. This school and its principal have been the ideal combination of kindness and discipline. I'm hoping that while this school is fairly new, all involved will recognize the enormous potential and commitment it has towards directing our youth towards success and self-fulfillment."

"My son is a 6th grader in the CIG program at the school," writes a parent. "I have found the teachers to be caring, and the staff to be warm and welcoming. The smaller size of the school allows the staff and administrators to know the children personally and treat them as individuals. While we considered some of the larger schools, such as Mark Twain, we believe we made the right choice for our child who is getting probably more attention at 381 than he would have at a larger school."

I have come into the school as a student teacher and have found the experience very helpful. Mr. Frangella  is a very effective leader that acknowledges his parents and values their contribution to the school.  It seems as though he has a good rapport with his teaching staff hence the 100% rating mentioned above. He helps to maintain order and respect amongst the students as best as he can and encourage the teachers to emulate likewise.  He helps to maintain order and respect amongst the students as best as he can and encourages the teachers to emulate likewise. Student behavior there is mediocre.   Most of the students are cooperative and comply with directions.  There are students that give minor resistance but it’s not to the point where it is outrageous and uncontrollable. Behavior can be managed. I’ve visited schools where the students fight brutally and use obscenities towards teachers.
 I’m hoping to see uniforms implemented throughout the building though. I had an opportunity to work with a very intelligent and collaborative ELA teacher named Mr. Engle.  He is extremely patient with the students and they respond well towards him. Although the teachers are very new, they remain very dedicated and do their utmost to foster academic performance.  For a new school I’m pretty satisfied with it and hope to return for another semester of student teaching.
