I attended first and second grade at PS 137 in the late fifties. When I attended, the classes were over crowed and the school day was one half a day. To get the opportunity to attend a full day of classes, many of the students were bused to schools in other neighborhoods. I was one of those students,
While I am glad to read that the school is no longer over crowded and that the students attend full days of classes, the facility has to be very old. PS 137 was ancient back in the fifties. Unless a great deal of interior design and renovation has taken place in the fifty years, I can only imagine how antiquated the facilities must be. The students and the community deserve some modernization. 
The world has changed a great deal since I went to school there, the facilities change to meet the challenges of teaching in such an information centric environment. While I agree that a school is comprised of much more than brick and mortar, a facility designed with more current imperatives could benefit both the faculty and the students, alike.
Thanks for reading this far.

NY Daily News reports that a plan to let people in District 23 choose their own schools regardless of where they live is leaving some parents frustrated since PS/IS 137 is the only school in the district with an "A" grade from the DOE. Read more here.

PS 137 is on a list of schools that the DOE may close. The schools were on the state's persistently lowest achieving list last spring and have low tests scores, with fewer than 30% of the students reading at grade level. Additionally all but one received a "D" or an "F" on the city progress reports. After last year's union lawsuit prevented the city from closing 19 schools, a judge ruled that the city needs to communicate better with the schools' communities. This year officials are also considering closing the 19 schools identified last year. Education officials will also consider alternatives to closing the schools, including removing the principals and changing staff. Check this link in the Daily News.

"Schools Chancellor Joel Klein and his deputy Diana Lam outlined the plan during a visit to PS 137 in Brooklyn, where they viewed what they consider innovative reading and writing approaches that could be used to help struggling third graders," according to a New York Post article written February 27, 2004. " They announced the intervention plan - and the new appeal process for parents of kids held back - following a revolt from some education advocates who object to basing promotion on a single standardized test."

P.S. 156 was highlighted as a "shining example" of the DOE's new Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts, which recommends guidelines for teaching visual art, music, dance, and theater, according to an article in the New York Times on June 26, 2006. The school "is filled with art," according to the article. "It's on the walls, on display tables in the halls, hanging from the ceiling. On a recent day students in a music class played expert percussion, jamming on bongos and steel drums. In the dance studio, third graders paired off to do the tango, part of their study of Latin American culture."

"It's a wonderful atmosphere; teachers are really encouraged to come up with ideas and innovations," says Irwin Albert, a retired supervisor from District 32 who came to the school as a mentor in 2003 and now volunteers two days a week.

Principal-intern Kevin Caifa says, "in this building, both schools talk. There's synergy. They take one plus one and make it three."

"The secret is constant communication," Malave says of the relationship between the two schools in the building. "We are one building; we are one school."

According to an October article in The New York Times, the jazz program at PS 156, now in its second year, has become part of the daily routine for elementary students. Using lesson plans and recordings from Jazz at Lincoln Center as well as videos, film and supplementary recordings, teachers at 156 are exposing their students not only to the musicians and their art, but also to social and political history. The program seems to be a hit with teachers and students who have even written poetry on the topics they are studying. The principal is quoted as saying, "We have been successful at integrating the arts into readings, social studies and especially writing. We're going to continue the same way."Extracted from New York Times article "Jazz Sits In on the Curriculum and Moves a Young Audience" by Roberta Hershenson 10/8/03)

P.S. 178, is a school that has it's up's and downs just like many other school's. At one point it was at the top, then it slowly dropped down, now it is in the process of rebuilding it's standards and values and is trying to be molded to be the great school that it once was. It's not just the building that makes the school, but its the community and the people that go there. It takes a village to raise a child and if the parents aren't involved or care as they should, then it's only but so much that the staff and teacher's can do to the best of their ability. There are many pro's and con's of P.S.178 and we can sit here and talk about how much it has changed and what a disgrace it is,but if we don't take a stand and advocate for what we really want and believe, then change is not going to happen in the way we see fit. Jay Asher, from Thirteen Reasons Why said, "You can't stop the future, you can't rewind the past, the only way to learn the secret...is to press play." So in the 'now' what are we as a community going to do? And how can we make that change for the better and for the long run of our future generation, happen?

As an excessed teacher (ATR), I have had the opportunity to work throughout the Brownsville/Oceanhill district as a substitute. Many of the schools are deemed underperforming through no fault of their own: they are plagued by lack of funding, severe social issues, as well as lack of parental support. Day in and day out, teachers strive to do their best to educate but are met with many challenges. In the meantime, charter schools are taking over the public schools and the already struggling population of students are shuffled into neighboring schools, thereby putting further strains on the resources of those schools. There seems to be little hope left for the public schools in this area.However, there is a small gem of a school in the southern part of the district. PS184 was noticeably different. The first thing that struck me upon entering the building was that the Student of the Month pictures were actually in frames on the wall. Everywhere I looked throughout the building, I saw no evidence of the usual graffiti on the walls. The school itself is quite old with the beautiful and unusual characteristics of a building from that era, however the inside was spotlessly clean with everything working as if this was a new building. It was quite apparent that the custodial staff took pride in maintaining the school in tip top condition.The teachers were hardworking, devoted, and professional. They took a genuine concern in their students and the camaraderie between the staff was evident.The students were polite and eager to learn. They took enormous pride in everything they did.The principal, Mr. Lamson Lam, is a very calm, approachable, and inquisitive individual. He takes great interest in any ideas offered for improvements to his school. It is obvious that he wants nothing but success for his school, his students, and his teachers. He ends every announcement on the PA system with the following phrase: " PS184, a place where the teachers want to teach, students want to learn, and parents want to help."I truly believe it.

Currently, I have two children attending P.S. 184M, my husband and I are very satisfied with the progress of our children in both their English and Mandarin studies at P.S. 184M.  My husband has a doctorate in mathematics and I have a M.B.A. and our children have attended other public and private schools before settling on P.S. 184M.  So, we have seen and attended schools, both public and private, in and out of New York, and we have talked with numerous parents whose children attended other schools.  When we compared the core curriculum of P.S. 184M with that of other schools, P.S. 184M inevitably came out on top, and other Chinese parents were always impressed with the ability of our children to speak, read and write Mandarin as well.  So, our own independent assessment is that the school is doing a great job in educating our children in both English and Mandarin, and we hope that the school will continue its course of excellence.  We hope these accusations against the school will be cleared quickly so the school staff can go back to focusing 100% on educating our children instead of wasting time fighting these groundless accusations.

Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced 73 schools selected to join the Learning Partners Program, an innovative and collaborative initiative that brings schools together to share practices to improve learning in the classroom and raise student outcomes. Through the program, one host school with strong practices in a particular focus area will support two partner schools seeking to strengthen their own practices in that area. The principal was my 5th grade teacher at PS 230. She read the first three Harry Potter books to us (out loud!) and ignited my love for literature. "I forgot" was never a valid excuse. Because of improvements in its test scores, PS/IS 323 was removed from the state's list of schools needing improvement and is now considered "in good standing" under No Child Left Behind.

The parent of a kindergartener writes to tell us that the school now has a gifted and talented class in kindergarten and 1st grade. She writes: "My son likes it there and I like the way the principal has acted so far."

A Jan. 2, 2007 article in the New York Post, "High Marks for B'klyn Model," reports that PS 323 "is an oasis of safety in the shadow of one of the city's toughest housing projects and a homeless shelter....." The article, by David Andreatta, credits the fact that the school now includes elementary and middle school grades as helping to "defuse the violence that racked the school" in the past. It quotes Principal Linda Harris as saying the presence of younger children in the former junior high school has "helped tremendously with discipline. When an eighth-grade child sees the first teacher he ever had or a little brother or sister walking down the hall, there's a certain respect there, and they're protective."
A security guard says, "This is a good school. It has a lot of stuff to offer...a lot."

Brownsville Collaborative Middle School is among 40 middle schools selected for an extension of the Middle School Quality Initiative, a program that increases professional development on Common Core-aligned literacy strategies and gives targeted funding for literacy training and materials. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

IS392 is still an excellent school. Though not as great as it once was, it is still a contender ranking in the top 14% percent of NY middle schools (schooldigger.com). It is a tough school that expects students to achieve goals that go beyond middle school--they inspire students to see themselves as future college graduates. The workload is a lot, but well worth it when hardworking and motivated students earn admission to private and top public high schools(including specialized high schools: Bronx HS of Science, Stuyvesant, Brooklyn Tech, Brooklyn Latin). The teachers expect hard work from their students, but are there to reward their hard work as well.

I.S.392 is an excellent school with a demanding academic program for those students who want to achieve a successful career. The school accommodates about 310 students, and offers a variety of opportunities for students to participate in. Students are encourage to get involved in sports and walk-a-thon events.  In addition, the school organizes yearly trips to foreign countries, which students look forward to with great expectation and enthusiasm.


The  staff at I.S.392 is very friendly and makes one feel comfortable and appreciated. At some time during the school year, parents are invited to visit live classes to get a first-hand view on how their children are being taught.

I.S.392, a school for the gifted and talented truly lives up to its name.  The assignments are tough, but it helps the students to remain focus on what's important to them. Overall, I.S.392 is an excellent school with a strong academic program with a dedicated staff who envision the success of all their students.  I highly recommend it without any reservation.
MS.HURDLE!!!!!!!!

My daughter just graduated June 2015 and her attending I.S. 392 was truly an unexpected blessing. Four years prior to submitting her application my son attended I.S. 383 Philippa Schuyler School for the Gifted and Talented and I had more negative experiences with that school than positive; don't get me wrong the school was OK at that moment in time when my son attended, but based off that experience with my son I had a far better understanding of the kind of school environment I did not want for my daughter.

At I.S. 392 my husband and I found the right school environment we were searching for our daughter.  From the moment you walk into the school building you are greeted by NYC's #1 school safety officers who are dedicated, firm when they need to be, nurturing and extremely attentive to all the children (as they know so many by name).  Being known by name and not an ID number is a definite component of the ideal school environment I envision for my children.  I.S. 392 is a small school with a
couple hundred students that shares 2 floors of the clean and vibrant school
building with an elementary school (***kudos to the janitorial staff***).  The school administration and staff are dedicated and nurturing with strong and supportive leadership from the school’s principal Ms. Joseph.  

The academic standards and uniform policies are highly enforced; academics can be closely monitored by parents through an online resource (pupilpath.skedula.com) that is frequently updated with grades (classwork, homework, project, quiz, test) and frequent communications from the school administration and teachers.  I.S. 392 also offers MANY afterschool opportunities and even free summer programs for their students; as a parent who was unable to afford dance (ballet, tap, modern,
African, hip-hop), photography, African drumming, vocal, theatre, violin…it was
truly a blessing for my daughter to attend this school.

I have enjoyed my time at I.S.392. The teachers were great. They knew who their students were and cared about them. The school was always clean. They had great after school activities. The teachers treated all students equally. The inclusion kids were included in everything we did. We had to wear uniform but that ok. When you get jobs later in life you have to wear uniform so its preparing us for the real world.  Over all I.S.392 is a great well rounded school. I would recommend it tto other students.

I.S.392 is a wonderful school. My daughter went there from 6th to 8th grade. They have an amazing staff. I knew that when I sent my daughter to school she was in a safe environment. While attending this school, my daughter recieved many different expriences and opprotunities. The school offers programs that others junior high schools are not offering their students. I.S.392 is one of the best middle schools in brooklyn. My daughter is now in a great high school. I would recommend this school to any parent who wants to send their child to a great middle school.

IS 392 is a great middle school and I am happy that my daughter is a student here. She is in the seventh grade and she is happy here. The school has strict policies regarding homework, uniform, and behavior, but this is a training for the future. 
Homework is given every night and there are five projects per month, one for each class. The uniform is burgundy or white top with grey bottoms, and black shoes. Students are expected to conduct themselves in a manner that is respectful and befitting this institution. I see nothing wrong with any of these policies. Whatever organization or cooperation you work for, there will be rules and policies that you might not necessarily agree with, but for it to run effectively and smoothly and to be held in high regard, these policies and rules are necessary. 
This school has introduced my daughter to a number of cultural events and programs that I am not sure she would be exposed to at another lesser esteemed school. I am proud to be a parent of a student that attends IS 392 and would gladly recommend it to any parent that is looking for a structured and rigorous junior high school to send their student.

I hope anyone reading the earlier postings will forgive students who obviously think school should be a free-for-all.  I am sure they will be embarrassed a few years from  now when they realize how low their expectations were for themselves.
I am a parent and I am pleased with the school. My son is happy there and has not complained about any incidents. The teachers push them to grow academically.  The principal and guidance counselor introduced my son to programs and opportunities that my other children did not experience in their schools.
Thank you I.S.392.

We're a magnet school, not some type of normal school. We have many after school programs. Trust me those tickets are a lot.  We have dance after-school, ceramics, photograph. Many more. Each year the 8th grade performs a show. Which is actually written by the students. We have 7 classes. Each homework is due on each day. Going to this school, can help you learn a lot, then what an average middle school teachers. So, please don't be appalled at what you're seeing written there, because its been over exaggerated to the point. Everyone down there, at least had many good times. You should pay a visit one day, and see how its actually like for your self, and you be the judge of it. =)

I've been a student at Kappa V under the care and protection of former Principal Anthony Shepherd. Honestly, Ever since he left that school, it started to go down hill. It will never be the same. It's impossible because no one can be like him and no one can discipline his students like him. That man was fired because he wanted to make a difference in his students even the ones that used to give the most trouble. He didn't want us to go out into the World with a bad reputation,  bad mentality and character. Ever since I graduated from KAPPA V, I became more responsible and more wiser. He was teaching us to be leaders and not followers. He was more than just a principal, he was a father to a lot who was fatherless. Yes he was strict but that's what you call a principal. They will have to be strict sometime. When you don't stand your ground , how can you be respected. It was ridiculous to see how many students disrespected him. It showed me that they didn't have any home training. Without him, I don't know what I would've done when I finished junior high. His motivation alone inspired me to become motivated. He was a man of his word. He wouldn't make promises he cant keep. It really amazed me to see how many parents and students of the graduating class after us hated him so much to accuse him of things he didn't even do. All of those rumors that I was hearing, I didn't appreciate it at all. It was so disgusting. All of those scavengers and crows picking at an innocent man that was only doing his job. I guarantee that if the board or whoever was to call all of the parents and students of my graduating class, he would be a principal again no doubt. I don't care what others think of him but I know that he was the best of the best and Principle Dellie Edwards will never take his place because he was the heart of KAPPA V, without the heart being there, there's no heartbeat. I apologize if someone feels offended  but I have the freedom of speech and I'm standing on my own two feet. I'm heading off to college with an Advanced Regents Diploma. I WAS IN THE GRADUATING CLASS OF 2007  AND I WILL PROUDLY SAY " LEAD OR GET OUT THE WAY, THERE'S NO EXCUSE FOR YOUR SUCCESS, I AM DOING IT!!!"  THANKS TO FORMER PRINCIPAL ANTHONY SHEPHERD KNOWN AS COMMANDANT SHEPHERD. I WAS PROUD TO BE A CADET.

as the mother of an active young black man, i believe eagle academy is one of the best options for his education. i have little experience with public schools because my son has attended private school for most of his life, and when i saw the public schools that were available, especially in brooklyn, i was appalled. i was so happy to entrust the education of my child to mr. meade and the the other educators at this school that understood our situation, and have been flexible and kind enough to offer extra assistance and support during difficult times. the academics, extra curricular activites and special events actually make my son want to go to school. 

i also appreciate the extra focus on improving reading and writing skills that the eighth grade provides, and parent-teacher night is very informative- most of the teachers can demonstrate the learning level the child entered class with, and the growth that has taken place since then. this school provides scholar and family support which i think is necessary for a successful student. the discipline is also excellent for young boys that have a high enery level. i have seen mr. meade go into a lunchroom full of busy children and say- I AM- and the children know to respond "globally conscious and globally competitive." it is wonderful to see the respect that most of the children have for their teachers and principal, which is rare these days. this school is a good combination of order and discipline balanced with strong academics and afterschool activities. and the five pm dismissal means my son is not traveling with the general school population at three o'clock. overall, i am very grateful for this school.

I Am A Proud Parent of An Eagle Scholar.   During the three years that my son has attended Eagle, I have seen a great deal of improvement in my son, not only in his educational confidence but in his emotional, social growth.    Another important factor that Eagle stresses is respect for yourself and others.  Respect, of course, begins with the parents at home but respect for educators and authority must also be instilled.  As parents we all have to work together not against each other, to resolve any problem we feel is affecting our child’s educational progress. Our sons, being minorities, will confront many things that will try to hold them back.  Some are faced with various obstacles which impede on their educational progress in their neighborhood, at home, etc.    The first thing we have to do is come together to protect our children’s education which is now being threatened by cuts in teaching staff, school funding for education programs, Title I programs which help our at risk students, schools being shut down,  funding for community services and afterschool programs for students, and summer youth employment programs, etc.  If we, as parents, do not come together to protect our children’s educational rights, we will soon be faced by problems faced in the 1970’s in education which include teacher layoffs, overcrowded classrooms and sub-standard education  for our children.  Parents need to get involved.  Our children have a right to receive a quality and well-rounded education and this is the new Civil Rights movement we need to keep sight of.  We need to come together not only for our children, but for those who fought for those Civil Rights for us in the past. 

We, as parents, do have a voice in our child’s education.    Let’s use our voices respectfully and with dignity not belittling or negatively.   All parent concerns matter.  Together, with positive action, we can resolve issues that we feel are affecting our scholars.  You chose Eagle for a reason.  Parent involvement is a strong requirement of an Eagle Scholars Education.  We have to work together to help improve all the educational conditions that affect the students citywide.   It really does take a village to raise a child and caring not just about our own child but all children is what matters most.   We need to help each other as much as we can in whatever capacity we have to give.  As parents we are the first line of defense in our children’s lives.  Their first educational and ethical values are learned from us, the parents.   Parents, be honest and ask yourselves the following questions:  Do you know what your child is learning at school? Do you know all your children’s teachers by name?  Do you attend the Parent /Teacher conferences, PTA meetings, SLT meetings, Community Education Council meetings, parent workshops?  What do I know about Title I and how does it affect my child?   Are you volunteering in any respect at your child’s school?  Do I  help out in my child’s school in any capacity? Do I volunteer my talents to my childs school? Do I address my issues to the Principal, Guidance Counselor, Parent Coordinator, Social Worker, or District Family Advocate?

We do not want our children to fail but want them all to succeed.  Let’s get together to make sure that we as parents receive the resources we need to help our children succeed.  We need to make sure our children receive a high quality and well-rounded education  that will help carry them throughout their lives.  Parent involvement is a key to student success.

I has visited eagle academy on numerous occassions and have been disappointed in this school's actual commitment in engaging students in academic learning as oppose to what the school administration verbally conveys to parents. I also find the so called "ranked" student system at eagle academy to be similar to prison guards allowing a few inmates to be the jailhouse enforcers in which enforcement of rules are arbitrary and subjective.

So many of our young parents look to their children's schools for parental guidance. Many have asked the educators to be mentors and "fathers".  Some educators do become extremely passionate and can seem irritable when they discipline at
Eagle.  However, in their defense, I must say, as a strong supporter of the Eagle program, I will not let a shout deter me from continuing to express sincerest appreciation for the opportunity to be a part of a community that strives on a daily basis to serve our "boys" who so badly need these "fathers".

As a parent of a Eagle Scholar, who has been attending the school for three years I felt betrayed by the lack of integrity that I discovered by one of the educators. When addressing this situation with the principal I was disappointed by his response. I understand that our young men come from many single mother homes and most woman are looking for father figure but a school should not be a place to seek parental guidance or "fathers". I been in the school on several occasions and I witnessed something totally different from these other parents. I saw educators screaming at the top of their lungs at the "scholars", not once, or twice, on numerous times. This makes me very uncomfortable to see these educator behaving in this manner. The "boys", as they are considered, will no longer be "boys" they will become young men and will no longer accept this behavior from staff. It will surface chaos, I hope this will not be the case but you will reap what you sow. A good school becomes great by admitting mistakes and being humble to change, I don't see this happening at this school. Everything is not for everyone, I came to see that this is no longer for us. I hope for CHANGE.

Has the potential to be a good school if the leadership will stop pretending to be perfect and see that there are far too many fights for a school that is supposed to be fraternity like. When these young men complain of bullying or inappropriate statements from staff that child becomes a target.

l am a proud parent of an Eagle Scholar.  My son has been at the school for two years.  He has two years of perfect attendance because he likes to go to school. Even Saturday school.  When I walk in the school, Mr. Meade knows me and can tell me immediately what my son is doing.  I like that. If I had to describe Eagle Academy in one word it would be FABULOUS.  
I gave them a not so sure of himself mama's boy and in return they gave me a confident respectful young Sergeant. As a single mother the staff has taught me how to nurture my son without babying him and he is a better young man for it. The excitement that I hear when he talks about his brothers and  how they come together, how they earn points, trips  and other privileges makes me just as excited as him. 
The staff from Mr.Meade the Principle down to the Dave and Danny the Janitors are respectful, caring and they listen. I can reach out and speak or email them and get a response right away or before the day is out. 
We have a wonderful time at our PTA meetings, we  are very supportive of each other and especially of our new incoming parents. The PTA committee is always coming up with new ideas. They always find a way to let us know they appreciate the fact we came out to the meeting.
 I would recommend this school to anyone that wants their sons to know they can be anything they want to be. 
GLOBALLY CONSCIOUS GLOBALLY COMPETITIVE. That's our motto.

"Our school is a response to the issues and the plight of our young men and this community," founding principal Rashad Meade tells Insideschools. "Our school is built on this idea that we're helping the community -- and that's not just the students. We're helping the parents and the community as a whole."
Brooklyn Environmental Exploration School is among the schools with the most improved 2017 state English test scores, Chalkbeat reports.

Principal Nadia Lopez left the school July 1 after her doctor warned her that stress of running the school during the Coronavirus epidemic threatened her health, Chalkbeat reported.

https://ny.chalkbeat.org/2020/7/17/21328535/coronavirus-nyc-principals-return-to-school

Chalkbeat reports that Mott Hall Bridges has built an active social-emotional support team for its students after it lost one of its recent graduates in a nearby shooting. To know who to check in on, Principal Nadia Lopez administers surveys at the beginning of the year to take note of students who may be quietly dealing with loss.

Mott Hall Bridges is on a list of 50 schools that will participate in the DOE's Bronx Plan, which will boost salaries in hard-to-staff positions and "give teachers formal decision-making power in their schools" according to Chalkbeat.

Mott Hall Bridges Principal, Nadia Lopez, shares what it means to her to be a principal and mentor explaining, "It’s not just about being present for the kids. It’s about having the audacity to fight for them: to fight for the opportunities they deserve, to make sure people know they are not invisible," The Atlantic reports.
Mott Hall Bridges Principal Nadia Lopez is featured in EdWeek telling "How to Build a School from Scratch," the BookMarks blog reports.

Principal Nadia Lopez takes a personal approach with her middle school students in, "How to run a thriving school in a tough neighborhood," in the Wall Street Journal.
Principal Nadia Lopez is a finalist for a one million dollar global teacher prize. Read more here.

Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced 73 schools selected to join the Learning Partners Program, an innovative and collaborative initiative that brings schools together to share practices to improve learning in the classroom and raise student outcomes. "Many of you have seen me in the hallways, classrooms, and at student events as Assistant Principal of ELA and ESL," she wrote.

"Over the last two years, I have had the opportunity to communicate and meet with parents, assist students in their learning in the classrooms and in afterschool activities, and to work side-by-side with teachers to enrich their instructional practices and inspire them to bring their best every day  for our students. Graduated from this school about 6 years ago and can say that my experience there was not too bad.  The students in the honors classes are great and the teachers are quite good. But I wouldn't say that I ever felt unsafe, as there were only a few immature troublemakers.  I ended going to Stuyvesant High School, along with 15 other students of my grade! I now attend an Ivy League institution and I know quite a few I.S.5 alumni who went to other great institutions. I can certainly say that this school, in some ways, did prepare me for the more challenging academics that were to come.

Amy, a student, writes: "I think this school is pretty good because every time there's a problem, teachers get right to it." However, she writes: "Often this school is overcrowded, especially the 'B' wing. Since the school is now separated into academies-- science and tech., law and humanity, and arts and media -- students get their own wing. I often don't like staying in one wing." She adds that she "just doesn't see any point" to the academy system.
A student writes that the school is "cool" because "there is always something to do."
A student writes: "IS 5 is a great school, but the buildings are sometimes overcrowded. The teachers are really involved in our learning. One teacher even offered to come to my house to tutor me!"
Biana, a student, writes that her experience at IS 5 "has been wonderful ... I wouldn't change a thing. It's such a diverse friendly environment where everyone gets along so well."

A former student writes that the school does have "excellent equipment, a few great teachers, and beautiful new facilities" but "I loathed the school because of the students," who she categorizes as "disruptive".

"My experience at IS5 was, how can I put this, amazing and so enjoyable," writes Swathy M., a former student. "The workload was bearable and the teachers were outstanding. They worked hard to get us on the right path and cared so much for our success and education. Mr. Katz was a great principal and loved to make jokes. I will miss IS 5 greatly." She adds, "I am who I am because of this school."

A student who currently attends 51st Avenue Academy writes that she hopes to go to IS 5 next year, because her sister, who attended the school for 4 years, and her cousin, who is in the 6th grade there, said it was a great school.

A parent writes, "As a member of the School Leadership Team for 3 years I have been able to see the school up close and personal. The teachers and administration are top-notch and totally involved." She complains about a lack of parent involvement, but notes that this problem may be partially due to a lack of translators. She adds, "At any rate the school is safe and for anyone who wants to learn the opportunities are there. The SP courses are especially good. The school was able to place well over 20 students into Stuyvesant, Bronx Science, and Brooklyn Tech, with the bulk going to Bronx Science, but six or seven to Stuyvesant, so the math and verbal training, at least to the top classes, is superb. My youngest son will start there next fall."

"IS 5 is a great place to teach and learn," writes a teacher. "Although we have our own little problems, my teaching experience over the last three years has been tremendously positive. Great staff, great kids."

"I am very pleased with the education my daughter is receiving at the school," writes Mrs. Woods, a parent. "The teachers are hard working and caring. My daughter is motivated to complete homework assignments on a daily basis. This all due to the wonderful teachers that she has this year in 7th grade at I.S 5."

I went to PS 12 from 1970 to 1975....There were a couple of Asian kids...a sprinkling of latin kids, a few italians and greeks, and the rest were white....Everyone spoke english. This is a good example of how race is a construct and has little to no bearing on reality. Probably in "Tony's" day none of these groups were considered "white". It's hard to not sense a value judgement in his description and not to bridle at that. Stemming from before the 1930s, white was considered Caucasian (and if you recall the politics of the Nazi era, white was also considered "good"). If, and this is problematic, one were to use the same construct, Italians, Greeks, and people from Baghdad were all loosely classified as Caucasian. The idea of Caucasian as white is deeply flawed pseudoscience from the mid-19th century (See the New Yorker article called The Hidden Past of Sochi). Recent genetic tests have underlined how political boundaries are ropes that tie very different peoples together. Iraq, Greece, and Italy, contain people that often descend from different haplogroups--or shared genetic ancestry. In the past, Irish and Britons have been considered prime examples of "white" and "Caucasian." That's interesting, because most Irish and Britons we now know are descendants of farmers who left Iraq some 10,000 years ago. In other words, those quintessential "white" people are, in Tony's lingo from "Baghdad." Race it seems exists in our imagination, and changes according to what we believe. Progress, I guess.

I went to this school in 1967/1968, graduating to IS 61. I have nothing but wonderful memories of this school, those were the days when you could leave the school to go home for lunch, my friend Maryse (sp?) and I would go to her house around the corner, having to be back in one hour. I believe my teachers name was Mrs. Wainright, not positive, but I do remember her screaming all the time, although her bark was bigger than her bite, she was actually a great teacher! While there was a great racial diversity, there was never the prejudice that other schools were experimenting at the time. I believe those were still the days of innocence, our graduation consisted of doing the Mexican Hat Dance in the lunchroom, and then off to IS 61. I also remember my friends and I playing dodge ball in the school yard, and I understand that game was outlawed, for good reason, can you imagine playing that game today, there enough "angry" kids as it is, sad but true!. I happened upon this school from a movie I watched and was curious to see if the school was still standing, I read there are 1600 kids enrolled, I don't remember the population back then, I'm sure it wasn't close to that number! If anyone should remember me, please don't hesitate to drop a line, my email address is jpd0605@hotmail.com

"This was a great school. I still think that Ms. Gottlieb and lamarca are very good principals. It is too bad that during the time that Mrs Calibar has been the principal, the school has gone down hill," writes a parent who has sent children to the school for the past five years. "The principal does not listen to parents' concerns (for example, there are very little Spanish books in the [bilingual] class, the teacher has to photocopy the books because there were not enough for every body). My 2 children who had this teacher did so good with her. They learned English really fast, she gave them good homework and she was very interested in each child meeting with us parents almost every day. Now, in the end of May, the teacher was taken out of the class to do "more important business". More than half the parents in the class had a meeting with Mrs. Calibar asking her to allow the students to finish the year with her, and I even told her I wanted my son to have her again next year, that no other teacher had given my son that much personal attention. She showed that her decision was final and there was nothing we could do about it. There is a substitute teacher in the class that does not give homework and does not even teach math. My son tells me she makes them cut letters every morning for an hour and then they have to read all day."
A first-year teacher writes, "Despite the high demands [of teaching], the administrators, coaches, and teachers around me are very supportive. They all love to help and will provide help."
For the 2006-07 school year, PS 19 is newly identified by the State Education Department as "in need of improvement."
I Will miss Ps.19Q

An alumna who attended the school from 1993-1999 writes: "Those were the most rewarding years of my life. Now a high school junior, I realize the importance of those six years. The teachers in this school did not only teach us to 'live to learn'; they taught us to 'learn to live.' They showed me the importance of knowledge and how without it, I'd be nowhere. I'm managing a 3.6 average in HS with a tough workload (and it's junior year!)." She adds: "Throughout my time [at PS 19], I was in the Gifted and Talented Honors program, and enjoyed every minute of it. Teachers there emphasized the importance of independence and despite the enormous age gaps, treated their students like friends."

I am a former student of Ps/Is 49, and from the view of a student who actually attended the school, dispite the facts some parents are giving I was actually able to experiance what this school has to offer first hand, and I got to experiance what a great and safe environment this school is. This school did such an amazing job preparing me and my peers for high school I am so thankful to have had the opportunity to grow and learn in such an amazing environment. I attended 49 since kindergarten until 8th grade, I had both principals Mr.Lombardi and Mr.Carty, both were amazing principals and did so much to help the school. This school had such a wide range of classes for the kids to take such as art and music, it also had various early morning and after school programs to help prepare for the state wide test. The school also provides accelerated classes which personally have helped me so much, I am now a freshman in high school, and am taking math and science classes people would usually take junior year. Now, while in English and history class I am more advanced than most kids in my class in writing essays and well developed paragraphs because of how well Ps/Is 49 prepared me.

My name is David Mendoza and I graduated in 1999. I remember Mr. Lombardi playing Frank Sinatra every Friday. About a year ago I bought Franks greatest hits collection and couldn't help but give the credit to my elementary school principal.

Overall, this is a great school with strong academics. I am very happy with the education my children have received, and they are well-rounded, as they are exposed to lots of music and technology as well. They now have Science and Phys Ed teachers, which is great. Teachers are wonderful and there are lots of extra-curricular programs like band, string-program, chess club, newspaper, robotics. Test prep is important for State Tests and kids that need extra help, are invited to attend Saturday mornings. Principal does run a tight ship, but he cares about the kids and is accessible to parents. PTA is amazing.
On the down-side, there's a new math curriculum that not all parents are too happy with, it's experimental, but the principal is sticking by it. Accelerated math has continued with upper grades, but discontinued for lower grades which put those kids in a disadvanage, since they're redoing math from over a year ago. The office does not seem the most welcoming place. If you're late to pick up, or you have to sign out your child early, they may get really annoyed which is uncomfortable for parents. Ofcourse there's the mean lunchroom lady who loves to scream at kids and not too nice, but my kids will survive. Once in a while, she's nice.
My pros for this school outweigh the cons, and my kids love going to school, so I do recommend PS/IS 49.

To the parent who commented about her 9 year old: Dismissal can always get a little hectic at times - my children know to wait for me at a designated spot outside of school and they know they are not to wander around looking for me. It sounds like you are very concerned but this site isn't designed to provide assistance - just information. Good luck.

"I graduated from P.S.49 in 2006. I absolutley loved that school. The school was small, compared to my new school (I.S.73). Everybody knew everyone, literally. Mr. Lombardi knew many of his pupils by name. Our NYS test scores were really high. I remember Mr. Lombardi saying on the loud speaker, that only about 3% of the test takers got less than a 3 and 4 score. Teachers and students interacted very well togethor. Im not sure if they still teach classes the same way, but I loved it. We used to sit on a big rug for ELA and the teacher would give us a lesson and read part of a book. Many classes were taught on the rug, and that was really fun and I learned alot. Music and art was a big priority of the school. Every Friday, half the school would meet up (in two sessions) and sing many patriotic songs. Everyone also played the recorder (at least), and one class of the 4th and 5th grade would be the band class. I was in that band class and my music teacher, Mr. Auriemma was a great teacher."

A parent writes that she is "overall satisfied" with her children's education at PS 49, pointing to the Teachers College Reading/Writing Workshop and Everyday Mathematics programs as a reason that "test scores are very good." She writes, "They try hard to raise all the kids' performance. ... The only thing my kids are missing out on is phys ed and the fun of having yearly plays or science fairs. Teachers do get shifted around a lot."

"My son loves P.S. 49 and so do I. The principal is great and so are the teachers. My son loves to read the books he brings home nightly and to sing songs he learns in class. The curriculum is top-notch with daily reading, writing and math workshops and weekly periods of science, music, art, computers, social studies, and 'maps and globes.' P.S.49 manages to balance being a high-achieving school with a relaxed environment that offers a well-rounded education," writes a parent who praises the school's high level of parental involvement.
Disagree

"P.S. 49 helped me become the person I am today. I thank all of my teachers and Mr. Lombardi for introducing me to the music and the arts," writes former student Anastassia. "I'm now an 11th grader at LaGuardia High School as a music major. I always look back at P.S. 49 with a longing to recapture those days. I still sing the songs I learned and can't believe how much that school has helped me to be a better person."

Alia, a student, writes: "This school is great! ... I have been here since 3rd grade. I am now in 5th grade and I have experienced a lot. I used to go to a Catholic school and it is very different [at PS 49]. ... I think it was a right thing to come to this school."

The teachers at P.S. 58 are great. My child has been blessed with great teachers every year. I can't say the same for Principal Tripoli. There is no stability for the teachers since they are moved from one grade to another year after year. How are they to improve their lesson plans for our children when they have to make up a new lesson plans each year because they are teaching another grade level. One year, a teacher will be teaching in the 6th grade and the next year, the 2nd grade. Let the teachers stay in the grade they are teaching so they can develope and improve their lesson plans each year and the test scores should improve (something that Tripoli wants so badly, yet isn't happening with the way she is moving the teachers around). You will never see her at the school greeting the kids or out in the schoolyard in the morning. If you are a parent with a child in kindergarten or 1st grade, you will see Principal Tripoli driving into her usual parking spot when you are walking your child to the blue door. I can say I have only seen Principal Tripoli in the schoolyard in the morning ONCE, that's ONCE in 3 years time. You will not see Principal Tripoli at the student of the month assemblies to encourage the kids at all. The principal is also very condescending to the parents. The Principal's Homework she gives the students are a joke. This year's 2nd graders were given poems to decipher that were too deep for them to even understand. Case in point, they were given "Heal the World" as their first assignment. The kids can learn Italian, but there are no homework assignment and I really don't any of the work they do in class for it. Each year, you are forced to do the parent survey before you are allowed to see your child's teacher. Last year, I was able to do it online, however, this year I was not even given that option. I have a couple of friends whose kids were bullied and Principal Tripoli did nothing to remedy the situation. One friend had to go to the district in order to get any help. Another friend's child is being placed in the same class with the kids who bullied him year after year for 4 years now. This may have been a great school at the beginning but has deteriorated as the year goes by. The direction of this school is at a downward spiral with no other direction except at the speed it's going down. It's time for a new principal to breathe some life, direction, and harmony into the school.

PS 58 is one of 21 schools the Department of Education is investigating for "ethical misconduct" on the annual surveys taken by parents and teachers. The Daily News reports that "Principal Adelina Tripoli is being investigated for pressuring teachers to give the school favorable ratings." Read more: City investigating 21 cases of ethical misconduct on annual schools survey.

My kids are very happy in ps58. Ps58 has lots of activities and classes. My boys are learning hip hop dancing, ballroom dancing, keyboard, Italian, art, and computer beside the regular classes. With budget cut and ps58 can still keep these classes and smaller classes, I am impressed! Great teachers and strong PTA. Yes, for the year 2011, ps58 has become a C school although it had always been an A school all these years, but I can tell the school is doing something about it like to have workshops for parents, has a new email system to communicate with parents, encourage parents to attend PTA meetings so we all have better communications. Teachers are working hard to help kids on academic. One thing is that ps58 only have extended hour for kids who need extra help in class. I wish it has something like tutoring, art and sport after school program for kids.

No one has commented in a long time.  This is not the same school that it has been in the past by looking over the comments.  The school a C rating now, with the staff rating it a D.  While technology is useful, how has it really helped learning as the scores have steadily declined over the year.  It has also been reported that the principal is under investigation.  There is a problem with this school and the Board of Education needs to look into it and fix the problem.

Parent Ana Ford praises the school's "high skilled" teachers and "great" principal. "The teachers really get the students involved and make learning more fun and action-filled," through activities such as the Math Olympics, she writes. She adds that the school is very clean.

A former student writes: "PS 58 has a wonderful education and family involvement setting. It is a great school for children with special talents that they like to share. For example, there is an excellent chorus run by Ms. Digivonna that helps children show off all their wonderful talents. Math and English are also ... top priorities in the School of Heroes." This student continues: "I remember from last year, being a graduating 6th grader, Mrs. Tripolii would always remind our school how wonderful it was to live in America and all the opportunities we have by playing inspirational music while [we] were walking into our classrooms. When we would have performances in the auditorium Mrs. Tripolli would always say 'PS 58 is a school that strives for excellence,' and the students replied 'And achieves it.' When these words were said it helped me to remember that if we worked hard we could ... achieve anything we ever wanted to."

Parent Mia Koumoutsos writes: "Before my son was ready for Kindergarten, I began questioning parents of students that attend the schools in my area. We were looking for a school that offered collaborative team teaching. Luckily for us, PS 58Q offered it. Another school in the area offered it too, but I chose PS 58Q based on the wonderful comments I received from both parents and students that attend the school." She continues: "At the time of this writing, the school year is half over, and I am amazed at what my son has accomplished so far. The teachers work with the parents to help the children. The PTA. is [composed] of a great group of parents. They work closely with the principal, the teachers, the staff, and the parents. [The school has] a wonderful open-door policy. In this school, the principal knows your name and your child's name just because they attend the school, not because they've ever had to 'go down to the principal's office' if they were misbehaving. Everyone in that building has one goal in mind: to help the children. You can't ask for more than that."

"PS 58 absolutely deserves its name, the School of Heroes," writes Brian Tung, a student. "This year started off with a blast! We had a new Olympics program called the Reading Olympics and they were as much fun as the Math Olympics! ... The teachers work hard to make the lessons fun and exciting while you're learning. If I had to give this school a rate I would give it a five out of five star rating!"

Cheryl, a former student, writes: "This school is a great school for the performing arts. ... The school is great but the subject science is not very much focused on." She adds: "In this fabulous school there is chorus music and drama after school or in school."

"This is a truly wonderful school," writes Warren W., a student. "I even heard that a kid went into Hunter from this school. If you went to the 6th grade this year and was in our school you might have gotten, a Trophy, Gift Certificate, Badges, Certificate Ribbons, or a Plaque. You could have gotten more than one award one person even got 8 awards! So please check out this school before you decide which school you or your son/daughter should go to."

"This is a fantastic school!" writes student Brian T. "The school gives us an opportunity to look at what's in store for students who learn there. Also there are fantastic teachers and staff members that help students succeed to their full potential. PS 58 is great!"

Cheryl, a student, writes, "The School of Heroes is fantastic. PS 58 is a beautiful school, the gym is very large, which gives each child some space. And those who are interested in performing and dance can always take ballroom dancing or chorus as a subject." She adds, "PS 58 also has many well rounded students. Our school motto is ?PS 58 is a school that strives for excellence and achieves it ... I am going to be so disappointed when leaving this school, but I will always remember the dedicated hard work that each and every teacher has made in order for me and my fellow students to get the best education possible."

Kasia, a student, writes, "This school is great! Since I'm a 6th grader graduating this year, this is a really sad moment. I'll miss my friends and teachers that helped me throughout the year. You can't come out of that school saying you didn't learn something great that day."

A student writes, "The 6th-grade graduation plan has been great so far. We've been a Broadway show and to New Jersey for a Medieval Times show which was absolutely fantastic. I am very excited about the upcoming dance and the actual graduation day." She adds, "PS 58 has opened up so many opportunities for me and I got to experience many different things. The teachers, PTA, principal, and the rest of the staff make this school an incredible place to be in."

Isabella, a student, writes, "PS 58 is amazing! This upcoming first elementary graduation will be so much fun. Principal Tripoli planned a lot of fun and exciting activities. We also held the Math Olympics." She adds, "There are superb coordinators ... You would be very lucky to be in this school."

"This school is a great school," writes a student. "It has a lot of activities, such as, the Pow Wow (Held last year, 2002-03), and the chorus concerts. The teachers here are very cooperative and teach very well. We also have a gigantic gym and a school library."

"This school is a great school with highly skilled teachers and a great principal," writes Jianxiang, a student. "Principal Tripoli has a lot of fun and exciting events like the Math Olympics where, kids learn Math and also enjoy it." She continues, "During this year I have improved a lot thanks to my wonderful teacher Mrs. Stabile and the wonderful staff here at PS 58.This school truley deserves the title The Schools Of Heroes."

"The teachers in this school really get the students involved and make learning more fun and action-filled," writes a student. "I love all of the special activities such as, the Math Olympics and all of the shows and holiday concerts. Many of the teachers treat us, students like equals but also let us know that they're still teachers and we have to treat them like they're teachers. I love the extra-curricular activities: chorus and ballroom dancing. This school is also very clean. Many of our special activities/shows, such as the Math Olympics, aren't just ordinary shows, where the host just announces the speech and the rest of the time, everyone's quiet. The principal and the teachers make things more interesting, action-packed, and fun, and I get really involved. I like my class a lot because everyone gets along with each other and there are a lot of mixtures of different personalities."

"The school really excels in reading and math," writes a student. "The teachers are very involved with the activities the children does. The principal is excellent! Students have so much fun in this school!"

"If you are looking for a great school which strives to the top and never stops go to this wonderful school," writes Jianxiang, a student. "I have learned many things here at this wonderful school and hope to move on to Hunter, Harvard, and maybe even Oxford."
